Fittingly, he had tried once before but lost faith in his people, and was inspired to try again by another paragon: Commander Shepard. As noted in the [Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony) section above, Eve's description of the halcyon days of the ancient Krogan, they sound like they were a lot like Wrex.

[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): While not overt, it appears that he's taken this role toward Grunt, being enthusiastic about letting him take the [Rite of Passage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RiteOfPassage) to become a member of Clan Urdnot in *2* as well as placing him in charge of [Aralakh Company](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassArmy) in *3*, in recognition of Grunt's skill. One of his comments in the second game insinuates that he may be grooming Grunt to be his successor as Overlord of the krogan.
[Papa Wolf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf): Becomes this for his entire species. He also develops a paternal instinct for a few of Shepard's youngest squadmates, particularly Tali.

[Pen-Pushing President](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PenPushingPresident): Downplayed. He still spends chunks of *2* and *3* in the thick of the action but admits that he wishes he could join Shepard adventuring around the galaxy rather than spending as much time as he does keeping the krogan in line and butting heads with the Council in his de-facto chief of state role. In *Citadel* he's ecstatic to finally cut loose after a while.

[Properly Paranoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProperlyParanoid): He was hired by Saren once, the turian gave Wrex such a bad feeling that he bailed on the job without even waiting around to get paid. Turns out all the other mercs he was working with were found dead a week later.
    - In *3* he also knows that the dalatrass won't let the genophage be cured without trying something (SPOILER) which leads him to discovering Shepard's treachery should they take her up on her offer and sabotage the cure .

[Proud Warrior Race Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRaceGuy): [Deconstructed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MySpeciesDothProtestTooMuch); he knows full well that the krogan people are too attached to their short-sighted warrior traditions to save themselves from extinction. In the sequels, he subjects the trope to [Reconstruction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Reconstruction) by seizing power of Clan Urdnot and working to return the krogan to a proud warrior race they should have been instead of a race of thugs for hire.

[Radish Cure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RadishCure):  (SPOILER)  "Eve"/Bakara decides to *encourage* star-struck lady krogan who want the savior of their race to father their children as of the *Citadel* DLC, and Wrex has gone from [excited at the prospect of doing his part for his revitalized race](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChivalrousPervert) to putting ice packs on his aching quad and sneaking off to have an adventure with Shepard just to get away.

[Really Gets Around](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallyGetsAround):  (SPOILER) If the Genophage is cured, every krogan female under the sun wants a piece of him. Unfortunately for Wrex, he's been having so much sex that he needs a bag of ice for his currently-aching quad.

[Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallySevenHundredYearsOld): We don't know how old exactly Wrex is, but given that he defeated a Thresher Maw *over* a thousand years ago and hints that he may have been around during the Krogan Rebellions (which happened in *700 AD*)... yeah, Wrex is *very old*, even for a krogan.
    - For those not willing to do the math this would make Wrex nearly 1500 years old at the start of Mass Effect. Even Samara would be half a millennium his junior.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): About as reasonable of an authority figure as you can be for an entire species of [Blood Knights](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight).
    - While it's unspoken, it's worth noting that Wrex is perfectly content to allow Shepard, an *alien*, to serve as a member of Grunt's krantt during their [Rite of Passage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RiteOfPassage), likely because he knows that they [don't actually have a rule](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoopholeAbuse) that says that the members of your krantt have to be *krogan*.
      - Who is in the prospective krantt says a lot. Depending on who you take with you, it's either just Shepard, who has iron-clad and gold-plated badass credentials in Wrex's eyes, or Shepard and someone that Wrex fought alongside in the last game, who has also proven themselves as a badass.
[Red Eyes, Take Warning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedEyesTakeWarning): And red skin, red armor, and red guns...
[Red Oni, Blue Oni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedOniBlueOni): Is blue compared to his brother Wreav and the rest of the krogan as their leader, but is red compared to Eve.

[Refuge in Audacity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RefugeInAudacity): If he helps infiltrate the casino in *[Citadel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownloadableContent)*. First he'll claim to [be a food inspector](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies) (though as krogan leader, he could just [declare himself one anyway](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewTheRulesIMakeThem)), then he'll just start distracting the guards *by berating them for doing a bad job*.

[Revenge Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RevengeBeforeReason):
    - At a species level, he's initially the only krogan you encounter in the entire game to defy this. Though he retains some of his racial prejudice against salarians and turians he's got no real problems working with Garrus (other than chewing Garrus out for making some [Innocently Insensitive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InnocentlyInsensitive) comments) and Captain Kirrahe (provided you talk him down in the standoff on Virmire). He also laments how the krogan are more concerned with maintaining their grudges than actually preventing their own extinction. By *2* he decides to do something about it by unifying the krogan under his rule to focus more on rebuilding krogan society than getting revenge against the turians and salarians. Going by how many of the krogan are following his lead, he does a damn good job of it. - (SPOILER) In ME3, if you betray his friendship and sabotage the genophage cure, he will come after you on a [Roaring Rampage of Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoaringRampageOfRevenge). To elaborate, he comes to the Citadel armed with a giant shotgun (visitors are forbidden from carrying weapons on the station), assaulting a C-Sec officer and shooting at Shepard in broad daylight. Even if Shepard doesn't kill him himself, it doesn't take long until C-Sec reinforcements arrive and swiftly kill him. He really should've thought of a better plan. Then again, he was probably so angry and hurt that he wasn't thinking straight or didn't care enough for his own safety anymore.

[Royal Blood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalBlood): To a degree; his father was an overlord of Clan Urdnot. If he survived Virmire, Wrex will take over as clan leader and de facto ruler of the krogan homeworld of Tuchanka in *2* and *3* (as his dealings have positioned Clan Urdnot to be the most powerful clan).

[Royals Who Actually Do Something](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalsWhoActuallyDoSomething): Wrex used to have a tribe of his own, though he fled Tuchanka after a fight with his father. Later, he will become the ruler of most of the krogan clans.

tropeName: Screw the Rules, I Make Them!
tropeNotes: [Screw the Rules, I Make Them!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewTheRulesIMakeThem): His stance when traditional-minded krogan impede his vision. A necessary evil, for the traditional mindset is what led to the decline of the krogan people in the first place.

tropeName: Screw This, I'm Out of Here!
tropeNotes: [Screw This, I'm Out of Here!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOutOfHere): In his backstory, he met Saren while working on a job. Something about Saren rubbed him the wrong way, so he left without waiting long enough to be paid. His instincts were right: he was the only merc from that job to survive.

[Self-Made Orphan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfMadeOrphan): In self-defense, as revealed in the first game and expanded on in the third. He reveals that his father tried to kill him when he was young, so he was forced to have him crushed under the rocks.

[Sensitive Guy and Manly Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SensitiveGuyAndManlyMan): Believe it or not he embodies both sides of this trope. The latter is obvious but he shows a surprisingly caring side of himself after Virmire. He's the only one to talk about Ashley/Kaidan's death other than Joker and the Virmire Survivor, and the only character to comfort Shepard over it, telling you he respects your decision. The relationship between him and Paragon Shepard also fits this trope.

[Slave to PR](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlaveToPR): He executes a gang leader against your orders because he was hired by the Broker to personally kill him. He even gives you the bounty if you don't bring him along and beat him to the punch — he won't take credit or payment for something he didn't do.

[Snark-to-Snark Combat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SnarkToSnarkCombat): With the human C-Sec officer who tries to warn him away from Fist in the first game.
QUOTE **Officer:** You *want* me to arrest you?

QUOTE **Wrex:** I want you to *try*.
[Sociopathic Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SociopathicHero): Mostly in the first game, less so in the sequels.

[Special Snowflake Syndrome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpecialSnowflakeSyndrome): The Codex notes that krogan biotics are exceptionally rare, even as biotics go. So, naturally, the krogan who joins the adventuring party just happens to be a biotic. This was for lack of anyone else to fill the Vanguard slot in the original team.

[The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic): It's a significant moment whenever he really does emote. QUOTE "Shepard." "Wrex."
    - When Wrex joyfully bounds out of his "throne" to greet Shepard with unabashed happiness in *2*, it's fairly startling. Especially in contrast to the cold shoulder they get from the Virmire survivor on Horizon. - He also appears openly enthusiastic about having Grunt join Clan Urdnot, with almost fatherly pride when he completes the rite. Especially if Grunt kills the Thresher Maw, something no one has done since Wrex himself 1000 years prior.

[Stop Being Stereotypical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StopBeingStereotypical): He dislikes the self-destructive violence of the other krogan, who justify their reckless and bloodthirsty actions with little more than a declaration of "I'm a [Proud Warrior Race Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRaceGuy)!" and leave it at that. Wrex even ended up leaving his clan in his backstory because he became so disgusted with how his fellow krogan kept [Dramatically Missing the Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DramaticallyMissingThePoint) about why they were subjected to the genophage in the first place. Should Wrex survive the first game, he's working to change this mindset as clan leader through reforms that defy tradition and the [Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight) mindset, albeit not without some butting of heads (both figuratively and literally) from the other krogan.  (SPOILER) And should Shepard help him go through with it, Wrex will succeed in getting the genophage cured in *3*, proving him right.

[Suicide by Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideByCop): Should  (SPOILER) Shepard sabotage the genophage cure , he'll come gunning for them on the Citadel... with no barriers and armed with only a shotgun, in full view of several fully-armed C-Sec officers. It's pretty obvious how he expected the encounter to end.

[Supporting Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportingLeader): If he survives the Virmire mission, he's this for all krogan as of the third game, who can provide the second highest amount of War Assets (only behind the Systems Alliance).  (SPOILER) This all depends on how you handle curing the genophage, however . Even in the mission on Sur'Kesh, he keeps the enemy distracted to make Shepard's mission easier.
[Super-Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperStrength): Like all krogan. Particularly shown in the *Citadel* DLC, where he one-arm tosses 150+ kg power-armored mercenaries like hacky sacks.

[Surrounded by Idiots](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SurroundedByIdiots): Provided he survives Virmire and you don't betray him, he mentions multiple times he feels this way trying to keep the krogan in line. It's played for laughs in *Mass Effect 3* when he has to explain non-war societal development to them when all they're used to doing is blowing enemies up.

[Taking You with Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingYouWithMe): If you betray him in *Mass Effect 3*, he specifically calls off krogan support for the final battle so that humanity will be as doomed as the krogan.

[This Is for Emphasis, Bitch!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisIsForEmphasisBitch): Wrex drops a hard one when Allestia Iallis reveals herself to be a sleeper agent for Benezia.
QUOTE **Wrex:** We'll see about that, bitch.

[Token Evil Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenEvilTeammate): [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope). Wrex admits he pretends to be this, simply because it's *expected* of krogan. While Wrex isn't *evil*, he is the most ruthless of Shepard's original six squadmates. When the player is faced with a major Paragon/Renegade choice, one squadmate will always endorse the paragon choice, and one will always endorse the renegade choice. Wrex is the only party member to always endorse the renegade choice regardless of party combination. Even Ashley, the next most renegade squadmate, will endorse the paragon option if she is in the party with Wrex. The only exception is the “save the Council” decision, where Ashley understandably advocates holding the fleets back and not risking human lives.

[Too Dumb to Live](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive): What he thinks of anyone that goes up against Shepard.
QUOTE **Wrex:** Anyone who fights us is either stupid or on Saren's payroll. Killing the latter is business. Killing the former is a favor to the universe.

[Took a Level in Cynic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInCynic): Long before the first game began. He tried to change the self-destructive nature of the krogan in the aftermath of the Krogan Rebellions. He was opposed by many warlords, including his own father, Jerrod. His father trying to kill him on sacred ground where violence is forbidden, about the only rule the krogan actually respected, and [being forced to kill him in self defense](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfMadeOrphan) caused Wrex to lose all hope in the krogan adapting to the genophage and abandon his plans to reform krogan society.

[Took a Level in Idealism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInIdealism): Starts out as cynical as they come. If continuously supported by Shepard, he becomes more and more idealistic with each game. If  (SPOILER) the genophage gets cured  in the third game, he is arguably the least cynical character in the story.

[Tough Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToughLove): Essentially his approach as leader of the krogan. Wrex is absolutely uncompromising and quite harsh in putting his reforms in place, because he knows that they are vital to survival of the krogan people. He may not win all of the popularity contests with the krogan, but everything he does is to their benefit.

[Troll](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Troll): Wrex has become this in *3*.
QUOTE **Wrex:** Hell of a showdown back there on Sur'Kesh. Just like the old days, right down to me pulling your ass out of the fire. 
**Shepard:** *I* was the one with bullets flying at me! 
**Wrex:** And I gave you the moral support to dodge them! *(chuckles)*

[Try Not to Die](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TryNotToDie): The worst possible "goodbye" before you try and summon Kalros.
QUOTE **Wrex:** I know you're doing this for your own reasons, Shepard, but try to make sure you don't get your ass killed. I wouldn't know what to say at your funeral.

[Tsundere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Tsundere): Wrex comes off as this as he first appears as a mercenary who just gets the job done for extra cash but he is revealed to have a personality that is unique from other krogan. He is a type 1 male non romantic version of this trope. He actually cares about other people, including his own species as he shows great concern towards the well being of the krogan. He tries to get them to stop being violent towards each other and focus on maintaining his own species, which led to him being betrayed by his own father. He even openly voices this concern towards Shepard several times.
[Uncomfortable Elevator Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UncomfortableElevatorMoment): [Wrex seems to really like the elevators.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vOg-nLWe71w)

[Undignified Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndignifiedDeath):
    - *Mass Effect 1* gives Wrex a rather miserable death, should they choose to deal one out to him. Namely, he can be knocked down with a punch or a shot, and then shot multiple times like a dog. You then have the option of telling Captain Kirrahe to dump his corpse in the swamps. On top of that, he immediately becomes a [Forgotten Fallen Friend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForgottenFallenFriend) to the rest of the group. - In *Mass Effect 3*, if Shepard (SPOILER) sabotages the genophage cure, he is unceremoniously shot dead by either Shepard or C-Sec. His corpse is then spaced like yesterday's garbage and the media portrays him as a random mercenary who turned violent over a gambling debt.

[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): By the second game, even if he can't go with Shepard, it's clear that he has nothing but undying respect for them and will help them anyway he can. However, Shepard can later lose Wrex's trust by deleting Maelon's research and making no attempt to apologise. If they support the Krogan the entire series, Wrex's loyalty to Shepard is unbreakable.

[Use Your Head](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UseYourHead): [In true krogan fashion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership), he uses this to assert his dominance.
    - Unfortunately, he doesn't see it when Shepard has the opportunity to follow his lead, headbutting *the same krogan that Wrex did earlier* to get him to shut up. The Shaman does see, and finds it hilarious. - In the Citadel DLC, he and Grunt start headbutting as a prelude to some good old-fashioned asskicking to determine who's the stronger krogan. Shepard shuts it down before it goes too far.

[Unwanted Harem](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwantedHarem): The Citadel DLC reveals there are downsides to being the clan leader who cured the genophage — namely, everyone wants their firstborn to have his genes. There's a line of women outside his dwelling that stretches "as far as you can see", he has to sneak out his own bathroom window to get away, and he still gets jumped leaving Tuchanka.

[Vitriolic Best Buds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VitriolicBestBuds): With Garrus. They butt heads frequently during elevator conversations in *1* but grow to respect each other. By *3* their conversations are full of good natured bantering and barb-trading.

[Vocal Evolution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VocalEvolution): Barr gave a much deeper, more gravelly tone of voice for Wrex in *1* and *2*, one which bordered on monotonous at times. When *3* rolls around, Wrex has *much* more range to his voice than before, and generally expresses a lot more emotion. Justified since his earliest appearances in the series take place very recently after he hit [rock bottom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon), and his experiences with Shepard (whether positive or negative) ended up giving him the push he needed to take charge of his life and his people.

[Wasteland Warlord](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WastelandWarlord): Becomes the most powerful and influential clan leader on Tuchanka, such that by the third game, he is treated as the de facto leader of all Krogan across the galaxy.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero):
    - If he's taken to Noveria and Shepard spares the rachni queen, he's deadset against it. As he reminds you, millions of his ancestors died to defeat the rachni the first time. By the third game he seems to have softened his attitude, though; he merely says to Shepard that if the rachni prove a problem, it's their ass on the line for it. - If you deleted Maelon's research, he has some choice words for you in *3* — you can apologise, but while he doesn't like mistrusting you, he doesn't immediately accept it; it takes rescuing Eve, following him to the Shroud and trying to patch things up between missions for Shepard to win his friendship back. - (SPOILER) If you betray his trust by sabotaging the genophage cure, he tries to kill you. On the same occasion, he also calls you out for your actions during the Citadel coup if you killed the Virmire Survivor — *and* for the turian bomb on Tuchanka if you let it go off. It's a bit of a low point for Shepard, all in all. QUOTE **Wrex:** (SPOILER) What's the matter? Ashley not around to do your dirty work? Oh right, you killed her, too! And it's time you found out how that feels!

[What Would X Do?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatWouldXDo): After the events of the first game, he takes Shepard's example and advice to heart and decides to return to Tuchanka and make another attempt to save his people from themselves.

[Where It All Began](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhereItAllBegan): At the end of Priority: Tuchanka,  (SPOILER) if Eve is alive , you will meet up with him at the place where his father ambushed and tried to kill him, and he will remark about how the genophage turned the krogan into "animals".

tropeName: Why Don't Ya Just Shoot Him?
tropeNotes: [Why Don't Ya Just Shoot Him?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhyDontYaJustShootHim): Wrex is a firm believer in using violence to solve his problems. Sometimes he'll threaten to eat somebody instead, just to spice things up.

[World's Best Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorldsBestWarrior): On Tuchanka, anyway, but he has some impressive feats throughout the rest of the galaxy, too. The only person probably superior to him is Shepard, and his only clear successor is Grunt. He's also the most capable War Asset among all of Shepard's companions.

[World's Strongest Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorldsStrongestMan): [Chris Priestley](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod) [confirmed](http://web.archive.org/web/20160816183410/https://forum.bioware.com/topic/246325-strongest-squad-member/#entry7231820) that he is the physically toughest of Shepard's followers.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): He considered his [Friendly Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendlyEnemy) Aleena <sup>note </sup>  who is heavily implied, but never explicitly stated, to be Aria  to be this. Wrex also views Shepard as one when they first meet, seeing them as a warrior worthy of his respect. He drops hints in the first game that he believes in a fight Shepard could take him down - which, considering Wrex once single-handedly defeated a *Thresher Maw*, says a hell of a lot. By the end of the second game, Shepard's probably done a lot of the same things he did, and without the [Made of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron) characteristics that the krogan have going for them. It's no wonder Wrex respects them.

[Ambiguous Start of Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousStartOfDarkness): He was always a brutal [Knight Templar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar), but it was ambiguous whether he was always a monster or a [Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist), when he was indoctrinated, and how many of his actions were influenced by the indoctrination.
[Anti-Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiMagic): He can use the Damping power to prevent his enemies from using biotic and tech powers.

[Apologetic Attacker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ApologeticAttacker): If you successfully convince him that  (SPOILER)  the galaxy can beat the Reapers and that Sovereign is manipulating him through indoctrination , he will apologize to Shepard for his actions before the final boss fight. Of course, if you *further* convince him of his own strength, he ends up  (SPOILER) shooting himself to stop Sovereign .
[Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy): The most personal adversary to Commander Shepard, by far.

[Artificial Limbs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtificialLimbs): Replaced his left arm with a Geth platform's arm donated by the Heretics, and later  (SPOILER) gets many Reaper implants, both exterior and internal.   (SPOILER) By the time of his death, he had so many mechanical implants and replacements that Sovereign was able to "Assume Direct Control" of them, turning Saren's Husk corpse into the [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss) .
[Avenging the Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AvengingTheVillain): His older brother [Desolas](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TouchedByVorlons).
[Battle Aura](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleAura): As the only turian biotic encountered until the third game, he gets an appropriately awesome charge-up scene whenever he enters into battle.

[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): Saren's attack on Eden Prime kicks off the entire plot. Once he's declared rogue by the Council, he becomes Shepard's main target, thus making him the first game's antagonist.  (SPOILER) Ultimately [subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope), however, as it's revealed on Virmire that he's just the [Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy) [Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon) to [Sovereign](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMan).
[Body Horror](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyHorror): Looks completely *wrong* compared to every other turian in the series, thanks to being full of reaper tech.

[Bond One-Liner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BondOneLiner): He gets one at the end of *Mass Effect: Revelation*.
QUOTE **Edan:** [You're not going to throw away three years of my groundwork just so you can have the satisfaction of shooting me.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TemptingFate) 
*[[Boom, Headshot!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoomHeadshot)]* 
**Saren:** I don't mind waiting a few extra years, I'm a very patient man.
[Boss Remix](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossRemix): A remix of Sovereign's theme.

[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy):  (SPOILER) He was originally corrupted by the Arca Monolith, a Reaper (mistaken for Prothean) artifact that his brother Desolas discovered during the First Contact War. Sovereign finished the job. He saw this coming (since his history with the Monolith made him aware of the effects of Indoctrination), but underestimated the danger.

[Broken Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenAce): The Council considered him their best agent, but Anderson pegged him as "broken, twisted", having long become addicted to killing without ever bothering to look for an alternative.

[Creepy Blue Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreepyBlueEyes): *Glowing* blue ones too, and if you look really closely, they resemble the Illusive Man's, which hints that  (SPOILER) both have been touched by Reapers.

[Cyborg](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cyborg): He lets Sovereign implant him with tech. Among other things, his left arm's been replaced by the arm of a geth.
QUOTE **Saren:** The relationship is symbiotic. Organic and machine intertwined, a union of flesh and steel. The strengths of both, the weaknesses of neither.
[Dark Messiah](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkMessiah): To the geth.  (SPOILER) .. well, not all of them .
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): During the Council meeting, he mocks the fact that a *dream* is their sole evidence against him.
[Devil in Plain Sight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DevilInPlainSight): Till the Council manages to get what he's trying to do through their thick skulls.

[Draco in Leather Pants](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DracoInLeatherPants): [In-Universe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InUniverse). *Lair of the Shadow Broker* reveals that there's at least one documentary portraying him as a misunderstood hero. Discovering this [drives Anderson to drink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/INeedAFreakingDrink). The fact that during Kasumi's heist, a statue of Saren is seen as a desirable gift, seems to imply that Saren is the subject of a *lot* of [Misaimed Fandom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MisaimedFandom) in-universe. The [Death Glare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathGlare) Shepard gives the statue doesn't begin to sum up their obvious feelings about this; it could be argued that a Paragon Shepard who convinced Saren to  (SPOILER) kill himself  thinks of Saren as ultimately a [Fallen Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallenHero), and the glare is actually one of sadness.

[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon):  (SPOILER) While he at first appears to be the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad), he's just a puppet to his sentient flagship, [Sovereign.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination)

[Dramatic Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DramaticIrony): His stated motivation on Virmire is to try and prevent galactic annihilation by surrendering to the Reapers. Shepard rightly points out it's insane, and conversation with Vigil in the endgame reveals an important little fact: Reapers don't offer or take surrender.

[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): Even Wrex is wary of him. He's right to be.
QUOTE **Wrex:** I don't know what he wanted. He was just moving through the ship. Watching. Couple of the mercs called him by name, but he never spoke to them. Never spoke to anyone. I had a really bad feeling about him, so I got the hell out. Didn't even wait to get paid... That was the only time I saw him. Didn't even know who he was. Still wouldn't, if I hadn't joined up with you. But my instincts were right. Every other merc on that mission turned up dead within a week. Every damn one.

[Driven to Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide):  (SPOILER) Can be talked into this during his [Villainous BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBSOD). The Charm option has Shepard telling Saren he can still redeem himself, before he decides this route. The Intimidate option has Shepard say that this is the only way out... if Saren "has the guts".

[Dying as Yourself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DyingAsYourself):  (SPOILER) With a Charm/Intimidate, the last lucid independent thought Saren can have is to kill himself to make the [indoctrination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl) end.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): In *[Revelation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/MassEffectRevelation)*, one of the many people he beat for information was a batarian who was going to beat a prostitute. Saren makes clear that he's disgusted by this, and then goes on to torture the batarian for information. What makes this noteworthy for Saren is that the prostitute is human, a species he openly despises.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): Can be seen as a version of Shepard who's willing to cross the [Moral Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralEventHorizon) in order to achieve "greater good." This is especially made clear in the Paragon ending of *Mass Effect 2*.

[Evil Hand](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilHand):  (SPOILER) The implants that reanimate him at the end of the game were given to him after Virmire; Sovereign became suspicious of him, and wanted to keep a closer eye on his enforcer.

[Evil Is Not a Toy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsNotAToy): According to *Revelation*, Saren's first thoughts on learning about Sovereign were how to use its power to put the turians on top of all the other races. That didn't work out so well for him.
[Evil Is Petty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsPetty): In the lead-up to the final battle on Citadel, Saren is briefly seen taking pot-shots at the keepers, despite that they pose no threat to him.
[Evil Overlooker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilOverlooker): Can be seen in the boxart.
[Evil Sounds Deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSoundsDeep): Comes with being voiced by [Fred Tatasciore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/FredTatasciore).

[The Extremist Was Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheExtremistWasRight): By the time you reach the final battle, his plans seems to have become to use the Reapers to merge organics and synthetics into a new unified hybrid species. Shepard quite sensibly dismisses this as simply an insane delusion brought about by Reaper brainwashing.  (SPOILER)  However, *Mass Effect 3* comes along and this becomes one of the 3 possible endings to the trilogy, as well as the one ending the Catalyst shills the most heavily for. Granted, Saren's version of the plan was flawed and would probably have resulted in everyone getting turned into Husks instead of hybrids with free will.

[Eye Lights Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyeLightsOut): His cybernetic eyes stop glowing the moment he dies. Best seen when  (SPOILER) he offs himself via headshot if Shepard managed to [show him the errors of his way](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TalkingTheMonsterToDeath) .

[Fallen Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallenHero): Though Captain Anderson's recollection of his time working with Saren, along with the [prequel novel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/MassEffectRevelation), both make it clear he was always a jerk. Played a bit straighter in *Evolution*, where it's implied that the seeds of Indoctrination have already been planted in him by the Arca Monolith, influencing his actions in *Revelation*.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): While it's mentioned several times in the game, the novel *[Revelation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/MassEffectRevelation)* clearly show his hatred for humanity. This makes his admission of Shepard being a [Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent) all the more noteworthy.

[Fiction 500](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Fiction500): He was a major investor in Binary Helix, which allowed him to fund various research projects, not to mention the veritable army of mercenaries he regularly hires.
[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss): Of the first game, though  (SPOILER) Sovereign is directly controlling him at this point.
[Final Boss Preview](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBossPreview): You get a teaser of the proper final battle with him when you fight him on Virmire.

[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): During the last fight against him in the Legendary Edition, geth reinforcements will show up to assist him for each quarter of his life bar he loses.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To a Renegade Shepard, who will develop the same glowing eyes as Saren unless they undergo regenerative surgery, and during Zaeed's loyalty mission, will sacrifice innocent lives in an oil refinery to get a target — just as Saren did in the prequel novel.

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing):
    - His (SPOILER) [One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel) form anticipates the Brutes and Marauders of *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)*. - Likewise, the way that (SPOILER) Sovereign hijacks his body foreshadows Harbinger doing this to his minions throughout the second game.
[Freaky Electronic Music](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreakyElectronicMusic): His theme is a menacing sounding synthesizer piece, which also plays whenever you get a Game Over.
[Genius Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser): A terrifyingly effective fighter, an excellent tactician, and an intelligent businessman who became filthy rich with some smart investments.

[Glasgow Grin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlasgowGrin): Done somewhat subtly, as part of his roboticisation — look at his mouth, then look at any other turian's. A normal turian mouth goes pretty far back... but not *that* far, nor is it that wide at the cheek.
[Glowing Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlowingEyes): Which [shut off](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyeLightsOut) when he finally dies.

[The Heavy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeavy): The main villain who moves the plot along.  (SPOILER) Since [Sovereign](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMan) is posing as his flagship, Saren takes center stage as the villain in eyes of the galaxy.

[Heel Realization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelRealization):  (SPOILER) Can be talked into having one of these .
QUOTE **Saren:** Goodbye, Shepard. And thank you.  (SPOILER) *(BANG!)*
[Heroic Willpower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicWillpower):  (SPOILER) How he manages to overcome Sovereign's indoctrination long enough to kill himself — that is, if Shepard is persuasive enough.

[Historical Villain Upgrade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HistoricalVillainUpgrade): In the second game. While Saren wasn't really a nice guy to begin with, the Council is quick to demonize him and exaggerate his villainy, in spite of the fact that  (SPOILER) Sovereign was the one behind it all. Saren is painted as the mastermind and becomes a scapegoat so that the Council can ignore the Reaper threat; he is also painted as a [Con Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConMan) who used the Reapers as a ruse to trick the geth into following him and send Shepard on a [Snipe Hunt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SnipeHunt).
[Improbable Age](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableAge): He became a Spectre at the age of *19-20*.

[In the Blood](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InTheBlood): His older brother Desolas was a prominent commander in the First Contact War. Their father is implied to have served with some distinction as well.
QUOTE **Saren:** I'm an Arterius, but I'm also sworn to defend my people.
[Karmic Transformation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmicTransformation):  (SPOILER) Getting turned into a Husk *after* dying is awful(ly poetic).
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER) No matter what happens, he *will* die, whether by his own hand or by Shepard.
[Knight Templar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar): "Is submission not preferable to extinction?"
[Last-Name Basis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastNameBasis): Inverted. Almost everyone refers to Saren in first name only, but the Avina VI mentions his last name during the endgame.
[Last-Second Chance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastSecondChance): Shepard can offer him this, and if they are persuasive enough  (SPOILER) Saren will break free just long enough to kill himself.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): "Saren's Theme" is also the "Game Over" music, which almost subliminally makes the player hate him *even more*.

[Les Collaborateurs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LesCollaborateurs):  (SPOILER) Seemingly, he helps the Reapers because he thinks they will spare at least some organics if Saren can prove they are helpful. Really, though, it's [More than Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl) in action.

[Machine Worship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MachineWorship): Saren convinced the geth to obey him by doing this, acting as the "prophet" for the return of the Reapers.  (SPOILER) Unfortunately for him, [it didn't stay an act for long.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl)
[Macross Missile Massacre](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MacrossMissileMassacre):  (SPOILER) After Sovereign takes control of him, his new husk-like form can spam explosive projectiles.

[Master of All](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfAll): When he's finally confronted he has: extremely powerful shields, a high level assault rifle and pistol, the Damping and Sabotage tech powers, the Shield Boost and Carnage combat powers, and the Throw, Barrier, and Warp biotic powers. It's impossible for Shepard or any squadmate, even via [New Game Plus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NewGamePlus), to have that combination of powers and weapons. He's effectively a combination of all the game's classes; no wonder he was considered the best Spectre.

[The Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMentor): According to *Andromeda*, he was one for former Spectre Avitus Rix, managing to avoid [Evil Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilMentor) since Avitus is actually a stand-up guy, who has nothing but respect for Saren (he assumes the whole thing with the geth was Saren having snapped, not knowing about indoctrination).
[Mind over Matter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindOverMatter): The only onscreen named turian biotic of the series until the Omega DLC of the third game.
[More than Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl):  (SPOILER) He's been indoctrinated by Sovereign.

[Motive Decay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MotiveDecay): Reaper indoctrination will do that to you. Even more so when Sovereign decides to crank up the dial. Saren goes from "prove ourselves useful to the Reapers" to "we should merge organics and synthetics". Liara and Shepard can even discuss this, wondering what Saren's original goals were and how far he's strayed, though Shepard points out it doesn't really matter now. He's a threat either way.

tropeName: Names to Run Away from Really Fast
tropeNotes: [Names to Run Away from Really Fast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NamesToRunAwayFromReallyFast): [Doesn't that name sound familiar?](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarin) He is also named after [Søren Kierkegaard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kierkegaard), the father of existentialism. Though, funnily enough, his name isn't actually considered odd for a turian in-universe; [supplemental material](https://masseffect.fandom.com/wiki/Cerberus_Daily_News_-_May_2010#05.2F07.2F2010) offhandedly references other people also named Saren, like a rescue worker who pulled a child out of rubble on Taetrus.

[Necessarily Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NecessarilyEvil):  (SPOILER) Believes that proving organics to be useful will save them from the Reapers. [He's proven horrifically right about that by the sequel.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssimilationPlot)

[N.G.O. Superpower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NGOSuperpower): He's not just a [state-sponsored terrorist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheDog) with years of experience. He has [asari commandos](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperpoweredMooks). [Krogan mercenaries.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight) An army of [geth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MechaMooks). And Binary Helix, [an interstellar biotech conglomerate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MegaCorp) that [pays for all of it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Fiction500). And don't forget his [Creepy Starship.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolStarship)
[No One Could Survive That!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoOneCouldSurviveThat): At the end of the game.  (SPOILER) [He doesn't.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession)

[Obviously Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObviouslyEvil):
    - An in universe example of the trope since he's a barefaced turian, given that most barefaced turians are considered untrustworthy. - In his very first appearance, the cutscene practically draws flashing arrows pointing to the massive number of tubes festooning his back and to the glowing blue lights of cybernetics under his skin. - According to Wrex, when he worked for him as a hired gun simply seeing Saren personally set off so many warning signs in him that he quickly chose to leave him without getting paid. (SPOILER) Reminding him that Saren is evil and that having the Krogans permanently indebted to him is a [Fate Worse than Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FateWorseThanDeath) is one of the ways to talk him down from the standoff .
[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): Has a minor one on Ilos when Joker combat-drops the Mako almost right on top of him.

[One-Man Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneManArmy): He was considered the best Spectre for a reason. In the prequel novel *Revelations*, he wipes out the Skulls mercenary group with ease as an afterthought, and later rampages through a pirate-held refinery, gunning down whatever he encounters. In-game, he's the most powerful enemy encountered and can easily swat aside Shepard's squadmates if you're not careful, each of whom qualifies as a One-Man or One-Woman Army in their own right.
[One-Winged Angel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel):  (SPOILER) When Sovereign activates his implants and takes over his body.
[The Paragon Always Rebels](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParagonAlwaysRebels): Saren was one of the best Spectres before he went very, *very* far off the rails.

[Post-Mortem Comeback](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PostMortemComeback):  (SPOILER)  Gets reanimated into a puppet for Sovereign. His death triggers a lowering of Sovereign's shields and his balance, allowing the *Normandy* and the Alliance to take it out.
[Primal Stance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrimalStance): Normally, Saren's posture is wonderful. However, when he starts to get ticked off...
[Properly Paranoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProperlyParanoid):  (SPOILER) About being controlled by Sovereign.

[The Quisling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheQuisling):  (SPOILER) Though how much of this was his own thinking and how much was Sovereign's [More than Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl) isn't entirely clear.

[Rabid Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RabidCop): Certainly fits the trope during *[Revelation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/MassEffectRevelation)*.
QUOTE **Saren:** Some Spectres arrest people. I *don't*.

[Rasputinian Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RasputinianDeath): He gets shot hundreds of times, falls off his hover board from a very tall height through a glass floor, gets impaled on a large shard of glass, and then is shot two more times in the head by Shepard's squadmates just to make sure he's dead.  (SPOILER)  *[It doesn't work.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel)*

[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): Twice. If you count  (SPOILER) his huskified form  as a separate boss battle, thrice. The first battle with him is on Virmire. The second battle with him is on the Citadel.  (SPOILER)  If you have enough Charm/Intimidate points, you can convince him to break free of his indoctrination long enough to kill himself, allowing you to skip fighting him on his hoverboard.

[Redemption Equals Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEqualsDeath):  (SPOILER) He can be persuaded to kill himself so Sovereign can't make him open the Citadel Relay. Subverted since the galaxy still sees him as a monster. Ironically, he was viewed as a legend while he was working for Sovereign. 
QUOTE **Saren:**  (SPOILER)  Sovereign is too strong. I'm sorry. It is too late for me.  
**Shepard:**  (SPOILER)  [It's not over yet. You can still redeem yourself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreBetterThanYouThinkYouAre).  
**Saren:**  (SPOILER)  [Goodbye Shepard. Thank you](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide).

[Red Herring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedHerring): It's implied at the beginning and in the prequel novel that Saren's driving motivation is his hatred towards humanity.  (SPOILER) This is largely bogus, since it was purely coincidental that his first attack happened to be a human colony, and he's acting equally against all the galactic civilizations.  He also openly admires Shepard, a human.

[Red Right Hand](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedRightHand):
    - The massive number of cybernetics he's visibly crammed with, including a geth arm replacing one of his organic ones, kinda screams evil. - Assuming you knew nothing about [The 'Verse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVerse) before playing the first game: when you watch the scene in which he first appears, you've only seen one other turian up to that point. As you go on and meet other turians, it becomes apparent that Saren looks *very* abnormal compared to the rest of his race. Here are pictures of [Nihlus](http://images1.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20120402214046/masseffect/images/5/5b/Spectres_Codex_Image.jpg)◊, [Executor Pallin](http://images4.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20090208005946/masseffect/images/thumb/1/10/Executor_Pallin-Citadel_Tower-Arguement_with_Garrus.png/270px-Executor_Pallin-Citadel_Tower-Arguement_with_Garrus.png)◊, and [Garrus](http://images1.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20100306223761/masseffect/images/thumb/3/35/Garrus_Character_Box.png/270px-Garrus_Character_Box.png)◊. Have a look and then scroll up and look at the picture of Saren again.
[Rogue Agent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RogueAgent): Used to be the Council's best and most famous Spectre.

[Sequential Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequentialBoss):  (SPOILER)  His first, skippable (provided that you can persuade him) form, and his second, husk-like form, where Sovereign is directly controlling him.

[Skippable Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkippableBoss):  (SPOILER) Sort of. There are two stages to his boss fight, so convincing him to go through [redemption by suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEqualsDeath) simply skips the first part of the fight and propels you into the second section of the battle.
[Sky Surfing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkySurfing): His first two boss fights involve him flying around on a floating platform.

[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): Saren is a very dangerous threat all by his lonesome. However,  (SPOILER) he vastly overestimates his agency due to the decades of indoctrination Sovereign had subjected him to, and is little more than a convenient puppet with enough connections and smarts to seize the Citadel to signal the Reapers for invasion. This trait is even more prominent at the end of *Revelation*, where his lust for power and [hatred of humans](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism) override his common sense, even after seeing what Sovereign had already done to Dr. Qian and Edan Had'dah. He begins devising plans to investigate Sovereign through intermediaries, wary of indoctrination, but he evidently threw caution to the winds at some point and ends up the helpless thrall he is by the start of the first game.

[The Social Darwinist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSocialDarwinist): He has elements of this.
QUOTE **Saren**: Your species needs to learn its place, Shepard.

[Start of Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StartOfDarkness): Seen in the *Mass Effect: Evolution* comic.
QUOTE **Saren:** I have a duty to Palaven. Like you. We all do. [Some secrets were meant to stay buried until we're ready to understand them](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWorldIsNotReady). I will mourn for you, and avenge you!

[Story-Driven Invulnerability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StoryDrivenInvulnerability): Averted. Every time Saren appears in the earlier parts of the game, it's either in a cutscene where Shepard isn't present, or as a hologram that Shepard is incapable of throttling. When they finally meet face-to-face, it is on. Played straight in the battle on Virmire. The fight will end when he has 1/5 of his health left, even if you hit him with a weapon that should down him in a single hit.

[Super-Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperStrength): As a result of his cybernetics, he is able to (among other things) [Neck Lift](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeckLift) a large man in full power armor and leap several times his own height.

[Talking the Monster to Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TalkingTheMonsterToDeath): A literal example:  (SPOILER) With a high enough Charm/Intimidate rank, Shepard can convince Saren that he is fully indoctrinated, causing him to kill himself. Of course, Sovereign later takes over his remains.

[Tragic Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicVillain): Willingly joined the Reapers, believing that he could ultimately save all organic life in the galaxy in doing so.  (SPOILER) He was so very, very wrong - and unwittingly became their indoctrinated pawn in the process.
[Token Evil Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenEvilTeammate): In *Mass Effect: Revelation*, he's the Renegade [Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil) for Paragons David Anderson and Kahlee Sanders.

[Villain's Dying Grace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainsDyingGrace):  (SPOILER) With a sufficient Charm/Intimidate rank, Shepard can convince him to finally admit that he was wrong about the Reapers all along, and all of his villainous actions have been for nothing, before he commits suicide.
[Villain Respect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainRespect): He admits that he's genuinely impressed by Shepard's actions on Virmire.
[Villain with Good Publicity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainWithGoodPublicity): At first. He gets exposed quite early on, though.
[Walking Disaster Area](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingDisasterArea): All Spectres seem to share this trait with Shepard. In *Revelation*, he blew up an oil refinery as part of his mission.

[We Can Rule Together](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeCanRuleTogether): To Shepard, twice.
QUOTE **Saren:** I am a vision of the future, Shepard. The evolution of *all* organic life. This is our destiny. Join Sovereign and experience a true rebirth! 
**Shepard:** [I'd rather die than live like that!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpHannibal)

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist):  (SPOILER) Wants to usher in the Reaper invasion because he believes that if organics make themselves useful, they will be spared by the Reapers (he's right, but [not quite the way he hoped](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlaveRace)). Though it's impossible to tell how much of that belief was implanted by Sovereign, and his original plans for the ship weren't exactly nice.

[Will Not Tell a Lie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WillNotTellALie): Like all turians. Saren's interview with the Council is an excellent demonstration of his unwillingness to tell a direct lie. He deflects all the accusations with insults and intentionally misleading statements: [He really does resent the accusations against him because from his point of view he's doing the right thing, and the Spectre he murdered really was a colleague and friend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactWords). He then goes on to insult humans in general and Anderson specifically in order to change the subject.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): Despite his intense dislike of humans, he's *very* interested in getting Shepard on his side, going out of his way to do so twice in the middle of a battlefield.

[Wrong Genre Savvy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrongGenreSavvy): On Indoctrination. Having witnessed his brother Desolas get Indoctrinated by the Arca Monolith, he assumed this was because Desolas was exposed to the Monolith almost constantly. Saren incorrectly assumed that he had been unaffected by the Monolith because he had not been exposed to it as often, and decided he would use the same strategy on Sovereign - keeping his distance from it unless direct contact was absolutely necessary. Unfortunately for him, this proved to be a gross miscalculation, the seeds of his own Indoctrination were effectively planted by the Monolith, but Saren's less frequent exposure to it and Sovereign only meant that the process took longer than previous victims.
QUOTE **Desolas:** I don't understand much of anything. My mind... is going. 
**Saren:** That's how it works. I don't know why I was unaffected — maybe it had something to do with indirect contact.

[Affectionate Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffectionateNickname): She refers to Liara as "Little Wing".
    - Doubles as an [Actor Allusion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActorAllusion) to Marina Sirtis' [best known role](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Series/StarTrekTheNextGeneration), who was also a powerful psychic, had a strained relationship with a controlling mother, who insisted on referring to them by the [Embarrassing Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmbarrassingNickname) of "Little One". Speaking of which, this isn't the first time she's played [a blue-skinned villain who happens to be the mother of one of the heroes.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/WesternAnimation/Gargoyles) - Revealed in *3* to be a reference to something Liara's father once said.

[And I Must Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream):  (SPOILER) Indoctrination is already a case of this, but it's even worse for Benezia as she locked part of her mind away and was fully aware of what was happening the entire time.
[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): She had good intentions, but  (SPOILER) Sovereign  was one step ahead of her.
[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): While Saren's [Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon) in the game's overarching plot, she's the central villain for Noveria.

[Authority Equals Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorityEqualsAsskicking): As an asari matriarch, she possesses powerful biotic abilities, and is by far one of the hardest boss fights in the game.  (SPOILER) She also gets extra points for being able to resist Sovereign's mind control .
[The Baroness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBaroness): Only while evil.
[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy):  (SPOILER) Turns out that she's indoctrinated.

[Buxom Beauty Standard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BuxomBeautyStandard):  (SPOILER) Aethtya  practically goes starry-eyed remembering her magnificent rack, producing a [Too Much Information](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooMuchInformation) response from Liara.
[Cleavage Window](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CleavageWindow): Liara's other parent  (SPOILER) Aethyta  fully admits having been entranced by that rack, "even before she hit the matriarch stage"...
[Dark Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkActionGirl): One of the toughest boss fights in the game and Saren's right-hand woman.

[Dark Is Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsEvil): Dresses in black by the time of the first game.  (SPOILER) Given that she was brainwashed and tried resisting, she was [Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil) to an extent .
[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): Acts as Saren's right-hand woman.
[Dying as Yourself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DyingAsYourself):  (SPOILER) She reverts back to her true self before dying.

[Evil Costume Switch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCostumeSwitch): Though it's only implied two games after her appearance, in *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)*, when Liara mentions that when she was a child, her mother loved to dress in yellow.
[Evil Matriarch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilMatriarch): To Liara.  (SPOILER) Not by choice.

[Fighting from the Inside](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingFromTheInside):  (SPOILER) Prior to speaking to the rachni queen. She's able to completely resist Saren's influence, after taking enough ammunition to stop an entire commando unit, long enough to help Shepard at least somewhat, but eventually succumbs to her injuries from the fight beforehand. [She declines medigel if offered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDieFree), saying she'd just go back to being a slave anyway.
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): She's damaged, for some reason, by her summoning more and more geth troopers and asari commandos in an attempt to take out Shepard and their squad.

[Go into the Light](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoIntoTheLight):  (SPOILER) Cruelly subverted by her dying words. 
QUOTE  (SPOILER) No light... They always said there would be a... a...

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):  (SPOILER) Her final act is to give Shepard the coordinates to the Mu Relay and then request that they kill her so she will no longer be under Sovereign's control.

[Heroic Willpower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicWillpower):  (SPOILER) That plus her biotics allow her to seal off her consciousness long enough to have a last talk with Shepard. She's also the only character in the entire series who breaks free of indoctrination for longer than the few seconds it takes to put a pistol to one's head.
[I Die Free](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDieFree):  (SPOILER) She specifically refuses medigel after Shepard's party fatally wounds her.
[Ink-Suit Actor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InkSuitActor): Her facial features are very similar to Marina Sirtis's.
[Lady of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar): A prominent political figure with a dignified air, and an extremely powerful biotic. Liara evidently gets it from her.

[Magnetic Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagneticHero): As a highly respected Matriarch, she had many followers and admirers. When Benezia decided to join Saren to dissuade him from his cause, she offered her followers the choice whether to come with her or not, since she knew it would be dangerous. Very few said no.

[Male Gaze](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MaleGaze): When we first see her on Saren's ship, the first things we see of her are her rear end as she walks towards Saren, and then her chest before the camera pans up. Humorously, she coughs as if to say [My Eyes Are Up Here](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyEyesAreUpHere) to the player *and* BioWare. The Legendary Edition removes these two shots, opting for a long shot, but medium shots still show her ample bosom.

[Maligned Mixed Marriage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MalignedMixedMarriage):  (SPOILER) Being an asari, this is inverted. Benezia is the one who couldn't face the stigma of raising a pureblood daughter, and left Aethyta while she was still pregnant.
[Mind over Matter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindOverMatter): A powerful biotic, even by the standards of a matriarch.

[Mind Rape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape):
    - (SPOILER) Benezia states that Sovereign's hold on her feels like "his teeth are at my ear — fingers on my spine..." - She admits to tearing the information about the Mu Relay from the Rachni Queen's mind, ominously and remorsefully saying that she was "not gentle."

[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): Noted in-universe. She showed up on Novaria "in a pinstripe suit" that got people excited, and  (SPOILER)  Aethyta  talks about how "Nezzy" used her sex appeal to get people to listen to her.

[My Beloved Smother](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyBelovedSmother): It's implied her relationship with Liara was tense, in part due to Benezia's overprotectiveness. When Shepard first meets Liara, she says that she hasn't talked to her mother in years. They *are* asari and live for a thousand years, but Liara was barely more than a child at the time.
QUOTE   (SPOILER)  **Aethyta**: I told her, "You're treating her like a baby bird, 'Nezzy, but she's going to raise one hell of a storm with those little wings."  
**Liara:** *(choked up)*  (SPOILER) "Little wing"?

[Necessarily Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NecessarilyEvil): She started off helping Saren as a way of trying to dissuade him from his destructive path.  (SPOILER) Then Saren's [Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination) friend got involved...

[Never Mess with Granny](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMessWithGranny): She's fairly old by asari standards (even if she doesn't look it), since matriarchs are typically around 700 years old when inducted. She also stands out as one of the hardest boss fights in the game.
[Non-Standard Character Design](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonStandardCharacterDesign): Benezia is the only asari matriarch have wrinkles and creases on her face to denote her advanced age.
[One Bad Mother](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneBadMother): The [Evil Matriarch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilMatriarch) variant,  (SPOILER)  though not by choice.

[Religious Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReligiousBruiser): Revered among the asari for her many writings on the subject of Theology.
    - Revealed in *3* that she was one of the few asari who still actively practice worship to the goddess Athame. - More notable since it's also revealed that (SPOILER) Athame was actually a Prothean. Liara mentions that Benezia had research notes on the Temple of Athame dating back centuries, implying that she indeed knew the truth, but nonetheless *still* kept her faith.
[Redemption Equals Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEqualsDeath):  (SPOILER)  Her last act was to temporarily break free of indoctrination to give Shepard the coordinates for the Mu Relay.
[Spikes of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpikesOfVillainy): Her headgear has this.
[So Proud of You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoProudOfYou): (SPOILER) [Tells Liara this before she succumbs to indoctrination again.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TearJerker)
[Suicide by Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideByCop):  (SPOILER) Because she knows she can't break Sovereign's [Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindControl) completely.

[Tragic Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicVillain):  (SPOILER) She only joined Saren because she hoped that she could stop his evil from within. Then Sovereign decided to [chime in](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape).

[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): Fully two thirds of the tropes on this list either apply to her death scene or are references to her mentions in later games. That, and her debut scene makes her out to be more important than she winds up being.
[We Hardly Knew Ye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHardlyKnewYe):  (SPOILER)  Before her death on Noveria, she only appears in one scene and via a voice recording.

[Abusive Precursors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbusivePrecursors): The first Reaper you meet, he is the one to establish that *they* created the relays, and intend to destroy the galaxy's current civilizations as they have so many others.

[Ambiguous Situation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousSituation):
    - In conversation with Vigil, it speculates that Sovereign's actions by that point could be overconfidence or the Reaper equivalent of a mad scramble to get things back on track. - His reaction to being worshipped by the Geth is to feel *insulted*. Is it because he's just so arrogant that he thinks their worship is beneath him, (SPOILER) or is it because the Catalyst created the Reapers to stop synthetics from destroying organic life and being worshipped by synthetics kind of goes against that ?

[Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss): He says flat-out that he doesn't give a crap about the geth, and actually seems a bit *insulted* that they revere him as a god. That, and [Reaper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl) [indoctrination.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FateWorseThanDeath)

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): Pretty much his entire speech on Virmire. When combined with his [very, very deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSoundsDeep) [mechanical voice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoiceOfTheLegion), it can [give most people the shivers.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R_NAoNd4YyY) QUOTE **Sovereign:** **YOU EXIST BECAUSE WE ALLOW IT. AND YOU WILL END BECAUSE WE DEMAND IT.**
    - I am the vanguard of your destruction

[Believing Their Own Lies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BelievingTheirOwnLies): Sovereign more than any other Reaper seems to truly believe all the hype that his race is immortal and incapable of losing. Even if he's merely bluffing in an attempt to throw Shepard off their game, his complete lack-of-focus on defending himself against the Alliance ships attacking him in the end (instead focusing much of his attention on fighting Shepard through Saren) implies that he has a much higher standing of himself than reality.

[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): He's the true force behind Saren, working to usher the return of the Reapers and begin the next cycle of extinction.  (SPOILER) However, he, like all other Reapers, is [The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon) to [The Catalyst](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain).

[Blatant Lies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies): For as badass as his speech on Virmire is, a majority of his responses prove to be pure fiction, such as claiming the Reapers have no creator or that the reasoning for their actions is beyond organic comprehension.
[Blue-and-Orange Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality): He outright tells Shepard that the Reapers' motivations are incomprehensible to organics.
[Cold Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColdHam): He delivers truly epic threats and contemptuous mocking, all in a hard, level tone.
[Color-Coded for Your Convenience](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedForYourConvenience): Sovereign is red, Harbinger is yellow. When Sovereign assumes control of Saren, the possessed body is red.
[Cool Starship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolStarship): He *is* the starship.

[Cultural Posturing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturalPosturing): His claim that Reapers have no beginning and are infinite can be interpreted as this, especially since that's actually an outright lie ( (SPOILER) as the Catalyst and Leviathan reveal ). Though, even without that knowledge, it's highly doubtful the Reapers predated the Big Bang and creation.
[Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle): Effectively sets up the power level of the Reapers. Remember, this is one ship out of *tens of thousands at least*.

[Desperation Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperationAttack): Thanks to the Prothean scientists who managed to "reprogram" the Keepers so they'd ignore Sovereign, Sovereign over the course of a few hundred years started to grow increasingly desperate. It tried every sort of trick and finally choose the unsubtle tactic of recruiting part of a synthetic race (the geth) to help it take the Citadel by sheer brute force; keep in mind, the Reapers were created because of rebellious [A.I.s](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AIs) like the geth in the first place. On some occasions, Sovereign will **ASSUME DIRECT CONTROL** of Saren *just to throw a temper tantrum* or shoot Keepers for their "betrayal". When Saren is killed, he takes over his body just to attack Shepard directly, even though it seriously puts its plans at risk.

[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope). He may be an unfathomably ancient evil far grander than any human, who is capable of driving people insane from mere proximity and for whom even a single thought is immense, but he's still of this universe, just as bound to the laws of physics as anyone else, drives people insane through completely scientific neurochemistry and is not supernatural in the slightest, being still technically mortal.
[Evil Gloating](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGloating): Practically every single line he has.
[Evil Sounds Deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSoundsDeep): He has an *extremely* bass voice. Being voiced by [Peter Jessop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/PeterJessop) tends to help.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): None of the Reapers like organic life exactly, but through [Blue-and-Orange Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality) they seem to think they're doing the right thing. Sovereign, on the other hand, appears genuinely spiteful.

[Fatal Flaw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatalFlaw): Arrogance, and it doesn't just doom him: it potentially dooms his entire *species*. Nearly every defeat and setback the Reapers suffer throughout the series can be directly traced back to Sovereign's decision to engage in [Evil Gloating](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGloating) on Virmire - if he had simply decided *not* to tell Shepard who he was and what his goals were, the Reapers would very likely have had a regular cycle with a small blip at the start due to Prothean tampering with the Keepers. Instead, they face a galaxy somewhat prepared for them, with a singular hero who eventually ends their threat for good.

[Fighting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingAShadow): When he possesses Saren. It's the only time you'll fight him in the game.
    - Subverted, as Saren's death while controlled by Sovereign gives him enough feedback that he apparently suffers something akin to a computer crash, completely losing his ability to fight back against the fleet. He doesn't last too long after that.

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): His possession of Saren and the ensuing difficult boss fight foreshadows Harbinger's relentless possession of drones and the following difficulty in beating them.

[Genre Shift](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenreShift): Before you meet Sovereign, the game plays out like a thriller or government conspiracy chase film where Shepard is under covert orders to bring in renegade Spectre Saren, though there were hints beforehand this was not the case. The second you meet him however, the game and the series dives into [Cosmic Horror Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CosmicHorrorStory).

[Hive Mind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiveMind): According to Legion, the geth "touched" its mind, and ultimately assumed that its mention of every Reaper being "each a nation" meant this. Meeting the Human Reaper confirmed the geth's theory.
QUOTE **Legion:** An interesting choice, Shepard-Commander. Your species was offered everything Geth aspire to: True unity, Understanding, Transcendence... You rejected it. You even refused the possibility of using the Old Machines' gifts to achieve it on your species' own terms. You're more like us than we thought.

QUOTE **Shepard:** You told me the Reapers were more my future than yours. You knew what they were, didn't you?

QUOTE **Legion:** Transcended flesh. Billions of organic minds, uploaded and conjoined within immortal machine bodies. "Each a Nation." We did not "know". It was one hypothesis among many. When Nazara corrupted the heretics, we touched its minds. We perceived they were different from ours, but could not tell how.

[Hoist by Their Own Petard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoistByTheirOwnPetard): He's so dead set on making sure the signal to the rest of the Reapers can be sent out that he directly inhabits Saren's body as a [Meat Puppet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeatPuppet) to try a last-ditch effort to kill Shepard and get control over the Citadel. This turns out to be [what helps defeat him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobFixingItVillain) once the body is slain and Sovereign is left vulnerable by the [Poke in the Third Eye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PokeInTheThirdEye), with extra irony coming from how the puppet he manipulated and controlled as little more than a fleshbag for his machinations ends up the cause of his downfall.
[I Am Legion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IAmLegion): Concerning the Reapers. And he's absolutely right, in more than one way.

[Interface Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterfaceSpoiler): Inverted. He's the only character in the series whose subtitles don't have a character name in front of the dialogue to distinguish who's speaking.

[I Shall Taunt You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IShallTauntYou): Makes some pretty badass boasts. QUOTE "**[YOUR WORDS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustAMachine) ARE AS EMPTY AS YOUR FUTURE. I AM THE VANGUARD OF YOUR DESTRUCTION.**"
    - Given an amusing [Ironic Echo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IronicEcho) in the *Leviathan DLC* for the third game, where Shepard repeats this comment to a piece of wreckage salvaged from Sovereign, kept within a forcefield in Dr. Bryson's lab. QUOTE **Shepard**: Sovereign, the "vanguard of our destruction". How's that [working out for you](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidYouJustPunchOutCthulhu), big guy?

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Is *much* more condescending than Harbinger and the unnamed Destroyer Reaper on Rannoch. While those two display that — through their own [Blue-and-Orange Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality) — they view the Reapers' actions as beneficial to organics, Sovereign's dialogue makes him sound almost spiteful to the point where he seems to have a dislike for organics. He and Saren are pretty much a match made in hell.
    - Doesn't seem to think very much of synthetics either, if what he thinks of the Geth are any indication. Maybe he just [Hates Everyone Equally](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HatesEveryoneEqually), though considering the reason the Reapers were created, it's more likely all Reapers hate synthetic life.

[The Juggernaut](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheJuggernaut): He tanks fire from two entire fleets without a scratch. Keep in mind, at least a couple of those ships were *dreadnoughts*, whose main gun pack several times the power of the Hiroshima bomb. In fact, Sovereign was so untouchable that for the most of the battle he doesn't even bother firing back, he simply plows straight through several ships.
[Karmic Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmicDeath): Killed by humans in the process of trying to activate the Reapers' relay precisely because he underestimated them so much.
[Knight of Cerebus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightOfCerebus): The entire series takes a dramatic turn for the darker once Shepard meets him on Virmire.

[Laser-Guided Karma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserGuidedKarma): *Personally* forces a deceased Saren to fight Shepard through a painful [Karmic Transformation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmicTransformation). Cue Shepard defeating Saren and Sovereign losing enough control over the Citadel and his own systems, allowing the assembled fleets to destroy him.
[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): His [deep brass musical motif](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MEc1OTFaWnI) becomes the general Reaper theme.

[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): In naval terms. Sovereign is immense and powerful, but shockingly maneuverable and fast. At one point Joker reports that Sovereign pulls a turn that "would shear any of our ships in half."
[The Man Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMan): The true force behind Saren.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Both of his names are meaningful; "Sovereign" is [Exactly What It Says on the Tin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactlyWhatItSaysOnTheTin), and "Nazara" is an early Greek translation of Nazareth meaning observer in Greek.
[Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindControl): Called "Indoctrination" in the game. All Reapers can do it — even when they're dead.

[Mind Rape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape): Indoctrination is also this. [It's permanent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream) and [is about the most horrible fate a person can suffer.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FateWorseThanDeath)

[The Mothership](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMothership): This is what everyone on Eden Prime calls Sovereign, for lack of a better word. Referred to in the Codex as "Saren's flagship" before its true nature is revealed.

tropeName: Names to Run Away from Really Fast
tropeNotes: [Names to Run Away from Really Fast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NamesToRunAwayFromReallyFast): Something named "Sovereign" likely doesn't have humble or benign intentions. Averted in *[Mass Effect 2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect2)* when Legion reveals "Sovereign" to be a title coined by Saren and that the Reaper had previously introduced himself to the Geth as "Nazara".

[Nigh-Invulnerability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NighInvulnerability): Comes with being a Reaper. He is destroyed but it takes the combined efforts of *two entire fleets* to finally bring him down—*and* after his shields got dropped by Shepard killing his vessel, Reaper Saren.

[Non-Indicative Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonIndicativeName): Sovereign is the Reaper that is left behind after the previous cycle's genocide, the one which keeps an eye on the re-establishment of organic civilization, and the one that ultimately signals the rest of the Reaper swarm to return through the Citadel and begin the cycle all over again. As such, a more appropriate name for him might be *Harbinger.*

tropeName: Normal Fish in a Tiny Pond
