    - (SPOILER) See the [Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice) entry above for what happens if you don't get Thane's help, or he isn't alive in the third game.
[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): He doesn't hold back when he gives his speeches.
[Majorly Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MajorlyAwesome): If he lives through Virmire, he gets promoted to this by *3*.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Named after Currahee Mountain, a mountain used during WW2 to train Paratroopers.

[Rousing Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RousingSpeech): A fan of these. Mordin somewhat exasperated with them, preferred to get the job done instead of wasting time with "chest-pounding."
    - His "Hold the Line" speech in *1* is particularly great given that it's impressive to the (obviously human) player, despite him referring to events that the player had never heard of before. - In *3*, if the krogan aren't on Earth, Kirrahe will be giving one to his troops, though this time with a [Dare to Be Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DareToBeBadass) theme.

tropeName: Screw the Rules, I'm Doing What's Right!
tropeNotes:
[Screw the Rules, I'm Doing What's Right!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewTheRulesImDoingWhatsRight):  (SPOILER)  If he survived Virmire, you'll meet him again on Sur'Kesh, where he promises to lend the STG's support to retaking Earth regardless of what deals you have going with the dalatrass. Should you help Mordin or Padok cure the genophage, he makes good on that promise. 
QUOTE **Hackett:** These STG guys know the score. They're not going to jeopardize the entire Salarian Union just because some dalatrass didn't get her way.

[Sticky Bomb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StickyBomb): When you meet him again in the third game he's carrying a Scorpion as his sidearm. The Scorpion is a salarian pistol that launches blue sticky grenades, which he helpfully demonstrates on a couple of Cerberus [mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Mook). Garrus complains about it... But after the mission, you can buy it and ease his (and your) gun desires.
QUOTE  **Garrus:** How do I *not* have one of those?

[Vitriolic Best Buds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VitriolicBestBuds): With Mordin. Referred to as a "bit of a cloaca <sup>note </sup>  A cloaca is a general purpose genital/waste excretion orifice on some non-mammal species - ergo he's calling Kirrahe a dick *and* an asshole " by Mordin in the present, [even if Kirrahe is dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverSpeakIllOfTheDead). Mordin's Shadow Broker dossier includes an STG report that reveals that on the mission to  (SPOILER)  distribute the modified genophage on Tuchanka , the two of them spent most of the time flinging cloaca-based insults at one another, with Mordin poking fun at Kirrahe's insistence on following the plan to the letter and suggesting that he "[has foreign object in cloaca](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExpospeakGag)", "suggests foreign obstruction in cloaca is Kirrahe's cranium" and Kirrahe losing temper at constant jibes and Mordin incessantly asking about shifting mission parameters and calling Mordin a "walking cloaca." However, when Mordin was injured in battle and refused to obtain medical attention until his work was finished, Kirrahe admiringly called him "one tough cloaca." Furthermore, cut content from *Mass Effect 2* includes an email from Kirrahe (assuming he survived Virmire) in which he admits that he's been exchanging friendly emails with Mordin over special equipment requirements, and remarks that he's "a good agent. [Nervy for a tech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotBad). [Bit of a cloaca, though](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag)."

[By-the-Book Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ByTheBookCop): Disapproves of the Spectres as they operate outside the law. This causes much friction with Garrus, who is a [Cowboy Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CowboyCop). Despite this, Pallin actually thinks Garrus is a good officer, when he's not railing against the rules.
[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): He believes humanity's meteoric rise is due to humans being favored by the Council, and doesn't approve of the amount they've been given.
[Malaproper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Malaproper): An example of turians not having the best grasp of human colloquialisms, as he mangles "fingers in every pie".

[Noble Bigot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleBigot): Despite his general distrust of humans, he seems fine with many of them joining C-Sec and it's implied human officers are treated fairly under his command.

[Series Continuity Error](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SeriesContinuityError): He's no longer head of security by *Mass Effect 2*. The "Mass Effect: Inquisition" comics shows that he was killed by Bailey when Bailey catches him seemingly working for the Council's enemies, and Bailey confirms this to Shepard in the third game. For some reason, the codex states that Pallin was still alive until *Mass Effect 3*, where he helped foil the Cerberus Coup and was killed by Kai Leng.
[Awesome Moment of Crowning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwesomeMomentOfCrowning): If he becomes the human Councilor.

[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): While he lacks biotic powers or cybernetics, he's still a badass nonetheless. Particularly noticeable in the prequel novel "Revelation", where he surprises, injures, and drives off the krogan battlemaster Skarr with nothing more than a heavy pistol, quick reflexes, very good aim, and some luck. Skarr, by the way, is a 500-pound alien who can bench press a car and toss an APC [with his mind.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindOverMatter)
[Beehive Barrier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeehiveBarrier): Fortification is one of his powers during the intro to *3* — in his admiral's uniform, to boot.

[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): While not officially leading the Alliance, he's the only authority figure other than Admiral Hackett that Shepard consistently respects. When he's  (SPOILER) promoted to Admiral by *3* , he, Admiral Hackett, and Commander Shepard share this role, with Shepard acting as a military ambassador getting species together, Hackett being the man behind the  (SPOILER) joint species fleet  while Anderson is the leader of  (SPOILER) the Earth resistance troops.

[Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey): [Played for Drama](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayedForDrama). He has to take crap from  (SPOILER)  Saren, who ruined his chances to become a Spectre by blaming the destruction of an element zero refinery on him in *Revelation*; Udina, who belittles Anderson and complains about everything he says in addition to shafting him mid-game, [forcing him to step down and hand over the ''Normandy'' to Shepard.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuicklyDemotedLeader) When he overrides the lockdown, you can either get him shot by C-Sec or have him punch out Udina (funny how he'll always choose the latter if you leave the decision up to him).

[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): Zigzagged. He's 49 by the third game, which is pretty old for an active duty military man in our time, but human life expectancy and quality of life has increased dramatically by *Mass Effect* to the point where living to 150 is considered lucky. So it's unclear if the same military retirement standards would apply.

[Continuity Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContinuityCameo): You get to meet Anderson's old flame, Kahlee Sanders (from *[Revelation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/MassEffectRevelation)*), in a *Mass Effect 3* side mission.  (SPOILER)  If you manage to rescue her, Anderson hopes to hook up with her after the war is over. The *Citadel* DLC also implies that they do meet up occasionally at his Citadel apartment .
[Cosmic Plaything](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CosmicPlaything): The universe just piles on the crap for this guy. [He still gets up and does his job though.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDeterminator)

[A Day in the Limelight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ADayInTheLimelight): The tie-in prequel novel *[Mass Effect: Revelation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/MassEffectRevelation)*, which elaborates on how he used to be in the running for first human Spectre before Saren screwed him over.
[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): He only has one scene in the second game.

[Desk Jockey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeskJockey): What he's demoted to when Shepard is given command of the ship.  (SPOILER)  You can decide whether he stays like this or gets promoted to Councillor at the end of the first game.  He shucks this role in *Mass Effect 3*, when he becomes the leader of the remaining human forces on Earth resisting the Reapers.

[Doomed Hometown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoomedHometown): According to the first *Mass Effect* novel *Revelation*, Anderson was born and raised in London.  (SPOILER)  Guess where one of the main targets for the Reaper invasion of Earth is?
[Easily Forgiven](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasilyForgiven): If you let the Council die at the end of *1*, Udina's actually pretty calm about Anderson punching him out.
[Elites Are More Glamorous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElitesAreMoreGlamorous): Anderson is a member of the N7 special forces and served with honor in the First Contact War against the turians.
[A Father to His Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen): Especially when it comes to Shepard.

[Four-Star Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass): Gets some admiral's stars in *Mass Effect 3*, and if he was Councilor, he has retired from that post to return to the military. Takes charge of the resistance on Earth once Reapers start their galactic harvest.

[Friends with Benefits](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendsWithBenefits): Heavily implied to be this with Kahlee Sanders in the *Citadel DLC*. Her overnight bag (containing [massage oils](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappyEndingMassage)) is found in Anderson's apartment on the Citadel and a recording mentions her as being present while Anderson relates some life stories for the biography being written about him.
[The Good Captain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGoodCaptain): Probably Shepard's most reliable authority figure.

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): Fights with Shepard directly during the intro level of *Mass Effect 3*. Breaks the trend set by the first two games, in that he survives this role.  (SPOILER) For the time being.
[Hero of Another Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroOfAnotherStory): Of *Revelation* and *Retribution*. Again in the third game.
[I Choose to Stay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IChooseToStay): Anderson refuses to leave Earth with Shepard in *3*, wanting to help with the war effort against the Reapers there.

[I Need a Freaking Drink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/INeedAFreakingDrink): In the two years between *Mass Effect 1* and *Mass Effect 2*, apparently. The [Shadow Broker's dossier on him](http://masseffect.wikia.com/wiki/Shadow_Broker_Dossiers/Captain_David_Anderson) shows that he's two steps from becoming a full-blown alcoholic due to [all the booze he's had to down to ignore all the stupidity he's been exposed to.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrowningMySorrows) His tab at Dionysus Imports: 2 bottles of white wine after viewing "Saren: A Hero Betrayed", 1 bottle of [Gargle Blaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GargleBlaster) after viewing a documentary on what *really* happened behind the Citadel attack, 2 bottles of [Vodka Drunkenski](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VodkaDrunkenski) after watching "Path of Lies: A History of the Alliance Military" and a documentary on the [airquotes "Reapers"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MemeticMutation) back-to-back. Followed by a call to [Kleen Sweep Home Maintenance.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VomitDiscretionShot)

[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER) On the Citadel in the endgame of *3*; after the Illusive Man forces Shepard to shoot him, he succumbs to the wound and dies peacefully .

[Knight in Sour Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInSourArmor): He knows full well the galaxy is run by idiotic politicians and bureaucrats. He does not like this. He gets up and does his job anyway.

[Like a Son to Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LikeASonToMe): How he views his beloved protege, Shepard.  (SPOILER) His final words are calling them son/child (depending on gender) and telling them how proud he is of them.
[The Men First](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMenFirst): Why he stays behind on Earth in *3*, because someone has to lead the resistance.
[The Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMentor): To Shepard.
[Mentor Occupational Hazard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MentorOccupationalHazard):  (SPOILER) Interestingly enough, he actually makes it to the very end of the trilogy before dying.

[Mildly Military](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MildlyMilitary): At least with Shepard by *Mass Effect 3* who he jokingly reprimands for referring to him formally.
QUOTE **Shepard:** Good to see you too, sir. 
**Anderson:** *"Sir?"* I may have reinstated you, but that doesn't give you permission to get all formal on me. 
**Shepard:** Then I'm glad you managed to keep your ass alive, Anderson. 
**Anderson:** *[chuckles]* That's more like it.

tropeName: Not Even Bothering with the Accent
tropeNotes: [Not Even Bothering with the Accent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotEvenBotheringWithTheAccent): He really doesn't sound like a Londoner. *Revelation* explains this to be because of cross cultural exposure through electronic schooling, the internet, and pan-global entertainment.

[Obsolete Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObsoleteMentor): Subverted. Despite being surpassing their [Old Master](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldMaster), Shepard still answers to Anderson as their superior and throughout the trilogy, consistently will turn to him for advice on what to do.
[O.O.C. Is Serious Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OOCIsSeriousBusiness): Usually, he's pretty calm. Asking him about Banes in *1* is one of the few times he snaps at Shepard for anything.
[Opt Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptOut):  (SPOILER) Whether you choose him to be the Councilor or not, Anderson opts to quit his position in *Retribution*, leaving Udina as Councilor.

[Papa Wolf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf): To humanity and his protege, Shepard, in particular. If he was made  (SPOILER) Councillor  in the second game, one reason you can imagine that he stepped down for was because he couldn't legally defend Shepard's actions in the *Arrival* as the  (SPOILER) representative of the human race.  However, as a member of the Alliance, once he was promoted to the Admiralty, he *[could](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePlan)*.
[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): Three guesses for whom.

[Passing the Torch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PassingTheTorch): Was meant to be  (SPOILER)  the first human Spectre  until Saren ruined his candidacy. It's implied that he chose Shepard as his protege, because he saw in them the potential to take up where he left off.

[Quickly-Demoted Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuicklyDemotedLeader): Udina forces him to step down as Captain of the *Normandy* after Shepard becomes a Spectre. Subverted when he becomes an authority figure once more in the other two games, (potentially) becoming a Councillor in *2* and an Admiral in *3*. Though he does  (SPOILER) [Opt Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptOut) of being the human Councillor  before *3*, in the tie-in novel *[Mass Effect: Retribution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/MassEffectRetribution)*.

[Quintessential British Gentleman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuintessentialBritishGentleman): According to *Revelation*, though he [doesn't have the accent.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotEvenBotheringWithTheAccent)

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): One of the two human authority figures Shepard can actually count on throughout the entire series, (the other being Admiral Hackett). In the third game, Anderson has apparently having repeatedly gone out on a limb for Shepard during their time in the Alliance brig. Despite Shepard's trial being interrupted by the Reaper invasion without coming to a verdict, Anderson promptly drops the charges and reactivates them back into service, as Earth needs the person most experienced at fighting the Reapers in the galactic war.
[Rebel Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RebelLeader): During *Mass Effect 3*, he decides to stay on Earth and lead [La Résistance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaResistance) during the Reaper occupation.

[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass):  (SPOILER) In a manner of speaking. When the truth comes out about Saren, Shepard inquires if he has thought about reapplying to become a Spectre. Anderson admits that he's "too old" to go chasing about the galaxy and he trusts Shepard to [pick up where he left off](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeUpMySword).

[So Proud of You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoProudOfYou):  (SPOILER)  After you stop the Illusive Man from killing him, his last words in the entire series are how proud he is of his protege.   (SPOILER)  This is also the name on the soundtrack of the [Mood Motif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoodMotif) during this scene when he dies.

[The One That Got Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheOneThatGotAway): Seems to feel this way about Kahlee Sanders. The feeling is mutual and it's alluded to multiple times in *3* that both of them wish to renew their relationship once the war is over.
[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): He will always be there to support Shepard. The feeling is mutual with Shepard as well.

[Ambiguous Situation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousSituation): The codex entry for  (SPOILER) the Cerberus coup wonders if he was a high-functioning victim of Reaper indoctrination, or just desperate. Said entry notes that his actions would have played right into the Reapers' hands if they succeeded, but that there was no obvious opportunity for them to sink their claws into him.
[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim):  (SPOILER) He assists the Cerberus coup in *3*, and is shot by either Shepard or the Virmire Survivor for his efforts.

["Ass" in Ambassador](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssInAmbassador): In spades. The turians describe him in the second game as "a diplomatic incident waiting to happen." Despite his high rank, Udina comes off as having barely a *shred* of political tact.

[Awesome Moment of Crowning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwesomeMomentOfCrowning):
    - (SPOILER) Can be given a Council seat at the end of the first game. - In *Retribution*, the novel sequel to *Mass Effect 2*, (SPOILER) Udina is the Councilor regardless of your choice. Anderson opts to quit his job.

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): At the end of *1*, if suggested as human councillor, he'll make a genuinely badass speech about "driving the Reapers back to dark space", complete with fist clench. Undercut in *2* by his and the Council's belief that the Reapers were a lie by Saren.

[Beleaguered Bureaucrat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeleagueredBureaucrat):
    - While the Renegade ending of the first game leaves no doubt as to the kind of person he is, Udina sometimes seems as tired of politics as everyone else, but he has to deal with it because it's his job. This is most obvious if you talk to him after Feros. - In *Mass Effect 3*, he'll tell Shepard he has more power than any human *ever* had in history - and it's almost worth nothing.

[Character Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterCatchphrase):
    - Frequently utters just why "This is an OUTRAGE!". - In *3*, he states his PR campaign for Earth to get alien support is "Help the humans, help yourselves."

[Deal with the Devil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DealWithTheDevil):  (SPOILER) His deal with Cerberus to help them overthrow the Council in exchange for immediate military support for Earth in *Mass Effect 3* is explicitly described by [Those Two Guys](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThoseTwoGuys) as a deal with the devil.
[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): Like Anderson, he only has one scene in the second game.

[Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon): He clearly crosses it after Earth is attacked. Speaking to him, he will talk about how he was on [First-Name Basis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FirstNameBasis) with all of the Alliance bigwigs before they were killed in the attack.
QUOTE **Udina:** The Council. You saved their lives, and for what? Apologies that boil down to, "maybe later." If we don't figure out something, 'Maybe Later' will be an epitaph on a mass grave of eleven billion.

[Didn't Think This Through](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntThinkThisThrough):  (SPOILER) EDI's after-action analysis suggests Udina's plan after the coup was to launch an all-out attack on the Reapers in the hope of freeing Earth, which would've been tactical suicide.
[Divided We Fall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DividedWeFall): When he grounds Shepard as opposed to letting them go after the Conduit because he's afraid of losing the Council's favor.

[Even Evil Has Loved Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasLovedOnes): More like co-workers than loved ones, but Udina does show grief over the fact his colleagues in the Systems Alliance Parliament were all killed when the Reapers destroyed their headquarters at Arcturus.
[Face–Heel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn):  (SPOILER) In *3*. Not that he wasn't already slipping in that direction to begin with, though.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Udina is okay with Shepard killing the last rachni queen because, as he puts it, he doesn't want "a bunch of bugs" running around the galaxy.

[Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): Particularly in the first game where Udina is a thoroughly unlikable, smug and obstructive politician who second guesses Shepard at every turn and stabs them in the back when it's politically convenient. His one brief scene in the second game reminds players that he's still an [Ungrateful Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UngratefulBastard) to Shepard. The third game is the only point where he becomes at all sympathetic, working his ass off to rally support for the Reaper-invaded Earth.  (SPOILER) And even then, this one redeeming quality ultimately drives him to perform a [Face–Heel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn) and join Cerberus, plotting to murder the rest of the Council so he can claim ultimate power on the Citadel to better help save Earth.

[Horrible Judge of Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HorribleJudgeOfCharacter):  (SPOILER) One of the reasons everyone wonders if he was indoctrinated. By the point he stages the coup, Cerberus have stepped up to blatantly sabotaging anti-Reaper efforts, huskifying their troops and outright terrorism, and yet he still lets them onto the Citadel. And for all this, the Illusive Man still considered Udina totally expendable, so he probably wouldn't have lasted long afterward.

[Inadequate Inheritor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InadequateInheritor): He's a hell of a step (or possibly a whole flight of stairs) down from Goyle, his predecessor as Earth's ambassador (mentioned *once* in the first game, and who has a major role in *Revelation*).
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Ambassador Udina seems to enjoy his job a little too much, especially when foiling Shepard.

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Jerk
tropeNotes:
[Jerk with a Heart of Jerk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfJerk):
    - If you (SPOILER) give him the position on the Council , does he serve as a "true advocate" for humanity? *Balls no*. He goes right back to being an [Obstructive Bureaucrat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObstructiveBureaucrat) and (SPOILER) may even completely deny the existence of Reapers. - In *Mass Effect 3*, it is eventually revealed that (SPOILER) Udina was outright working with Cerberus to engage in a coup against the Council. Strangely, this is perhaps the most sympathetic he gets; his entire motivation for working with Cerberus was to force the Council to send support for his besieged homeworld. Before that, too, he's unusually dedicated and not as harsh towards Shepard as usual.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): If Shepard goes out of their way to make things difficult for him or refuses to exercise any kind of diplomacy in dealing with the Council, he's within his rights to call them out on it.
QUOTE **Udina:** *[Upon being told that Shepard has rudely refused reinstatement into the Spectres]* Are you *trying* to start an interstellar war? What the hell is **wrong** with you?!

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): He was responsible for  (SPOILER) Executor Pallin's death  in *Inquisition*, where he tries to use the fact there could be enemies in the Council to further a pro-human agenda.
[The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole):  (SPOILER) He is this in *3*. It is unknown how long he was working with Cerberus, but he was the one who helped them get to the Citadel.
[Obstructive Bureaucrat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObstructiveBureaucrat): Though he's fairly helpful at first. But not for long.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog):
    - If you convince the Alliance to return Nirali Bhatia's body to her husband, Samesh, or save Chairman Burns from biotic extremists, Udina is nice enough to supply them with Shepard's e-mail address so that they can properly thank Shepard in *Mass Effect 2*. Udina will do this even if (SPOILER) Shepard recommends Anderson to the Council. - In *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)*, he puts forth a motion to the Citadel Council to transform the embassy docking bay into a refugee camp.

[The Quisling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheQuisling):  (SPOILER) In *Mass Effect 3*, he has joined in with Cerberus, and plots to assassinate the other Councillors and stage a coup with their aid. It's left ambiguous whether he was indoctrinated, idiotically ambitious or just plain desperate and scared when he went with this plan.
[Riddle for the Ages](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RiddleForTheAges): Was Udina  (SPOILER) indoctrinated or just desperate ?
[Slave to PR](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlaveToPR): More concerned with making sure humanity looks good than anything else, though it's more "looks good to the Council" than actual PR.

[Too Dumb to Live](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive):  (SPOILER) His collaboration with Cerberus can only be defined as fatally stupid, considering that, as the Human Councilor and thus a high-level official, he would have known very well that Cerberus was directly undermining the Alliance war effort, using Reaper-augmented soldiers, and attacking civilian targets. The leap in logic required to see this [Obviously Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObviouslyEvil) enemy as a source of backing is enormous.

[Took a Level in Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInJerkass): It's easy to forget, but at the beginning of the first game, while he was not the friendliest guy, he at least would give Shepard the benefit of the doubt. But then he started basing his judgement purely on PR.

[Took a Level in Kindness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInKindness): In *Mass Effect 3*, in a way. He's much less abrasive towards Shepard; it helps that he's visibly beleaguered and worried about the state of Earth in the wake of  (SPOILER) the Reaper invasion , and he apparently took steps to accommodate the growing refugee population. Though he and Shepard aren't always in agreement, they're on the same side.  (SPOILER) Or so it would seem; it later turns out he's working for Cerberus.
[Tragic Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicVillain):  (SPOILER) He worked with Cerberus in a bid to get support to save Earth.

[Tyrant Takes the Helm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TyrantTakesTheHelm):
    - (SPOILER) If you kill off the Council and put him in charge of the new one, he'll start restricting Spectre positions because he doesn't want anybody to operate outside of his authority. Even though the last person who did so *saved the freaking galaxy*. - In *3*, he's apparently changed his mind since he backs and appoints the Virmire Survivor as a Spectre (SPOILER) only to manipulate them against Shepard when he's about to be exposed as a collaborator in the Cerberus coup.
[Ungrateful Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UngratefulBastard): Even if you  (SPOILER) recommend him to be on the Council , don't expect him to give you a warm welcome in the sequel.
[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist):  (SPOILER) Works with Cerberus to engage in a coup against the Council. He did it to get support for Earth.

tropeName: What the Hell Is That Accent?
tropeNotes: [What the Hell Is That Accent?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellIsThatAccent): Has elements of a British and Irish accent; the latter is much more prominent in *3*, particularly in the conversation Shepard can have with him in his office after the Council meeting. His last name, "Udina", is Egyptian.
[You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness): Pulls this card when siding with the Council against Shepard near the end of the first game.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra): Goes from being just a voice telling you about side-missions, to being arguably Shepard's most frequent and [trusted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure) contact in the Reaper War.

[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): A large number of the side missions in the original *Mass Effect* come from him. He will always express surprise and delight with Paragon Shepard's ability to avoid causalities.
    - In *Mass Effect 3*, Shepard reports directly to him and he is, for all intents and purposes, the leader of the entire human race. - *Mass Effect 3* essentially makes him part of a [Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood) Ensemble along with Shepard and Anderson. The humans on Earth look up to Anderson, Shepard looks up to Hackett and the rest of the galaxy looks up to Shepard.

[Batman Gambit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BatmanGambit): Pulls one on Shepard in the first game's side mission "the negotiation". The mission is only avaliable if Shepard is big enough of a [Renegade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CowboyCop) and involves Shepard being sent to negotiate with an [extremely unpleasant pirate who insults them practically every sentence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake). if the "negotiation" ends in a shootout (which is guaranteed to happen unless you pick the *Paragon* choice every single time, even as the man insults you), Hacket clearly doesn't sound *too* disappointed in the after-mission debrief. Shepard can call him out on this, pointing out that Hackett clearly knew what was going to happen when sending [a Renegade Shepard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodIsNotSoft) to negociate. Hackett [claims he has no idea what you're talking about but thank you for "trying" to talk the criminal down](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlausibleDeniability).

[The Cape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCape): Subtle, but even though Hackett won't expect Shepard to find peaceful resolutions to difficult missions, he'll be extremely pleased when he does, saying most people would take the easier route.
[The Cavalry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCavalry): *Epically* at  (SPOILER) the climax of the first game.

[Character Narrator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterNarrator): He narrates the ["Where Are They Now?" Epilogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhereAreTheyNowEpilogue) for the high-EMS "Destroy" ending and the low-EMS [Bittersweet Ending](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BittersweetEnding) (with *heavy* emphasis on the "bitter").
[Clint Squint](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClintSquint): Seems to be the neutral state of his eyes.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): He is this thanks to being [The Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoic).
QUOTE **Hackett:** All I know is I sent you out there to break Amanda Kenson out of prison, and now an entire system is destroyed. I hope you can fill in the leap of logic between those two events.

[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): Only appears in the second game if you have the *Arrival* DLC, though he'll still offer you side missions and send you messages via the Private Terminal.

[Dirty Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyBusiness): The crux of his side missions in the first game. Now that Shepard is a [Spectre](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteAgentsAboveTheLaw), they can be used to deal with any sensitive situation the Alliance wouldn't want the Council to know about, although in most cases they're sent there after the fact to clean up.
[Father Neptune](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatherNeptune): Serves as this for the Alliance Navy.
[Four-Star Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass): He's an admiral and one of the biggest thorns in the Reapers' side short of Shepard themselves.

[Good Hair, Evil Hair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodHairEvilHair): Hackett wears the classic [mirror universe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Series/StarTrekTheOriginalSeries) goatee and mustache combination, but he's definitely a good guy.
[Good Scars, Evil Scars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodScarsEvilScars): Has a very prominent scar on his right cheek, and his right eye looks like it's taken its fair share of right hooks.

[Gray-and-Grey Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrayAndGreyMorality): As an Admiral, Hackett is naturally concerned with maintaining the law; however, following Shepard's promotion to Spectre, he has Shepard perform more "under the table" missions to maintain Alliance confidentiality.

[Guile Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuileHero): Some of his missions (such as sending a Renegade Shepard to possibly assassinate Lord Darius) edges him closer to this territory.
QUOTE  **Shepard:** You put Darius in power, but he was getting greedy. You wanted me to kill him. 
**Hackett:** The Alliance does not condone assassination. We would never give that order. Killing Darius was your decision alone — and because you're a Spectre, we couldn't reprimand you if we wanted to.
[Ink-Suit Actor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InkSuitActor): Hackett's face has more than a passing resemblance to [Lance Henriksen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/LanceHenriksen)'s.

[Ironic Echo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IronicEcho): "You've done a hell of a thing."  <sup>note </sup>  What Hackett tells Shepard in the first game if they manage to save everyone in the Paragon-exclusive mission. Also what he says after Shepard [buys the galaxy some time](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheDog) in *Arrival*.

[Nerves of Steel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NervesOfSteel): Probably the calmest and most unflappable human leader in the series. Even when Reapers tore the Alliance a new one. Pointed out by Jacob in the third game. Case in point: in the [Low EMS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadEnd) final battle there's a scene of a Reaper destroyer landing on a Dreadnought, presumably his flagship. We're treated to a scene inside of the [CIC](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBridge) with fires breaking out, panels exploding, alarms blazing and Alliance personnel screaming and running in horror, while the admiral just stands there calmly, gritting his teeth and holding on to a railing.
QUOTE **Jacob:** If they make old guys any tougher than that, I'd like to see it.

[Old Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldSoldier): Hackett's age doesn't diminish his badassery in any way. He's been with the Alliance for a very long time. He doesn't let it slow him down.
QUOTE  **Jacob:** If they make old guys any tougher than [him], I'd like to see it.

[Precision F-Strike](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrecisionFStrike): In a new cutscene added in the Extended Cut, during the final battle, once Hackett is notified that Shepard has  (SPOILER) reached the Conduit and boarded the Citadel. 
QUOTE  "Holy shit, they did it."

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): He uses Shepard's loyalty to the Alliance to get them to take on some sensitive missions. However, he does at least acknowledge that they are doing him a favor and acts appropriately. At the end, he defers to Shepard as the (wo)man in the field, despite his much higher rank.
    - In *Lair of the Shadow Broker*, (SPOILER) his dossier reveals that he denied an Alliance desk jockey's request to have Shepard detained and interrogated for a few months due to their ties to Cerberus, and with style. QUOTE **Hackett's entire response to a lengthy request email:** Request denied. - Later in the same DLC, Liara (SPOILER) reveals that Hackett was the one who gave her Shepard's dogtags, and confirmed that Shepard was still alive before they actually met, wishing Shepard well. - In the *Arrival* DLC, after Shepard is forced to (SPOILER) kill 300,000 batarians, Hackett notes that he will do what he can to protect Shepard and delay any fallout that they will have to face as long as possible saying that they did what they did for the right reasons. He even tells Shepard to keep his report because he doesn't need it to know that they did the right thing.

[Rousing Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RousingSpeech):  (SPOILER) He gives one during the endgame of *3*. 
QUOTE   (SPOILER) "Never before have so many come together - from all quarters of the galaxy. But never before have we faced an enemy such as this. The Reapers will show us no mercy. We must give them no quarter. They will terrorize our populations. We must stand fast in the face of that terror. They will advance until our last city falls, but we will not fall. We will prevail. Each and every one of us will be defined by our actions in the coming battle. Stand fast. Stand strong. Stand together. Hackett out."

[Shoot the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheDog): A lot of his missions seem to revolve around this trope. After the events of *Arrival*, Hackett tells Shepard that  (SPOILER) ***they*** have to be (metaphorically) sacrificed to the batarians to avoid a war, after they kill over 300 000 of them to blow up a mass relay the Reapers were minutes away from using.
[Supporting Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupportingLeader): He leads the charge against Sovereign in the final act of the first game.

[Unexpected Successor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnexpectedSuccessor): Following the Reapers' initial assault on human space, and the destruction of Arcturus Station, Hackett essentially becomes the de facto leader of the human race, particularly after the death of Udina. By the end of the game, as the leader of the multi-species alliance, he is arguably the single most powerful organic being in the galaxy.

[Unseen No More](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnseenNoMore): He spends most of the first two games as [The Voice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVoice), but appears in person for the first time at the end of *Arrival*.

[Up Through the Ranks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UpThroughTheRanks): He spent four years as an enlisted man and volunteered for several high-risk exploration assignments beyond the Charon Relay before receiving a commission as a second lieutenant in 2156. He's now the fleet admiral of the Alliance Navy.
[The Voice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVoice): Until the second game DLC *Arrival*.
[Voice with an Internet Connection](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoiceWithAnInternetConnection): In the first and third games.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): He's restrained about it, but he's vexed when Shepard comes back from a mission to rescue a single person to blowing up a mass relay and killing 300,000 colonists in the process.

tropeName: You Are Better Than You Think You Are
tropeNotes: [You Are Better Than You Think You Are](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreBetterThanYouThinkYouAre): In a particularly poignant moment, when Shepard is expressing doubts about their ability in the war, he sums up why they are so important and deserving of their position. They have the ability to inspire such confidence in troops, that they will literally follow any order given simply because they believe in them.

[You Are in Command Now](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreInCommandNow):  (SPOILER) A strange case: He's already the highest ranked flag officer in the Alliance Navy, but with the death of the entirety of Alliance Parliament, and subsequent treason and death of Udina in the third game, Hackett is the de facto leader of what's left of the Systems Alliance.
[Younger Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanTheyLook): He is about 52 in *Mass Effect 3*. You'd be forgiven for thinking he is in his 70s.

[The Bus Came Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBusCameBack): Sort of. Pinnacle Station and Intai'sei both show up in *3*; the former can be scanned to earn some War Assets (Guard Captain Vidinos' spec ops team), and the latter for a sidequest [Plot Coupon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlotCoupon).

[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): As long as you can impress him in the simulations, he'll *give you a [Big Fancy House](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigFancyHouse) on a remote planet* with infinite grenades, medi-gel, a big-screen TV and, most importantly, an avenue to purchase *the best equipment in the game*.
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): He tends to be very caustic.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): During the First Contract War he was given a near-suicidal mission against dozens of turian mercenaries. He survived, and to this day carries a grudge.
[Four-Star Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass): Same as Admiral Hackett, though not with nearly as much political power.
[Large-Ham Announcer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHamAnnouncer): Uses his commentary during Shepard's matches in the simulator as an excuse to chew the scenery.
[Not Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotBad): His initial reaction to Shepard beating the current records.
[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): He's not technically retired, but he no longer participates in war-fighting.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): He's not even mentioned in *Mass Effect 2,* and you can't visit the apartment he gave you on Intai'sei (though you being dead might have something to do with that).
[Action Mom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionMom): What else would you expect from Spacer Shepard's mother?
[Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatchPhrase): Though you only have two chances to speak with her, she signs off with "[I have to go](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LikeFatherLikeSon)."

[Death by Origin Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathByOriginStory): If Shepard has either of the two backgrounds other than Spacer, she and Shepard's father were either killed by batarian slavers attacking the colony of Mindoir (Colonist), or died of unknown causes on Earth leaving their child an orphan (Earthborn).
[The Dreaded Dreadnought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreadedDreadnought): Commands the SSV *Orizaba*, a *Kilimanjaro*-class dreadnought, in *2*.

[Four-Star Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass): She's a Captain in the first two games, though it's mentioned in the second that it's only because she keeps *refusing* to become an Admiral, preferring to continue to [serve with her crew](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMenFirst) instead of behind a desk. By the third game, she's been rapidly promoted to Rear Admiral, in part because of the losses the fleet have suffered, but mostly because she's so badass it's the rank that she honestly *should* be by this point. [She is a Shepard, after all.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassFamily)
[It Runs in the Family](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItRunsInTheFamily): A decorated Alliance soldier, well respected by her crew, and signs off with "[I have to go](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatchPhrase)".

[The Men First](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMenFirst):
    - Gives this reason as why she kept refusing to become an Admiral. - Zabaleta recalls that she always stuck up for him when they served together on the *Einstein*. The only reason he even agrees to go to Veterans Affairs Office to deal with his PTSD is because she told him to.

[Outliving One's Offspring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutlivingOnesOffspring): She had to experience this between the first and second game. This is part of the reason for her [What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero) message below. May have to do so *again* depending on the ending in the third.
[So Proud of You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoProudOfYou): Expressed in the above quote, and through Hackett in *3*.

[The Voice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVoice): Presumably because Shepard's mother looks like her child, and the player is the one who chooses what Shepard looks like. She is heard in *1* if Shepard had a Spacer background and contacts her about one of her old shipmates. He calls her again in the Citadel DLC in *3*.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): Sends Shepard an email in *2* asking why she had to learn her child was still alive [third hand](http://masseffect.wikia.com/wiki/Hannah_Shepard) through Alliance brass. She relents a little, assuming it's a classified thing, but still wants her kid to call. QUOTE So I have to find out my child is alive third-hand from the Alliance brass? Where the hell have you been? I figure whatever you're doing is classified, likely part of your Spectre operations. Just stay safe out there, and keep doing your mom proud. And sneak something through a secure channel next time.

[Cassandra Truth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CassandraTruth): If you gun down the scientist he's holding at gunpoint, then in *Mass Effect 2*, a news report mentions his claims about Cerberus weren't believed.
[Driven to Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide): Depending on how you play his mission.
[Insistent Terminology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsistentTerminology): It's *Corporal* Tombs. Not mister.
[Shell-Shocked Veteran](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShellShockedVeteran): Not like you can blame the guy.

[Sole Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoleSurvivor): Is the only surviving member of his unit. If Shepard has the [Sole Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoleSurvivor) background, they both react with surprise upon seeing the other alive.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): If he survives, in *Mass Effect 2* he sends Shepard a message tearing them apart for working with the people who tortured him. Just be glad you never have to meet him in person. For [his](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroAntagonist) [own](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DontMakeMeDestroyYou) [sake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbstompBattle).
[Character Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDeath):  (SPOILER) He is captured and executed by Cerberus after uncovering their research facilities on Binthu.

[Cruel and Unusual Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CruelAndUnusualDeath): (SPOILER) You find his body in a cage with horrific monsters swarming over it.
    - Surprisingly subverted, as (SPOILER) examining his body reveals that, despite being surrounded by horrific monsters, his body is completely unharmed except for a needle mark in his arm, implying that he was killed by lethal injection and *then* left in a cage with monsters. It's possible Shepard saved him from [A Fate Worse Than Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFateWorseThanDeath) by finding him when they do. Knowing the rachni, they probably ignored it, since they're at least human-level intelligent and had no use for the body, and were focusing on their captors instead.
[A Father to His Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen): He is highly respected by his soldiers, and in turn he is extremely dedicated to them as well.
[Four-Star Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass): Served with distinction during the Skyllian Blitz.
[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): It is mentioned that he has a wife and three children.

[Ambiguous Situation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousSituation): He only appears in-person during the Snap Inspection assignment in the first game, and is never heard from again...until the third game, where he and his flotilla are a War Asset only if Shepard let the Council die.
    - [Uncertain Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UncertainDoom): Given the above, how he is otherwise never mentioned after ME1 and the losses the Alliance fleets take in saving the Council, one could reasonably assume he dies in this scenario.

[Artistic License – Military](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtisticLicenseMilitary): He's technically not in the Normandy's chain of command, and the Normandy's design specs are highly classified and since information is on a need-to-know basis he would get in serious trouble with Alliance brass for demanding to inspect the vessel, and even without Spectre status Shepard would be entirely justified in forbidding him from accessing the ship (which you *can* actually do), or even outright *arresting* him on suspicion of espionage.
[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): It's pretty clear he's in it for straight-up fights, grumbling about the *Normandy* being designed for stealth operations rather than warfare.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism):
    - He initially raises some not entirely unreasonable concerns about having aliens onboard what is ostensibly an Alliance vessel, but then sneeringly wonders if Shepard still remembers what color their blood is. As the conversation goes on, he makes it clear he doesn't trust any alien race, nor does he see any reason he should. Surprisingly, the guy never said anything against Tali's presence.
      - Which is even more hilarious when you consider that she's actively working with the Engineering team on the state-of-the-art engine and may have stolen the schematics for her fleet
    - Unsurprisingly, he also hates batarians, and in *3* an email can be found mentioning he's all too willing to let the batarians take as many 'heroic sacrifices' as they can against the Reapers.

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Even without the aliens, he's pretty rude to Shepard, regardless of how polite they are back. He even insults the *Normandy*! Whether Shepard lets that slide or not is up to the player.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): He criticizes the Normandy's CIC layout design, which is a turian design where the commanding officer is in the back rather than surrounding his crew like on Alliance ships. Shepard can handwave it away by saying they can use radio, or Shepard can just shout really loud, and the crew is disciplined enough to minimize idle chatter. But in cutscenes (such as the approach to Ilos in *1* or the approach to the Heretic Base in *2*) Shepard is usually in the cockpit next to Joker and not at their designated posting near the galaxy map. Then again, that might just be to make cutscenes look better.

[Obstructive Bureaucrat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObstructiveBureaucrat): Meets Shepard at the *Normandy*'s berth to demand an inspection of the ship. Shepard can either let him do it or use Spectre authority to shut him out, with Mikahilovich threatening them that his report will reflect this. Of course, since Shepard is a Spectre and on a mission for the council, his report doesn't count for much.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Downplayed; he's the one senior Alliance officer you meet in the first game who *isn't* in favor of Shepard being given command of the *Normandy*, mostly because it was supposed to be part of his command. He also dismisses Shepard being made a Spectre as a triviality, and complains that the *Normandy* cost more to build than a heavy cruiser. However, it's possible with sufficient Paragon and Renegade points to at least convince him that Shepard knows what they're doing with her.
[Sleepyhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Sleepyhead): How he avoided the geth - he needed a nap to get through his shift.

[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): He appears in one scene but is the person who identifies Saren's role in the geth attack, kickstarting Shepard's attempts to bring the rogue spectre down. He's also the one who instructs Shepard to take the cargo train to get to the Prothean beacon in time.
    - And by extension, ruined the plans of (SPOILER) a millions year old galactic extinction cycle run like clock by countless machine gods.
[Character Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterDeath): If you fail to save him in *Mass Effect 1*.
[Corrupt Politician](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptPolitician): By his own admission, he took the job just as a stepping stone to put on his resume.

[Heel Realization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelRealization): If you save him from the biotic terrorists in *Mass Effect 1*, in *2* he admits in a letter to Shepard that he took the job mostly for the power, but now realizes that was wrong, which leads to his:

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): After seeing the biotics suffering firsthand, he realizes just how wrong it was to use them for personal gain and dedicates himself to making amends.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): If saved in the first game he sends you a letter saying that the L2 biotics received their reparations and that he is going to help humanity reach its full potential with minimum bloodshed. He also mentions that he is receiving considerable political heat for this decision — but no real details either are given, and we never see much followup.

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): Not that anyone takes him seriously. Or that the one making the boast is much of a badass.
QUOTE **Conrad:** Why don't you sit back and let me show you how it's done? I've got some asses to kick.

[Badass on Paper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassOnPaper): How he looks to Jenna from Chora's Den. Yes, he does try to take a bullet for Shepard, but it's *his* stupidity and ineptitude that put Shepard in danger in the first place. From Jenna's perspective though, he looked like a [Badass Bystander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBystander).
[Borrowed Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BorrowedCatchphrase): "I should go."
[Bullying a Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BullyingADragon): Matriarch Aethyta *begs* you to get Conrad the hell out of her bar before she hits him with a Matriach-level Singularity.
[Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey): He exists for unpleasant but amusing things to happen to.

[Comically Missing the Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ComicallyMissingThePoint): Several times. Put a gun up to his head to prove he's not ready for what he's proposing and he'll think you were teaching him how to be an extreme badass in the second game. He'll also mention how supportive his wife was and how she even paid for his transportation off world. [Cue a facepalm from the asari bartender standing behind him.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FunnyBackgroundEvent)

[Continuity Porn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContinuityPorn): In a series known for its save game bonuses, his story arc takes the cake. He only shows up in *[Mass Effect 2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect2)* if you spoke to him all three times on the Citadel in the first game and didn't get him killed. Then, he will only appear in *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)* if you completed his quest and [didn't get him killed again](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey). Finally, he will contribute his  (SPOILER) doctoral dissertation on xenotechnology  to the war effort, then get you some helpful specs, but the latter only if Shepard completed the side quest for a minor N.P.C. on Feros in the first game, completed the [asari writings collection](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwentyBearAsses) in the first game, and purchased an Elkoss Combine requisition license in the first game. *And then* he will  (SPOILER) only survive his [Side Quest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SideQuest) if you helped get a minor character named Jenna out of Chora's Den in the first game , who will save him by disabling his  (SPOILER) Cerberus contact's gun . *Damn.*

[Cruel and Unusual Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CruelAndUnusualDeath):  (SPOILER) If Shepard tells him to get lost, a news report says he is killed attempting to stop youths from hitching a ride on top of a bus. It goes on to say he fell from the bus, hit several passing cars, and landed in the power turbine of a bio-mass recycling facility. Ouch .

tropeName: Desperately Looking for a Purpose in Life
tropeNotes: [Desperately Looking for a Purpose in Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperatelyLookingForAPurposeInLife): Happens in the first and second games. In the sequel, Shepard can inspire him to do something other than emulating them. And in the third, Conrad finally gets to be the badass he always wanted to be — and actually *was* all along.
[Dumb Blonde](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DumbBlonde): He's often way too naive for his own good. [However...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusDitz)

[Failed a Spot Check](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailedASpotCheck): In *Mass Effect 3*, he supports Cerberus while failing to notice that they just  (SPOILER) attempted to violently overthrow the galactic government and install a human puppet in its place .

[Friend to All Children](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendToAllChildren):  (SPOILER) If Shepard deals with him in a Paragon fashion in the second game, Conrad goes on to found a charity for children orphaned by the Battle of the Citadel named after Shepard. If asked about this in the third game, he states that he spent everything he had in order to get the kids to safety.

[Genius Ditz](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusDitz):  (SPOILER) Conrad actually has a *doctorate* in xenotechnology and wrote a dissertation on dark energy. He'll actually contribute to the war effort in *Mass Effect 3* if you ask him.

[Girlfriend in Canada](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlfriendInCanada):  (SPOILER) You learn in *3* that he either *never* had a wife, or she's long gone. The line from *2* about her paying for him to leave seems to support the latter. His closest current relationship is apparently his [Stalker Shrine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StalkerShrine) to Shepard.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):  (SPOILER)  Takes a bullet for Shepard . Can be subverted, if  (SPOILER)  Shepard helped Jenna in the first game; she'll sabotage the shooter's pistol before he can fire and save Conrad's life.
[Hero-Worshipper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWorshipper): So much so that by *Mass Effect 3*, Conrad is supporting *Cerberus* because Shepard worked with them in the second game.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths):
    - He has (SPOILER) a *doctorate*, and wrote his dissertation on xenotechnology and dark energy integration. That's *Doctor* Moronic Fanboy to you! - Not only this, but he has no money and is a refugee in *3* because (SPOILER) he spent everything he owned to get the kids in his orphanage (The Shepards) away from Reaper attack.

[Ignored Epiphany](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IgnoredEpiphany): Even if Shepard chose the Paragon route in *1* (thereby convincing him to stay with his family), he still shows up as a wannabe mercenary in *2*.
    - Of course, this is due to a save import error, which will always assume that Conrad was dealt with in a Renegade fashion. Modifying the save to correct the error results results in an accidentally [Dummied Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DummiedOut) Paragon scene involved Conrad [pretending to be Shepard's](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ATxE9JlSOlg) [Lancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Lancer). QUOTE **Conrad:** [I'm Commander Shepard's squadmate! I'm practically](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies) *[second-in-command!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies)* - Lampshaded in *Mass Effect 3*, where [he apologizes for lying that Shepard pointed a gun at him, saying it was just nerves.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedGlitch)
[Ignored Expert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IgnoredExpert): Part of his backstory.  (SPOILER)  Turns out, his ideas on dark energy might just end up helping to save the galaxy .

tropeName: I Just Want to Be Badass
tropeNotes: [I Just Want to Be Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IJustWantToBeBadass): He deeply wants to be like Shepard.

[In-Universe Factoid Failure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InUniverseFactoidFailure): Verner thinks Aethyta's bar is dealing in illegal drugs. Aethyta tells Shepard 1) no, they aren't selling red sand, 2) even if they were, red sand is legal on Illium.

tropeName: Irritation Is the Sincerest Form of Flattery
tropeNotes: [Irritation Is the Sincerest Form of Flattery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IrritationIsTheSincerestFormOfFlattery): He's taken to dressing like Shepard in the sequel.

[It Runs in the Family](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItRunsInTheFamily): *Andromeda* reveals that Conrad's behaviour isn't limited to him alone. His sister Cassandra claims she had to leave *the galaxy* because of his Shepard worshipping... and then turns out to be more nuts than him. At least Conrad hero-worships an actual hero, rather than a violent gang boss.

[Lampshade Hanging](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging): His primary purpose, aside from being a [Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey), is to make fun of gameplay mechanics as well as standard role-playing game tropes. Observe:
    - [Side Quest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SideQuest): In *[Mass Effect 2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect2)* he will say that he has been wandering the galaxy between games, helping random strangers who will share personal problems just by him talking to them. - [Kleptomaniac Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KleptomaniacHero): He says he pokes through random crates for extra credits in *[Mass Effect 2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect2)* - [Canon Discontinuity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonDiscontinuity): In *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)*, he apologizes for accusing Shepard of pointing a gun in his face even if they didn't do that, referencing the save game bug in the second game. - [Dialogue Tree](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DialogueTree): He will also ask Shepard the same question twice, because he likes to ask all of the questions he can think of and sometimes repeats himself, and reminds Shepard that they shouldn't be asking him so many questions while people are dying. - [Warfare Regression](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarfareRegression): Criticizes the galactic militaries for switching to thermal clips for guns. - [Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatchPhrase): Borrows Shepard's "I should go". - [Old Save Bonus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldSaveBonus): He'll bring up three unrelated missions from the first game if they were completed - Hossle's data on Feros, Matriarch Dilinaga's Writings, and the Elkoss Combine Armory License - for a bonus to War Assets if he's sent to work on the Crucible.
[Loony Fan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoonyFan): Goes from mildly misguided, to trying to emulate Shepard, to having a [Stalker Shrine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StalkerShrine).

[Lord Error-Prone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LordErrorProne): In the first game, he convinces himself that he can be the second human Spectre. In the second, he buys a set of fake N7 armor and tries to run around the galaxy right wrongs. In the third he joined Cerberus under the delusion that they're a fine group because Shepard once worked with them and tries to convince others likewise.

[Meta Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MetaGuy): His interactions with Shepard in the second and third games show off how odd some of the behavior of an average video game player character would be in-universe.
[Miles Gloriosus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MilesGloriosus): In the second game.

[Morality Pet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralityPet):
    - Potentially towards a Renegade Shepard. QUOTE **Shepard:** Conrad may be an idiot, but even he doesn't deserve to be manipulated like that! - In *3* Shepard can ask how he's holding up with the war going on, seems impressed when he admits he spent all his money to get the kids from his charity to safety and when he tries to take the bullet for them, even comforts him that he "did good". It's implied that, for all of his loony antics and how much he exasperates them, Paragon Shepard genuinely might be fond of Conrad.

[Never Be a Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverBeAHero):
    - The point of the second game. [Shepard has had intense, high-level specialist military training](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrainingFromHell), and possibly genetic enhancements and pseudo-psychic powers. Conrad has nothing of the sort. Leave the saving of the galaxy to Shepard. Somewhat subverted in the Paragon ending, though, because Conrad finally gets that there's more than just one way to be a hero. - In the third game, (SPOILER) he finally becomes a hero by [Taking the Bullet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingTheBullet) for Shepard. If he dies, he'll ask if he finally got to help, to which Shepard will reply he did.

[Old Save Bonus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldSaveBonus): He only shows up in *[Mass Effect 2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect2)* and *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)* if you completed his quest in the preceding game and saved him from getting killed in a myriad of horrific ways, and you transfer this action into your next game. His quest in *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)* also involves an impressive degree of [Continuity Porn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContinuityPorn).

[Orphanage of Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrphanageOfLove): Can be inspired to set one up in Shepard's name if you deal with him in a Paragon fashion  (SPOILER)  By *Mass Effect 3* it's gone thanks to the Reapers, but Conrad saved the kids by spending his last credits getting them out of there.

[Pretender Diss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PretenderDiss): Used as one in the "Citadel" DLC  (SPOILER)  against Shepard's clone .
QUOTE **Shepard:** Are you kidding me? *Conrad Verner* is better at being me than you are!

[Sarcasm-Blind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SarcasmBlind): How we learn about his [Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths).
QUOTE  **Shepard:** [Conrad, I'm building an ancient, Prothean, dark-energy device to stop the Reapers. Can you help with THAT?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SarcasmMode) 
**Conrad:** [Well, I did write my doctoral dissertation on xenotechnology and dark energy integration.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BluntYes) 
**Shepard:** *[[Beat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Beat)]* [...Really?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatWhat)
[Science Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScienceHero):  (SPOILER) As it turns out, he has a doctorate on xenotechnology and dark energy that actually helps a bit with the Crucible.

[Self-Deprecation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfDeprecation): A bug in *2* causes him to tell the asari bartender that Shepard waved a gun in his face in *1*, even though only Renegade Shepard did that. Paragon Shepard tells him to go home, because there's more than one way to be a hero. In *3*, when Shepard meets him again, [he apologizes for accusing Shepard of pointing a gun at him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorsSavingThrow).
[Small Name, Big Ego](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallNameBigEgo): Becomes one in *Mass Effect 2*, due to the aforementioned save game bug.

[Squee](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Squee): [This video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=87qTZV4Xnl8) is how Conrad would've reacted without the import save file bug. Go to about 2:00 to hear him say that meeting Shepard again is the happiest day of his life, fanboy squee in every word. If you take the Charm option in his quest and lie that he helped expose a dirty cop, he'll reply with a tiny, quivering, pathetic "Really?", as if he can't believe he *actually helped you out*. Aww, Conrad!

[Stalker Shrine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StalkerShrine): When asked in *3*, Conrad admits to having a shrine dedicated to Shepard. He claims it's in good taste, though.*"It's just a poster with a few candles. It's very tasteful."*

[Stalker with a Crush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StalkerWithACrush): In *Mass Effect 3* he may reveal that he's not actually married, in spite of the many earlier references to a wife who is also a fan of Shepard. He also has a shrine set up for Commander Shepard somewhere.

[Taking the Bullet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingTheBullet):  (SPOILER)  When he identifies his Cerberus contact, the contact tries to shoot Shepard, and Conrad leaps in the way of the bullet. Can be subverted if you helped Jenna from Chora's Den in the first game, as she Sabotages the gun causing it to make a bang, but the bullet doesn't actually fire.

[This Loser Is You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisLoserIsYou): Almost everything he says and does in *2* is a [Take That!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeThat) at the player. Conrad is what would happen if a real person were to emulate an RPG character.
    - In *ME2*: QUOTE **Conrad:** [I talk to people, y'know? Ask them if they have big problems that only I can solve. You'd be surprised how many people are just waitin' for someone to talk to them.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TalkToEveryone) [Sometimes I poke through crates, too. Y'know, for extra credits.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KleptomaniacHero) - In *ME3*: QUOTE **Conrad:** Do you really think you'll defeat the Reapers? **Shepard:** You just asked me that, Conrad. **Conrad:** Sorry, I like to [ask all the questions I can think of](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TryEverything), and sometimes [I forget which ones I asked already](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NowWhereWasIGoingAgain). [I should go](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BorrowedCatchphrase). - Conrad also [repeats](http://youtu.be/cEnIQWXCgzQ) many of the same complaints that those against the whole thermal clip system have in a possible bout of [Self-Deprecation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfDeprecation). He also claims that Cerberus are just a bunch of misunderstood heroes protecting humanity, almost certainly referring to the fandom the anthropocentric terrorist organization acquired during the second game.

[Throw the Dog a Bone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowTheDogABone): In *ME3*, he starts off being manipulated by a Cerberus agent and being his normal loony self, but then  (SPOILER) gives Shepard important information on dark energy from his xenotechnology dissertation, indirectly helps Shepard capture the agent, and, depending on the outcome of a sidequest in the first game, either dies saving Shepard's life by [Taking the Bullet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingTheBullet) or survives his attempted [Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice) due to a C-Sec officer causing the gun to misfire. If he survives, he even hooks up with the officer in question.

[We Need a Distraction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeNeedADistraction): Cerberus takes advantage of his overenthusiasm and hero-worship in *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)* to have him distract everyone in the refugee camp while a Cerberus agent poisons the medigel dispensers. Once he's told of the error in his ways, he immediately rats out his Cerberus contact.

tropeName: Why Do You Keep Changing Jobs?
tropeNotes: [Why Do You Keep Changing Jobs?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhyDoYouKeepChangingJobs): At various times he's an academic, a would-be vigilante crime fighter, a caregiver for orphans, and a pilot for a [cruise line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Ride/MassEffectNewEarth). This somehow still leaves him plenty of time to enjoy his [Loony Fan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoonyFan) hobby.

[Ascended Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedExtra):  (SPOILER) Was involved in a minor manner in two quests early in the first game. She was not seen at all in the second. In the third game, she shows up running a hospital on the Citadel where you can bring her on board as the *Normandy*'s medic instead of Dr. Chakwas.
[Blackmail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Blackmail): In the first game, some thugs threaten to reveal why she was fired from her previous job.
[Buffy Speak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BuffySpeak): Refers to Mordin's horns as "pokey-things".

[Damsel in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselInDistress): A mild case.
QUOTE  **Shepard:** Every time I come in here, I see someone threatening you.

[Distracted by the Sexy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DistractedByTheSexy): She has a *very* obvious crush on Garrus. In fact, her email in *ME2* which is meant to be thanking Shepard for their help in the first game ends up veering off topic and she starts gushing about Garrus instead.

[Dogged Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoggedNiceGuy): Her email in *ME2* indicates a crush on Garrus. This is understandable since he rescued her in *ME1*. When Tali learns that the doctor sent Garrus dextro-only chocolates "because they reminded her of him", she either warns a Garrus-romancing female Shepard to watch herself or amusedly notes Garrus's [obliviousness to Dr. Michel's attraction to him.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObliviousToLove)

[Everything Sounds Sexier in French](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EverythingSoundsSexierInFrench): She doesn't actually *say* anything in French, but she has a heavy French accent, which for some reason becomes *heavier* in *ME3*. [Justified](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustifiedTrope), since she may mention being from Geneva, which is located on the French-speaking side of Switzerland.
[Green-Eyed Redhead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreenEyedRedhead): She has extremely red hair to go with her green eyes. She's not Irish, however, but from Geneva, a French-speaking part of Switzerland.

[The Informant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheInformant): She provides the player with information during several quests. It tends to be information of the sort you wouldn't expect an ordinary clinic doctor to know.
[Just a Machine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustAMachine): She brings this up in an argument with Engineer Adams. Shepard can support her or Adams, who believes the opposite.
[Military Brat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MilitaryBrat): Her parents were both Alliance military.

[Mutually Exclusive Party Members](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MutuallyExclusivePartyMembers): In the third game, provided that Chakwas is alive, you can reject her offer to become your medic and ask Chloe instead.
[Rescue Romance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RescueRomance): Developed a crush on Garrus after he saves her in the first game.
[Romantic Runner-Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RomanticRunnerUp): Not to Shepard but to Garrus, given that she'll lose out to female Shepard  (SPOILER) or Tali.

tropeName: Screw the Rules, I'm Doing What's Right!
tropeNotes: [Screw the Rules, I'm Doing What's Right!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewTheRulesImDoingWhatsRight): In the past, she gave out free medical supplies, which resulted in her firing the aforementioned [blackmail](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Blackmail).
[Suspiciously Similar Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySimilarSubstitute): For Dr. Chakwas, if you bring her on board the *Normandy*. Hell, she even has the same haircut.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): If she's not brought aboard the *Normandy*, she vanishes without a trace once  (SPOILER) the Virmire Survivor  leaves the hospital.
[Broken Bird](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenBird): Due to having spent thirteen years as a slave.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): In [The Bible](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/TheBible), *"Talitha koum"* is the phrase Jesus speaks when bringing a young girl [Back from the Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BackFromTheDead). It means "Little girl, get up" - more or less what Shepard tells her.

[O.O.C. Is Serious Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OOCIsSeriousBusiness): She only refers to herself in the first person once Shepard convinces her to come to terms with her enslavement and receive emergency help so she can heal.

[Rape as Backstory](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RapeAsBackstory): Strongly implied. Talitha mentions the batarian pirates "doing things to her" in the dark, and she freaks out when Shepard approaches her because she doesn't want to be "handled". [This happened when Talitha was six](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Squick).
[Shoot the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheDog): Talitha will either do this to herself if she feels threatened by Shepard, or Shepard can order a sniper to do so.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): To *[Crime and Punishment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/CrimeAndPunishment)*, but Shepard's words of comfort are also taken from *[Aliens](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/Aliens)*.
[Stockholm Syndrome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StockholmSyndrome): She tried to heal the slavers when a woman came along and slaughtered them all.
[Third-Person Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThirdPersonPerson): How Talitha copes with what happened to her; she sees the trauma she faced as happening to another girl.
[Title Drop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TitleDrop): For the name of the Colonist background quest, "I Remember Me". See her character quote above.
[The Alcoholic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAlcoholic): One of the reasons he was cashiered. The first time you meet him, he's at Chora's Den.
[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): For Garrus's loyalty mission.

[Dirty Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCop): Anderson refers to him as an embarrassment kept in office only because he was one of the first humans in C-Sec and they desperately needed bodies in C-Sec to legitimize their presence in the Galactic politics. He was kicked out the second he was no longer needed politically.
[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward): He does his best to put on a tough guy act but caves the moment he's faced with a real threat.
[Fallen Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallenHero): Was praised for being one of the first humans in C-Sec, before he became corrupt.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): While he may be a disgraced dirty cop, he is somewhat accurate about both Anderson's past and Garrus's [Cowboy Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CowboyCop) tendencies.

[Never My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMyFault): Complains about being cashiered even though he casually admits to his many misdeeds in Chora's Den, treating it as being an overreaction, when he's had decades of misconduct, from assaulting suspects to outright theft, all piling up.

[Politically Incorrect Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoliticallyIncorrectVillain): Particularly towards FemShep, whom he acts like a chauvinist prick towards. Case in point, any interaction with him in both games is one of the few times in the trilogy a dialogue choice will explicitly be confined to one gender. Shepard can threaten to beat the stuffing out of him in *1* for calling her princess, and in *2*, if you allow Garrus to shoot him in the leg, you can have FemShep state that she would shoot Harkin [somewhere else](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GroinAttack).

[Ambiguously Bi](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyBi): Khalisah is known to have dated an asari at some point, and her voice-over cameo in *Citadel* indicates that she has something of a crush on Anderson.
