[Badass Bystander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBystander):  (SPOILER) During the Citadel coup, she risks her neck by hiding out near a seized comm tower, trying to get word out via her own broadcast gear to any cut-off C-Sec personnel that they need to retake the comm tower.

tropeName: Because You Were Nice to Me
tropeNotes: [Because You Were Nice to Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BecauseYouWereNiceToMe):  (SPOILER)  If you never assaulted her in the prior two games, Khalisah's value as a War Assest will double in *3*. The description will imply that Shepard's advocating for unity ultimately ended up rubbing off on her and integrating that into her journalism has made it more effective.
[The Chew Toy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChewToy): Shepard can punch her in every game. Also, the Shadow Broker videos show her getting punched by a krogan and kicked by a *volus*.

[Crouching Moron, Hidden Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrouchingMoronHiddenBadass):
    - She makes it to Top 10 scores at Armax Arena combat simulator in the *Citadel* DLC. Among such badasses as Aria T'Loak, James Vega, Commander Bailey and Shepard themself. This is how she learned to dodge Shepard's punch if she was never hit at all. - Also, if you fail the second renegade interrupt when trying to punch her in the third game she will manage to actually *knock* Shepard to the ground in a single punch to the jaw. Considering this is Shepard we're talking about, that's a pretty impressive achievement all things considered.

[The Dog Bites Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDogBitesBack): In the third game (should she get punched before), she'll actually dodge Shepard's punch, giving her a chance to punch them right back unless you press the Renegade Interrupt button fast enough.

[Endangering News Broadcast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EndangeringNewsBroadcast): In *Initiation*, she happens to run her smear job on Cora Harper  (SPOILER) right when she was beginning an exfiltration while under a false identity, giving away the ruse and triggering alarms.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): Compared to the *actual* [Intrepid Reporter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntrepidReporter), Emily Wong, though "evil" might be a bit of a stretch.
[Fangirl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FanGirl): Has a pretty obvious crush on Admiral Anderson during her interview in the *Citadel DLC*.

[Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): The whole purpose of her character is to be such an obnoxious, slandering paparazzi vulture that the player finds great joy in punching her. [Repeatedly.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag)  (SPOILER) She [grows out of it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn) in the third game.

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn):  (SPOILER) In *3*, if Shepard takes the Paragon interrupt, she stops being an intrusive ass and inspires wide charity support for Earth, becoming a valuable war asset. One that doubles in value if you never punched her.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths):
    - She’s on the leaderboard of several games on the Citadel, including combat simulation. These hints she has some experience in self-defense training. - Her interview with Anderson shows she *can* host a good interview when she feels like it.

[Hoist by Their Own Petard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoistByTheirOwnPetard): One way or another, her efforts to make Shepard look bad often backfire. Paragon Shepard makes her look like a raving bigot, and Renegade Shepard verbally steam-rolls her. All on camera.
QUOTE **al-Jilani:** Did we get that? Great. Bull-rushed on my own show.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): Lair of the Shadow Broker reveals that she's apparently in a relationship with an [asari](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreenSkinnedSpaceBabe) despite her reporting being pretty [pro-human/anti-alien](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism). Or maybe "everybody loves the asari!" <sup>note </sup>  Paraphrased from the Bachelor Party on Illium . Even xenophobes.
[Intrepid Reporter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntrepidReporter): Sees herself as this.

[Iron Butt Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IronButtMonkey): In addition to being punched (three times) by Shepard and the anonymous krogan, she's also kicked by a volus too, [just to add insult to injury.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumiliationConga)
[Ironic Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IronicName): "Khalisah" is Arabic for "sincere." The third game gives her a chance to live up to it.

[Logical Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LogicalWeakness): Her whole strategy is to get right up in her interview subject's face and confront them with a controversial and emotionally charged topic with no warning and provoke a response. In all three games Shepard can completely defuse her by simply keeping her/his cool and giving a serious answer, which makes a fool of her since she doesn't have any real arguments.
[Made of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron): The fact that she managed to survive getting punched into the air by a krogan should make her count as this.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Khalisah means sincere. When she makes her third appearance, she really is upset about what's happening on Earth and wants to do anything she can to help. Also, bint is an Arabic word meaning woman, but as a loan word in the Queen's English it has a derogatory connotation.

[Once per Episode](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OncePerEpisode): Shepard is presented with the opportunity to physically assault her in all three games, making it (disturbingly) easy to go, as *[Penny Arcade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Webcomic/PennyArcade)* puts it, "3-for-3" with her.

[O.O.C. Is Serious Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OOCIsSeriousBusiness): In *3*, she is clearly on the verge of CRYING during the interview, showing genuine compassion for perhaps the first time in her career.
[Paparazzi](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Paparazzi): What she *really* is.  (SPOILER)  [At least until the Citadel Coup.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBystander)

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): In *Mass Effect 3*, she will once again accost Shepard about leaving Earth, this time legitimately distressed and unhappy. While players have the option to do the usual Renegade interrupt, players who wait will get a *Paragon* interrupt. Hitting it will have Shepard comforting her, telling her that they're doing everything they can to stop the Reapers. Shepard even advises her to *keep* asking the hard questions, and to *keep* pressing people to aid Earth. This pays off, as her support becomes a legitimate war asset in the form of charity funding, which doubles in value if the player went the entire series *without* punching her.

[Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag): The opportunity to punch her.
QUOTE **Shepard:** [I've had enough of your snide insinuations/disingenuous assertions/tabloid journalism!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PreemptiveDeclaration) *[Throws a punch at her.]*
[Schmuck Bait](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SchmuckBait): If she is punched out at any point in the series, the player loses war assets. Not enough to make any real difference though.
[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): Especially after any physical beatdown you give her.

[Throw the Dog a Bone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowTheDogABone): After multiple games of being a pretty one-note, sleazy reporter antagonist, *3* not only fleshes her out and gives her a great deal of humanity, but  (SPOILER)  potentially lets Shepherd suggest they [always saw her as a good person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreBetterThanYouThinkYouAre), inspiring her to become a better reporter. Khalisah bravely also uses her civilian broadcast gear to help C-Sec during a coup in the same title, despite painting a target on herself in the process.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): A pretty small one in the grand scheme of things but going from getting knocked out in one punch in the first two games to dodging and potentially turning the tables on Shepard in the third game is still a pretty notable improvement.

[Took a Level in Kindness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInKindness): By *3*, she actually *does* become an [Intrepid Reporter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntrepidReporter), and if you take the Paragon interrupt with her, she and Shepard finally bury the hatchet.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): The trope below is the last time she's heard from. It's never been established what happened to her afterwards. (It's entirely possible the answer wasn't pleasant:  (SPOILER) Even if she survives the Cerberus coup, which she might not have given that she was actively trying to rally reinforcements for the defenders, she could have still been on the Citadel when the Reapers seized it. )

tropeName: What You Are in the Dark
tropeNotes: [What You Are in the Dark](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatYouAreInTheDark): During  (SPOILER)  Cerberus's coup attempt on the Citadel,  rather than keep her head down and hope for the best (especially since, as a human, she is in marginally less danger from the crazed nationalists), she uses her broadcast gear to help coordinate a response, showing that, under it all, she is a good and brave person capable of heroism.
[A Day in the Limelight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ADayInTheLimelight): Her tweets.
[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): If you only have the games to go by, a lot of the spoilers here will make absolutely no sense.

tropeName: Better to Die than Be Killed
tropeNotes: [Better to Die than Be Killed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BetterToDieThanBeKilled):  (SPOILER) Bleeding out, with no weapons and all Alliance cruisers destroyed, she chooses to ram her skyvan into a Reaper rather than wait for it to kill her.

[Death Equals Redemption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathEqualsRedemption): After realizing that  (SPOILER)  her live-tweets led the Reapers directly to the only effective evacuation point in the San Fernando Valley.

[Defiant to the End](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefiantToTheEnd):
QUOTE   (SPOILER) "Go on. [Make your noise](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HellIsThatNoise). [Try to scare us.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast)" 

QUOTE   (SPOILER) "You want to see how a human dies? At ramming speed."

[Dramatic Ammo Depletion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DramaticAmmoDepletion):  (SPOILER) She rides a skycar up to a reaper destroyer at the airport, intending to blast it with a [Blackstar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnrealisticBlackHole)... but sadly, [Blackstars only hold one shot, and Emily had wasted it on a test-fire hours beforehand](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntergration). This leads to the skycar taking a hit, the pilot dying, and a fatally wounded Emily resorting to a defiant suicide ram.
[Dying Moment of Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DyingMomentOfAwesome):  (SPOILER) Smashes her skyvan into *a Reaper*. And then there's the above quote .
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):  (SPOILER) Dies in the process of making sure evacuees get vital information.
[Intrepid Reporter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntrepidReporter): Live reporting *in the middle of the Reaper invasion*.

[Loose Lips](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LooseLips):
QUOTE   (SPOILER)  "This signal, going out and being rebroadcast everywhere… [I think they picked it up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap). [I led them here!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone)"

[Ramming Always Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RammingAlwaysWorks):  (SPOILER) Invoked. This is her logic when she decides to ram her skyvan into a Reaper, but we don't learn whether doing so actually worked... though chances are high that [it didn't](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NighInvulnerable).

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): Possibly. (SPOILER) Her final line might be a reference to (SPOILER) [the execution of Fabrizio Quattrocchi](http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-255463/Now-youll-Italian-dies.html), who, just before being shot dead by Iraqi militiamen, shouted: "Now you'll see how an Italian dies!"
    - (SPOILER) Her ramming the Reaper may also be a shout out to "[The Call of Cthulhu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/TheCallOfCthulhu)", where Cthulhu was subdued by ramming it with a ship. - (SPOILER) And of course her piloting a small ship that lacks any means to attack and ramming it into a giant enemy is extremely similar to what happened with the Defiant in *[Star Trek: First Contact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/StarTrekFirstContact)*, Worf's final order? "Prepare for Ramming Speed!"
[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): During the Reaper invasion of Earth. It culminates in her  (SPOILER) ramming a Reaper with a skyvan.
[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn):  (SPOILER) The Reapers were using her tweets to find areas where lots of people were gathered.
[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): *Nobody* cared when Thane killed her. Her own workers even *asked Shepard to kill her*. Hell, her company's stocks *increase* after she dies.

[Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss): *Very* bad, especially during Thane's recruitment mission in *2*, in which she is *horrible* to the salarian workers under her.
QUOTE **Salarian worker:** And tell that assassin to aim for her head... because she doesn't have a heart!
[Big, Screwed-Up Family](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigScrewedUpFamily): Let's just say trust issues are the *least* of their problems.

[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): She's on both sides. In *1* one of her sisters, a mercenary and slaver, blackmails her to avoid the bad press and shame of a being known relative of a vile criminal, so she decides to manipulate Shepard into killing her. Then in *2* we learn that a third sister wants her dead.
[Corrupt Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive): Arguably in the first game, *definitely* in the sequel.

[Developer's Foresight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DevelopersForesight): In the first game, it's possible to complete her sidequest before you ever talk to her. If you do, when you report to her that her pirate sister has been killed, she replies, "Oh! And I was all set to manipulate you into killing her for me!"

[Jumping Off the Slippery Slope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JumpingOffTheSlipperySlope): Goes from a manipulative but ultimately reasonable businesswoman in the first game to a psychotic, ultra-paranoid nutcase.

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog):
    - She decide to kill her harmless workers for no good reason during Thane's recruitment mission. - During Thane's recruitment mission, it's mentioned that Nassana has made a practice of killing those who threaten her reputation, which was probably why Thane was sent to kill her, and is paranoid to the bone. One poor salarian worker you meet tells you about how she's sent mechs and mech-dogs to kill everyone, and about how he's seen workers jumping out the windows to escape the dogs. That and if anyone leaves before their contract is up, it's implied she has them murdered as well. [Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss) indeed.

[Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard): She needed her sister out of the way, so she put on a show about being worried about Dahlia being held captive so Shepard would kill her.

[Pay Evil unto Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PayEvilUntoEvil): Manipulating someone into killing her own sister? A hard pill to swallow. Knowing her sister was a thug and a slaver who planned to extort her? Much more digestible. Shepard can concede that Dahlia deserved what she got, which Nassana will agree with.

[Right for the Wrong Reasons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RightForTheWrongReasons): Someone's killing her guys, so she believes someone wants her dead. She's right about the latter, but it's not related to the former.

[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): At the end of her quest in the first game, she *oozes* smugness, especially if you accidentally complete it before speaking to her, outright admitting how she was planning to manipulate Shepard.
[Took a Level in Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInJerkass): The worst thing she does in the first game is lie to you. By the second, though, she's done *much* worse.

[Wrong Genre Savvy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrongGenreSavvy): Despite Shepard's [insistence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CassandraTruth), she remains utterly convinced that Shepard is the [One-Man Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneManArmy) who's slaughtered their way through the building in order to kill her. She isn't *entirely* wrong—Shepard really was the one killing all her troops. But they weren't sent to kill her, they're searching for the assassin.  (SPOILER) Then Thane drops from the ceiling behind her.

[Ancient Artifact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AncientArtifact): She'll hand over a Prothean trinket if you resolve Xeltan's sidequest before hers, allowing Shepard to experience a vision on the planet Eletania.

[Big Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigGood): She leaves the Citadel to escape slander, but when the galaxy is in danger, she returns because people need her services more than ever — and she doesn't mean sex; she explains that the citizens of the galaxy are panicked and in need of comfort and strength, and she can provide that.

[Boldly Coming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoldlyComing): She will see (or "[see](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadedDoubleEntendre)") anyone, regardless of species or gender, though there is quite a waiting period. Among her known clients are a volus, a human, a salarian, a turian, and an elcor. In *2*, one of the SR-2 crew members excitedly says that he's got an appointment with her in a few months, and objects when another crew member calls her a prostitute. A krogan considers it the height of decadence, likening it to his obsession with eating a fish from the Presidium.

[Break the Cutie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheCutie): In *2* and *3*, she's gone through a *lot*. Made clearer in *Citadel*, where she has a single word of advice for Shepard.
QUOTE  **Sha'ira:** *[Win!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsUpToYou)*

[Fortune Teller](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FortuneTeller): Regarded by many on the Citadel to be nearly oracular, and she does make predictions for Shepard, both on completion of her quest and in an email. [Cut content](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DummiedOut) from *[Mass Effect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect1)* has the [rumor](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gmXDwXxl_80#t=26s) that she will soon predict the next race to join the Council. What's interesting is that she's still in her Matron life stage — asari Matriarchs are the advisors of the asari race, meaning Sha'ira is just hitting her stride and will be even *more* insightful.

[Graceful Ladies Like Purple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GracefulLadiesLikePurple): She and all of her acolytes wear purple dresses. The salarian among them doesn't wear a dress, but he does have the colors.

[Heroic Seductress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSeductress): We don't know much about what she does. Only that she helps people, and it sometimes involves sex. Whatever she does, it makes her one of the most powerful women in Citadel Space. She came back from her self-imposed exile when the Reapers attacked "because one does not flee the heart of the galaxy in troubled times", and her old clients needed her.

[High-Class Call Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighClassCallGirl): Emphasis on "high class". Most of her clientele is composed of famous and powerful people, and the Consort's Chambers and her acolytes are appropriately designed to accommodate them. The Consort's Chambers are even located on the Presidium and **opposite** the Citadel Embassies.
[Intimate Psychotherapy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntimatePsychotherapy): She gives "advice to some, comfort to others."
[Male Gaze](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MaleGaze): Her introduction scene has the camera linger on her butt as she walks back into her office, swaying her hips all the while.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): "Sha'ira" comes from an Arabic word meaning "poetess", or "female poet". Her name also resembles the name of the hetaerae [Neaira.](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neaira_%28hetaera%29)

[No Sense of Personal Space](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSenseOfPersonalSpace): She gets very... snuggly with Shepard when first asking the Commander for a favour, which is strange since when Shepard first enters the room she tells them "That's close enough" even when they're at quite a distance.
[The Ojou](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheOjou): Most seem to regard Sha'ira with a kind of reverential awe.

[Optional Sexual Encounter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalSexualEncounter): With absolutely zero warning, at that, beyond the fact that (Renegade) dialogue option on the wheel consists of wanting more than her 'gift of words'. "Uhh, thanks... I guess." Cue player cries of "the Consort raped me!"

[Platonic Prostitution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlatonicProstitution): Saying that she provides "[comfort](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SexForSolace)" to those who seek it is only partially a euphemism. She says she gives them whatever they need, be it verbal reassurance, cuddling or otherwise.

[Prophecy Twist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProphecyTwist): Hearing that Shepard was killed in *2* made her doubt her own clairvoyance. She admits to Shepard when meeting him that she was glad he was alive in part because it meant she hadn't lost her touch.

[Punctuation Shaker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunctuationShaker): An interesting case, considering no other asari so far is shown to have a given name with an apostrophe. It's possible that Sha'ira is not her real name, however. Since asari surnames often *do* have apostrophes, it's entirely possible that Sha'ira could just be her *[last name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastNameBasis)*.
[Sex Goddess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SexGoddess): While the asari in general are already considered this, Sha'ira is especially adept at giving pleasure to both mind and body.

[Sex Tourism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SexTourism): People will visit the Citadel just to see Sha'ira or at least her acolytes, though it should be noted that she's not *just* a prostitute, and she will sometimes turn down even very influential clients for her own reasons.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): During your [Optional Sexual Encounter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalSexualEncounter) with her, she will press her hand against the glass of her pod as a reference the romance scene in *[Titanic (1997)](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/Titanic1997)*.
[Drugs Are Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrugsAreBad): One of her driving motivations in asking for Shepard's help.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Her motivation for killing the other crime bosses is that they condone slavery and selling of red sand, whereas she simply wants to smuggle illegal products.

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): If you convince her to disband the gang, she shows up on Omega in the second game as a social worker. Shepard is impressed and is at a loss as to how she could keep up the job on [Omega](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WretchedHive) of all places. She replies that a place like Omega *desperately* needs a social worker, especially one who's been a *mob boss* before her reformation.

[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): Any outcome that doesn't result in her death; Shepard convincing her to undergo a [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn) may take some of the sting out of that.

[Know When to Fold 'Em](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnowWhenToFoldEm): Shepard can convince her to quit, through a threat or the reasoning that her organization has been irretrievably tainted. She'll sigh and acknowledge that it makes sense. She's fully aware that she can't defeat Shepard, but that isn't the motivation for it, since she'll attack Shepard if they try to arrest her, even knowing it'll result in her death.
[Mind over Matter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindOverMatter): A biotic.
[Never Going Back to Prison](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverGoingBackToPrison): She outright tells Shepard she's not going to prison; any attempt to arrest her will result in her death.
[Noble Demon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleDemon): Similar to Aria in many ways, which would explain why she's an underboss on Omega if she's allowed to continue running the gang.
[Suicide by Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideByCop): She'll attack Shepard if they try to arrest her, stating she's [Never Going Back to Prison](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverGoingBackToPrison).
[Younger Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanTheyLook): She looks like an older woman, but the fact that she's a biotic means she can't be older than 32-33 in the first game.

[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): To Shepard, at least. To Shepard's alien team members, he's less than polite, particularly with Liara, although he's more cordial to Wrex, who actually *agrees* with his assertion that military power brings prestige. Of course, it may have also been because he's [not stupid enough](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobodysThatDumb) to [insult a krogan battlemaster to his face](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BullyingADragon).

[Armor-Piercing Response](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmorPiercingResponse): On the receiving end of one from Garrus, if he tries bringing up military presence. Garrus may point out in the Turian Empire, *everyone* serves - even those who are physically invalid will still serve in support capacities. It's one of the few times Saracino can't come up with an immediate response.
[Beard of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeardOfEvil): Bearded and a high-level member of a racist political party.

[Bigger Stick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BiggerStick): Discusses and supports this philosophy, believing that Earth should focus on military spending to both keep up with the rest of the galaxy and levy their military power into political clout, so that their opinion will be taken seriously. After all, it worked for the turians.
[Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatchPhrase): "Remember Terra Firma on election day, because Terra Firma remembers you!"
[Corrupt Politician](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptPolitician): Sort of. Deleted dialogue in *2* restored for Legendary Edition notes he got busted for tax dodging.

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards): Ashley dislikes the party, in spite of her prejudices that may lead you to think otherwise; every point Saracino brings up, she counters coldly and with brutal accuracy. When he mentions Shanxi — the root of Ashley's suspicion of turians especially — she brusquely says that he wasn't *there*, thus he should shut the hell up.
QUOTE **Ashley:** Were you *at* Shanxi?! If not, shut your pie hole!

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): The entire point of Terra Firma in practice. They do have a semi-reasonable platform (keeping humanity's unique cultural contributions alive in the rush to advance and discover what lies beyond the Solar System), but it attracts a lot of bare-faced xenophobes.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint):
    - Despite his politics and his party's racist beliefs, the quote he makes above does make sense. - His comments about humanity embracing the [Bigger Stick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BiggerStick) philosophy similarly aren't without precedent, considering their incredible military power was one of the main reasons the turians gained their seat on the Council. Ultimately, he’s proven correct when the Alliance fleet’s role in defeating Sovereign earns humanity their own seat one way or another.

[Never My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMyFault): Insists that he's not responsible for the openly racist views espoused by members of his own political party, even though he's the head of it, saying he's not responsible for what they say.... even though they're only there because the Terra Firma party's views drew them in in the first place, and he does nothing to disassocaite the party from these people.

[The Starscream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStarscream): *Ascension* and the Shadow Broker's files show that he became party chairman when his chief rival, Claude Mennau, was assassinated by Cerberus because Mennau was seen as too moderate.
[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): He's one for Cerberus — the Illusive Man believed he'd be easier to influence than Mennau.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): She has quite a tongue when she's not pretending to be a secretary.
QUOTE **Parasini:** *[when asked why she doesn't go through her boss's records for evidence of his wrongdoing]* He's a crook, not a moron! He doesn't keep records saying "This month, I stole 3 million credits!"
[Hates Wearing Dresses](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HatesWearingDresses): The first thing she does after busting Bel Anoleis is to say she hates having to wear a dress to pose as a secretary.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): She reveals in *Mass Effect 2* why she's in Internal Affairs: she originally wanted to be a cop or C-Sec, but she came from a poor background and needed the money a corporate job would bring in. She also admits that dealing with white-collar crime means she doesn't have to investigate *"[things that make it hard to sleep at night](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NightmareFuel)"*.
[Internal Affairs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InternalAffairs): She's the *least* irritating person who can get you a garage pass on Noveria.
[The Lad-ette](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLadette): She gives off this vibe, preferring street clothes and beer to dresses and Illium.

[Miranda Rights](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MirandaRights): Invokes this when arresting Anoleis if Shepard helps her.
QUOTE **Parasini**: You have the right to remain silent. I wish to God you'd exercise it!
[Noble Bigot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleBigot): Has a racist streak towards asari.

[The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole): When you first encounter her, she's posing as [Administrator Anoleis's](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive) secretary, but  (SPOILER)  quickly reveals herself to be an [Internal Affairs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InternalAffairs) agent for some corporate conglomerate.
[Screw You, Elves!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewYouElves): She *really* enjoys busting Asari, commenting on how perfect they *think* they are.
[Ship Tease](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease): If you help her out in *Mass Effect 2*, she thanks Male Shepard by giving him a passionate thank you kiss.

[What Happened to the Mouse?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatHappenedToTheMouse): Her cameo in *2* implied that she was going to have some future role revolving around dark matter, but she's one of the few minor/supporting characters that *doesn't* return for the third game.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): Shepard can have him thrown in jail or killed in order to get a garage pass, and nobody is crying.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Corrupt Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive): He has his hands in pretty much every dirty deal going on in Port Hanshan. He is also driving up rent prices to line his own pockets, which is making some companies leave Noveria and is what draws the executive board's interest.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Cultural Posturing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturalPosturing): If Shepard's an Earther, he'll state at least *his* home planet is environmentally clean, not some over-polluted acid-choked waste.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Entitled Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EntitledBastard): Despite doing everything in his power to obstruct Shepard, combined with flat-out rudeness, he still demands Shepard help him if Parasini arrests him.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes:
[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Anoleis is on the receiving end of this; the Noveria Executive Board want him gone because his corrupt practices are driving away business and driving down their profits.
QUOTE **Shepard:** I thought corruption was the rule of law on Noveria. 
**Gianna Parasini:** The rule is don't rock the boat. Self-interest is tolerated only so long as it doesn't interfere with business. Anoleis's practices are driving away clients.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): He is clearly racist against humans.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): Authority figures in this series are traditionally obstructive and difficult, but the game makes it clear to players that this guy is going to be an enormous frustration and very unhelpful. Anoleis easily validates the game's expectations, as his refusal to give Shepard a garage pass, along with his incredibly racist demeanor, causes the player to feel immense frustration and annoyance.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Easily the most irritating and unpleasant person on Noveria, which is filled with immoral scientists and dirty cops.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Karma Houdini Warranty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudiniWarranty): If you avoid busting him in the first game, and Parasini lives through to *2*, she reveals she eventually got him anyway, after he was caught having sex with an asari tax inspector.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Laser-Guided Karma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserGuidedKarma): A large majority of players, even if they are Renegade, choose to help Parasini if only to just get back at him for making Port Hanashan so frustrating.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Morton's Fork](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MortonsFork): There's no version of Shepard's backstory he won't sneer at.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Mutual Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MutualKill): If informed that Parasini is a internal affairs agent, he will try to kill her, with both of them being fatally injured as a result.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Obstructive Bureaucrat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObstructiveBureaucrat): His corruption has pretty much brought getting anything done in Port Hanshan to a standstill, and his unhelpfulness forces Shepard to jump through a ton of hoops to get a simple garage pass to leave to investigate Peak 15 unless they take a shortcut through a sidequest.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): Gets one if Renegade Shepard brings him proof of Opold's dealings, then threatens him into giving up the package anyway. It's about the only time his composure slips.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Overly Long Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OverlyLongName): Par for the course for a salarian.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [The Scapegoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheScapegoat): Funnily enough, according to the newscasts you can hear, he gets the blame for the Peak 15 incident, which he's only peripherally involved in at best.

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes:
[Stupid Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StupidEvil): [Zig-Zagged](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZigZagged). His corruption is past the point of sustainability for Port Hanshan, but he's smart enough to not keep evidence that could incriminate him among his records.
QUOTE **Gianna Parasini:** He's a crook, not a moron! He doesn't keep logs on his computer saying "This month I stole three million credits!"

TvTName: Administrator Rannadril Ghan Swa Fulsoom Karaten Narr Eadi Bel Anoleis
tropeNotes: [Underestimating Badassery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnderestimatingBadassery): While he clearly isn't stupid enough to pick a direct fight with a Spectre, making him smarter than a good chunk of people Shepard and co. have to deal with, he clearly doesn't rank Shep high as a threat. If they intimidate him into letting them keep some contraband, he begrudgingly admits he underestimated them.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Probably the snarkiest turian in the first game outside of Garrus. He particularly likes taking note of some of the odd human sayings Shepard uses.

[I Need a Freaking Drink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/INeedAFreakingDrink): A Renegade Shepard can destroy his career for being reluctant to testify against Anoleis. When he finds out, the poor guy's reaction is "Excuse me, please. I feel the need to order more drinks while I can still afford them."

[Insane Troll Logic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsaneTrollLogic): If Shepard hands over Lorik's evidence to Anoleis, he is stunned and meekly asks why, leading to this potential exchange:
QUOTE **Commander Shepard:** You refused to testify. Obviously, you hate justice and deserve this. 
**Lorik:** [What insane breed of logic is that?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging)

[Skewed Priorities](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkewedPriorities): After asking Shepard to kill the dirty cops at the Synthetic Insights office and recover his evidence, he requests that they try to avoid getting any blood on the carpet.

[Badges and Dog Tags](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadgesAndDogTags): She served ten years as a Alliance marine before leaving the service and joining ERCS, who gave her command of the Port Hanshan detachment due to her combat experience.

[Gratuitous Japanese](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GratuitousJapanese): Refers people as "Parasini-san" "Stirling-san" and "Benezia-sama" but otherwise speaks entirely in English. However, given the universal use of [Translator Microbes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TranslatorMicrobes), she may just be speaking in Japanese and Shepard hears it translated as English.

[Horrible Judge of Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HorribleJudgeOfCharacter): She has a zero-tolerance policy on bribery. All well and good. But she also has the blatantly rabid Kaira Stirling as an underling, and despite acknowledging that she's "mercenary", doesn't notice the woman's on the take, along with several other officers.

tropeName: I Did What I Had to Do
tropeNotes: [I Did What I Had to Do](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDidWhatIHadToDo): If Shepard gets angry at her for pointing a gun at Shepard's party, she responds that she was doing what she thought was correct.

[Only Sane Woman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlySaneWoman): She is pretty much the only person in Port Hanshan who doesn't have a hidden agenda, simply preferring to try and keep the peace between the corporations and any offworld visitors.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): If Shepard kills the dirty ERCS officers at Synthetic Insights and tells her about it, she understands completely and doesn't hold it against them since the officers were corrupt. That said, if you lie to her face about what happened she'll [call you out on it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero), and no matter what you say leaves by saying she has to write condolence letters to the families of the officers you killed.

[Always a Bigger Fish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysABiggerFish): Her coworkers refer to her as their secret weapon because Stirling is a biotic. Shepard's squad has multiple biotics that are way above her level.

[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): Should Shepard kill her, even the other cops don't seem terribly broken up about it. The only one that does is implied to be a fellow [Dirty Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCop).

[Dirty Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCop): She is on the take, and confronts Shepard if the player raids the Synthtic Insights office to get evidence that Administrator Anoleis is dirty. Stirling is pissed off that Shepard killed her fellow dirty cops who were guarding the office for Anoleis and calls them a cop killer, but Shepard and the current party members simply point out they were dirty and then kill her.
QUOTE **Stirling**: You know what we do to cop killers on my world? 
**Tali**: You're here off duty for bribe money and you expect us to feel guilty for stopping you? 
**Wrex**: You're breaking the law for bribe money. You know what we do to dirty cops on *my* world?
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Aside from being a dirty cop, she is intensely hostile towards Shepard when they arrive on Novaria, and seems to want to pick a fight with Shepard.
[Mind over Matter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindOverMatter): She is a biotic, and can use barrier and lift in combat.

[Too Dumb to Live](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive): Spoiling for a fight with a person who may or may not be travelling with a krogan, but definitely is armed to the teeth is one thing. Doing so even after learning they're a Spectre, who have carte blanche to kill is another. *Continuing* to try and threaten them even after Shepard's already shot their way through several guards by that point... killing Stirling probably is a favor to the universe.

[Creepy Monotone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreepyMonotone): He describes the death of his co-worker in gory detail, with no emotion in his voice. Even for a [volus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VaderBreath), he sounds really cold.
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): See the above quote. To the asari commando holding him at gunpoint, no less.

[It's All My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllMyFault): He blames himself for being part of the research team that was responsible for bringing the rachni back, and also for shutting the door on the tram when one of his collegues was trying to board it, causing her to be killed by the attacking rachni. He's well aware that leaving the door open would have just led to his death as well as hers, but he feels no less guilty about it.

[Only Sane Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlySaneMan): When a couple of fellow scientists tell him if he's going to be crazy, to be the quiet kind.
QUOTE  **Han:** Crazy? I'm sane. God, am I sane!
[Sole Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoleSurvivor): If you go to the hot labs first, then Han says that he's the only civilian left, Ventralis having killed the rest under Benezia's orders.

[Survivor's Guilt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SurvivorsGuilt): To such an extreme that in his message to Shepard in the second game, he practically wishes that he had been killed instead of his friend. At the very least, he's not ungrateful to Shepard.
[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): Though not to the extent of Reaper victims, given that the Thorian's mind control is different from indoctrination.

[Death Before Dishonor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathBeforeDishonor): Despite having been in symbiotic cooperation with the Thorian like the rest of Zhu's Hope up until now, Fai Dan draws the line at killing people and opts instead to shoot himself.
[Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon): Not being able to protect the colonists.
[Driven to Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide): Kills himself when the Thorian attempts to make him kill Shepard.

[Everything Fades](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EverythingFades): One of the few exceptions. While most bodies fade quickly, Fai Dan's body stays. There's also a noticeable pool of blood, one of only two times in the game.
[Gory Discretion Shot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoryDiscretionShot): The camera cuts away just before he shoots himself.
[Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindControl): As with all of the colonists, he is being used by the Thorian.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): More like, My God, What Did I Let Happen?, but he blames himself for what happened to the colonists, and is likely part of the reason for his suicide.

[Senseless Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SenselessSacrifice): Him committing suicide out of fear of harming Shepard makes sense... Unless you still have anti-Thorian gas grenades in your inventory, in which case you could simply have tossed one in his direction to solve the problem while saving his life in the process. Even if Shepard's move incited him to shoot, the Commander's armor and shields would barely have been scratched by the shot.
[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): Part of the Zhu's Hope control group used by ExoGeni to study the Thorian.
[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): Greta Reynolds and Arcelia are trained soldiers. But all of the women fight when  (SPOILER) controlled by the Thorian.
[Apologetic Attacker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ApologeticAttacker): Lizbeth Baynham. She shot Shepard without looking, and feels really bad about it, even in *Mass Effect 2*.
[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): Like all of the people under the Thorian's control.

[Broken Record](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenRecord): Any time they're asked stuff, they tend to get evasive and say something along the lines of "talk to Fai Dan". And if you do talk to Fai Dan, he's just as evasive.
[Combat Sadomasochist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatSadomasochist): Ian, who enjoys "invoking the master's whip" when he is controlled by the Thorian. Others mention he is unstable.

[Determined Homesteader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeterminedHomesteader): They want to make their home work, and think they should be self-sufficient. They say this even when not controlled by the Thorian. Except for Hana Murakami, who wants to leave.
[Happily Married](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyMarried): There are two married couples: Hollis and Calantha, and Davin and Greta. They are all in stable, happy relationships.

[Hive Mind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiveMind): A side effect of the Thorian spores after the creature dies. Most of the colonists can sense each others thoughts. Fortunately, they can use this to resist indoctrination, and, later on, turns them into effective soldiers since they can coordinate telepathically and teach skills to make even the weakest member move like a commando.
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Arcelia is pretty blunt and hostile.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): Arcelia can state that she only thinks Shepard and co. have shown up because of the geth, and don't care about them. Depending on the player's choice of action, including immediately asking about the geth, she's right.
[Let's Get Dangerous!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LetsGetDangerous): If Shepard keeps them alive, they turn into a dangerous crew when the Reapers attack in *Mass Effect 3*.
[The Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMedic): Hollis Blake. He handles Zhu's Hope's medical problems after the previous doctor was killed in a geth attack.

tropeName: Not What I Signed on For
tropeNotes: [Not What I Signed on For](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotWhatISignedOnFor): Arcelia laments that she was only supposed to be a security guard keeping kids from spraying graffiti on the walls and instead found herself fighting off geth and mind-controlled by a giant sentient plant.

[Small Steps Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallStepsHero): What they ask for from Shepard: They need to get their water systems back online, some old power cells, and go hunting to supplement their rations.
[Token Minority](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenMinority): Ledra, who is the only salarian at the colony.  (SPOILER) If you spare her, Shiala is the only asari.

[Bizarre Alien Biology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BizarreAlienBiology): She contains the genetic material of her predecessors, which allows her to lay fertile eggs without mating. In addition, rachni communicate through whalesong-like sounds (which may be partially telepathic, since they can be [heard in a near-vacuum](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpaceIsNoisy)) that they refer to as "singing". They also seem to have synethesia, describing the singing of the Reapers as "a sour yellow note", and so on.
    - Their method of communication is stated to be an organic version of quantum entanglement communication in the *Leviathan* DLC of *3*. This is the technology that allows galaxy-wide communication in the series.

[Blue-and-Orange Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality): Asks Shepard to exterminate the remaining Rachni on Noveria, as they were born without her influence to shape their minds, leaving them completely feral. She admits it's regrettable, but it *has* to be done.

[Characterization Marches On](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterizationMarchesOn): In *Mass Effect 1* and *2*, it is claimed that the rachni were a peaceful race that were manipulated against their will into war with the rest of the galaxy. In *3*, they were still manipulated, but it's indicated that they were pretty hostile anyway and were in fact *bred* to be vicious and cunning. The queen herself is also presented as being more alien than before, partially achieved by (SPOILER) having her speak using numerous krogan dead simultaneously to achieve a choir-like effect rather than the impression of speaking to a single entity.
    - On the other hand, her rather abrasive temperament in the third game might be due to having been restrained, tortured and forced to give birth to children that were then turned into huskified abominations for several months. One can only begin to imagine how utterly *pissed off* she was by the time Shepard rescues her. - Also, if you compare the voice acting with that of her replacement, the Rachni Breeder, you will realize just how much gentler she sounds. Furthermore, if you refuse to help her this time, she won't hold it against you and accept your decision peacefully, unlike the Breeder who will flip out and scream for Shepard's blood. - Given that the queens possess [Genetic Memory](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneticMemory), you can understand why their offspring would naturally be inclined to be hostile; considering the last time the rachni encountered sentient life in the Galaxy, the Protheans tried to turn them into *[shock-troops](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy)* and tried to exterminate them when it didn't work!

[Chekhov's Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsArmy): If Shepard spares her life,  (SPOILER) she will send a messenger in the second game in order to pledge her support against the Reapers when the time comes. She delivers, though not in the way as you think. Her children aid building the Crucible instead of being combatants. It makes a lot of sense considering the Rachni have had enough of being shock troops and would rather show off their *brains* than their *brawn*. 
QUOTE **Hackett:** I wouldn't believe it, but the rachni are helping us build the Crucible. 
**Shepard:** You're kidding! 
**Hackett:** Turns out they have a knack for weapons of mass destruction. In hindsight, I guess they'd know a thing or two about waging a galactic war.

[Creepy Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreepyGood): She's a giant, completely inhuman insect queen that communicates through others telepathically...but she's ultimately entirely benevolent and genuinely doesn't want to hurt anyone.  (SPOILER) She comes to help Shepard in *3* if saved and aids in building the Crucible.

tropeName: Did We Just Have Tea with Cthulhu?
tropeNotes: [Did We Just Have Tea with Cthulhu?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidWeJustHaveTeaWithCthulhu): Shepard has the option to do this twice to her, once in the first game and again in the third. If you choose this option in the first, in the second game  (SPOILER) an asari who's been in contact with them delivers a personal message from the Queen herself thanking you and offering her support against the Reapers , and if you play your cards right she keeps her word and helps you build  (SPOILER) the Crucible  in the third game, leading to an amusing incident mentioned in an email where the rachni's presence freaks out most of the staff as yet another example of this trope.

[Damsel in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselInDistress): At least, if the term "Damsel" can even apply to a giant insect. Regardless, the Rachni Queen gets captured in both *1* and *3*, both times with Shepard being the only one to rescue her if they so choose.

[Face Death with Dignity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceDeathWithDignity):  (SPOILER) If you decide to kill her in the first game, her asari thrall tries to stop you. If you leave her to die in the third game, she accepts it as a release from the Reapers' torture. Her breeder replacement, by contrast, screams at her children to kill you.

[Gentle Giant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GentleGiant): Is clearly a caring mother to her children, and given that she saved an asari's life, she shows that the rachni are more peaceful than the Codex says.
[Genetic Memory](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneticMemory): Appears to be the case, at least between generations of rachni queens.

[Genocide Dilemma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenocideDilemma): On one hand, everybody and their grandma tells you about how dangerous the Rachni Wars were. On the other hand, she's done nothing wrong and swears to live in peace. It's up to Shepard to decide how it goes.

tropeName: God Save Us from the Queen!
tropeNotes:
[God Save Us from the Queen!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GodSaveUsFromTheQueen): (SPOILER) [Averted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AvertedTrope) in the second game; if you spare her, it seems she's held to her promise not to cause trouble, and pledges to aid you in any way that she can when the Reaper war begins .
    - (SPOILER) In *Mass Effect 3*, she is found strapped to Reaper machinery and forced to give birth to Husk versions of the rachni. However, she still remains defiant and vengeful against the Reapers, and will aid you in the war effort if you choose to save her again. [Possibly her genetic memory keeps her free will intact, even though the same doesn't apply to her children](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WildMassGuessing). - (SPOILER) Played straight with her Reaper-created clone, if you killed the original. If you spare her this time around, she and her children will ditch you in revenge, after massacring most of the Alliance engineering corps.
[Hive Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiveQueen):  (SPOILER) One of the few good examples.

[I Am the Trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IAmTheTrope):
QUOTE We are the... mother. We sing for those left behind. The children you thought silenced. We are rachni.
[Last of Her Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastOfHerKind): She is the only remaining rachni queen, which means the rachni race will die with her if she is killed.

[Mama Bear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MamaBear): The Rachni Queen is utterly livid that the Reapers are using her to breed children only for them to be condemned to a [Fate Worse than Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FateWorseThanDeath), and pleads with Shepard to release her so she can avenge them.
    - When speaking to Shepard on Noveria, the Queen's tone is notably more hostile when referring to her children being driven insane by Binary Helix's wrongdoing.

[O.O.C. Is Serious Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OOCIsSeriousBusiness): If the Queen is asked on Noveria about why the rachni went to war, the Queen says "I do not know what happened in the war!". In all other times she refers to herself, she uses the [Royal "We"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalWe), instead of the personal pronoun I, emphasizing that she had no idea why her race became hostile. It is the only time she does this.

[People Puppets](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PeoplePuppets): Although she can do this, she only does it to communicate with Shepard and even then only because the person she's controlling is already (nearly) dead.
    - Depending on dialogue choices, Shepard can show concern that she is doing this in the second game. However, the one that Shepard's worried about is happy to help the rachni. - Some of the backstory clearly hints that (SPOILER) those rachni who fought in the Rachni War were controlled by the Reapers. Sort of a parallel there with the heretic geth. The third game's *Leviathan* DLC, however, suggests that the Leviathans may have been the ones controlling them.

[Red Herring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedHerring): Your Codex entry, and the fact that all the rachni attack you on sight seems to set up the Queen as a possible villain along with Matriarch Benezia. As it turns out, the Rachni Queen is completely innocent, she is shown to be peaceful, and the rachni attacking you are insane due to Binary Helix's meddling.

[Royal "We"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoyalWe): Though as a [Hive Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiveQueen) who uses telepathy to calm and control her offspring, you could consider it a plural "we" as well.  (SPOILER)  Her Reaper-created clone, on the other hand, does not use this, which is an indicator that *[something is very wrong about her.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilTwin)*

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut):
    - Done almost whole-cloth (right down to the Queens killing the daughters that didn't share "harmonious" views) from the bugs in *[Ender's Game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/EndersGame)*. - Both interactions with her have a lot of [Shout Outs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut) to the *[Alien](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/Alien)* franchise. Her discovery, and being used by a shady corporation, resembles Alien, while meeting underground in *Mass Effect 3*, with dead bodies pinned to the wall and being atop a makeshift throne is a direct reference to Aliens.
[Starfish Alien](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StarfishAlien): Doesn't resemble anything remotely human.

[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): To Shepard, if they decide to let her go on Noveria. Before departing, she pledges to sing to her children of Shepard's mercy and in the second game, sends an envoy offering the rachni's support when it comes time to fight against the Reapers.

[Voice of the Legion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoiceOfTheLegion): In *3*,  (SPOILER) she uses about fifteen *dead* [krogan puppets](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PeoplePuppets) to speak with Shepard's squad.

[Cold Equation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColdEquation): In the several hundred years it took the Reapers to finish off the Protheans and clean up all the evidence, the cryogenic systems of the bunker Vigil was maintaining started to falter. Faced with a choice of letting some of the frozen Protheans die or all, Vigil started diverting power from less essential personnel. Subverted in that it was a failsafe programmed into Vigil, and not a real decision made by the software. If Shepard agrees that it was a necessary choice, they net some Renegade points.
[Cozy Voice for Catastrophes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CozyVoiceForCatastrophes): Understandable, since it's a virtual intelligence.

[Do Androids Dream?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoAndroidsDream): Vigil has far more nuance and ability to comprehend things than any other VI you meet in the series. It's highlighted since soon after meeting him you get a chance to talk to the Citadel VI, Avina, again, and she is so clearly more limited. Maybe it can be credited to superior programming or personality imprints, and his leitmotif probably helps, but Vigil evokes an emotional response.
    - It's later learned in *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)* that Prothean VI's contain the *total* [imprints](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainUploading) of a specific Prothean, as was the case of Vendetta, the VI at the Thessian temple of Athane. So, Vigil is the actual personality of the overseer Ksad Ishan, and bordering on, if not totally, an actual artificial intelligence. However, Vigil does flatly state that he can't discuss anything outside of his core purpose: stopping the Reaper cycle.
[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): Liara states that Vigil was the inspiration for her own plan in case things go wrong.  (SPOILER)  In the Refusal ending, it *works*.

[Leitmotif](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Leitmotif): [Vigil's theme](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T7bE3hUwylQ) is not only the menu music for the first game, but in *Mass Effect 2*, it's the music played when you and Kaidan/Ashley meet again on Horizon, when you get a hearty welcome from Wrex, and when you have the "date" with Liara on the *Normandy* after she (SPOILER) assumes the Shadow Broker mantle . In *Mass Effect 3*, it plays (SPOILER) after curing the genophage and/or after ending the geth-quarian war, in [The Stinger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStinger) , is also faintly playing on the menu screen, and is beautifully [hidden in the machine hum of the Normandy's War Room.](http://kotaku.com/5895616/mass-effect-3s-musical-secret)
    - In the Citadel DLC, "[Liara's Theme](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PinXwIZaQHc)" is a piano version of this song.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): In the most literal sense, considering its purpose.

[Mr. Exposition](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrExposition): Vigil fills Shepard in on what will happen with the Reapers, along with a few other details while he's there. Such as the fact that the Protheans weren't the first civilisation to fall prey to them.

tropeName: No Plans, No Prototype, No Backup
tropeNotes: [No Plans, No Prototype, No Backup](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoPlansNoPrototypeNoBackup):  (SPOILER) In the sequel, apparently once Vigil powered down it could not be reactivated again, making it an even riskier [Gambit Roulette](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GambitRoulette) by the Protheans. It's possible this was so the Reapers wouldn't be able to retrieve anything from its databanks even after it powered down, but that meant they left the fate of all future civilisations — sentient beings in numbers beyond counting — suspended by a single, slim thread. Even if it was a thread they'd never had before. [Justified Trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustifiedTrope) when you remember that he's been doing this for a very long time... He didn't power down naturally, he ran out of power completely.  *Mass Effect 3*'s "From Ashes" DLC subverts this by revealing that the Protheans had *several* alternate plans,  (SPOILER) which makes sense considering the remnants of their society had no way of contacting each other and made their own plans.  For example,  (SPOILER) Javik was supposed to lead a million-man army of cryogenically-suspended Protheans in rebuilding the Empire after the Reapers left. Another attempted to covertly uplift the proto-asari as they were deemed the most apt to lead the next cycle of all the "primitives".

[Omniglot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Omniglot): Learned English merely by studying Shepard's radio chatter. Considering the Protheans were extreme Omniglots themselves who could learn an entire *species's* history just by *touching* them, this makes a *lot* of sense.
    - Also counts as somewhat ironic. An earlier interaction with a damaged VI shows that because of the Cipher, Shepard was implanted with a subconscious understanding of the Prothean language, so learning English to communicate wasn't actually necessary at all. - Vigil addresses this. At first, only Shepard understands any of the Prothean communiques. By the time Shepard arrives, Vigil has learned English. And it was necessary in that it would be useful for Shepard's two squadmates, especially if one is Liara, to communicate with it as well.
[Power Echoes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerEchoes): There's a bit of an echo to Vigil's voice.

[Ragnarök Proofing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RagnarokProofing): Somewhat averted. After 50,000 years, just enough to remain functional through the next cycle, Vigil's data is corrupted, and it finally gives out just after speaking to Shepard between the first and second games.

[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): Vigil only appears for one conversation in the final quest of the game, but it provides a lot of context to the Reapers and their genocide of the Protheans, and his actions were instrumental in ensuring the next galactic civilization had a chance at stopping the cycle.
[Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeNaming): The Prothean VIs have all been named with a "V" word: Vigil, Victory, and Vendetta.

tropeName: Be Careful What You Wish For
tropeNotes: [Be Careful What You Wish For](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeCarefulWhatYouWishFor): He says he's itching for some action just before the Eden Prime mission. Too bad "action" in his case meant watching his homeworld get scorched and being gunned down by a pair of geth recon drones.
[Bunny-Ears Lawyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BunnyEarsLawyer): Despite his boundless enthusiasm and naïveté, various characters imply Jenkins was a very competent soldier.
[Decoy Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DecoyProtagonist): He's a placeholder for Ash, who joins about a minute or two after his death.

[Doomed Hometown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoomedHometown): Eden Prime is this for him. Pity he dies too soon for it to become a plot point. And it's not entirely doomed anyway; there's a DLC mission there in the third game.

[Forgotten Fallen Friend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForgottenFallenFriend): Averted. The *Normandy* crew is very upset about his death, and often recall him later in the franchise.
    - In *2*, Dr. Chakwas reminisces about him over drinks with Shepard. - One interpretation of when Shepard later encounters a young over-enthusiastic mercenary (who is also voiced by Josh Dean) on Omega, the reason they stopped dead in their tracks, turned slowly around and, if taking the Paragon interrupt, broke the kid's gun and ordered them home, was because he reminded them too much of Jenkins. - His name is on the memorial wall in the *Normandy* in *Mass Effect 3*, and he will be mentioned if Kaidan, James, or EDI is brought to the Eden Prime mission. - In private moments, Shepard is shown to [give themself grief over Jenkins' death since it was their orders that caused him to run into the ambush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChainsOfCommanding).

[Fun Personified](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FunPersonified): According to Chakwas. One of her stories involves him pestering Kaidan for a biotic demonstration, only for Kaidan to accidentally throw him so hard across the room, she thought he was seriously injured. Jenkins then leapt up, gleefully exclaiming:
QUOTE  **Jenkins**: That was *awesome*!

[Gameplay and Story Segregation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStorySegregation): If you're on a [New Game Plus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NewGamePlus), he'll be level 50+ and still die to a few bullets after having been ordered to take point.

[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): Despite being with you for at most a minute or two and dying right before the first fight, he is a fully functional squad member that can be issued orders and even has some skill points for you to assign despite never having an opportunity to use any abilities.
[Hero-Worshipper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWorshipper): To Shepard. This is rarely a good sign for a character's mortality rate this early in the story.

[Informed Ability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAbility): He's apparently a badass soldier of the Alliance, but he is shot dead in the first half hour of the game and never gets to display it. Then again, it was a surprise attack, and even his replacement barely survived one while losing her entire squad to them.

[Innocently Insensitive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InnocentlyInsensitive): If Shepard has a Survivor or Ruthless background, Jenkins can gush about what they've done is worth him being a Spectre candidate, to which Shepard can state that it's a past that brings them bad memories.

[Leeroy Jenkins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins): [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope), actually, [despite the name.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName) He's very eager to go out there and see action, but still follows Shepard's orders to the letter and takes point. In the end it still doesn't do him much good; some geth drones ambush the squad and Jenkins gets gunned down before the rest know what's happening.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Downplayed. He's named after [Leeroy Jenkins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins), and while he doesn't take it to the level of insubordination, he is rather reckless and eager.
[Naïve Newcomer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NaiveNewcomer): Definitely had an incredibly idealistic outlook on the Spectres, and the heroism of Shepard themself.
[Sacrificial Lamb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SacrificialLamb): He dies just before the player's first battle.
[We Hardly Knew Ye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHardlyKnewYe): He got one conversation and a couple of lines. For a BioWare squad member, that's waving hello in passing.
[Abusive Parents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbusiveParents): Let's just say Daddy is *worse* than what she says. And what she says ain't positive about Mr. Lawson.

[The Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAce): A noteworthy example, what with being genetically engineered to the summit of human perfection. She doesn't seem to have a problem with [mentioning it from time to time](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsufferableGenius). It's also Deconstructed through conversations. She suffers from an inferiority complex caused by having all her physical and intellectual abilities hand-tailored from birth, which causes her to feel that she can't take credit for any of her accomplishments on her own merit. Even more so, because she can't help but compare herself to the aforementioned [Commander Shepard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysSomeoneBetter), who she sees as having accomplished everything they've done without being genetically engineered.

[Ace Pilot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AcePilot): She adds "squadron commander" to her already voluminous resumé in *3*, though we never see it. According to the Shadow Broker terminal, she and her fellow ex-Cerberus defectors procure private fighters and begin using them to strike Cerberus targets.
[Action Film, Quiet Drama Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionFilmQuietDramaScene): In her loyalty mission where she debates whether or not to talk to her sister.
[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): Designed to be, indeed. Those biotics probably didn't come cheap. Especially since, officially, humanity had no idea what biotics were at the time.

[Always Someone Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysSomeoneBetter): If you choose to earn her friendship, she reveals she feels somewhat inferior to Shepard. She was designed to be perfect and easily accomplish impossible tasks she is set. Shepard is just a regular person but somehow manages to succeed in doing impossible tasks *anyway* and often completes them with results beyond what she could have done. It's also implied that she feels a bit jealous of how much faith the Illusive Man places in Shepard.

[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero): For most of 2 she's veering into (and occasionally entering) [He Who Fights Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeWhoFightsMonsters) territory and is generally both a [Knight Templar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar) and [Good Is Not Nice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodIsNotNice). From the end of 2 onward though she becomes more of a [Classical Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClassicalAntiHero). She has no further [Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog) moments, her entire quest arc in *3*  (SPOILER)  is about her trying to protect her sister from her father, and along the way, she tries to save refugees of all races from a husk facility masquerading as a refuge .

[Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy): Jack sees her this way, complete with an [The Only One Allowed to Defeat You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheOnlyOneAllowedToDefeatYou) mentality. This reaches its peak during a catfight that Shepard has to head off, possibly also losing the loyalty of one or the other.  (SPOILER)  Fortunately, as of the Citadel DLC, they've smoothed things over a bit .
QUOTE **Jack**: She'll survive. I hate to see her die [before I get the chance to filet her myself!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy)

[Archnemesis Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchnemesisDad): The reason she joined Cerberus in the first place was to gain protection from her father. Her dad actually had close Cerberus ties before this, but the Illusive Man valued her abilities over his resources.  (SPOILER)  Until the third game, that is. Besides, she's left Cerberus by that point (dead or alive) .

[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): In *3*, for her work with Cerberus and other things. To the point that she apologizes to Shepard for wanting to implant them with a control chip, even though the Illusive Man stopped her from going through with it.
[Awesome Aussie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwesomeAussie): By extension of being voiced by and face-modeled after one.

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): Early in *2*.
QUOTE **Miranda**: Worried about my qualifications? [I can crush a mech with my biotics](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindOverMatter) or [blow its head off from a hundred yards.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoomHeadshot) Take your pick.
[Badass Bookworm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBookworm): A very capable combatant and extremely intelligent as well, having led the Lazarus Project to bring someone back from the dead.
[The Baroness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBaroness): Sexpot variety, albeit a much less evil example than most.
[Barrier Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarrierWarrior): *Citadel* replaces Slam with the redesigned Reave.

[Beauty Equals Goodness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeautyEqualsGoodness): Played with. She's incredibly beautiful and while, initially, [not the most morally inclined member of Shepard's crew](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar), [she's far from evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold) and is also [one of the better members of Cerberus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenGoodTeammate).

[Beauty Is Never Tarnished](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeautyIsNeverTarnished):  (SPOILER)  In *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)*, after she gets the crap beaten out of her by Kai Leng, she doesn't appear to have any visible wounds on her body aside from a few scratches on her face. This is especially weird if she actually dies from her wounds. Then again, she easily could've had severe internal injuries from blunt force trauma .

[Because You Can Cope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BecauseYouCanCope): If you lose her loyalty by siding with Jack, you can regain it by saying that you did it because she's more understanding than Jack is.

tropeName: Because You Were Nice to Me
tropeNotes: [Because You Were Nice to Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BecauseYouWereNiceToMe): Paragon Shepard can cause her to resign from Cerberus, likely due to Shepard being the first person with authority over her to actually ask what *she* wants, not attempt to control her, and seeks her friendship with no ulterior motive for doing so. Even if that doesn't come to pass, Miranda will remain loyal to Shepard after resigning from Cerberus offscreen.

[Belligerent Sexual Tension](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BelligerentSexualTension): With a male Renegade Shepard, their [First Kiss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FirstKiss) pretty much comes about after he mercilessly teases and taunts her about her insecurities and is generally rude and challenging, which seems to be pushing all her buttons... with Miranda being [flabbergasted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PostKissCatatonia) and asking "Okay, what the hell was that?!" afterwards.

[Beneath the Mask](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeneathTheMask): Under the cocky, arrogant, and ruthless demeanor lies an extremely insecure woman with a hell of an inferiority complex, major daddy issues, and a surprisingly good heart that needs to be pushed in the right direction.
[Big Sister Instinct](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigSisterInstinct): She will go the ends of the galaxy and risk everything to protect Oriana.

[Birds of a Feather](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BirdsOfAFeather): Shepard can use this to argue for or against a relationship with her.
QUOTE **Shepard:** This won't work, Miranda. We're [Too Much Alike](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooMuchAlike).

[Bond One-Liner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BondOneLiner):
    - Once Shepard escapes the Lazarus facility, their first encounter with Miranda has her killing Wilson in cold blood. QUOTE **Wilson:** Miranda? But you're— *[Miranda kills him]* **Miranda:** Dead? - Then there's her loyalty mission: QUOTE **Miranda**: Goodbye (SPOILER) Niket , I'm going to miss you... *[bang]* **Miranda**:...figuratively speaking. - In the third game, at the end of (SPOILER) the Sanctuary mission if she's still alive : QUOTE (SPOILER) **Henry Lawson** **:** *[after releasing (SPOILER) Oriana ]* Alright, take her. But I want out alive, deal? *[Miranda uses her biotics to [throw him out the window](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DestinationDefenestration)]* **Miranda:** No deal.
[Brainy Brunette](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainyBrunette): She was the head scientist of the Lazarus Project.

[Broken Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenAce): Beautiful, intelligent, competent, and consumed with self-doubt and self-loathing due to being genetically engineered by her father to be absolutely perfect and capable of accomplishing anything. This causes her to view anything she accomplishes to be a result of her father's money and planning, and believes that only her mistakes are truly hers.
[Broken Bird](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenBird): See [Freudian Excuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianExcuse).

[Broken Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal): To the Illusive Man and Cerberus at the end of 2  (SPOILER) although they in turn seem to have become this to her, if her dialogue when Shepard destroys the Collector Base is any indication .

[Buxom Beauty Standard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BuxomBeautyStandard):
    - As the engineers put it... QUOTE **Daniels:** I've got green across the board. The forward tanks are buoyant and elevated. **Donnelly:** Are ya talking about the *Normandy* or Miranda? **Daniels:** I'm talking about the one that's covered and protected, not *bouncing in the breeze*. - Even Jack concurs in the Citadel DLC.
