If you want to do it in more of a Paragon way, though, then you can also catch her interest by beating up a male turian who's sexually harassing an asari dancer, convincing the bartender it'd be good business to give everybody a free round of drinks, dancing with an asari (a different one than the one who was being bothered by the turian), and warning a journalist investigating gang activity that her cover's been blown.
[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero): [Nominal Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NominalHero) at best.

[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): While a potential squad mate, if you side with Samara during her loyalty mission, then this is all Morinth winds up being as she's dealt with by the mission's end.

[Armor-Piercing Question](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmorPiercingQuestion): Mentioning that Samara was the one who gave birth to Ardat-Yakshi children.
QUOTE **Morinth:** *Mother*. 
**Samara:** [Do NOT call me that!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton)

[The Baroness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBaroness): She is *obsessed* with dominating people, especially troubled artists and recluses. In fact, her behavior is reminiscient of the infamous [Countess Elizabeth Bathory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elizabeth_Bathory). QUOTE "I love the moment you see it in your opponent's eyes: he knows you're better and he's going to die." "I love any game where your opponent can believe he's about to win... just before you kill him."
[Black Eyes of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackEyesOfEvil): When seducing her victims, although the black eyes are a trait of the asari as a whole, not just her.
[Black Widow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackWidow): Not for money or anything, but power. Both psychic and good old-fashioned manipulation.

[Blatant Lies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies):
    - She claims that Ardat-Yakshi are "the genetic destiny of the asari." Ardat-Yakshi are *sterile*. - Morinth claims that her only crime was being born an Ardat-Yakshi. Apparently murdering hundreds of people and enslaving villages don't count as crimes.

[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy):  (SPOILER)  If you choose her in *[Mass Effect 2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect2)* and she survives, the Reapers turn her into a [Banshee](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BodyHorror) you have to kill in London in *3*.

[Broken Ace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenAce): She is considered irresistible by anyone who meets her and Samara herself says that Morinth is her strongest and smartest daughter. She is a match for a justicar in combat and very cunning to have evaded capture for 400 years. She is also a [Sociopath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Sociopath) who's addicted to murder.

[Charm Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharmPerson): Her "Dominate" special ability, which borders on [Mind Rape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape). Using subtle mass effect fields to cover distances, she creates a powerful form of melding that highjacks a victim’s neurological functions, causing them to attack their allies for a short period. It’s essentially a variation of Hacking that works on organics.

[The Corrupter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCorrupter): As much as she loves her sisters and care for them genuinely. It's made very clear that she is encouraging (or even guilt-tripping) the two to ditch the monastery and become an unfettered, hedonistic sociopath like her. There is a good reason why her messages are always deleted unread.

[Dead Person Impersonation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadPersonImpersonation): If you choose to kill Samara, Morinth reveals she's quite good at imitating her mother's voice and does so for most of your missions.

[Death by Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathByIrony): She tells you, "I love any game where your opponent can believe he's about to win...just before you kill him." She spends most of the mission thinking she's about to win.
[Depraved Bisexual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DepravedBisexual): A complete psychopath who gets off on seducing and killing people.

[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): According to Samara, Morinth *refused* to accept any limits placed on her, and strived to be her own boss. Samara is proud of her determination and bravery — but she still needs to be put down because she's just so dangerous.

[Didn't Think This Through](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntThinkThisThrough): If we take her claim that she's "the genetic destiny of the Asari" at face value, it's possibly this. Either she's unaware that Ardat-Yakshi are sterile, or she just doesn't *care.*

[Disappeared Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisappearedDad): Nothing is ever mentioned of Morinth's father other than that she was an asari. The list of Samara's bequeathed belonging's implies that Morinth's fathered died prior to Morinth's diagnosis.

[Dropped a Bridge on Her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DroppedABridgeOnHer):  (SPOILER) There's no way to prevent her from being turned into a Banshee in the third game. You've got to kill her. Granted, [she probably deserves it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SerialKiller), though since you *did* personally [save her life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini) in *[Mass Effect 2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect2)*, having to kill her is probably still going to hurt.

[Enemy Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine): The fact that the Collectors and Reapers are a threat to *everybody* seems to be part of her motivation for joining you on the suicide mission. She is also, if this counts, just as suspicious of the Illusive Man as many of your other squadmates.
[Even Evil Has Loved Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasLovedOnes): She has enough affection for her sisters to still send them e-mails.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Well, *sort of*. She agrees the Collector Base should be destroyed, although it's not clear whether she thinks this for moral reasons or because of [a selfish sense of self-preservation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy). She knows the Collectors and Reapers represent a threat to her, and would likely sacrifice hundreds to save herself. In fact, she has. *3* proves she has every reason to fear the Reapers.
[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): To Samara.

[Exact Words](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactWords): Morinth's email to Rila and Falere if she survives *2* tells them that their mother "passed on while chasing the justice she loved so much". She doesn't tell them that the justice Samara was seeking was stopping *her*. However, she outright lies and says Samara died fighting the Collectors beyond the Omega 4 relay.
[Flat Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatCharacter): Storywise, she gets hit with this when compared to Samara. And as noted above, she doesn't get much development in the third game either.
[For the Evulz](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForTheEvulz): Her only real motivation is pleasure, and she gets pleasure from hunting and killing her victims.

[Freudian Excuse Is No Excuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianExcuseIsNoExcuse): When her condition is brought up, Samara retorts that she rejected the offer to live peacefully and chose to embrace being a [Serial Killer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SerialKiller), which her siblings with the same condition were able to avoid.
QUOTE **Samara:** She is a tragic figure, but not a sympathetic one.

[Glass Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlassCannon): Like Samara, Morinth can dish out a lot of damage but is rather physically weak. And unlike Samara, she doesn't get Reave to compensate for this, either. Using Dominate even leaves her vulnerable for about two seconds before the ability kicks in — the animation is somewhat similar to Harbinger controlling a Collector.

[A God Am I](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AGodAmI): Claims to be the "genetic destiny of the asari", despite the fact that Ardat-Yakshi cannot breed. Also, of course, the whole "setting herself as a goddess" thing she did, complete with demanding the sacrifices of daughters.
[Gory Discretion Shot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoryDiscretionShot): You get one when Samara makes the kill. Apparently it's so gory that even cast-iron Shepard averts their eyes.

[Goth Girls Know Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GothGirlsKnowMagic): She's a hedonist who likes to wear dark clothing and linger in the shadows, and is a biotic as an asari, and a powerful one at that due to killing so many people by sex.

[Guide Dang It!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuideDangIt): Resisting her mind control, which is required to recruit her, takes a *very* high Paragon or Renegade score. If you can't make the check, Shepard sides with Samara by default. For those who *want* Morinth, it's possible that you won't be able to choose her without [editing saves](http://social.bioware.com/forum/1/topic/103/index/2338026), depending on the decisions you make during the game. Both the cause and solution have been explained on the official forums via [Word of God](http://social.bioware.com/forum/1/topic/107/index/1197668/3#1429364). Knowing how the system works, you could just [use other methods](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SaveScumming).
[Has a Type](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HasAType): She's drawn to shy, reclusive artists. Or jerks.

[Heroic Willpower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicWillpower): Okay, maybe not heroic, but if she uses her Dominate ability on a Collector that is subsequently possessed by Harbinger, Harbinger will briefly fight for you. In other words she can out-will a *Reaper*.
[The Hedonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHedonist): Everything she does is for her own pleasure. *Especially* killing.

[Hipster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hipster): Morinth is attracted to these, especially those who invoke [It's Popular, Now It Sucks!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsPopularNowItSucks). Shepard is aware of it, and attracts her with this line: QUOTE **Shepard:** If you've heard of it, it's already too mainstream for me.

[Hidden Buxom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenBuxom): The catsuit she wears when Shepard first meets her makes her chest look considerably smaller than when she switches out to the [Navel-Deep Neckline](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NavelDeepNeckline) outfit of Samara. If her breasts really are as big as her mom's it makes you wonder how she could even breathe in the catsuit.

[High on Homicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HighOnHomicide): This is what makes Ardat-Yakshi like her so dangerous; the act of mating gives them an intense pleasure similar to doing narcotics. This is extremely addictive, and the more an Ardat-Yakshi does it, the more she needs to do it, meaning they'll create *astronomical* body counts in endless pursuit of that pleasure.
[I Am the Trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IAmTheTrope): Insists that she is the genetic destiny of the asari. She isn't. Ardat-Yakshi are sterile.

[Identical Grandson](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdenticalGrandson): If you choose to kill Samara and replace her with Morinth, the latter will reveal how she escaped from Thessia: not only is she a dead ringer for her mother, she can also *mimic* her almost perfectly (only Kelly and Kasumi notice any real difference).
[I Have Many Names](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveManyNames): "Morinth" is just one of many aliases she owns. Mirala is her birth name, and the one she uses when writing to her sisters.

[Insane Troll Logic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsaneTrollLogic): One of the justifications she gives for her actions is that the Ardat-Yakshi are the Asari's genetic destiny. Because the entire race being sterile is totally how evolution works.

[Ironic Echo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IronicEcho): "Embrace eternity!" It's an asari [Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatchPhrase) for when they mind meld with another — with her, it ends up being a whole different kind of "eternity".

[It's All About Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllAboutMe): Comes with being a sociopath. The best way to get on her good side during Samara's loyalty mission is to talk about things you know *she* likes. Trying to talk about your own tastes causes her to lose interest fast.
[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): If you side with her in ME2, she gets away scott-free with her murder spree.

[Karma Houdini Warranty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudiniWarranty):  (SPOILER)  ...However, come ME3, she's [turned into a Banshee](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FateWorseThanDeath) by the Reapers and there's nothing Shepard can do to prevent this. She's later encountered in London during *Priority:Earth*, and has to be killed like any other Banshee .

[Laser-Guided Karma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserGuidedKarma): If she survives ME2.  (SPOILER) After having made a career out of murdering people using mind control, it's only fitting that she ultimately falls under the control of the Reapers when they turn her into a Banshee.

[Lesbian Vampire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LesbianVampire): A [Recycled In Space](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecycledInSpace) version. The mission introducing her follows her hunting and eventually killing a pretty young human girl, and this trope's fingerprints are all over it. Morinth's "Dominate" ability is unique among the Asari shown in the series, and is an important aspect of her fitting this mold.
[Locked Away in a Monastery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LockedAwayInAMonastery): She refused this, which is why she's a hunted criminal.
[Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard): How she lures her victims.
[Master Actress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterActress): One of her “wide range of talents” is acting, which is perfected to the point where she can mimic Samara’s voice and cadence to a T.
[Mind over Matter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindOverMatter): A biotic, like all asari. Her method of killing people makes her even stronger.
[More than Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl): What eventually happens to her victims. They're her willing slaves until she tires of the game and kills them.

[Mutually Exclusive Party Members](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MutuallyExclusivePartyMembers): With her mother, Samara. Recruiting her will cause Morinth to kill her mother and take her place on Shepard's squad.

[Ninja Pirate Zombie Robot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NinjaPirateZombieRobot): She's an omnisexual mutant [blue-skinned](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreenSkinnedSpaceBabe) alien sex vampire  [IN SPACE](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecycledInSpace) !
[No-Sell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSell): To her mind control, if you have a high Paragon or Renegade score.
[Non-Standard Game Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonStandardGameOver): Have sex with her. Every character thinks it's a bad idea. For a very good reason.

[Odd Name Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OddNameOut): The only one in her family to have a name ending with a consonant. Asari as a whole tend to have names ending in vowels. Justified, as Morinth is not her original name, having changed it from Mirala.

[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): If Shepard resists her [Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindControl), which requires incredibly high rankings in either Paragon or Renegade.
QUOTE **Morinth:** *(angry)* Oh no, I see what's going on — the bitch found herself a little helper.

[Optional Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OptionalPartyMember): You can recruit her in place of Samara if you betray the justicar during her loyalty quest. Doing so requires a very high Paragon or Renegade score, so you may not even have the option to do so.

[Out with a Bang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutWithABang): Due to a bizarre genetic quirk, she burns out the nervous system of anyone she mates with, instantly killing them. This process not only gives her a boost of power and knowledge, but it's extremely addictive for her. The effect is narcotic — the more that she does it, the more she wants to do it.
[Patchwork Kids](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PatchworkKids): She is the spitting image of her mother, a fact that she has used to her advantage on more than one occasion.

[Perky Goth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PerkyGoth): [Darker and Edgier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkerAndEdgier). When you first encounter her face-to-face she seems very amiable in an [Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil), [Wicked Cultured](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WickedCultured) way, and all she seems to really care about is just 'lingering in the shadows' and '[experiencing as much pleasure as possible.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHedonist)' You might even start to think that Samara is overreacting, maybe her obsession has made her delusional. Except the 'Goth' elements aren't just an act; she's really an asari sex vampire who likes to kill and [Mind Rape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape) people, and she wants to keep doing it.
    - Starts acting nicer (to Shepard, anyway) once on board the *Normandy*. Doesn't try to [Mind Rape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape) you, or any of the crew (which according to EDI consists of 24, so any murders would be noticed). She *does* still want to have sex with you, and after the suicide mission is over she'll try to seduce you, saying she's sure that you're the one person who might be able to survive the experience and that it feels incredibly good. Whether she's just lying to try to get what she wants or if she really believes that is left to the player to determine. For whatever it's worth, if you turn her down she takes it fine and writes a goodbye letter to you in the third game which, coming from anybody else, would be touching.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): If she was alive at the start of the third game she [sends letters](http://youtu.be/c0Sz9NG2ObU) to her sisters in the monastery. She lies about how Samara died, but still says she misses them. Whether this is sincere or not, it's the one time she ever seems to suggest caring about anyone. Said emails were deleted unread, caught in the filter by the headmistress - with good reason. Morinth was tempting her sisters to leave the monastery and join her in being [The Unfettered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfettered).

[Playing the Victim Card](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingTheVictimCard): She tries to convince Shepard that *she's* the victim (it's not her fault that she's an Ardat-Yakshi) and that Samara is the evil one for trying to kill her. It doesn't hold any water, as her sisters (among others) are perfectly peaceful, she is just using it as an excuse for murder.

[Reformed, but Rejected](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReformedButRejected): Averted. She's not reformed at all and her emails to his sisters are deleted unread by the superintendent of the Ardat-Yakshi monastery, presumably to prevent her from trying to manipulate them.

[Schmuck Bait](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SchmuckBait): She's [Out with a Bang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutWithABang) incarnate, and you *still* have the option to bang her. [Guess what happens!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonstandardGameOver)
[Serial Killer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SerialKiller): [Through sex, no less.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutWithABang)
[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): Definitely exhibits this when attempting to lure in victims.

[The Sociopath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSociopath): Samara even shares some of her peoples' theories that Ardat-Yakshi are genetic relics of an ancient by-gone age in their species life, very similar to Real Life theories regarding the [evolutionary basis for psychopathy](https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/blame-the-amygdala/201301/evolution-and-the-psychopath). Explicitly stated in the "mission complete" overview after ending Samara's loyalty mission. QUOTE *Subject's expertise would have made her a valuable team member if sociopathic tendencies were mitigated.*

[Succubi and Incubi](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuccubiAndIncubi): Ardat-Yakshi means "demon of the night wind." In other words, she's a space succubus, complete with the [The Vamp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVamp) routine that ends with an [Out with a Bang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutWithABang) for her lovers. Although according to the [Word of God](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod), she's also a space *vampire*. In fact, in conversations with Samara, you learn that Morinth once set herself up as a goddess in one world and was worshipped by an entire village; many vampire stories refer to entire villages being held in thrall. Most telling of all, the name of the vessel that transported Morinth from Illium to Omega is the "[Demeter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut)," the name of the ship that carried [Dracula](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Dracula) to England.

[Thicker Than Water](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThickerThanWater): One of her more humanizing traits is that she still very much loves her sisters, sending messages to the Monastery to try to connect with them. However, all of the letters are destroyed by the headmistress before they can get them (that doesn't stop the Shadow Broker from getting copies, of course.)
QUOTE This must be my last letter, but I miss you. I need to let you know how much I wish we could meet again, even be together again.
[Token Evil Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenEvilTeammate): The only squadmate that can definitely be pinned down as outright evil, even next to the likes of Zaeed, Jack or Grunt.

[Tragic Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicVillain): According to Samara, though it doesn't make her any less evil.
QUOTE **Samara**: Morinth is a tragic figure, but not a sympathetic one.

[Troubling Unchildlike Behavior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TroublingUnchildlikeBehavior): Samara mentions Morinth went on the run the minute she learned she was an Ardat-Yakshi at the age of forty. That's the asari equivalent of becoming a [Femme Fatale](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FemmeFatale) before hitting puberty.

[Try Not to Die](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TryNotToDie): If she survives *2*, she'll send Shepard an email apologizing for leaving without telling anyone, and tells him "Take care of yourself. I'd hate to hear you were killed before we get a chance to meet up again." It would be heartwarming, if not for the fact Morinth wants Shepard all to herself.

[The Vamp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVamp): Greatly enjoys seducing sympathetic individuals and tries to do so with Shepard, complete with the sob story about her mother and being persecuted. In fact, should you choose Morinth over Samara, all of her dialogue with Shepard on the Normandy is laced with flirtation.

[Underestimating Badassery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnderestimatingBadassery): Played with; Shepard's role as bait is to demonstrate badassery to lure her out. However, if they have a high Paragon or Renegade score, they can completely shrug off her attempts at mind control, leading to Morinth having a minor [Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap) moment when she realises the person in front of them is far more dangerous than she thought.

["Well Done, Son" Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellDoneSonGuy): Despite everything, Samara is depressed by Morinth's death, calling her "the smartest and bravest of my daughters". It's doubtful Samara ever *told* Morinth that, however. It's hinted at when Morinth calls her "mother", and her speech about nothing she did ever pleased her (though Morinth is seriously deluded if she thought her centuries-long *murder spree* would be something Samara would be pleased with.)

[What Beautiful Eyes!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatBeautifulEyes): She has the same astonishingly clear-blue eyes as her mother, except when they [turn black when she uses her powers.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackEyesOfEvil)
[Wicked Cultured](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WickedCultured): As part of their role as bait, Shepard must take advantage of her love for exotic music, art and drugs.
[Woobie, Destroyer of Worlds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WoobieDestroyerOfWorlds): Invokes this to get sympathy points, but it [might be an act.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope)

tropeName: You Could Have Used Your Powers for Good!
tropeNotes: [You Could Have Used Your Powers for Good!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCouldHaveUsedYourPowersForGood): At the end of Samara's loyalty mission, the Illusive Man laments that she would have made an excellent ally against the Collectors if her sociopathic tendencies could be mitigated.

[Ace Custom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AceCustom): In regards to other Reapers, Harbinger's design is unique and far more powerful: he is larger overall, has a "crest" on top of his chassis, features glowing yellow spots on the front no other Reaper has, is missing the center "tentacle" and seems to have at least half a dozen of those Reaper beams compared to the one or two other Reapers are shown using. *Leviathan* reveals he was constructed in the image of the Leviathans, and that every subsequent Reaper was a design variation on his model.

[And I Must Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream): The Catalyst implies that Harbinger was the first species to be turned into a Reaper as a solution to the endless conflict its race had with synthetics. It was not happy with this solution. Now, the only remnants of the Catalyst's creators, who it mercilessly slaughtered, are stuck serving the very being that killed them for all eternity. This is later confirmed in the Leviathan DLC.

[Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy): Much of *Mass Effect 2* establishes how obsessed Harbinger is with destroying Shepard, sensing the human is a threat that *must* be dealt with to prevent any chance of the Reapers being defeated. This despite the Reapers' arrogant boasts they are infallible [Lovecraftian horrors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination) indicates an [uncharacteristic investment in a singular individual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OOCIsSeriousBusiness), especially from the Reaper armada's leader. The trilogy seems to build up to a final confrontation between the two... [only for Harbinger to leave upon mistakenly thinking it finally killed Shepard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope) at the end of *3*, with Shepard's final interactions being with fellow humans and [the Catalyst](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain), who Harbinger is [implied to not even know about.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DramaticIrony) The big guy doesn't even have a single line of dialogue throughout the entire third game, which is amusing considering how talkative it was in the previous one.

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast):
    - **"I WILL SHOW YOU TRUE POWER."** **"THIS IS WHAT YOU FACE."** And many, many more. [Here is a complete list.](https://masseffect.wikia.com/wiki/Harbinger_(Collector)/Battle_Quotes) - He makes another one in the final cutscene of the Suicide Mission. You can listen to it [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=re9C1-CdKUE), at the 58 second mark. QUOTE **Harbinger:** **Human, [you've changed nothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBattleDidntCount). [Your species has the attention of those infinitely your greater.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainTakesAnInterest) [That which you know as Reapers are your salvation through destruction.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality)** **Harbinger:** (*to the Collector General*) **[You have failed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveFailedMe). [We will find another way.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SequelHook) [Releasing control.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BookEnds)** - In the [trailer](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dZqwuHFIgIA) for the *Retaliation* content pack for the multiplayer mode in *Mass Effect 3* he makes another chilling speech. QUOTE **Harbinger:** **We have returned. The organic hordes rally, refusing to recognize our supremacy. They struggle in vain, trusting in numbers to stall our advance. Like every Cycle before, they will resist. And now they will understand, the full extent of our superiority.** [...] **The outcome is inevitable. They will succumb and ascend... or they will be annihilated.**

[Beam Spam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeamSpam): While Reaper Destroyers only get one main cannon and Sovereign-class Reapers get one for the mouth and one on each leg, Harbinger has *numerous* hydrodynamic cannons in his mouth area alone and probably more in his legs too (though only the former sees use). He's not called the most powerful Reaper for nothing, [as Hammer Group finds out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle).

[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): Prime antagonist for the main storyline of the second game, controlling the actions of his surrogates in much the same way as Sovereign did. [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Subverted) in *Mass Effect 3*. Despite being the oldest of them all, he is just another pawn of the Catalyst.

[Big Bad Ensemble](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadEnsemble): In both his appearances. The Shadow Broker, [Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain) Liara's story and [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) of *Lair of the Shadow Broker* in *2*, and the Illusive Man, [The Heavy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeavy) in *3*, are both presented as major threats but not directly aligned with him and in some cases directly opposed. Ironically, their plans were still to Harbinger's benefit, since the Shadow Broker wanted to give him Shepard's body to ensure his survival and the Illusive Man was doomed to fail because the Reapers had successfully Indoctrinated him at that point.

[Blue-and-Orange Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality): He sincerely believes that turning organics into Reapers is helping them, cut dialogue from the 2nd game has him actually express frustration at Shepard's efforts, believing that being made into a Reaper means that humanity will be immortal and that destroying a Reaper is a senseless waste of life.
QUOTE **Harbinger:** **THAT WHICH YOU KNOW AS REAPERS ARE YOUR SALVATION THROUGH DESTRUCTION.**

[Boss Banter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossBanter): When he "Assumes Direct Control" of a Collector he simply [will! Not! Shut! Up!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunctuatedForEmphasis) Some examples: "This hurts you", "You cannot resist", "This is what you face", "Face your annihilation", "You are bacteria", "You are shortsighted", "Pitiful", "We will end you", "We are the beginning, you are the end", "I sense your weakness", "Your attacks are primitive", "You cannot sustain your attack", "Your attack is an insult", "You are no longer relevant", "My attacks will tear you apart." Clearly he likes to hear the sound of his own voice.

[Boss in Mook Clothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossInMookClothing): Taken very literally. He doesn't appear in person, but [takes over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession) regular [Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Mooks), turning that particular Mook into a hyper-powered biotic killing machine. What's more, it doesn't take a lot out of him, so even if you beat his host, he just possesses one of its buddies.
[Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatchPhrase): **"ASSUMING DIRECT CONTROL."** And all variations thereupon.

tropeName: The Computer Is a Cheating Bastard
tropeNotes: [The Computer Is a Cheating Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheComputerIsACheatingBastard): Think you're safely in cover? Think again. He can knock you out of it at will.

[Contrasting Sequel Antagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContrastingSequelAntagonist): To Sovereign. Sovereign regarded all sapient life with total disgust and seemed to regard the Reapers' actions as merely [The Right of a Superior Species](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRightOfASuperiorSpecies). Harbinger is just as arrogant but sincerely regards organics as being worthy of, if not love, then certainly the Reapers' [benevolence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlueAndOrangeMorality). Their choice of minions is also opposite, with Sovereign acting mainly through the synthetic geth and Harbinger through the organic Collectors.

[Crazy-Prepared](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrazyPrepared): Even after sending the Collectors to destroy the *Normandy*, he has them make an effort to retrieve Shepard's body to make sure the attack worked, only failing because the Illusive Man got it first. In the *Arrival* DLC, it's revealed that the Reapers were plotting an invasion through the Alpha relay at the same time that Shepard was dealing with the Collector threat.

[Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle): Towards the end of *3*, Harbinger personally, physically comes down to Earth to annihilate the Alliance ground forces. The battle is over in a minute, with most of Hammer Group dead and Shepard left severely injured.

[Demonic Possession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession): **"ASSUMING DIRECT CONTROL."** Harbinger is better at it than Sovereign too; while the latter keeled over and got utterly wrecked after feedback from one interrupted possession, Harbinger can spam them in succession because he's performing them through his intermediary, the Collector General.

[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): He's still the apparent leader of the Reapers and thus the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) of the game, but his only appearance in *3* is showing up at the very end to attempt to stop Alliance soldiers from beaming up to the Citadel. To further emphasize this, remember how much he loved to speak and just wouldn't shut up in the second game? He gets nary a peep in *3*. Odd, considering you will hear Keith Szarabajka's voice in other parts of the game. Harbinger also makes a fully voiced appearance in the trailer for the ''Retaliation combat pack in Multiplayer, which brought the return of the Collectors as enemies.
[Don't Make Me Destroy You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DontMakeMeDestroyYou): **"IF I MUST TEAR YOU APART, SHEPARD, I WILL."**

[Dragon-in-Chief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonInChief): Since it's revealed that the Citadel is home to the AI that controls all of the Reapers, that would imply that Harbinger is its second-in-command. However, the Catalyst itself doesn't seem to do much, while Harbinger is the driving force of much of the invasion. It isn't even clear if he knows about the Catalyst at all.

[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): To *Shepard*. You can hear their hesitation and concern upon hearing that Harbinger is physically coming to the battlefield and basically tells Hammer Group to haul ass to the Conduit.

[Early-Bird Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EarlyBirdCameo): Long before his proper introduction on Horizon, one of his possessed drones can be seen on Veetor's security footage when you see it on Freedom's Progress.
[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): He's a Reaper, and, like Sovereign, just loves reminding you of how far beyond your comprehension he is.

tropeName: Exactly What It Says on the Tin
tropeNotes: [Exactly What It Says on the Tin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactlyWhatItSaysOnTheTin): "Harbinger": the first of many. A synonym to [precursor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbusivePrecursors).

[Easily Forgiven](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasilyForgiven): In the Synthesis ending, the synthesized people of the galaxy sure don't seem to mind Harbinger and the rest of Reapers helping them rebuild, despite the fact that the Reapers were trying to wipe out all life in the galaxy not too long ago. Possibly justified in that Harbinger was freed of the Catalyst's influence, and of course, all organics also gained understanding of synthetics in the process. Ditto for Control, although in that case, Harbinger is now a minion of Shepard, the new Catalyst. [Not that people could do much to him if they tried.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BullyingADragon)

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): Of a sort to Shepard, as both are the leaders on their respective sides.  (SPOILER) This ultimately ends up [subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope), as it's revealed the Catalyst is the true overseer of the Reapers and Harbinger ultimately does its bidding, thus making it Shepard's true counterpart. In the Control ending, Shepard can even take the Catalyst's place and order Harbinger around along with the rest of the Reapers. **[ASSUMING CONTROL](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony)** indeed.
[Evil Gloating](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGloating): Less so than Sovereign, but still.
[Evil Sounds Deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSoundsDeep): Almost on par with Sovereign.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism):
    - Sort of. He's very interested in humanity in general and Shepard in particular (which makes him less condescending than Sovereign), but makes dismissive comments about any non-human party members and their species. - It's a lot worse when you find out the reasons why their species weren't picked to be made into Reaper babies. The drell and krogan were dismissed out of hand due to lack of numbers, while the quarians were actually considered due to their aptitude for cybernetics.

[Fighting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingAShadow): His favorite tactic.
QUOTE **"YOU ONLY DAMAGE THE VESSEL, YOU CANNOT HURT ME."**

[Fireballs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Fireballs): He's capable of shooting them. They're kind of like the Warp power that Shepard and co can use, except it's colored differently and also lights things on fire.
[Frontline General](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FrontlineGeneral): **"DIRECT INTERVENTION IS NECESSARY."** **"I WILL DIRECT THIS PERSONALLY."**
[Glowing Eyes of Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlowingEyesOfDoom): Six eyes that glow ominously yellow. When he possesses a Collector their eyes glow the same colour.

[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain): The events of the novel *Mass Effect: Ascension* are largely his fault. Through the Collectors, he makes a lucrative offer to acquire human biotics. The novel's primary villains, Golo and Pel, are quick to sell out Cerberus and take Harbinger up on his offer.

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): After billions of years being controlled and directed to kill and enslave countless species, Harbinger finally is able to think for himself and stop the cycles without the catalyst’s influence in the *Synthesis Ending*. Alternatively, he continues to be controlled and influenced although this time by Shepard’s consciousness in the "Control Ending". Either way, he and the Reapers help the galaxy rebuild.

[Hero Killer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroKiller):
    - After humanity proved itself a threat, [he sent the Collectors to target them specifically](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainTakesAnInterest). First on the list: that upstart who got Sovereign blown up... - In actual gameplay, whenever he comes on the screen and you're on a higher difficulty, wave goodbye to your squadmates. Their AI tend to make them hide behind cover while periodically popping out and shooting, which doesn't work so well when Harbinger has the ability to knock them out at will while at the same time setting them on fire. Also, half the squad's powers don't even hurt him because he has armor instead of health. - Also, in the [Suicide Mission](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideMission), if you pick the wrong tech expert, squad leader, or both, then Harbinger kills your tech expert with a fireball. - At the climax of *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)*, Harbinger *personally* comes down and blasts Shepard, who is *on foot*. Amazingly enough, *Shepard lives and keeps on going*. However, if your military score is too low, [both of the squadmates](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tRNR3RbcVXI&feature=relmfu) with you are killed.

[Hero Unit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroUnit): It's a plot point that you're playing a 3PS/RPG, whilst Harbinger is playing an [Action RTS](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionRTS). He will occasionally [Assume Direct Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession) of one of its Collector mooks, which greatly boosts their shields and fuses its skin into tough armor.
[Hopeless Boss Fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessBossFight): When he appears in London, all you can do is dodge his attacks. There is no way to defeat him and he'll get you eventually.

[Hoist by His Own Petard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoistByHisOwnPetard): In the Control Ending Shepard becomes the guiding intelligence of Harbinger and the rest of the Reapers - in other words they ASSUME DIRECT CONTROL of him.
[Implacable Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImplacableMan): **"I WILL FIND YOU AGAIN."**

[I Am Legion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IAmLegion): Alternates between using "I" and "we". It's justified; not only does he have an entire species worth of potential vessels, but Harbinger himself is an entire organic species uploaded into a Reaper shell.
[I Shall Taunt You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IShallTauntYou): He is a [very verbal](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OaRdcVYTjRw) guy.
[Incoming Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IncomingHam): **"ASSUMING DIRECT CONTROL."**

[It's Personal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsPersonal): It becomes increasingly obvious as the games and battles rage on that Shepard's touched a nerve in him, to say the least. He even goes so far as to make planetfall to try and blast Shepard to Kingdom Come himself during the climax of 3. He hates you *that* much.
QUOTE **Harbinger:** **Shepard! You have become an annoyance!**
[The Juggernaut](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheJuggernaut): Like the other Reapers.

[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): In the Synthesis ending, where he pulls a [Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn) and helps the galaxy rebuild along with the rest of the Reapers. Also in the Refusal ending, where he and the Reapers succeed in their harvest, though they're stopped the next time around.

[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal): The *only* way to kill him, along with the rest of the Reapers, is to choose the Destroy ending in *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)*.
[Large and in Charge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeAndInCharge): The largest and oldest of the Reapers, and unquestionably their leader.
[Law of Chromatic Superiority](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LawOfChromaticSuperiority): He tends to glow yellow instead of red like the rest of the Reapers.

[Man Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManBehindTheMan): The first time you fight the Collectors, you'll be shown the Collector General possessing lower ranking minions. At the end of the game, when the Collector General dies, you see the actual Reaper, Harbinger. Shepard can have a conversation with him at the end of *Arrival*.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName):
    - He's the spokes-monster of the Reaper fleet, and claims that the *real* war is coming all too soon. - According to Leviathan, Harbinger was the first Reaper, which makes his name doubly meaningful — it's the first of many Reapers. The harbinger of many, as it were.
[Mind over Matter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindOverMatter): Possessed Collectors gain advanced biotic abilities.
[Monster Progenitor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MonsterProgenitor): According to Leviathan, Harbinger was the first Reaper, and created all other Reapers in its own image.
[My Name Is Inigo Montoya](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyNameIsInigoMontoya): **"WE ARE HARBINGER."** And a few variations thereof.

[Never My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMyFault): Thanks to his [God Complex](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AGodAmI), nothing is ever his fault. For example, he blames the Collector General for the defeat at the Collector Base, but the General was *never* in control of its own actions — Harbinger was. In the face of the mass relay being destroyed at Aratoht, Harbinger will ignore the fact that he couldn't stop Shepard.

[Non-Indicative Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonIndicativeName): Harbinger is the first, largest, and most powerful of all the Reapers, as well as their apparent leader; insofar as the Reaper swarm can be said to have a leader. As such, a more appropriate name for him might be *Sovereign.*

[No-Nonsense Nemesis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNonsenseNemesis): Despite his many verbal taunts, Harbinger does not fuck around with Shepard. He has the Collectors ambush and kill Shepard in the first ten minutes of the second game and then spent years attempting to acquire their body to be completely sure that they're dead. Afterwards, he pulls all the stops and traps possible to kill Shepard again. This culminates in *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)*, when he abandons the space battle over Earth to personally come down and blast Shepard himself.

[Non-Standard Character Design](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonStandardCharacterDesign): He's the oldest of the Reapers, formed from the Leviathans, and his design reflects this: the "tentacles" are fewer, his "eyes" glow yellow and his "tail" section is doubled by a crest.
[Not So Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoStoic): He's very unflappable, but when Shepard begins throwing his plans down the poop chute, his stoicism begins to crack.
[People Puppets](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PeoplePuppets): Between possessing Collectors at will, and [indoctrination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl), you expected less?
[Possession Burnout](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PossessionBurnout): He visibly burns his hosts alive - their health is replaced with armor and they crumble to dust after defeat.

[Powers via Possession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowersViaPossession): He can apparently force this upon those he controls. Includes heavy shield/armor upgrades and biotic-singularity-throwing as a package deal.

[Rank Scales with Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RankScalesWithAsskicking): Being a Reaper and all. He's also apparently the oldest and most powerful Reaper. [Considering even one regular capital Reaper can wipe out an entire organic fleet and depopulate a city in under an hour](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheJuggernaut), [Harbinger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BiggerStick)'s power must be incredibly impressive. Too bad we never see him tearing through other ships.

[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): Every time a Collector level rolls around, you'll encounter him again. And again. And again. [And again...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImplacableMan)
[Resistance Is Futile](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ResistanceIsFutile): **"YOU CANNOT RESIST."** **"WHY DO YOU RESIST US, SHEPARD?"** **"EVOLUTION CANNOT BE STOPPED."** And so on.

[The Reveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReveal): He's a Reaper and the [Man Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManBehindTheMan). Taken further in the third game's *Leviathan* DLC: he was the first Reaper ever made.
[Sapient Ship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SapientShip): Like all Reapers.
[Say My Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SayMyName): In the climactic Battle of London in *3*, Harbinger himself will land by the transit beam, and will boomingly say **SHEPARD** with its *real* voice.

[Scripted Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScriptedBattle): His single appearance in *Mass Effect 3* is less of a battle and more you frantically trying to dodge his lasers while you run to the Conduit. No matter what happens, [he ends up hitting you](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureIsTheOnlyOption).
[Super Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperPrototype): He's the very first Reaper and boasts more raw firepower than any other member of his fleet.
[Time Abyss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeAbyss): He's the oldest of the Reapers. This makes him, at a minimum, well over a billion years old.
[Tragic Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicVillain): He's actually the first species to be converted into a Reaper.

[Transformation Is a Free Action](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TransformationIsAFreeAction): Averted. His [Transformation Sequence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TransformationSequence) is several seconds long and he doesn't do anything else in the meantime. Since the sequence causes him to briefly rise into the air and out of cover, this is always the best time to attack him.
[Transformation Sequence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TransformationSequence): Whichever Collector he possesses floats into the air and flows throughout the transformation.

[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): Not counting the innumerable fights with possessed Collectors, you never directly confront Harbinger. Subverted in Mass Effect 3. [Harbinger confronts the Alliance ground team directly and destroys them in less than a minute.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle)
[Unholy Nuke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnholyNuke): His version of Warp is a sci-fi equivalent.

[Villain Override](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainOverride): Basically his primary schtick in the second game, having already taken control of the Collector General prior to the start of the game.Expect him in-game to be bellowing out one of his many [Catch Phrases](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatchPhrase) whilst taking over a Collector mook. Surprisingly, he did away with the trope come the third game, probably because he brought in *the entire Reaper Fleet* with him.
QUOTE **Harbinger:** ***ASSUMING DIRECT CONTROL.***

[Villain Takes an Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainTakesAnInterest): After humanity led the united charge against Sovereign, he apparently decided that humanity were this cycle's dominant race and sent the Collectors after them. Judging by the contents of the Collector Ship and the Collector Base, Harbinger picked humanity to be the cycle's new Reaper and was eventually going to send the Collectors to attack and abduct the entire population of Earth so they could be broken down into the [Human Resources](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanResources) to power it.

[Wave-Motion Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WaveMotionGun): Taken to an even more absurd degree than the lesser Reapers, who at are most limited to a laser on each of their tentacles, totaling five. Harbinger has one in each of his six eyes and one on either mandible - that's *eight on his face alone*. And they see use at the climax of *3*. [Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle) doesn't even begin to describe it.
[We Have Reserves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHaveReserves): **"KILL ONE AND ONE HUNDRED WILL REPLACE IT." "LEAVE THE DEAD WHERE THEY FALL." "THIS FORM IS IRRELEVANT."**

[What the Hell Are You?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellAreYou): Gives a backhanded compliment that he considers Shepard to be [an annoyance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent) in *Arrival*. Considering the massive ego of Reapers, this is actually quite high praise. In *3*, a dying Reaper tells Shepard that Harbinger has spoken to them about Shepard.

tropeName: Why Don't You Just Shoot Him?
tropeNotes: [Why Don't You Just Shoot Him?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhyDontYouJustShootHim): Averted. Harbinger has his Collector goons simply destroy the *Normandy* and kill Shepard in the first ten minutes of the game. [No drama, no gloating, just surprise and overwhelming firepower.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNonsenseNemesis) And while it's not clear if Harbinger could have known about Cerberus' plans to resurrect Shepard, he did try to verify Shepard's demise by buying their dead body from the Shadow Broker. It didn't pan out, but he wanted proof and didn't [just assume Shepard was dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverFoundTheBody). Played *literally* when doing a [Villain Override](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainOverride). He's trying *to kill Shepard himself*. In the third game, he wastes no time firing at Shepard with his main gun. In the low EMS endings anyway; if the EMS is high enough, he won't fire at Shepard until after their squadmates have evacuated the battlefield. But either way, he hits his target with ease and it's a miracle Shepard survived the blast at all.

[You Have Failed Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveFailedMe): Abandons the Collectors and the Collector General to their destruction or purging at the end of the second game, declaring they'll find another way. Turns out, the Reapers had some Collectors in reserve as shown when they return in *3*.

[And I Must Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream):
    - What happens to the beings that he's received, including the abducted human colonists. - This also happens to be (SPOILER) the very reason why he even exists .
[Bait-and-Switch Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BaitAndSwitchBoss): Played up as the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) behind the collectors, but is really just a puppet to Harbinger.
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): Subverted.  (SPOILER) It's technically the highest-ranking Collector, but is more of a mouth piece and physical avatar for the real villain, Harbinger.
[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon):  (SPOILER) To Harbinger, being used as a mouthpiece .

[Dying as Yourself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DyingAsYourself): How much of a conscious mind he had outside of Harbinger's control is unclear; nonetheless, Harbinger releases its control over him, and he apparently does regain whatever was left of his own self, seconds before his death.
[Eye Lights Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyeLightsOut): Just before he dies  (SPOILER) because Harbinger has abandoned him .
[Meat Puppet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeatPuppet): For most the game and, in fact, most of his life, he's been used as a mouth piece by Harbinger.
[Mouth of Sauron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MouthOfSauron):  (SPOILER) An unusual case, in that we never meet the mouth in person, either , unless you play the *Arrival* DLC before the final mission.
[Nightmare Face](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NightmareFace): There's something unsettling about its face.

[Non-Standard Character Design](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonStandardCharacterDesign):  (SPOILER) It's not for decoration. One might notice when Sovereign "assumed direct control" of Saren or when Harbinger "assumes direct control" of regular Collectors, they burn out the bodies when they're done with it long enough. The Collector General is thicker and hardier, as Harbinger uses the General for long periods of time.
[Red Herring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedHerring):  (SPOILER) He's not the real villain, just a vessel Harbinger uses, and he was under Harbinger's control for 99% of his life .
[The Reveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReveal):  (SPOILER) He's not the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad); he's [The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon) and a former Prothean .

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): He looks an awful lot like [a member of another race of](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Series/BabylonFive) [Abusive Precursors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbusivePrecursors).
[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): Shepard never sees him directly, and possibly never interacts with him at all.
[Tragic Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicVillain):  (SPOILER) Since he was just being controlled by Harbinger the entire time. The knowledge that he's a Prothean Husk only adds to the tragedy.

[Woobie, Destroyer of Worlds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WoobieDestroyerOfWorlds):
    - (SPOILER) Many people feel sorry for it considering it was most likely under Harbinger's control its entire life and the ending cinematic has it looking around in what looks like confusion and sorrow when Harbinger releases control. Especially impressive considering it has less than ten minutes of screen time in the game and no dialogue outside being Harbinger's mouthpiece . - (SPOILER) If expressionless bug aliens could make an [Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap) face, that's what it would have done right then . - (SPOILER) Then again, there is an alternate interpretation. Given how the Collector General slowly turns its head towards the explosion and makes no move to escape, perhaps it was still self-aware enough to realise [what it had become](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream) [and didn't try to escape so its suffering would end](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DyingAsYourself) .
[You Have Failed Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveFailedMe): Harbinger tells him this, word for word, after the destruction of the human-reaper.
[Abusive Precursors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbusivePrecursors): It is a Reaper.
[Almost Dead Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlmostDeadGuy): Justified as it is a mechanical [Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination).
[Cool Starship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolStarship): It *is* the starship.
[Dented Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DentedIron): It has this appearance.

tropeName: Did You Just Punch Out Cthulhu?
tropeNotes: [Did You Just Punch Out Cthulhu?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidYouJustPunchOutCthulhu): Was on the receiving end of this, [but even a dead god can dream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut).

[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): It is a [squid-shaped starship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchStarship). In fact, it's conscious and able to fight you, in a way, despite being dead.

[Eldritch Location](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchLocation): Played with. Its interior corridors are described as having disorienting, oppressive contours. See [Womb Level](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WombLevel) below for more.

[Fighting a Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingAShadow): Played with. At first the closest you get to fighting it in the game is through the waves of husks that attack you. Then you get to its power core and have to destroy it, during which it sends waves of husks to stop you.
[Load-Bearing Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoadBearingBoss): Justified as you're [fighting inside the boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WombLevel).
[Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindControl): Indoctrination. This is where it's revealed that Reapers can do it even when they're dead.
[Mind Rape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape): Indoctrination.

[Nigh-Invulnerability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NighInvulnerability): Though it's badly damaged, a glancing shot from the weapon that crippled it gouged a canyon out of the surface of a planet that can be seen from space.
[Night of the Living Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NightOfTheLivingMooks): Summons waves of husks and scions to attack you, heavily implied to be made from the huskfied remains of the Cerberus team.
[Only Mostly Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyMostlyDead): Justified as it is a bio-mechanical warship.
[Reality Warper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealityWarper): Of the [Mind Rape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape) variety, as seen in the quote above.
[Sapient Ship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SapientShip): Par for the course when it comes to the Reapers, though in this case, a nearly dead one.

[Time Abyss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeAbyss): Doctor Chandana and his team establish that a race in a cycle 37 million years ago managed to hole it with a mass effect supergun. It predates modern mammals, and apparently Harbinger didn't know it was still intact since he never attempted to find and repair it, but it can still turn humans into various Husk-forms.
[The Voiceless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheVoiceless): It never speaks.

[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): Simply realizing its existence and that its nature infers it is *a character* is a spoiler in and of itself, as that's not revealed until after the attack on the Collector ship (more than halfway through the game, at minimum).
[Womb Level](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WombLevel): The fight against the Derelict Reaper takes place inside it.

[And I Must Scream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream): According to Legion, individuals, despite being reduced to grey goo, all retain their intelligence (much like Geth run-times in a single platform.)
[Attack Its Weak Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackItsWeakPoint): Its eyes and chest, to be precise. Bonus points that said junctions are *literally* labeled "Weak Point".
[Background Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BackgroundBoss): Pops in and out of the background to make his attacks.
[Breath Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreathWeapon): Has a cannon in his mouth.

[The Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCameo): Appears towards the end of the Cerberus Base in *Mass Effect 3*, though it's inactive and heavily damaged. Depending on whether you left the Collector Base intact or not, you'll salvage either its heart or its brain as a War Asset.
[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): Being a Reaper.

[Fetus Terrible](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FetusTerrible): In Reaper terms, it hasn't even come close to being born yet. It was even at one point [supposed to be a giant Husk-ified human fetus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatCouldHaveBeen).
[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss): Of the second game.
[Go for the Eye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoForTheEye): Its eyes are two of its weak points. The other points are in its mouth and on its stomach.
[Humongous Mecha](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumongousMecha): And it's still mostly incomplete.

[It Can Think](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItCanThink): At first glance, EDI isn't even certain whether it's alive (for want of a better term) or not. Once Shepard shoots out the tubes, it turns out that, yep, it’s alive enough. And Shep just made it angry.
[Load-Bearing Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoadBearingBoss): The area it resides in starts falling apart after you defeat the Reaper.

[Nightmare Face](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NightmareFace): Take the infamous Terminator skull coming through the flames, add a few extra bits and pieces, and bump up the size to a ten story skyscraper. That's this thing.

[Non-Standard Character Design](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonStandardCharacterDesign): Compared to other Reapers, who's strange Cthulhu shape isn't even close to the humanoid appearance of the Human Reaper-Larva. It was [eventually revealed by Bioware](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WordOfGod) that the Larva would be the core of a Reaper "shell", which is the tentacled form we know from Harbinger and Sovereign, and that all other Reapers (perhaps with the exception of Harbinger) are made like this, preserving a sort of "effigy" of the race used to create it within each one. Concept art has the Human Reaper's spine and arms eventually becoming three of the reaper's arms.
[Powered by a Forsaken Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoweredByAForsakenChild): Is filled with millions of humans who were turned into [Gray Goo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrayGoo).
[The Reveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReveal): The Reapers have been kidnapping entire human colonies to create the biological component of this new Reaper.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): Bears a strong resemblance to the God Warriors from *[Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Manga/NausicaaOfTheValleyOfTheWind)*, particularly the grotesque, incomplete movie version by [Hideaki Anno](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/HideakiAnno).
[SkeleBot 9000](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SkeleBot9000): Even looks a lot like the Terminator.
[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): Its very existence is a major twist only revealed in the final level of *Mass Effect 2*.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Ambiguous Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguousGender): Of the very little that's known about the Broker, their gender (or, as Barla Von points out, even whether the Broker is a single person or a group of agents operating under a singular title) is not among it.  (SPOILER)  The Broker is revealed to be male .

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes:
[Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy):
    - (SPOILER) Liara considers the Broker to be hers after the events of *Redemption*. - The Illusive Man considers also the Broker "[his equal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent)" in terms of influence and intelligence gathering, and vice versa.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): Main antagonist of the *Lair of the Shadow Broker* DLC, as well as *Redemption*, a comic set between Shepard's death and revival.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes:
[Authority Grants Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorityGrantsAsskicking):
    - In the *Lair of the Shadow Broker* DLC, (SPOILER) he's the biggest and deadliest enemy you face. Also, (SPOILER) [Asskicking Leads to Leadership](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership) since he took control of the previous Shadow Broker's organization by starting off as a "pet" and then killing him. - The codex mentions that (SPOILER) his entire species are like this; they sort themselves into packs, and fight either physically or intellectually to discover the strongest. It also says that the losers generally accept the winner's authority without bearing grudges, and former enemies have no trouble working together once the hierarchy has been established. - This provides a possible alternative reason for (SPOILER) the fact that his personal computers lack any kind of security (beyond the rather significant fact that any intruder would have to get past him); Liara assumes it's because he never anticipated anyone being in a position to use them, but it's possible that the yahg tendency to not undermine those who have proven their superiority caused him to be a [Graceful Loser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GracefulLoser) with his resources, and not try to sabotage anyone who was strong enough to beat him. His predecessor tried to sabotage him in case he won, but was [stopped](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledMidSentence) before completing it.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Badass in a Nice Suit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassInANiceSuit): The Shadow Broker, despite his tremendous size and alien physique, wears an outfit that resembles a *business suit*, from the outer layer having folds that resemble the collar of a blazer down to the white armor beneath looking like a dress shirt and tie. Crosses over with [Man of Wealth and Taste](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManOfWealthAndTaste), as the outfit is clearly something he had to have tailored to fit his massive frame.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss): Treats his "employees" as quite disposable. He allows a  (SPOILER)  Spectre who works for him to off one of his agents to disguise her role in the killing of a loose end. He even dismisses the Spectre's death as costing him nothing but time.  He tortures Feron for betraying him and has his agents watch [to make sure they're properly motivated](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousDemotivator). When you've practically cleaned out his men, he basically shrugs and says [they're easily replaceable.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHaveReserves)

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton):  (SPOILER)  Calling him a slave. Or a *pet.*

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [The Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCameo): Makes a brief audio appearance in *Andromeda*, in one of Alec Ryder's audio files.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Characterization Marches On](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterizationMarchesOn): While he didn't physically appear in the first game, the way he was talked about by other characters indicated that he’s a neutral [information broker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnowledgeBroker) who’s neither benevolent nor hostile, always trying to preserve the balance of power. As of the second game however, he’s presented as a clear villain, who’s greedy above everything else.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [The Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster): The best player in the game, according to Anderson. The Broker somehow manages to sell info to everybody, but ensures that no faction ever gains the upper hand with it, and has been successfully doing so for decades. (Gotta keep those customers somehow.)

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Evil Is Bigger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsBigger): When he's finally revealed, the  (SPOILER) current  Shadow Broker is seated behind a desk and looks to be roughly the size of a Krogan. Once he loses his cool, he [tosses his desk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlippingTheTable) aside and stands up... and stands... and *keeps standing up* until he's revealed to be at least thrice as tall as [Grunt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBigGuy) and just as wide.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Evil Sounds Deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSoundsDeep): At first you think the Broker's using a computer to distort their voice/hide their identity. Then you meet  (SPOILER) him , and realize that it really is the Broker's voice, with subtle electronic alteration.  (SPOILER) Although it strains credibility for the synthesizer to transform Liara's voice into the same thing after she takes over, it's likely that the computer keeps the inflection and tone and converts the actual voice to a standard. It's also possible that Liara made the computer do that .

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Flipping the Table](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlippingTheTable): He throws his solid metal desk at the party, knocking Shepard's other squaddie unconscious.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [From Nobody to Nightmare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FromNobodyToNightmare): He started off as the last Shadow Broker's  (SPOILER) *pet.*

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Genius Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser): He speaks eleven languages without a translator (no small feat,  (SPOILER) considering how his mouth is shaped ), and has the savvy needed to run his network.  (SPOILER) He also happens to be larger than most krogan, and uses [The Berserker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBerserker) style of combat.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Giant Space Flea from Nowhere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GiantSpaceFleaFromNowhere):  (SPOILER) The yahg were  never even heard of until the DLC, and the (SPOILER)  species is completely different from *any* that had come before . It's handwaved by  (SPOILER) the yahg's homeworld being blacklisted by the Council due to their uncontrollably violent nature. Thankfully, Liara defied his taunt about ignorant fumbling and figured out enough about him to press his [Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton).

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Good Old Fisticuffs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodOldFisticuffs): Once he [takes enough damage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnsRed) he summons a totally bulletproof barrier to hide behind and recuperate.  (SPOILER) Shepard responds by seeing if it's fist-proof. It's not.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Hidden Agenda Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenAgendaVillain): Possibly the only antagonist more [elusive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IncrediblyLamePun) than the Illusive Man.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [It's Personal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsPersonal): The one exception to his agenda otherwise being entirely about procuring and dealing information is the destruction of Cerberus. His comments on the third squadmate brought to the encounter generally range from selling or dissecting bodies of interesting subjects (Jack, Grunt, Legion), collecting bounties (Garrus, Zaeed, Mordin, Kasumi), or just general comments on the squadmate's abilities (Thane, Samara, Tali). Bring Jacob or Miranda to the fight, however, and the Shadow Broker proclaims that killing both that one and Shepard will cripple Cerberus.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Kill and Replace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillAndReplace):  (SPOILER) How the mantle of the Broker ultimately changes hands, first from the original Broker to Operative Kechlu, and then from Operative Kechlu to Liara. Absolutely no one in the Broker's organization aside from Feron are aware of this.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Klingon Promotion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KlingonPromotion):  (SPOILER) How the current Broker came to power, and it's entirely appropriate given how yahg culture operates.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Knowledge Broker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnowledgeBroker): An *incredibly* good one, with access to the most privileged information in the universe. Even the Illusive Man, a figure so secretive that most people are unaware he even exists, can keep no secrets from the Shadow Broker, who knows about his private life in such detail that his dossier includes *which specific suit he is wearing that day*.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Large and in Charge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeAndInCharge):  (SPOILER) The yahg Shadow Broker is even larger than a *krogan*.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes:
[Legacy Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegacyCharacter):
    - He became the Shadow Broker after (SPOILER) *secretly killing the previous one.* As Liara ends up doing **the exact same thing**, it's implied that his predecessor wasn't the original Broker either. - (SPOILER) *"Operative Kechlu"* was the name of the agent the Shadow Broker sent to find him. After he was dead, the previous Shadow Broker sent a message that essentially said, "Congratulations, *you* are now Operative Kechlu".

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeName: More Teeth than the Osmond Family
tropeNotes: [More Teeth than the Osmond Family](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreTeethThanTheOsmondFamily): Seems to be  (SPOILER) a given among the yahg.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [N.G.O. Superpower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NGOSuperpower): For good reason; when your organization spans most of the galaxy, has hands in business and political interests in nearly everything in said galaxy, *and* specializes in collecting and using information to both support those interests and manipulate governments and corporations, you definitely should have impressive resources. The Broker owns a personal army capable of deploying hundreds of loyal soldiers in *minutes* on Illium alone, along with a supremely well-engineered atmospheric airbase-warship, and the enormous amounts of money, hardware, and political influence one would expect from an organization of this scale.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [No Name Given](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNameGiven): All [he's/she's/they're/it's](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PronounTrouble) known by is "the Shadow Broker."

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Outside-Context Problem](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutsideContextProblem): Even if you've played both games. Even the usual tactics of assuming that loyalty missions play to the strength of the character involved won't help you too much. Expect the unexpected.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy):  (SPOILER) The Lair of the Shadow Broker DLC reveals that the SB's reason for giving Shepard's body to the Collectors was his attempt to pacify the Reapers and save the galaxy. Of course, his primary reason was to save his own skin and his power.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [The Reveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReveal): "Lair Of The Shadow Broker" clears up several of the questions surrounding the Broker.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Stranger Behind the Mask](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrangerBehindTheMask): After so much build up around his identity, the *Lair of the Shadow Broker* reveals that  (SPOILER) he's a member of a species that had never before been seen or mentioned in the series. At least unique in that while Shepard has no clue on what it is, Liara does, and manages to send it into a [Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown) based on a paragraph's worth of information on his species .

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes: [Supervillain Lair](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SupervillainLair): One that would make [Blofeld](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Characters/JamesBondBlofeld) himself jealous. It's a massive ship that permanently orbits a planet with an extremely volatile atmosphere which conceals its presence. A private army of mercs and drones patrol and maintain the dangerous exterior, giant conductor rods that collect energy from the lightning storms, private detention centers, and torture facilities, and private quarters where he catalogs and utilizes secrets and informants that span the whole galaxy. Liara and Shephard both wonder what happened to the contractors that actually built it, [before concluding the obvious](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness).

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
tropeNotes:
[To Serve Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToServeMan): Implied with one of Feron's lines about the Shadow Broker, albeit for all aliens who come by, not just humans.  (SPOILER) Remember the Yahg are apex-predators on their homeworld, there's only one way in and out of his main room, and you never see anything that indicates it holds food in his quarters. 
QUOTE **Feron:** Not everyone who enters his office comes back out.

VGDCName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
TvTName: The Shadow Broker, AKA Operative Kechlu
