tropeNotes: [The Corrupter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCorrupter): Gavin Archer even equates him with the devil when quitting Cerberus. If the Overlord DLC was never followed, he just outright says TIM corrupts everything he touches.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Creepy Blue Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreepyBlueEyes): And they *glow*. What's especially noteworthy is that they look similar to Saren's eyes from the first game, possibly to hint that  (SPOILER) both have been touched by Reapers .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Cunning Linguist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CunningLinguist): Apparently can speak the asari and turian dialects unaided by universal translator, although this is seemingly because of  (SPOILER) the Reaper tech he was implanted with .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Cutscene Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutsceneBoss):  (SPOILER) At the end of the third game, you will either be able to [convince him to kill himself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TalkingTheMonsterToDeath), [like with Saren in the first game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallBack), or you'll have to take him out using one of two [Renegade interrupts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuickTimeEvent). Not taking either of them results in a [Nonstandard Game Over](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonstandardGameOver).

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeName: The Dark Side Will Make You Forget
tropeNotes:
[The Dark Side Will Make You Forget](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDarkSideWillMakeYouForget): The Illusive Man was already a [Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist) at best, [racist NGO](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism) at worst, but Shepard reminds him that being indoctrinated has made him stray from his original goals.
QUOTE  **Paragon Shepard:** You've forgotten everything you've stood for, Cerberus was supposed to be humanity's sword, not a dagger in our back.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Devil in Plain Sight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DevilInPlainSight): Doesn't matter whether Shepard is Paragon or Renegade; you always get dialogue options about whether or not the Illusive Man is trustworthy and whether he knows more than he lets on at the end of several missions (in both cases, often to his face). Granted, a lot of this has to do with Cerberus's reputation and the player's experience of them in the previous game, but even so, it's clear that Shepard and other characters are wary of him and his organization, especially as the game goes on and it becomes more and more obvious that they are still up to no good.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Disc-One Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalBoss): He is the last hurdle Shepard has to overcome before meeting  (SPOILER)  the Catalyst, the true [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) of the trilogy. Appropriately enough, Shepard also first deals with Cerberus as a whole before the final battle against the Reapers .

tropeNotes: [Driven to Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide):  (SPOILER) If Shepard can make him realize that he's being indoctrinated during their last conversation, he will choose to shoot himself.

It's so... perfect." - (SPOILER) If Shepard helps him realize he has been indoctrinated, he says "I... tried." in regards to controlling the Reapers. He then kills himself to prevent them from using him any more.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Electronic Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElectronicEyes):  (SPOILER)  After being blinded by a Reaper artifact sometime in the past, he underwent cybernetic implants to his irises in order to restore his vision.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Empathic Environment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmpathicEnvironment): His office, after the Suicide Mission.  (SPOILER) If Shepard made the Paragon decision at the end of the mission, the star will turn blue. Otherwise (i.e., the Renegade decision) it will turn red . Averted if Shepard doesn't survive. Regardless of what became of the Collector Base, the star will remain its normal color (orange with hues of blue).

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes:
[Enemy Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine):
    - *Mass Effect 2* revolves around an uneasy alliance between him and Shepard. Previously, he had one with Liara to secure Shepard's body from the Shadow Broker. - He seems to consider cooperating with non-humans as this kind of arrangement. Which is ironic, considering that he helped save the entire turian race from indoctrination back when he was still a mercenary.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes:
[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards):
    - The Cerberus facility that created Jack was actually a rogue facility outside his approval, and he ordered *all* of the surviving scientists from the project executed once he learned precisely what they were doing. Furthermore, his e-mail responses to both the Paragon and Renegade endings of the [Project Overlord incident](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DLC) give further credence to the idea that he still tries to maintain *some* ethical standards in his research projects. - However, his response to "Overlord"'s Renegade ending claims that while he thought the experiments went too far, he's happy that Shepard decided to keep the research subject within Cerberus. For the Paragon ending, he complains that "Though your decision is understandable, it has set our efforts to understand the geth back several years." It's possible that while the Illusive Man would happily reap the fruits of even the most unethical projects, he values Shepard's loyalty enough to go along with what they choose to do. - An email found in one quest in *Andromeda* shows he fired two scientists for this, though it's case of this and "Evil Thinks Your Idea is Completely Stupid" (which, given some of the other [''brilliant''](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SarcasmMode) ideas Cerberus signed off on...). He thought their idea for creating a hive mind was insane and impractical.
      - [Which actually makes sense](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FridgeBrilliance). He has Collector/Reaper tech on hand to do any brainwashing he wants to do, rendering a hive mind device pointless. He outright states in the scientists' termination letter that they have other "methods that show great potential for mental control over large groups of people."

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Evil Cannot Comprehend Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCannotComprehendGood): He believes that Shepard will always understand what he hopes to accomplish,  (SPOILER) even when it means using a base where hundreds of thousands of humans were liquefied as fuel for a Human Reaper-Larva . He also fails to see Miranda ever betraying him because he thought she was completely loyal to him.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes:
[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart):
    - Serves as one for Admiral Hackett in *3*, where they both are described as leaders of humanity (Cerberus and the Alliance respectively), both are gathering resources and intel to defeat the Reapers and both have sent Shepard on black ops missions in previous games. - His backstory in the comic *[Mass Effect Evolution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/ComicBook/MassEffectEvolution)* also makes him one to Shepard. Both were soldiers who received visions from an alien artifact that would lead them on the path to become major players in galactic civilization. Both of them were also willing to fight the Reapers rather than lay down and die. The difference is that Shepard understands the need to work with others whereas the Illusive Man arrogantly tried to shoulder the burden alone.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Evil Is Not a Toy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsNotAToy):  (SPOILER) As magnificent as he was, he was still way out of his league attempting to take control of the Reapers.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Evil Mentor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilMentor): Tries to be one to Shepard in *Mass Effect 2*, though it's entirely up to the player whether or not Shepard actually follows him.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [The Extremist Was Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheExtremistWasRight): His conviction that the Crucible can be used to control the Reapers is taken as simply further evidence of his rapidly-advancing insanity by Shepard and their allies, but  (SPOILER) not only does he turn out to be right, but there's an argument to be made for it being the most moral (or, at least, least immoral) resolution to the war. The one thing he was mistaken about was his own ability to control the Reapers, since he'd already been indoctrinated .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Face Framed in Shadow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceFramedInShadow): Although his facial features can occasionally be seen.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Fallen Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallenHero):  (SPOILER)  For a given definition of hero. From a self-made power broker who’d been thwarting Reapers since the First Contact War to an incoherently rambling slave, the Illusive Man ends his life as a faint shadow of what he stood for as Jack Harper .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Sort of; while he clearly seeks to see humans dominate the other races, at the same time he does express respect for the achievements of others, and he did save the turians from being enslaved by Desolas (Saren's brother) back before he founded Cerberus. He's also willing to work with nonhumans towards important goals so long as they benefit Cerberus and humanity, like stopping the Collectors, and  (SPOILER)  his openness to doing so is actually a major reason why Brooks abandons Cerberus.  This mostly stops in the third game, with him becoming a full-blown liability to the galaxy's fight against the Reapers  (SPOILER) but that's because he's been indoctrinated .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Fatal Flaw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatalFlaw): His [pride](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Pride). He's so convinced that the ends justify the means,  (SPOILER)  it leads to himself and the entirety of Cerberus getting indoctrinated by the Reapers .

TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper

And build an improved version of the most advanced experimental starship in the galaxy while he was at it. And this didn't really impede any of his other operations.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Fighting from the Inside](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightingFromTheInside):  (SPOILER)  A Paragon Shepard can help the Illusive Man realize he is indoctrinated. VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss):  (SPOILER) He is the last antagonist confronted in the trilogy, although he's a [Cutscene Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutsceneBoss). <sup>note </sup>  Unused concept art indicates the developers were considering the idea of turning him into a Reaperfied monstrosity and having a proper final battle with him, but it was scrapped for not being true to his character and for being too "videogamey" — and they *did* that with Saren already.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing). In *2*, TIM mentions his eyes are enhanced by Reaper technology. You don't say. <sup>note </sup>  Reaper technology, however, doesn't indoctrinate. Contact with Reapers, even *dead* ones, does, so it's probable TIM could have investigated the Leviathan of Dis or his experimentation in creating Husks got him *too* close to the Reapers' influence.

tropeNotes: [Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): Normally, he's not like this. But in *3*,  (SPOILER)  during his [Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown), he starts channeling [Palpatine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StarWars) when Shepard points out the fact he's indoctrinated and his plan to control the Reapers will not work .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes:
[Last-Second Chance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastSecondChance): Paragon Shepard will keep offering this. The only reason TIM doesn't accept is that he's indoctrinated.
QUOTE **The Illusive Man:** Your idealism is... admirable, Shepard.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard): Although he is not as manipulative as he wants to think, what with trying (and failing) to persuade Paragon Shepard to  (SPOILER) save the Collector Base .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Mean Character, Nice Actor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeanCharacterNiceActor): Martin Sheen has gone on [record](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OSFMZ1nWVv8) saying that he finds the Illusive Man "horrible" and untrustworthy.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Everything, *everything* related to this man is covered in layers upon layers of meticulously planned deception.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Mirror Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MirrorCharacter): The Illusive Man's development in *3* is rather parallel to Saren's from the first game: they both are [Well-Intentioned Extremists](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist) who cross many moral boundaries to deal with the Reaper threat.  (SPOILER)  While Saren feels that he can work with the Reapers to save all organic life, TIM decides to try to find a way to control them and uplift humanity. They both even justify their actions with the *exact same* argument; "the Reapers never truly wiped out all organics". Both of their paths lead to them getting Reaper implants, making them easier to be indoctrinated. In the end, they both can also die in the same exact way, committing suicide if Shepard manages to convince them that the Reapers are controlling them.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Motive Decay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MotiveDecay):  (SPOILER)  Indoctrination can do that. If every Paragon response is chosen, you can see him visibly struggling against his indoctrination during the Thessia mission, where he falters for a moment when Shepard asks him [how can he possibly justify betraying humanity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmourPiercingQuestion) by fighting them, instead of the *Reapers?!*

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): If you convince him that  (SPOILER) he's been indoctrinated  and that his actions have brought humanity to the brink of destruction, he shows great regret  (SPOILER) before committing suicide .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Mysterious Employer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysteriousEmployer): None of his subordinates know anything about him and the smart ones know better than to attempt to rectify that. In fact, many who work under his agents have no idea they're following his orders. Doubles as a [Mysterious Backer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysteriousBacker) in general.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Near-Villain Victory](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NearVillainVictory): The only thing that stopped him from achieving his goal — dominating the Reapers as Shepard potentially can do as an ending — is the fact that he was indoctrinated.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes:
[Necessarily Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NecessarilyEvil): His stance on some of his actions in *2* and just about everything he does in *3*.
QUOTE  "You think because I'm willing to use the enemy's tactics, that they're no longer my enemy?"

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Nice Job Fixing It, Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobFixingItVillain): He vetoed Miranda when she suggested implanting Shepard with a control chip, when it would've undoubtedly made his job much easier in the long run. Shepard even [comments](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging) on this when told by Miranda in *3*, saying that they figured it would've saved the Illusive Man a lot of trouble.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Non-Action Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionBigBad): In every appearance with him as an antagonist. He never takes to the battlefield himself in these appearances, instead sending his lackeys to do all the heavy lifting. Justified because his real strengths are [his charisma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCharmer), [his vast monetary resources](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Fiction500) and [his ability to manipulate people](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster), and with a number of powerful specialists and a whole army of [Elite Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteMooks) at his disposal, there's no reason to take to the field himself.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Not Me This Time](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotMeThisTime): At the end of Jacob's loyalty mission, Jacob accuses him of doing his usual manipulative thing by forwarding the Hugo Gernsback information to him. The Illusive Man truthfully denies it - it was actually Miranda.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Not So Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoStoic): For most of the two games he's in he maintains a calm demeanor. However, during the final confrontation, if you use the persuasion options he starts to sound increasingly angry and desperate, culminating in him  (SPOILER) trying to shoot Shepard or taking his own life .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Not-So-Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoWellIntentionedExtremist): He claims he wants the best for humanity, but humanity and Cerberus are the same thing in his mind. Even though he is very sincere in leveraging Shepard's talents to combat the Reaper threat and has a knack for drawing in genuinely honorable and talented people, he fails to truly appreciate the severe downsides of his ethically compromised operations. By *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)*, the reputation of Cerberus has decayed to the point where some of his most talented and even most dedicated employees want nothing to do with him and his goal has shifted from *fighting the Reapers* to *controlling their power*, though ironically, at this point, he's been indoctrinated, dooming his plans from the outset.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [No, You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoYou): A sign of just how far he's fallen in *3*, on Thessia, when a Renegade dialogue prompt has Shepard call him out on his actions thus far and how they're hurting humanity, is that he responds with a slightly more eloquent version of this.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [O.O.C. Is Serious Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OOCIsSeriousBusiness): He remains extraordinarily calm and coolheaded in basically all of his scenes, even in *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)* when the Reapers have invaded and  (SPOILER) Cerberus is completely falling apart . He only gets upset in two very specific scenes:  (SPOILER) the Paragon ending of *[Mass Effect 2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect2)*, in which he chews out Shepard for destroying the Collector Base, and the ending of *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)* when he's confronted by Shepard and Anderson on a Reaper-occupied Citadel . Both are extremely important character moments for him.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [People Puppets](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PeoplePuppets):  (SPOILER) He gains this power after getting Reaper implants. He uses it to hold Shepard and Anderson in place as he monologues and also to force Shepard to shoot their mentor.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Personality Powers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PersonalityPowers): He's a skilled manipulator and chessmaster who  (SPOILER) gains the ability to control people's bodies. Ironically, he only gains these powers because he himself is being manipulated.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): He complies with his employees' requests and is willing to work with aliens so long as it suits his goals. He even went as far as refusing to contain Shepard with a control-chip, despite knowing full well that their morals were at odds with those of Cerberus, because he believed that preserving Shepard's true personality was critical to stopping the Reapers.  (SPOILER) The fact that he abandons this pragmatism in *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)* despite this making him an enemy of both Shepard and *all of galactic civilization* is a telltale sign that something has gone *very* wrong with his mind.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Psychotic Smirk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychoticSmirk):  (SPOILER) Give him the Collector Base at the end of the game, and he'll have a rather creepy one of these .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Really Gets Around](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallyGetsAround): According to his Shadow Broker dossier, he's something of a [pornomancer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePornomancer), though [there could be one](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmpoweredBadassNormal), maybe [two reasons for that](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RuleOfCool).

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Presents himself as such during his working relationship with Shepard. He gives the commander plenty of resources and broad discretion about how to oppose the Collectors.  (SPOILER) The only time when he stops acting this way is in the Paragon ending of *2*, where he makes it clear he would've stopped Shepard from destroying the Collector Base if he could have.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Red Right Hand](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedRightHand): Creepy, synthetic, glowing eyeballs.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Shadow Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShadowArchetype): He's essentially what a Renegade Shepard could grow into after becoming too old to fight on the front lines.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes:
[Shut Up, Hannibal!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpHannibal):
    - (SPOILER) What Paragon Shepard does to him after destroying the Collector Base. Bonus points for Miranda doing it too, when asked to convince them not to do it. Extra bonus points for "Shut up" being the actual dialogue option that shows up on screen . QUOTE **Renegade Shepard:** I'm sorry, I'm having trouble hearing you, I'm getting a lot of bullshit on this line. - (SPOILER) The whole of the final confrontation with him in the third game consists of this combined with a healthy dose of [Kirk Summation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KirkSummation) and ["The Reason You Suck" Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReasonYouSuckSpeech) .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes:
[Shut Up, Kirk!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpKirk): In *3*, he tends to stumble a bit whenever Shepard reminds him that [it is illogical for them to be fighting each other amidst the Reaper invasion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeAreStrugglingTogether), and resisting Shepard's Last Second Chances actually *causes him pain*, but he is still able to bite back with this.
QUOTE Don't ever question my intentions. I've sacrificed more for humanity than you'll ever know.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Slouch of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlouchOfVillainy): He sits rather casually in his lounge chair most of the time.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes:
[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake):
    - Not as bad as Leng (being voiced by [Martin Sheen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/MartinSheen) helps), but prevalent in *3*. Constantly giving arrogant lectures to Shepard whenever they meet, never truly explaining his motives beyond human supremacy, and never willing to admit there could be a better option. As with most smug snakes, many of his arguments are [full of holes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LogicalFallacies). A number of his remarks are also often accompanied by an annoyingly smug grin. (SPOILER) Of course, indoctrination has the effect of making even the best [Evil Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGenius) into a [Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake). A telltale sign he's indoctrinated is when he politely tells Shepard not to interfere anymore, as if that's supposed to deter them. Both Saren and Amanda Kenson before him had done the same, and all three ultimately devolved into child-like whining when the indoctrination became most severe and when their plans started to fall apart . - This is also very much present in *2*, though hidden more because most of his questionable schemes do not involve antagonizing Shepard. Several of the operations he funds result in [hilarious failures](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EpicFail) causing him to beg Shepard to clean up said messes. However, this trope truly reaches its head at the Collector Base, where he's utterly *shocked* (and enraged) if Shepard chooses to blow up the base rather than hand it to him. Even if Shepard had spent the whole game as a Paragon whose every word to TIM dripped with contempt.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [The Social Darwinist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSocialDarwinist): Develops shades of this in *3* (an attitude Kai Leng embraces wholeheartedly). In this case, "evolution" =  (SPOILER)  becoming Reaper-tech transhumans .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Spanner in the Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpannerInTheWorks): Part of how Cerberus operates in *3*.  (SPOILER) Attacking Sur'Kesh to kill the fertile females, and attempting to set off a turian bomb on Tuchanka in order to prevent races from uniting. And if Shepard is diligent, Shepard spanners them right back every time.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Space Base](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpaceBase): The Illusive Man's personal base - the Cronos Station - is an unobtrusive mobile space station that periodically moves from system to system to remain hidden. Primarily orbiting minor supergiant stars, using the bursts of solar output to become nearly imperceptible. Only top-level agents are allowed to know about its existence, much less visit, mainly using steganographic extranet messages or personal quantum communicators to relay information.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Start of Darkness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StartOfDarkness): The events of *[Mass Effect Evolution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/ComicBook/MassEffectEvolution)* detail his.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Suspiciously Similar Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySimilarSubstitute): To  (SPOILER) Saren  in *Mass Effect 3*.  (SPOILER) Both seek to use the Reapers as a means to secure the dominance of their race, and end up indoctrinated and implanted with Reaper tech for their efforts. Shepard can even talk the Illusive Man into suicide in an almost exact replication of Saren. According to a Prothean VI, every cycle has groups like these that emerge.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Talking the Monster to Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TalkingTheMonsterToDeath):  (SPOILER) You can convince him to kill himself at the end of *Mass Effect 3*. However, unlike with the encounter with Saren in the first game, which just requires a bunch of points in the Charm or Intimidate skills, the dialogue option to do this with the Illusive Man is *very* [difficult to unlock](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuideDangIt); you have to have a completely full Reputation bar, *and* have to have taken all of the Persuade options in *every conversation you have with him during the game*, which means taking every left "tell me more" option to add additional dialog options.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Touched by Vorlons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TouchedByVorlons):  (SPOILER) Before becoming the Illusive Man, he was exposed to a Reaper artifact that had an effect on him and is strongly implied to be the reason behind some of his personal abilities.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Tom the Dark Lord](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TomTheDarkLord): His real name is  (SPOILER) Jack .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Totalitarian Utilitarian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TotalitarianUtilitarian): It's quite telling how he tends to refer to his employees as "resources".

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes:
[Tranquil Fury](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TranquilFury): If you destroy the Collector base it's pretty clear that despite his relatively calm demeanor he's absolutely livid when Shepard confronts him in the debriefing. Given that he invested untold money and resources into resurrecting Shepard, rebuilding the Normandy, and preparing the mission only to have the resources he was after be destroyed it's easy to see why.
QUOTE **Illusive Man:** Shepard. You're making a habit of costing me more than time and money.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [The Unfettered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfettered): Is willing to allow any manner of *horrible* experiments happen to people in order to secure human dominance, even if those experiments are on other humans.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): In *Mass Effect 3*. This is slightly justified since he is a [Non-Action Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionBigBad).  <sup>note </sup>  Unused concept art indicates that the developers were considering the idea of turning him into a [Reaperfied monstrosity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneWingedAngel) and having a proper final battle with him, but they decided that it didn't fit his character whose weapon had always been his mind/ideals and for being too "videogamey" — and they already *did* that with Saren in the first game.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Ungrateful Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UngratefulBastard): Cerberus will oppose Shepard in *Mass Effect 3* regardless of whether or not they  (SPOILER) decided to destroy the Collector Base ,  (SPOILER) though it later becomes clear that this is largely due to indoctrination .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes:
[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): To the Reapers. He thinks he is working against them, but is unwittingly indoctrinated by them. He also serves as a case of [History Repeats Itself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HistoryRepeatsItself), as during the Prothean cycle, there was also a faction who tried to control the Reapers instead of destroying them and only helped them divide the galaxy to make the harvest more easy and were later discovered to be indoctrinated.
QUOTE **Shepard:** So...the Illusive Man was right after all?

QUOTE **The Catalyst:** Yes, but he could never have taken control, because we already controlled him.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Utopia Justifies the Means](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UtopiaJustifiesTheMeans): His grand Utopian vision is that of a galaxy where humanity is in charge and never has to fear being threatened or dominated by another alien race ever again. There are very few (if any) lengths he'll not go to in the name of realizing that vision.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes:
[Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown):
    - (SPOILER) If you destroy the Collector Base . He doesn't rant and rave, but he's clearly *not pleased* that (SPOILER) Shepard basically gave him the middle finger and told him they're doing things Shepard's way from now on, or he can sod off . His last words before being cut off are even a pathetic "Think about everything Cerberus has done for you!" - In *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)*, he has a pretty epic one when (SPOILER) confronting Shepard and Anderson at the endgame, especially if Shepard keeps pointing out that his plan to control the Reapers is failing because he himself is indoctrinated and playing into their hands . It ends with him either (SPOILER) ranting violently at Shepard and trying to shoot them and Anderson, or fighting off his indoctrination and committing suicide .

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Villain with Good Publicity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainWithGoodPublicity): While he's painted as a terrorist by the Alliance, he does get an ambiguous portrayal in the second game that makes it possible for Shepard to ally with him.  (SPOILER) In the third game, it turns out he's worked very hard on that facade by carefully selecting the Cerberus operatives that Shepard comes into contact with while never letting them get close to his more traditionally villainous schemes or henchmen. This is why the *Normandy* SR-2 is staffed by people like ["Cerberus is not anti-alien, it's pro-humanity" Kelly Chambers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WideEyedIdealist) rather than ["Only a dead alien is a good alien" Kai Leng](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism) and why Shepard's technological assets are an upgraded version of their old ship and a fairly benign AI rather than whatever husk-related crimes against sapience Cerberus cooked up in its atrocity factories.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Villain Respect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainRespect): The Illusive Man has a great deal of respect and admiration for Shepard, even after they become clear enemies. He is always attempting to make them see his point of view and bring them to his side, and even when they don't, he still admires their will and idealism. He tries to get Kai Leng to show this respect, but it doesn't work.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Visionary Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VisionaryVillain): Designed to be the best and worst of humanity all at once.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [We Have Reserves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHaveReserves): Played with in *2*; he prefers not to get rid of a valuable resource if he can, but he's not above sacrificing Cerberus personnel to further his goals, demonstrated when he shrugs off the death of the entire Project Lazarus team except for Miranda and Jacob as acceptable casualties — as do Miranda and Jacob themselves, albeit the latter is a little more uncomfortable with it — and later describes the indoctrination of the team aboard the derelict Reaper as "unfortunate, but unsurprising". Played straight in *3*, where he's prepared to throw away anyone and anything if it helps his goal of controlling the Reapers.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Wicked Cultured](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WickedCultured): Has pretty high class tastes and is a [Necessary Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NecessaryEvil) at best.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes:
[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): In *3*, he views Shepard as one, respecting them as an adversary despite their ideological differences. QUOTE **Illusive Man:** Your idealism is... admirable, Shepard.
    - Also shown when he chastises Kai Leng for *clearly* underestimating Shepard.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [Wouldn't Hurt a Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldntHurtAChild): He approves of a lot of extremely shady and unethical scientific experiments to advance Cerberus' cause, but apparently  (SPOILER) took action to shut down the Teltin facility on Pragia, which was running brutal experiments on children like Jack to create super biotics . Later [averted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AvertedTrope) when  (SPOILER) he uses the refugees, including entire *families*, on Horizon as test subjects in his experiments into indoctrination . Though at that point  (SPOILER) he's pretty deep into being indoctrinated himself.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeName: You Could Have Used Your Powers for Good!
tropeNotes:
[You Could Have Used Your Powers for Good!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCouldHaveUsedYourPowersForGood): Shepard outright tells him that he had the power, intelligence, knowledge (his information network nearly rivals the Shadow Broker's), and charisma to stand a significant chance of defeating the Reapers. Indeed, without his intervention, Shepard would not have recovered from the destruction of the original Normandy.  (SPOILER) Too bad his [pride](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Pride) led to him getting too close to Reaper tech and becoming one of their biggest assets against Shepard. 
QUOTE **Paragon Shepard:** You've forgotten everything you've stood for, Cerberus was supposed to be humanity's sword, not a dagger in our back.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [You Have Failed Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveFailedMe): More than one of his project leads have engaged in [reckless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive), [truly unethical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards), or [recklessly unethical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreadEggsBreadedEggs) methods in their efforts to avoid this when their deadline was coming close.

VGDCName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
TvTName: The Illusive Man, AKA Jack Harper
tropeNotes: [You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness): When he turns on Shepard in *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)*, he outright calls them a tool that's served its purpose and is no longer needed. He's also quick to turn on his people who were working on technology from the Collector Base, [terminating their contracts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadlyEuphemism) once they'd done their jobs.  (SPOILER) This flies in the face of the sheer lengths he went to in resurrecting Shepard, as well as refusing Miranda's suggestion of implanting them with a control chip, not to mention that there was no prior evidence of him killing off his own employees provided they were competent at their jobs. Sure enough, there's more to the story. He's actually been indoctrinated.
[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero): He is mostly a good guy, but he is more than willing to bend the law and work with criminals if it helps keep the peace.

[A Day in the Limelight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ADayInTheLimelight): *Mass Effect: Inquisition*, where it's revealed that  (SPOILER) Bailey ended up killing Pallin while investigating him under Udina's orders. Of course, he believes that Pallin's innocent of whatever he was accused of despite evidence to the contrary .
[Canada, Eh?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanadaEh): Michael Hogan's northern Ontario accent comes through pretty strongly.

[Casual Danger Dialogue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CasualDangerDialogue): Engages in some with Shepard during  (SPOILER)  the Cerberus attack on the Citadel .
QUOTE **Shepard**: Bailey! What are you doing here?!

QUOTE **Bailey**: I'm getting my ass shot off me trying to retake headquarters!

[Commanding Coolness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CommandingCoolness): Gets promoted to this by the time you meet him in *3*. He hates it.
QUOTE **Shepard:** [...Congratulations?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker)

[Cowboy Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CowboyCop): Bailey compares policing the Wards to [patrolling New York City](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/UsefulNotes/NewYorkCityCops), and prepares himself and his officers accordingly.
QUOTE **Bailey**: *[when Shepard questions some of his actions]* This isn't the Presidium! [...] Down here we've got drugs, organized crime and murder. Policing a Ward is like policing New York City.
[Da Chief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DaChief): For Zakera Ward in *2*, then moves up into even higher echelons in *3*.
[Desk Jockey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeskJockey): He complains about being one of these after being [Kicked Upstairs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickedUpstairs) in the third game.

[Dirty Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCop): A [Zig-Zagging Trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZigZaggingTrope). Bailey is obviously crooked, as he's willing to torture suspects and makes under-the-table deals with thugs, but at the same time he's more of a [Pragmatic Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticHero); he's actually a good person since he's doing these things because adhering the inflexible rules wouldn't get the job of keeping the peace done in the gritty life of the Wards. He's also not obstructive in any way to Shepard, Paragon or Renegade.

[Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment): His first meeting with Shepard when Shepard is listed as dead. He demonstrates his willingness to bend the law for the sake of good by making a technically illegal altercation of records, saving Shepard a lot of bureaucratic headaches.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): Towards Executive Pallin. Unlike Pallin, who was a by-the-book cop and deeply distrusted Spectres because of their disregard for rules, Bailey is willing and able to bend the rules if he feels it gets the job done, and is perfectly willing to request and use a Spectre's authority granted to him to move things along.
[Friend on the Force](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendOnTheForce): Acts as one to Shepard.
[Grey-and-Gray Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreyAndGrayMorality): Will bargain with crooks if it ultimately means it'll keep peace on the Citadel.
[Hidden Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenHeartOfGold): Willing to engage in dirty business to keep the peace, but he's anything but a thug — see below.

[Knight in Sour Armor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightInSourArmor): His divorce, estrangement from his children, and the things he's seen on the job have made him pretty sour. Still does his best on the job though.
[Made of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron): During  (SPOILER) the Citadel coup  in *3*, he takes a shot to the gut and just shrugs it off.

[Oblivious Guilt Slinging](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObliviousGuiltSlinging):  (SPOILER) If Wrex confronts Shepard for sabotaging the genophage cure and is subsequently gunned down, Bailey will wonder what set him off. If you don't tell the truth and say Wrex just went crazy, he'll say that it doesn't surprise him, given how the genophage has devastated the krogan and left them with nothing to live for, not knowing that it was thanks to a decision *you* made.

[Old-Fashioned Copper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldFashionedCopper): On your first trip to the Citadel, you overhear him encouraging a younger officer to "make [the suspect] scream a little" to extract a confession, and then offers to do it himself if she can't handle it.

[Odd Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OddFriendship): With Paragon Shepard. Shepard might disapprove of his style and methods of policing, but nonetheless it's clear the two have nothing but an honest respect for each other.

[Noble Bigot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleBigot): Subverted. Although this trope often goes hand in hand with [Old-Fashioned Copper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldFashionedCopper), Bailey is one of the few NPCs in the series to avoid this. During Thane's quest he shows empathy towards the alien population's fear of humans, observing that many of them have lived on the station since before humanity discovered space travel. All the more impressive given that many of the C-Sec officers throughout the game are very openly speciesist, including (at first) Garrus.

[Parental Abandonment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalAbandonment): He considers this the root of many of the Citadel's social problems, which is why he jumps at the chance to help Thane and Kolyat. He'll eventually admit, albeit implicitly, that he's been in Thane's shoes himself — "You think he's the only man who ever screwed up raising a son?"
[Pragmatic Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticHero): He does whatever he needs to for the job to get done, but he is unfailingly just.
[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Perfectly willing to help Shepard out, even when it involves breaking the law.

[Retcon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetCon): An accidental one regarding his name. A background news report in the second game refers to him as Owen Bailey, but the [Lair of the Shadow Broker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DLC) archives refer to him as Armando Bailey. A later Cerberus Daily News report patched up the mistake by giving him the rather unwieldy first name "Armando-Owen."
[Retirony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Retirony): Defied. He tells you he wants to retire to a nice place in the foothills on Earth, but then quickly adds that he won't be doing so any time soon.

tropeName: Screw the Rules, I'm Doing What's Right!
tropeNotes: [Screw the Rules, I'm Doing What's Right!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewTheRulesImDoingWhatsRight): His excuse for being a dirty cop.

tropeName: You Kill It, You Bought It
tropeNotes: [You Kill It, You Bought It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKillItYouBoughtIt):  (SPOILER) Basically how he got his job, though unintentionally .

[Bullying a Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BullyingADragon): Though [not by choice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope), only by proxy: her superiors ordered her to detain Samara, even though Samara's code would force her to kill Anaya to avoid it. Fortunately, both of them are willing to be reasonable about it.
[By-the-Book Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ByTheBookCop): She only accepts your evidence against Pitne For because Samara vouches for you.
[Da Chief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DaChief): To the cops in her district.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Very much so.
QUOTE **Shepard:** You're not going to lock her up? 
**Samara:** Any attempt to put me in a [passive restraint system](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SesquipedalianLoquaciousness) will be regarded as a hostile action, and I will be forced to attack. 
**Anaya:** Yeah, that.
[Friend on the Force](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendOnTheForce): Will follow up on some of Shepard's leads if you go to her.

[Hero-Worshipper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWorshipper): Like most asari, is in total awe of a justicar like Samara, even if that justicar will [probably end up eventually killing her.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LawfulStupid)
QUOTE  "It's a great honor to have her here, but I could do without the honor of having her kill me."
[Honor Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonorBeforeReason): She'll follow orders even if it's guaranteed to get her killed by a Justicar.
[I Want Grandkids](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IWantGrandkids): States once everything's over she now has a story to tell her grandkids. And that she might now live long enough to have them.

[My Country, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyCountryRightOrWrong): She makes it very clear that she will follow her orders to detain Samara if Samara does not leave Illium, even knowing that her odds of survival are close to zero.
QUOTE **Anaya:** I'm a cop and I know my duty.
[Noble Bigot with a Badge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleBigotWithABadge): At the end of Samara's recruitment mission, Anaya admits that she didn't expect so much from a human.
[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): She's willing to work with Shepard and Samara to make sure they can do what they need to.

[Teeth-Clenched Teamwork](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeethClenchedTeamwork): When dealing with Renegade Shepard, who's much ruder toward her for no real reason. At the end of everything, she'll admit she's not sorry to see them go.
[A God Am I](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AGodAmI): A *biotic* god, to be exact.

[Ascended Meme](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedMeme): So popular that he spawned a number of in-jokes in the [Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3) multiplayer. The biotic challenge group rewards you with the banner "Biotic God" with a picture of a biotic volus. There's also a volus adept character called, you guessed it, a biotic god.
[Battle Aura](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleAura): Unfortunately, it's the most impressive trick he has.
[Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle): The victim of one if he faces Wasea.
[Intoxication Ensues](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntoxicationEnsues): The reason for his odd behavior. If he is spoken to afterwards, he is rather embarrassed.
[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): His "biotic god" speech is quite over-the-top.

[No, You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoYou)
QUOTE **Shepard:** You need help. 
**Niftu:** *You* need help! You stand before the mightiest biotic ever!
[Shaped Like Itself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShapedLikeItself): "I am a great wind that will sweep all before me like... a great wind! A great biotic wind!"

[Suicidal Overconfidence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicidalOverconfidence): Tanked-up merchant with no combat experience versus the leader of a murderous [Amazon Brigade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmazonBrigade). "I shall toss Wasea about like a rag doll!" He does not. You can knock him out to prevent this or...
QUOTE **Shepard:** Charge... 
**Jack:** That was mean. But damn funny. 
[Niftu proceeds to get *[absolutely slaughtered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle)*]

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): Implied to have achieved this off-screen in Mass Effect 3's Citadel DLC, as he managed to somehow get the second-highest score in the Armax Arsenal Arena, with *Aria T'Loak* being the only one with a higher score.

[Wizard Duel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WizardDuel): He fires a tiny Warp field that 'pops' an inch from Wasea's nose, then turns and walks away. She unceremoniously one-shots him, knocking him into the air and behind a few barrels just as Shepard and co. walk in.
[All Girls Like Ponies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllGirlsLikePonies): Lampshaded by Aethyta, saying she got Liara a squad of asari commandos because she was too old for a pony.
[Art Evolution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtEvolution): She gets a slight redesign in the third game, with more purple skin and older facial features.

[The Bartender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBartender):Shepard notes that Matriarchs are usually wise elders who give advice. She replies basically that's what a bartender *does*.  (SPOILER)  She only takes bartending jobs to keep an eye on Liara without arousing suspicion.

[Bouncer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bouncer): Implied to be Aethyta's other job at *Eternity*. Fittingly, her father was a krogan.
QUOTE **Eternity's Owner:** Take her away! Before I have my bartender throw her out!

[Brain Bleach](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainBleach): Talks about her mother putting on her old commando leathers for 'special nights with Dad' with embarrassment, and later evokes a similar response from one of her kids while reminiscing about the other parent's breasts.

[Cassandra Truth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CassandraTruth): Whether or not she believes in the Reapers before *3*, the events of the first game led her to advise her people on Thessia that "art and philosophy and political prowess wasn't gonna cut it", but they didn't want to hear it.
QUOTE **Aethyta:** We can't go one asari lifetime without some big war breaking out! We need to get our daughters working earlier, not spending their wild maiden years stripping or in merc bands.

[Combat Pragmatist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatPragmatist): Notes that the asari aren't made to fight Reapers, so is willing to let others do it.
QUOTE **Liara:** My reports don't show a lot of activity from the asari military against the Reapers. 
**Aethyta:** Cmon, you know how asari work. Infiltration and sabotage. 
**Liara:** But against Reaper forces, that's... 
**Aethyta:** I know. About as useful as tits on a hanar. Good thing we've got the turians and the krogan do the heavy lifting. Our people just aren't built for the front ranks.
[Cool Old Lady](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldLady): Thanks to being a [Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker) and [Dirty Old Woman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyOldWoman).
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Nearly everything she says includes a sarcastic quip.

[Dirty Old Woman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyOldWoman): Says she goes for asses in *2*. And in *3* she waxes poetic about Nezzy's rack. She also makes a pass at Shepard the *first time* they talk to her by implying that she would have sex with Shepard if she hadn't just cleaned the bar.
QUOTE **Aethyta:** [If it's all civilized, you're not doing it right.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/MaeWest)
[Disappeared Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisappearedDad): Well... *technically.*

[Easter Egg](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EasterEgg):  (SPOILER)  If you order a "mystery drink" at the kiosk or just get flat *smashed*, then talk to her again, her character model is of a much younger and more attractive asari due to Shepard having the [Beer Goggles](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeerGoggles) on .

[Flat "What"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatWhat): Her reaction when Conrad says that he heard the bar is a front for dealing red sand. <sup>note </sup>  For one, even if the bar *did* sell it, it's *legal* on Illium.
[Funny Background Event](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FunnyBackgroundEvent): Her reaction to Conrad's wife paying for his ticket out is a [Face Palm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FacePalm).
[Hard Head](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HardHead): It might be partially because she is half krogan, but that is most likely not the only cause since she can take out a full krogan with a headbutt.
[Hot Skitty-on-Wailord Action](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotSkittyOnWailordAction): Has had sex with at least one elcor.

tropeName: If You Ever Do Anything to Hurt Her...
tropeNotes: [If You Ever Do Anything to Hurt Her...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IfYouEverDoAnythingToHurtHer): She gives Shepard a barely-veiled threat along these lines if they've been  (SPOILER) romancing Liara in the third game. Shepard can throw it right back at her once they find out exactly *why* Aethyta has been spying on her.

[Insistent Terminology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsistentTerminology):  (SPOILER) She insists that she's Liara's father, not her other mother, because she "didn't pop her out. Anthropocentric bag of dicks."

[Ironic Echo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IronicEcho):  (SPOILER) If you're romancing Liara, a Renegade interrupt lets you throw "Nobody messes with my girl" back in her face by saying you won't allow any assassination attempts on Liara. She is impressed .
[Grievous Harm with a Body](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrievousHarmWithABody): Asks Shepard to rein in  (SPOILER)  Conrad Verner  before she decides to beat him to death with his own spine.
[Jade-Colored Glasses](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JadeColoredGlasses): She's faced a lot of crap.
[The Lad-ette](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLadette): To be expected. Her dad was a krogan, after all.

[Lamarck Was Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LamarckWasRight): "Scientists say that stuff about us getting genetic material from our fathers is crap. Seems like I got a bit of his mouth, though."
    - [Nature Versus Nurture](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NatureVersusNurture): She was raised by a krogan father, so it would have rubbed off, genetics or no.
[Made of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron): In one of the Shadow Broker archive videos, Matriarch Aethyta headbutts a krogan... and the *krogan* falls to the ground.
[Mrs. Robinson](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MrsRobinson): She flirts with Shepard quite a bit.  (SPOILER) The fact that she's Liara's dad plays it even closer .

tropeName: My Species Doth Protest Too Much
tropeNotes: [My Species Doth Protest Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MySpeciesDothProtestTooMuch): Her view towards asari's hat. She believes that they should be doing more constructive things with their Maiden years, and warns that there's a big war every asari lifetime, so they ought to focus less on culture, more on preparing.

[Never Mess with Granny](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMessWithGranny): As Aethyta herself puts it, she's no commando but she's had a thousand years to learn how to fight dirty and is implied to be a powerful biotic even for an asari. When she worked at Eternity it was implied that she doubled as the bouncer and a video in *Lair of the Shadow Broker* shows her taking down a *krogan* with a headbutt.
QUOTE **Aethyta:** Thanks for taking care of that crazy guy. Saves me having to beat him to death with his own spine. That makes the other customers nervous.

[The Nicknamer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheNicknamer):
    - Well, she only gives one example rather than tendency, but it's memorable enough to stick to mind: she calls Matriarch Benezia "Nezzy". And refers to Shepard as 'babe' in *2*. - (SPOILER) Also inspired Benezia's pet name for Liara, "Little Wing".

[Noodle Incident](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoodleIncident): She uses one from her late-maiden/early-matron years to stress the importance of not eating food from the wrong chirality. Namely, what happened the time she witnessed a krogan drink a liquefied turian on a dare.
QUOTE **Aethyta:** Nobody came out of *that one* looking pretty.

[Only Sane Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlySaneMan): Was laughed off Thessia for suggesting that they make a serious effort to study and duplicate the Mass Relays. After the third game  (SPOILER) becomes even more so after the relays blow or are damaged in any ending in which the asari species survives . In *3* it does seem like she has a lot more authority; keeping watch on the Shadow Broker aside, two random sidequests have her namedropped. A commando has her approval to get writings on being a warrior made into required reading, and another asari looking into improved biotic amp interfaces mentions her.

[Papa Wolf](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf): Technically falls under this rather than [Mama Bear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MamaBear) since she's the father in the situation. Either way, (SPOILER) she has been making sure nobody messes with Liara. The jobs at both Eternity and Apollo's Café were to keep the other matriarchs satisfied that Liara was under control so they wouldn't order a hit .
    - [Mama Bear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MamaBear): Presumably played straight in regards to (SPOILER) Liara's [unseen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnseen) half-hanar sister .

[Parental Abandonment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalAbandonment): In a hilarious, if a bit twisted, way. Her father fought in the Rachni Wars, while her mother fought in the Krogan Rebellions. Aethyta's mother figured it out very early, but stayed quiet while her husband boasted. When he found out when he was pushing a thousand and she was a matriarch, they told Aethyta, who was barely over a hundred, that they would fight each other to the death, and that she should "love whichever one survived. Turned out to be *damned easy*! Since neither one did."

[Really Gets Around](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReallyGetsAround): "You find peace in whatever arms will hold you." Apart from  (SPOILER) Benezia , the lovers she sees fit to mention are a turian, an elcor, and a hanar,  (SPOILER)  the latter one whom she even had a child with .

[Red Oni, Blue Oni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedOniBlueOni): The Red to (SPOILER) Benezia's Blue . Aethyta is a [Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker) with a rebellious streak and who's not afraid to solve arguments with a headbutt, whereas (SPOILER) Benezia was reserved, traditional and diplomatic.
    - Which is possibly why she has concerns about (SPOILER) Shepard's [friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LikeFatherLikeSon) (or [relationship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LikeParentLikeSpouse)) with Liara, as they are likewise the Red to her Blue. This is also likely the reason why she approves more if Shepard takes the Renegade Interrupt and stands up to her, defending their relationship by using her [own words](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulEcho) against her .

[The Reveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReveal): (SPOILER) She has been confirmed to be Liara's father. Not that Liara didn't already figure it out. ([seen here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ExcPXH3ThzA).)

[Seen It All](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SeenItAll): Almost. When told Benezia was indoctrinated, she'll state wistfully that even though she's lived over a thousand years, she *hasn't* seen it all.
QUOTE **Aethyta:** Thousand years old and I still don't know crap.
[Sophisticated as Hell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SophisticatedAsHell): Uses the terms "anthropocentric" and "bag of dicks" in the same breath.
[Too Much Information](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooMuchInformation):  (SPOILER) Liara's  reaction to what she says about  (SPOILER) Benezia's  magnificent rack.

[The Unreveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnreveal):  (SPOILER) If Shepard tells Liara that Aethyta is her father, she'll reply she knows already.  She'll also tell Aethyta that she knows that the latter is keeping an eye on her for the Asari government. Aethyta will tell her what did she expect when [she was threatening to flay people alive as an information broker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContinuityNod)?

[Use Your Head](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UseYourHead): As stated above, there a video in *Lair of the Shadow Broker* shows her take down a krogan with a headbutt. She insists to her daughter that this is perfectly normal for asari who have krogan in their family tree.

[Who Wants to Live Forever?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhoWantsToLiveForever): Shep can [ask her](http://youtu.be/b2Zs9_oxnSA) about what it's like to live for a thousand years. Rather than talk about comparative lifespans, Aethyta says it's violent, good news is the exception, and you take comfort where you can. QUOTE "Then one day you wake up, your figure's gotten matriarchal, and everyone else is too young to remember how the quarians looked inside those suits."
[Wolf Whistle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WolfWhistle): Whistles the two-note glissando when fondly recalling  (SPOILER) [Benezia's rack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BuxomBeautyStandard) .

[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): He's awfully polite to Shepard despite being a smuggler and drug-peddeler. If you give him the proof of his criminal activities rather than turn it over to Detective Anaya, he'll compliment your advice to not write it down when he's doing something illegal, and notes that Shepard is a better criminal than him.

[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): It's hard to feel sorry that the mercs are hunting him when he conveniently withheld information about the drugs he sold them. His partner is also likely one of these.
[Blatant Lies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies): It's immediately obvious that he's not being straight with Shepard when the latter asks him about his involvement.

[Card-Carrying Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CardCarryingVillain): Well, more like Card Carrying Dirtbag Salesman.
QUOTE  **Shepard:** It sounds like you're a swindler and your actions have finally caught up with you. 
**Pitne:** True and true.
[Cracking Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrackingUp): Shep does this to procure Pitne's passcard into the Eclipse base, prompting Pitne to hand it right over.
[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward): He's caught trying to escape all the trouble he caused with Eclipse.

[Villain Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainHasAPoint): He forewarns you that all members of the Eclipse Sisterhood are cold-blooded killers who commit a murder to earn their uniform. This information becomes pertinent during your encounter with Elnora, an initiate of the Sisterhood who claims not to have understood what they were really like but is pulling a [False Innocence Trick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FalseInnocenceTrick) on you and was in fact responsible for the killing of Pitne's murdered partner.

[With Friends Like These...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithFriendsLikeThese): Shepard and co. encounter Niftu Cal, a fellow volus who was part of Pitne's trade group, while hunting the mercs. In retaliation for Pitne selling them biotic-enhancing chemicals without telling them how dangerous they were to the user, they pumped Cal so full of drugs that by the time Shepard finds him, he's as high as a kite. Also applies to Pitne's murdered partner, for whom Pitne sheds no tears, insisting that he knew the risks when he took to spacing. Referenced when your squadmates make comments about how Pitne cares more about money than friends.
[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): Everything he did was only out of fear for his safety.

[Bond One-Liner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BondOneLiner): Garrus delivers one of these if he succeeds in killing Sidonis.
QUOTE  **Garrus:** Betrayal repaid, Sidonis.
[Boom, Headshot!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoomHeadshot): What Garrus does to him if you don't stop him.

[Cruel Mercy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CruelMercy): When Shepard points out that Sidonis is badly suffering.
QUOTE  **Garrus:** He still has his life! 
**Shepard:** Look at him, Garrus. He's not alive. There's nothing left to kill.
[Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon): So much so that Sidonis invites death by walking out into view of Garrus, whom he knows is attempting to kill him.

[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward); He sold out his entire team to save his own skin, then ran before Garrus could catch up to him. He deeply regrets his actions later on, driven so far over the [Despair Event Horizon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DespairEventHorizon) out of shame, he practically feels dead inside.

[Forced into Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForcedIntoEvil): *Mass Effect: Homeworlds* reveals that the Blue Suns captured him and "coerced" him into selling Garrus out. Given he was a member of Garrus' squad said coercion was likely [Cold-Blooded Torture](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColdBloodedTorture).

tropeName: If You Kill Him, You Will Be Just Like Him!
tropeNotes: [If You Kill Him, You Will Be Just Like Him!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IfYouKillHimYouWillBeJustLikeHim): It's more, "If You Kill Him, You Will Completely Lose Yourself", but Paragon Shepard spends the mission trying to convince Garrus that it's not like him to be so intent on killing his former friend. What truly separates the Paragon approaches for Garrus's loyalty mission and Zaeed's mission are a difference of 20 years. Whereas Zaeed had only recently met Shepard and before that had spent 20 years hunting down the man whom he thought was his friend, Garrus was friends with Shepard before, and had only recently turned to vigilantism. As a result, it's unnecessary to charm Garrus into realizing that he was only out for revenge like it takes with Zaeed, as Garrus knows and trusts Shepard enough that he can let it go on his own.

[Mercy Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MercyKill): With how empty Sidonis' life is, his death can be seen this way.
QUOTE **Sidonis:** No more sleepless nights... 
**Garrus:** For either of us, Sidonis.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): He deeply regrets selling out Garrus' team.

[Precision F-Strike](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrecisionFStrike)
QUOTE **Shepard:** I'm the only thing standing between you and a hole in the head. 
**Sidonis:** ...*Fuck*.
[Pay Evil unto Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PayEvilUntoEvil): What Garrus *thinks* he's doing.
[That Man Is Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatManIsDead): When Shepard calls him by his real name, Sidonis angrily retorts with "Don't ever say that name aloud!"

[Tragic Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TragicVillain): Talking to him shows just how guilty he feels over betraying Garrus, and he can't even eat or sleep because of what he's done. If spared, he attempts to turn himself in to C-Sec for the "murder" of their squad, with the police being unsure what to do since he didn't directly kill anyone, it happened outside Citadel jurisdiction, and there's technically no proof.

[We Used to Be Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeUsedToBeFriends): Was one of Garrus' partners until he sold out the team. Tragically, this sentiment seems to be one-sided on Garrus' part as the deeply regretful Sidonis seems to still think highly of his former boss.

[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): While he's technically the target whom Shepard and Thane are trying to prevent Kolyat from killing, it's immediately clear that Talid isn't a morally clean individual.

[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): It's hard to feel sorry for this guy if Shepard puts a slug in his head. Shepard even states how badly Talid deserved it, and Bailey doesn't even bother to arrest anyone over it, though this likely also has to do with Shepard being a Spectre.
QUOTE **Shepard:** He was a racist and a criminal. [Isn't that enough?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvokedTrope) 
**Thane:** To some, I suppose.
[Call-Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallBack): Talid has no markings, something that Garrus noted was the mark of liars or politicians.
[Corrupt Politician](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptPolitician): He hires Blood Pack mercenaries to shake down business owners on the Citadel.
[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward): Even though one of his talking points is the number of humans in c-sec, he doesn't resist calling them to save his own skin.
[Evil vs. Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilVsEvil): Elias Kellum is a criminal human who hires Kolyat to assassinate him.
[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): The entire point of his campaign.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): Naturally. His entire campaign is based around cleaning up organized crime on Zakera Ward, which he preaches to voters before going to extort human businesses. But his hypocrisy is especially noteworthy in that while he complains about the human presence in C-Sec, his first reaction upon being sighted by Kolyat is to call for C-Sec.
[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): For all his rhetoric, the Paragon outcome has him saved from a non-human by humans.

[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): The Paragon ending, though what happens with his campaign once it comes to light that he's working with the Blood Pack to extort human businesses is unclear. Considering he's not heard of at all after Mass Effect 2, [it can be assumed that his campaign failed.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope)

[No True Scotsman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoTrueScotsman): Like Saren and Warden Kuril, Talid lacks the clan markings that most turians have on their face. This serves a dual meaning, as Talid is both untrustworthy and a politician, with the term "barefaced" being turian slang for politicians.
[Pay Evil unto Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PayEvilUntoEvil): The Renegade solution to dealing with him.

[Shoot the Hostage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheHostage): Shepard puts it best.
QUOTE **Shepard:** Hostages only work when your enemy cares that they live. 
**Thane:** ...Interesting solution.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): When asking what the humans have done for any of the other races, a salarian replies that he likes their food in a reference to *[Monty Python's Life of Brian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/MontyPythonsLifeOfBrian)*.
[Alliterative Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlliterativeName): Though his full name is never actually used by anyone.

[Antagonistic Offspring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntagonisticOffspring): Subverted. Kolyat isn't evil, just misguided, nor is he directly after Thane. Shepard can even suggest he's trying to follow in Thane's footsteps on some level. [Thane doesn't care for the idea.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilParentsWantGoodKids)
[Calling the Old Man Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallingTheOldManOut): He's really got it out for his father when you show up.

tropeName: Daddy Had a Good Reason for Abandoning You
tropeNotes: [Daddy Had a Good Reason for Abandoning You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DaddyHadAGoodReasonForAbandoningYou): It turns out that Thane had set out to  (SPOILER) avenge Irikah by hunting down her killers. He left Kolyat for too long, however, causing the rift between them to develop .

[Due to the Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DueToTheDead):  (SPOILER) If you completed Thane's loyalty mission and Thane survived until the Citadel Coup, Kolyat will be there at his side during his death, during which he will say prayers for his father and Shepard to see them to the afterlife. In *Citadel*, he asks Shepard to hold a memorial ceremony for Thane at their apartment.
[Flat "What"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatWhat): Says one when Thane explains that it was  (SPOILER)  his fault Irikah died, that her killers went after her to get to Thane .

[Heel–Faith Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaithTurn): If convinced to turn away from his destructive path, in the third game he mentions spending the last year studying the Drell Religion, with the implication that he's decided to honour his father by becoming a priest, rather than an assassin.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): Despite the hatred he's built up for Thane, it's generally implied he doesn't want to. He notes that he used to look up to his father as a child, and Shepard can propose that his attempts to become a [Professional Killer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProfessionalKiller) are an attempt to feel closer to Thane, which is the latter's greatest fear. If you get him out of trouble, Captain Bailey can get him running vigilante for a time, before he takes a more legitimate job after *2* and he cements his positive turnabout by becoming a priest of the Drell Religion, which Thane notes is exceedingly rare among young drell nowadays.

[Morality Pet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralityPet): Together with his mother, for Thane. Thane's greatest wish as a father is that [Kolyat will not follow his path and become a good man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilParentsWantGoodKids).
[Professional Killer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProfessionalKiller): Or at least, he's on his way to becoming one.

[Rebuilt Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RebuiltPedestal): This speech from *Citadel* sums up his new feelings about his father nicely.
QUOTE **Kolyat:** When I was little, I thought my father had it all figured out. He said men must be [loyal to their friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueCompanions) and [dangerous to their enemies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PayEvilUntoEvil). But when he prevented me from... from hurting someone, he had changed. He said enemies and ego are not as important as loved ones. [I didn't want to hear it.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallingTheOldManOut) I was... lost. [I called him a hypocrite in a thousand different ways](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalHypocrisy), said that [he was going soft](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VirtueIsWeakness). Now... I think maybe he did have it all figured out.
[Say Your Prayers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SayYourPrayers): Finishes Thane's prayer  (SPOILER) as he lays dying in *3* .
[Strong Family Resemblance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StrongFamilyResemblance): Bears a strong resemblance to his father, albeit with a more bluish skin tone and a recolored set of clothes.
