[When You Coming Home, Dad?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhenYouComingHomeDad): He reminds Thane that he was barely around while Irikah was alive, much less when she died. Bonus points for the Achievement being called "Cat in the Cradle".
QUOTE **Thane:** You're angry because I wasn't there when your mother died. 
**Kolyat:** You weren't there when she was *alive*! Why would you be there when she died?!

[All for Nothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllForNothing): He comes to this horrifying realization (SPOILER) if David remained with Overlord, and the geth conflict was resolved before meeting with him again . This pushes him into committing suicide.
    - What’s worse is that (SPOILER) even without these conditions, the Project was still ultimately pointless, as Legion reveals that the majority of geth have no interest in war with organics and he himself willingly acts as a conduit to communicate with organics.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner):  (SPOILER) He quit Cerberus after the events of *Overlord* and is more than willing to help Shepard to defeat the Reapers in Mass Effect 3.

[Borrowed Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BorrowedCatchphrase): If Shepard never did the Overlord DLC, Gavin will sadly say of having to kill his brother with a nuclear strike, "It all seemed so harmless."
[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel):  (SPOILER) A non-lethal version, where he presses his own brother into an overwhelming, mind-destroying VI link.

[Crocodile Tears](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrocodileTears): A variation. He makes a seemingly heartfelt plea for Shepard to let him become [The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner)  (SPOILER) and take care of David. If Shepard says no, it slips very quickly and he shouts "No! He's too valuable!" and tries to shoot Shepard.

tropeName: Did You Just Flip Off Cthulhu?
tropeNotes: [Did You Just Flip Off Cthulhu?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidYouJustFlipOffCthulhu):  (SPOILER)  Reveals in 3 that he refused the Illusive Man's demands to restart Overlord by finding a replacement for David and handed in his resignation by telling his employer that if *"his intention was to deal with the Devil, he only had to look in the mirror"*. The Illusive Man's response was to put a price on Archer's head .

[Driven to Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide):  (SPOILER) If David was sent to Grissom Academy and you fail to save him from the Cerberus attack or just keep quiet about it to make Gavin squirm; or if David wasn’t sent to Grissom and the geth issue was resolved before speaking to Gavin, (meaning what he did was completely pointless) , he pulls out a pistol and walks away to "escape from this nightmare." [You hear a gunshot a second later.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoundOnlyDeath)
QUOTE **Archer:** God be with you, Commander. He was never with me.

[Even Evil Has Loved Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasLovedOnes): He does love David in his way, but his desire and desperation for vindication lead him to  (SPOILER)  horrifically exploit his brother. That said, he is deeply relieved if Shepard tells him they rescued David from Grissom Academy when Cerberus attacked it .
QUOTE **Archer**: *( (SPOILER)  if Shepard freed David and rescues him from Grissom Academy )*  (SPOILER)  Commander? Thank you for saving David. *both* times .

[Fatal Flaw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatalFlaw): In *2*, his desire for vindication. You can already see the signs of him realising how badly wrong things have gone and the horror of his own actions, such as him looking wistfully at a picture of him with his brother David, both smiling, and his comment about "Man's reach exceeding his grasp" at the start of the DLC, but he [lacks the moral fortitude](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward) to be completely upfront about what happened at Overlord and to admit to himself and others that it was not worth it, even if "It all seemed harmless."  (SPOILER) Even at the end, when the monstrosity of his actions is screaming at him from his brother's torturous position, he still wants to keep doing what's he's been doing to get something out of it all.  Later averted in *3*,  (SPOILER) at which point he's all done rationalizing, and if the Paragon ending was picked what he wants most is to know that his brother is alright .

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): In *3.* [Shepard's still not happy with him.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceDoorSlam)
QUOTE  **Shepard:** I have to go, and I'm not gonna pretend it was nice to see you again.

[Heel Realization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelRealization):  (SPOILER) By *3*, he realizes the horror of what he did; if Shepard took David away, the Illusive Man asks him to do a second Project Overlord. Gavin responds by telling him that "if he wanted to find the devil, he need only look in the mirror." Subsequently, he quits Cerberus, destroys his research notes and hardware, and is among the ex-Cerberus scientists that Jacob is protecting. If you go so far as to screw with him or let David die or resolve the geth issue without saving David and before speaking to Gavin, he commits suicide .

tropeName: I Did What I Had to Do
tropeNotes: [I Did What I Had to Do](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDidWhatIHadToDo): What he claims, but it doesn't come anywhere *near* justifying what he did.
[Kill on Sight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillOnSight):  (SPOILER) Every Cerberus soldier was given this order on him after he ended Project Overlord and defected from Cerberus .

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): A delayed one, but he eventually has this reaction to what he did with Project Overlord.
[Pistol-Whipping](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PistolWhipping): Delivered to him by *[Paragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OOCIsSeriousBusiness)* Shepard.

[Politically Incorrect Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoliticallyIncorrectVillain):  (SPOILER)  He callously experiments on and exploits his autistic brother, David; even prior to the final experiment, Gavin was happy to use him as a human dictaphone, even shouting at him for not reacting on time. He even dehumanizes him as "a human computer," and claims that his mind is "more alien than an actual alien," bringing to mind all-too-real issues of the discrimination and abuse people with mental illnesses and neurodivergent outlooks suffer.

[Reformed, but Rejected](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReformedButRejected): While he does attempt to become [The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner) in *3*, he's well aware that nothing can make up for his horrific actions (SPOILER) against his brother. QUOTE **Archer:** *[talking to Shepard]* I know you think I'm a monster, and you're right.
    - If Shepard never did the Project Overlord DLC, enough prodding on what happened will make Shepard a little suspicious that Archer did something far worse than he's letting on.

[Shoot the Shaggy Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheShaggyDog): His project turns into this. Almost everyone associated with the project gets killed.  (SPOILER) Legion reveals the majority of the geth have no interest in another war, and Legion himself is perfectly happy to communicate voluntarily with humans. So in the end, everything that Gavin put David through was pointless . This is especially evident if you play the mission *after* recruiting  (SPOILER) Legion . If Shepard never did the Project Overlord DLC, Archer reveals the area had to be [nuked](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NukeEm) to stop David.

[Sunk Cost Fallacy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SunkCostFallacy): At the end of the DLC, Archer will insist he *must* try to continue the experiment because he needs to not have wasted time and lives on *nothing*. By *3*, he's given up.

[Sympathy for the Devil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SympathyForTheDevil): Averted. Gavin fully understands why Shepard views him as a monster and admits that even he knows that nothing he does can make up for what he did  (SPOILER) to his brother .

[This Is Unforgivable!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisIsUnforgivable): Shepard's stance on his actions by *3*, [Archer doesn't think any better of himself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone).
QUOTE **Archer:** Not a day goes by where my dreams aren't haunted by what I did to  (SPOILER)  David . All I can do is hope that one day he forgives me.

[Too Clever by Half](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooCleverByHalf): Pressure from the Illusive Man to produce results pushed Archer to run a dangerous experiment without even running any simulations beforehand. It all went downhill from there.

[Too Dumb to Live](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive):  (SPOILER)  In the Paragon ending, when Shepard declares his intention to free David, Archer pulls a pistol- probably not the wisest move to use on a man/woman with *infinitely* more combat experience who doesn't need another excuse to kill him. Fortunately for him, Shepard merely settles for disarming Archer, then kicking his ass .
QUOTE **Shepard**:  (SPOILER)  I've seen enough of your cruelty to know [David] will never be free from it here. I'm taking him away . 
**Archer**  (SPOILER)  No, leave him! [He's too valuable!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForScience)  
**Shepard:**  (SPOILER)  *[pistol-whips Archer, then jams the Carnifex pistol under his nose]* You even *think* about coming after your brother, and [this bullet will be waiting for you](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpliedDeathThreat). *Then* we'll see who's valuable .
[Utopia Justifies the Means](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UtopiaJustifiesTheMeans): In this case, it doesn't.
[Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown): Has a brief one in *Overlord's* Paragon ending.
[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): Aside from the fact that he's a scientist working for Cerberus, nearly everything else about him would constitute a spoiler for *Overlord*.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): What he does to his brother is morally abhorrent but his ultimate goal is to save lives by preventing future conflicts with the geth.  (SPOILER) By the time of the third game he's had a full [Heel Realization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelRealization) and refused the Illusive Man's offer to make a second attempt at controlling the geth.
[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero): In his movies.
[Ascended Meme](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedMeme): Started out as a joke on Bioware forums, and then was incorporated into the games as a fictional character.
[Big "NO!"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigNo): Gets a completely flat one after his elcor partner Bubin is shot.
[Beware the Silly Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheSillyOnes): He's a hanar who also happens to be a *Spectre*.

[The Casanova](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCasanova): *"He's got a lover in every port..."*
QUOTE  "Did someone mention an Enkindler? This one is familiar with enkindling. It has enkindled multiple females across the galaxy."

[Casting Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CastingGag): Blasto is voiced by Mark Meer (Male Shepard), while his [Love Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoveInterest) in Blasto 6 is voiced by Jennifer Hale (FemShep).

[Cowboy Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CowboyCop): Plays one.
QUOTE **[Da Chief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DaChief):** Bottom line: You can't touch the vorcha. He's got diplomatic immunity.

QUOTE **Blasto:** Then this one will not attempt diplomacy.
[Day in the Limelight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DayInTheLimelight): He got an official tie-in comic called "Blasto: Eternity is Forever".
[Dull Surprise](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DullSurprise): He's a hanar, so this comes naturally.
[Expospeak Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExpospeakGag): "This one has grown tired of your solid waste excretions."
[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Basically a Hanar version of [Dirty Harry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/DirtyHarry).

[Guns Akimbo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GunsAkimbo): *"...and a gun in every tentacle."* Exemplified in the *Citadel DLC* where he brandishes ***half a dozen [Carnifex Pistols](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandCannon)*** at Shepard.
[It's All About Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllAboutMe): "This one does not share top billing."

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes:
[Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold): Blasto may be a [Cowboy Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CowboyCop), but he genuinely cares about Bubin and Bubin's sister, honey.
    - [Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): His actor, on the other hand, just comes across as this.

[Loophole Abuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LoopholeAbuse): Bubin insisted Blasto bring in the corrupt vorcha ambassador by the book. Blasto lets the ambassador draw a gun on him, letting Blasto immolate the guy in self-defense.

[Lost in Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LostInCharacter): The actor doesn't seem quite clear on the concept that he isn't really the SPECTRE and badass hero he plays in the movies. Of course, he *is* on set at the time.

[Memetic Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MemeticBadass): [In-Universe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InUniverse), though Shepard is rather unimpressed.
QUOTE  **Shepard**: I've been in the "club" for 3 years now.
[My Sister Is Off-Limits](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MySisterIsOffLimits): Invoked by Bubin, who's naturally furious when he find Blasto in bed with his sister.

tropeName: My Species Doth Protest Too Much
tropeNotes:
[My Species Doth Protest Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MySpeciesDothProtestTooMuch): Both his character and his actor.
    - The Council thought that Blasto, the first hanar SPECTRE would play by the rules. They were wrong. - The hanar are well known for being ceaselessly polite, but Blasto's actor is smugly dismissive to Commander Shepard, the Hero of the Citadel, and Javik, an individual whom the hanar revere as *gods*. The only other hanar that's a jackass is the one who's indoctrinated, and he's not even as big a jackass (though he is far more evil and dangerous).

[Narm Charm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NarmCharm)/[So Bad, It's Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoBadItsGood): Blasto 6 and the cheap production values of Blasto 7 imply that this is the large reason it's so popular in-universe.

[Nice Character, Mean Actor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceCharacterMeanActor): Blasto isn't exactly nice, but he is a [Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold), while his actor is a smugly dismissive prima donna.

[No Celebrities Were Harmed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoCelebritiesWereHarmed): In-universe, he takes a lot of Shepard's traits. He's a badass Spectre who doesn't play by the rules, tried to warn the Council about the Reapers and killed Sovereign in the Battle for the Citadel. His next movie involves him curing the genophage. Shepard thinks he's just a "big stupid jellyfish". He's also voiced by Mark Meer, which means he will even *sound* like male Shepard, which leads to one of the most epic [Acting for Two](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActingForTwo) scenes in the Citadel DLC.

[The Prima Donna](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePrimaDonna): His actor appears to be [one](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass) in the *Citadel DLC*, immediately insulting [Shepard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne) and [Javik](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Precursors) by refusing to share top billing for *Blasto 7* with them. Even Paragon Shepard, who seemed willing to go along with it at first, eventually finds it too hard to put with him. To emphasize this, it's the Paragon interrupts that cause you to intercede and tell him to stuff it. QUOTE **Shepard**: Uh, THIS one is the hero of the Citadel! I'll handle this. **Blasto**: This one insists! *(shove)* **Shepard**: *(shoves him back even harder)* This one DOESN'T CARE!!! **Javik:** *(blasts the Vorcha councilor)* THIS one wishes he was still frozen in the refridgerator!
    - The size of [his ego](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallNameBigEgo) is also shown when he's downright dismissive of Javik, a member of the race the hanar revere as *[Gods](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LikeAGodToMe)*.

[Primal Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrimalScene): In Blasto 6, between Blasto and Bubin's sister. As they are a hanar and elcor, it consists of ridiculously polite, monotonous "dirty talk", that is as hilarious as it sounds. The fact that they are voiced by Mark Meer and Jennifer Hale only makes it even more hilarious.
[Show Within a Show](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShowWithinAShow): One of the most popular film series in the *Mass Effect* universe.
[Sibling Murder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SiblingMurder): Blasto killed Sovereign, and now his brother Sluggard wants revenge.
[[Verb] This!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VerbThis): "Enkindle this."

[Arbitrary Weapon Range](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArbitraryWeaponRange): Defied hard. He makes it abundantly clear that if you shoot a weapon in space, it *will* ruin someone's day whether that is a ship, the planet behind that ship, or some planet ten thousand years from now.
[Genius Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser): While never seen fighting, he *is* a Marine. The genius part comes in with his clear knowledge of physics.
[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): His explanation on firing a rocket certainly counts.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): His [hamminess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam) aside, the point he is trying to make is that once fired, a slug will ultimately hit *something* with more force than an atomic bomb, so they must aim carefully and be *very* sure they are firing at the right target.
QUOTE  **Gunnery Chief**: That is why you check your targets! That is why you wait for the computer to give you a damn firing solution! That is why, Serviceman Cheung, we do not "eyeball it"! This is a weapon of mass destruction! You are not a cowboy shooting from the hip!
[Bring It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BringIt): States she hasn't lost a contract negotiation in three hundred years, and if the Zhu's Hope colonists want to settle the matter in court, "*try it.*"

[Broken Bird](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenBird): As a pureblood, Erinya was probably always at least a *little* snooty, but it was the deaths of her wife and daughters which truly pushed her into xenophobia. Once this is found out, Shepard can get her to make concessions to the Zhu's Hope colonists.

[Death of a Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathOfAChild): Her bondmate died on Rannoch in the first stages of the geth rebellion, but it was losing *both of her daughters* during Sovereign's attack on the Citadel which really broke her.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): One dialogue option has her go on a rant about (in turn) the salarians, the turians, and humans, blaming all of the galaxy's current ills on their combined actions.

[Heel Realization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelRealization): Shepard can either sympathize with or bully her into understanding that her behavior is completely opposite to that of her bondmate and daughters, all three of whom loved learning about and interacting with other races.
[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): Depending on the player's choices, her actions risk harm to another asari, but she doesn't acknowledge that.
[My Country, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyCountryRightOrWrong): Suffice to say her low opinion of *every other Council species* goes hand in hand with a belief in asari moral supremacy.
[Rules Lawyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RulesLawyer): Very haughtily informs Shepard that the terms of the contract the Zhu's Hope colonists signed were perfectly clear and are completely ironclad.

[Saying Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SayingTooMuch): No matter what tack her conversation goes in, Shepard can quickly peg that it's the loss of her family that's motivating Erinya's act of spite.
[While You Were in Diapers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhileYouWereInDiapers): Brings up to Shepard that she's been dealing with contracts while Shepard's ancestors were still burning witches.
[The Faceless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFaceless): Quarians, obviously.
[Four-Star Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourStarBadass): While they're all admirals, special points go to Han'Gerrel.  (SPOILER) And even more special points go to Zaal'Koris in *3* .

[Gray-and-Grey Morality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrayAndGreyMorality): All of the Admirals seemingly have the best interests of the Migrant Fleet at heart, but all of them have their vices. In rough order from lighter to darker shades of gray:
    - Zaal'Koris is a [Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass) to Shepard and Tali in court, but is the sole admiral who wants to make peace with the geth (believing the other admirals are moving dangerously close to open war). Assuming Tali is acquitted and Shepard urges the Conclave to pursue peace with the geth, Koris warms up to the duo considerably. - Shala'Raan wants to avoid open war with the geth and is a [Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure), but the other admirals imply that she is shy in expressing her opinions and just jumps on the bandwagon of the majority. - Rael'Zorah seemed to have been a strict officer and a clever fighter, but remained distant from his daughter Tali (though he still loves her dearly). Based on speaking to the other four admirals, Rael seemed to share Gerrel's opinion in driving the geth out of Rannoch. (SPOILER) To that end Rael deliberately reprogrammed, captured or dismantled geth to perform experiments, in an effort to successfully hack their neural network. By experimenting on active geth, Rael not only violated sacred laws that predated the quarians' flight from the homeworld but got everyone on the Alarei killed and endangered the entire fleet . - Daro'Xen is determined to help the quarians regain control of the geth with minimum bloodshed... by [mind raping](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape) them back into slavery. Tali's responses indicate that Xen has a [Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist) or [god](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AGodAmI) complex. - Han'Gerrel is a friendly and honorable man, but he believes total war against the geth (even with evidence they're not brainless murdering machines and that the geth who sided with the Reapers are heretics) is the only way to reclaim Rannoch.
[Just a Machine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustAMachine): Gerrel and Xen's views on the geth, while Raan doubts that "they have different factions" will convince people. Koris is an exception.

[Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard): The trial isn't about whether Tali really did endanger the Flotilla, but what course should the quarians take concerning the geth. Tali just got caught in the crossfire.

[Always Save the Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysSaveTheGirl): She says her main priority in the trial is getting Tali acquitted.
QUOTE **Raan:** *[angry]* I don't give a vorcha's ass about the fleet! I was trying to protect you, Tali!

[Cruel to Be Kind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CruelToBeKind): Her decision to not tell Tali about  (SPOILER) the circumstances behind her father going missing(and eventually being found dead) as a result of the attack on the Alarei  and letting her find out about it during the trial causes Tali no small amount of anguish, but potentially helps prove that Tali had no idea what happened.
[Da Chief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DaChief): One of the patrol fleet's main duties is internal fleet law enforcement; as an admiral, she's more police commissioner than soldier.
[Driven to Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide):  (SPOILER) If Tali's dead and you save the geth over the quarians , she shoots herself in the head.

[Et Tu, Brute?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EtTuBrute): Shaala and Han Gerrel have this reaction if you choose to expose Rael's actions to the quarian public, appalled that her friend could do something so horrific.
[Honorary Uncle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonoraryUncle): Tali's "Auntie Raan". She and Tali's mother shared a clean room during Tali's birth; Raan was sick for a week, but it was worth it.

[Meaningful Rename](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulRename): In the third game, if you've managed to help the quarians  (SPOILER)  regain their homeworld , she sends you an email signed "Admiral Shala'Raan vas  (SPOILER)  Rannoch ".

[My Country, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyCountryRightOrWrong): If Shepard  (SPOILER) experiences the geth consensus , Raan reads their account of seeing it and seems, at the least, taken aback by it and its evidence that there isn't malice on that side of the [Robot War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RobotWar). She can tell Shepard that there was information there that she hadn't been aware of, but denies having second thoughts if Shepard inquires.

[Neutral No Longer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeutralNoLonger):  (SPOILER) Initially was wishy-washy about her stance in the whole retaking-the-homeworld question, but once momentum started, she sided with Xen and Gerrel. While Xen wanted to test out all her new toys, and Gerrel was simply itchin' for a fight, Raan just wanted Rannoch reclaimed .

[Nice Job Breaking It, Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceJobBreakingItHero): Cast the deciding vote that determined that the quarians would go to war against the geth, resulting in an entirely unnecessary conflict with numerous fatalities on both sides and creating a huge clusterfuck for Shepard to fix.

[Parental Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ParentalSubstitute): Signs point to Raan becoming a surrogate mother to Tali after Tali's biological mother died in her youth. She's "Auntie Raan" to Tali.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): She "wears holes in her suit" for Shepard and Tali's sake, has to keep Koris and Gerrel from bickering at each other in the middle of proceedings, and is the only Admiral not trying to push her personal agenda ahead of Tali's well-being.

[Rules Lawyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RulesLawyer): Serves as one on the Admiralty Board during Tali's trial, so that she can ensure that quarian law is upheld — and that Tali is given a fair trial.
QUOTE  **Koris:** Objection! This human has no business at a hearing involving such sensitive military matters! 
**Raan:** Then you should *not* have declared Tali crew of the *Normandy*, Admiral Koris. By right as Tali's Captain, Shepard *must* stay.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero):
    - Gets one from Tali and Paragon Shepard for (SPOILER) not telling her about her father's (at the time) presumed death so her reaction would be more genuine . - Gives one herself towards the duo if the trial ends with (SPOILER) Tali simply being exiled. Raan is livid that they wasted the opportunity after she "wore holes in her suit" to make it happen. - Gives one to Gerrel for (SPOILER) firing on the geth dreadnought with Shepard, Tali/Xen and their squadmate(s) inside , although she does try to placate Shepard.

[A Father to His Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen): To the point that he has to be talked into being rescued rather than saving his troops. He'd rather die than let his crew get exterminated by the geth. Unfortunately, if you want the best possible outcome between the geth and quarians (something that Koris wants to achieve), you have to force him to sacrifice his crew. On his return, he quickly realizes he was desperately needed by the Civilian Fleet for leadership.
[Clothing Switch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClothingSwitch): Swaps out the pink-trimmed suit for one in all black before  (SPOILER)  being shot down and crash-landing on Rannoch .

[Didn't Think This Through](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntThinkThisThrough): He angrily objects to having Shepard - as a human - at a hearing involving a sensitive military matter like Tali's trial. This was after he voted to declare Tali part of the Normandy crew, which under the quarians' own laws would require Shepard, as her captain, to represent her. Raan calls him out on this.
[Embarrassing Last Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmbarrassingLastName): While Koris is his family name, the name of the Qwib-Qwib, his home ship, gets him a lot of unwanted attention.

[The Extremist Was Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheExtremistWasRight):
    - No-one takes his belief in brokering a peace with the geth feasible, mainly because the geth have maintained a shoot-on-sight policy for all organics for the last 300 years, and the only geth who've tried to contact organics since then have been Sovereign's genocidal minions. (SPOILER) He's crucial in *Mass Effect 3* should you choose to secure the peace, proving he was right after all . - If Shepard exposes Rael's criminal actions at the trial, Koris sounds incredibly calm when he demands that Rael be posthumously exiled.

[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): He goes from being the antagonist of Tali's loyalty mission in the second game to possibly an ally in the effort to achieve peace in the third game. Despite him trying to scapegoat Tali in her trial, the two may end up becoming political allies if Tali is promoted to Admiral herself, both casting the dissenting minority votes in the Admiralty's choice to invade Rannoch.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): A lot of the things he says to you in *2* make sense (most especially if the player pursues peace in the next game), even if he's a jerk when he says them. Justified, since he espouses an unorthodox stance in regards to geth that opposes to the mainstream Quarian society forcing him to toughen up.
    - The *Alarei* was overrun by live geth; deactivated geth platforms hardly reactivate themselves, so something shady involving them *must* have gone down aboard it ( (SPOILER) and it turns out something did ) whether or not Tali was knowingly abetting whatever it was. - He opines as well that the geth who killed the crew weren't homicidal machines; they were *living beings in pain*, a contrast to everyone around him. Tali tries to defend the Morning War by saying the geth attacked them and drove them from Rannoch, and Koris counters that *of course* they did — the quarians tried to destroy them first. - Even his reasons for opposing a war with the geth and wanting to have Tali found guilty are sound: the war is a long one, marked by brutalities on both sides, but if their people don't stop fighting they stand to lose everything; ergo experiments like the ones Rael'Zorah was running on the *Alarei* are things he cannot condone, because they treat the geth as less than people and he feels it's important to send a message that that view is untrue. Tali even admits she understands his position, despite not agreeing with it. (SPOILER) And ultimately, he is vindicated regarding Rael's experiments; they were so terrible that if the truth is revealed after Shepard uncovers it, the entire gathered crowd are shocked and appalled by it, excluding [Admiral Xen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForScience).

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes:
[Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold): Is a jerk in Tali's trial, but makes it clear that it is not personal as he respects her greatly. As well as seeking peace with the geth, if you ask him about the Admirals' infighting after the first part of the trial he'll apologize for letting it interfere with the proceedings. If Tali is cleared, he'll thank Shepard for being there for her when the Admiralty board wasn't. He is also one of the lone quarians who support peace with the geth, and is (SPOILER) the only Admiral other than Tali who votes against going to war with them in the third game. He is essential to brokering peace between the two sides in the Rannoch arc.
    - Expose Rael's actions in court and he warms up enormously to Tali and Shepard. - Even forcing a mistrial compels him to admit it was wrong to scapegoat Tali for what happened, and he apologizes. - It's also implied in both the second and particularly the third game, Koris is generally a cordial, selfless admiral all around who greatly values protecting the Quarian People along with the civilian fleet he commands, so much so that putting them in danger is why he's angry during the trial as now there are Geth on the Alerei that endanger the fleet.

[Kangaroo Court](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KangarooCourt): Sets up one for Tali in *2*, and goes so far as to try to deny her any legal representation at all. Shepard can shut the whole thing down simply by pointing out that Koris has no actual evidence of wrongdoing on her part and is only pushing the trial as a way to score political points.

[The Men First](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMenFirst):  (SPOILER) After crash-landing on Rannoch, he's adamant that Shepard leaves him behind to save the rest of his crew. You can convince him otherwise, and despite feeling guilty, he agrees in hindsight that Shepard was right to do so (as he keeps his Civilian Fleet from faltering) .

[My Country, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyCountryRightOrWrong): He was against the war with the geth, his Civilian Fleet was against the war too, but they came anyway when the Migrant Fleet moved against the synthetics.

[Never Heard That One Before](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverHeardThatOneBefore): Judging by how Tali warns Shepard to not ask about [his name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnfortunateNames), and the exasperated way he explains that he tried and failed to get his ship's name changed in the past, the whole Quib-Quib situation is a source of this for him.

[Nothing Personal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NothingPersonal): If Shepard gets Tali acquitted  (SPOILER)  without showing the incriminating evidence  at her trial, he says this to Tali about the attempt to get her killed or exiled. Shepard can optionally refuse to buy it.

[Only Sane Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlySaneMan): In *2*, he's the only quarian Admiral (in fact, one of the few quarians in general) who wants to avoid war with the geth. He is the only Admiral who realizes that an outright war is suicidal (justified, since he's in charge of the civilian fleets). This puts him at odds with [Admirals Gerrel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneralRipper) and [Xen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist), who often mock him for being a coward and geth apologist (a "suit-wetter", in Han's own words). The combination of all this pressure has made him extremely frustrated and desperate, and it makes your initial impression of him in *[Mass Effect 2](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect2)* a harsh one. By the third game, he has his act together. He is also one of few quarians who thinks that their ancestors were wrong to try and exterminate the geth.
[Ramming Always Works](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RammingAlwaysWorks): When a geth ground cannon starts ripping through the quarian fleet, he crashes his ship into it.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Not immediately obvious in *2*, since he seems too willing to [get Tali exiled for the sake of politics](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog), but by *3* he fits this trope just fine.

[Resigned to the Call](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ResignedToTheCall):  (SPOILER) Should you rescue him after his crash-landing, he becomes a hero to his people, having set foot on the homeworld and lived to tell about it. He's reluctant because the entirety of the rest of his ship's crew perished in the process. Ironic, considering he thought the idea of taking back Rannoch was suicidal folly at best .

[Senseless Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SenselessSacrifice):  (SPOILER) If Shepard lets him die to save his crew, it becomes harder to [avoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeAThirdOption) the [Genocide Dilemma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenocideDilemma) later. Moreover, the death of such a high ranking figure causes morale to drop in the fleet and some civilian ships to flee only to be butchered by the geth in the process, leading to thousands of senseless deaths that would not have happened otherwise.

[Sensitive Guy and Manly Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SensitiveGuyAndManlyMan): The sensitive guy to Han'Gerrel's manly man. While Gerrel is a hawkish asskicker who leads the main battle fleet and would love nothing more than to get a piece of the geth, Koris looks out for the civilian fleet and wants nothing more than to make peace with the geth, even if that means forgoing the homeworld. He thinks the price of war is simply too high.

[The So-Called Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSoCalledCoward): Han'Gerrel views him as a coward — a "[suit-wetter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BringMyBrownPants)", to be precise — because he believes in looking for a peaceful resolution to the geth conflict.  (SPOILER) In actuality, Koris is an exceedingly brave man, and proves it in *3*. He crashes his ship into a geth planetary defense gun to save civilians, and then willingly volunteers to sacrifice himself to save his crew. Gerrel even tells Shepard if Koris dies that he would not have been able to accomplish the same thing .

[Stealth Pun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StealthPun): He occasionally considers transferring to a ship with a respectable name like Defrahnz or Iktomi.  (SPOILER)  Which would make the last part of his name either "vas deferens", the part of the male anatomy that connects the testicles to the urethera, or "vasectomy", a procedure that permanently sterilizes a man by cutting the vas deferens .

[Teeth-Clenched Teamwork](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeethClenchedTeamwork): Some dialogue options in *3* make it clear Shepard still absolutely detests him for his actions at Tali's trial, but works with him because of his strong leadership and the fact that Shepard needs as many fleets as possible for the war effort. The 'Intimidate' version of the conversation where Shepard convinces him to let himself get rescued basically consists of [Can't Kill You, Still Need You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantKillYouStillNeedYou) and accusing him of being a moral coward. If you're working for the [Golden Ending](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoldenEnding) of the Rannoch arc by brokering peace, you need to ally with him and ensure his survival.

[Took a Level in Kindness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInKindness): In *3*, compared to Han'Gerrel's [Took a Level in Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInJerkass). Although this is partially because this time around, Shepard has an interest in stopping the war just like Koris does (because Shepard needs as many fleets as they can get to fight the Reapers, and the quarians' decision to fight the geth could potentially cause a waste of valuable quarian resources). Depending on previous interactions, if Tali is promoted to Admiral in her father's place, the two form an alliance in the concerns of the Admiralty and vote against the invasion for the same reason.

[Unfortunate Names](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnfortunateNames): He is *proud* of the Qwib-Qwib, and refuses to transfer over "petty insults". Which may be a good thing for him, because the two ship names he suggests are even worse (Vas Defrahnz/Vas Iktomi- "[Vas deferens](https://www.verywellhealth.com/vas-deferens-4846228)" and "Vasectomy"), though in the quarian language, these are actually proud names.
[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero): Of the unscrupulous but mainly good variety, as he's pitted against the Reapers.

[Attack! Attack! Attack!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackAttackAttack): Unless reined in, he *will* launch a full frontal assault on anything resembling a geth ship. This includes the geth dreadnought that a fellow Admiral and a hero of the fleet is aboard, and later on  (SPOILER) he'll order the entire Migrant Fleet to open up on the geth fleet while they're disabled, and continue even when they've been upgraded with advanced Reaper coding unless Shepard, Tali, Koris, *and* Raan all order him to stop. In fact, even though Reaper-boosted Geth [No-Sell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoSell) his attacks, *he'll continue to order the ships to fire at any cost* instead of retreating .

[Bitch in Sheep's Clothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BitchInSheepsClothing): He initially comes off as a [Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure), but also supports [Revenge Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RevengeBeforeReason) when it comes to the geth.

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards): Killing all the geth in the name of revenge is a-OK in his book, but what Rael'Zorah got up to aboard the Alarei —  (SPOILER) he reactivated geth platforms to use in weapons testing  — is going too far, even for Han.
QUOTE (if Shepard keeps it a secret, then tells him afterwards) *Keelah.*

[Et Tu, Brute?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EtTuBrute): Expose Rael's experiments to the public and Gerrel will be appalled and horrified. He agrees that Rael should be exiled posthumously, while saying he never would have believed it. He sounds like he is on the verge of weeping when he admits it has to happen.

[Fire-Forged Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireForgedFriends): With Rael when they teamed up to fight off a batarian attack before they were of age.
QUOTE **Han:** The crew called us heroes. The brass called us idiots. Slapped some medals on our chests and kicked us off to Pilgrimage a couple years ahead of schedule.

[Flanderization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Flanderization): In the second game, he was the most vocal admiral about wanting to go to war with the geth, but was otherwise incredibly respectful to Shepard and was one of the most sympathetic admirals towards Tali during her trial. Come to the war in the third game, and he becomes single-mindedly obsessed with destroying the geth at the cost of the Migrant Fleet's civilian ships and  (SPOILER)  even Tali and Shepard while they're on board the geth dreadnought . That said, we never saw him at war in *2*.

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): His story in 2 about how he and Rael took on a batarian pirate attack with a small frigate ship hints at his [Leeroy Jenkins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins) tactics in the third game.

[General Ripper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneralRipper): Puts destroying the geth as a higher priority than preserving quarian lives, [because he believes doing so will be beneficial in the long run.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist) In addition, when Shepard reports to Hackett after escaping the geth dreadnought, it turns out Hackett immediately knows the name, as Gerrel had also been causing problems on the turian border for years.
[Going Down with the Ship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoingDownWithTheShip):  (SPOILER) If you choose the geth in Rannoch, he stays onboard while his crew tries to escape.

[Honorary Uncle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HonoraryUncle): Not to the same degree as Raan, but Gerrel's long-standing friendship with Rael, affectionate behavior torward Tali, and the fact that Tali chose Gerrel's ship to serve on after completing her pilgrimage all point to Gerrel being Tali's surrogate uncle. This makes his choice to destroy the geth dreadnought with Tali still on board look even worse, and the invasion debacle as a whole results in a major [Broken Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal) on Tali's part.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): In *2*, when Shepard mentions getting the quarians to help fight the Reapers, Gerrel states that if it comes to a fight, they'll need somewhere to put all the non-combatants while they do so. It's his stubborn desire to get Rannoch back that can potentially get those non-combatants killed to a quarian in *3*.

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Seems to have switched places with Koris in *3*, considering his over-eagerness to destroy the geth dreadnought before Shepard and crew were evacuated from it. But Gerrel and Koris never actually switched their primary goals. Shepard's *own goal* has switched from game to game; in *2*, Shepard was primarily interested in exonerating Tali. Since Tali was the daughter of fellow warmonger Rael'Zorah and since Tali (initially) shared Rael's views, exonerating Tali would help Gerrel's cause and set Koris' cause back, so Gerrel is helpful to Shepard and Tali while Koris is a jerk. In *3*, Shepard is gathering as many fleets as possible to take on the Reapers, so it's in Shepard's best interest that the quarians not be too busy fighting a war with the geth. So *this* time, Shepard's own switched goal helps Koris' cause and obstructs Gerrel's cause, so Gerrel is at odds with Shepard and Koris is on Shepard's side.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint):
    - He's completely justified to dislike and distrust the geth, who have been nothing but 100% hostile to all organics since the Geth War began ("Revelation" even mentions that they butchered diplomats from the Council when they tried to contact them) and gave no indication peace ever was a realistic option to begin with. It doesn't help that the only geth that have left the Veil in 300 years have been the Heretics (who the 'true' geth made no attempt to stop or even differentiate themselves from), and that the only potential shred of evidence that he's wrong in his opinions were the words of Legion... who presents no evidence for its claims (aside from its loyalty mission, which Gerrel wasn't witness to) and cut communications with Tali in the gap between the second and third games when she tried to set up negotiations. (SPOILER) He comes across as especially justified if Legion died in *2*, as peace between the two sides will then be impossible. - Shepard can also potentially concede that, given the options at the time, firing at the Geth Dreadnought immediately after the shields came down probably was the best option. Just warn Shepard about it next time. - If Shepard chews him out for firing on the Dreadnought but does not punch him and kick him off the Normandy, Gerrel will counter that Shepard would have done the same if they could retake Earth. (SPOILER) This actually holds up credibly if Shepard later chooses to sacrifice all synthetic life to destroy the Reapers. - Siding with him over Raan in their argument results in him [sacrificing a bunch of frigates](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHaveReserves), which ultimately allows him to save other, more important ships. This results in a net gain of war assets +25 for the Heavy Fleet. Jerk or not, he knows what he's doing when it comes to commanding a battle fleet.

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold): His hatred towards the geth is motivated more by paranoia than actual malice. If Shepard can genuinely convince him that the geth will not be hostile, he backs down from attacking them after much deliberation, though arguably also out of self-preservation. After this, he goes along with the peace, leading his Heavy Fleet alongside the geth against the Reapers.

[Kicked Upstairs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickedUpstairs): He tells Shepard that in his youth he and Rael went cowboy to save a merchant ship they were assigned to from batarian pirates, saving the ship and crew but incurring the disfavour of "the brass", who subsequently "slapped medals on [their] suits then kicked [them] off to Pilgrimage a bit earlier than usual".
[Knight Templar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightTemplar): By *3.* As they say, [War Is Hell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarIsHell).

[Leeroy Jenkins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins): His general strategy in battle is to order the Heavy Fleet head-on into the enemy, and then warn the Civilian and Patrol Fleets that, without support, his fleet will be wiped out.

[Manipulative Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ManipulativeBastard): Some of Gerrel's tactics reveal the admiral's cunning political mind; by forcing the attack on the geth dreadnought, he put Raan in a position where she either had to back him or risk the destruction of the whole fleet, giving him the chance to destroy the geth flagship and give the quarians a fighting chance again.  (SPOILER) He tries the same thing after Shepard destroys the Reaper on Rannoch, and the Renegade way to [Take a Third Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeAThirdOption) is for Shepard to calmly state that they aren't falling for it this time: if Gerrel doesn't call off the attack, Shepard will stand by and watch as the Quarians are wiped out in the ensuing [Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle).

[Ooh, Me Accent's Slipping](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OohMeAccentsSlipping): Speaks with what can be considered a Received Pronunciation accent when he's introduced in *Mass Effect 2*, before switching to a vaguely Yorkshire-sounding one (the change in his vowel sounds are particularly noticeable) for his first few appearances in *Mass Effect 3* - only to then try to mix the two during the Priorty: Rannoch mission.

[Revenge Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RevengeBeforeReason): Well intentions or not, the conflict with the geth clearly also has a personal stain for him, which causes his [General Ripper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneralRipper) tendencies to get the better of him sometimes.

[Talk to the Fist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TalkToTheFist): When Gerrel orders the Migrant Fleet to  (SPOILER)  bombard the geth dreadnought Shepard and Tali/Xen are aboard , the aftermath discussion gives Shepard a Renegade interrupt to gut-punch him and boot him off the *Normandy*.

[Teeth-Clenched Teamwork](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeethClenchedTeamwork): With Tali and Legion in *3*, as they don't agree with his approach in the war. Shepard also generally disagrees, but by how much is up to question.

[Took a Level in Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInJerkass): He goes from being a good friend of Tali and her father to willing to sacrifice her and Shepard to destroy the geth dreadnought. And that's not even covering what he does  <sup>note </sup>  or at least intended to do before thinking better of it should peace happen  at the end of the Rannoch arc.

[The Unfettered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfettered): He will stop at *nothing* to have his vengeance on the geth.  (SPOILER) Even if you manage to get the quarians and geth to make peace, it's clear that he's absolutely *furious* .

[Warhawk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Warhawk): In his view, the extermination of the geth is the only war for his people to finally be free of this threat, so he constantly insists on waging war with them to wipe out the entire race completely.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): In *2*, he reveals that he believes Tali and Shepard about the Reaper threat (and is one of the few people in any position of authority to do so), and justifies the need to go to war with the geth by claiming that without a planet to shelter their noncombatants, the quarians would be unable to devote the full force of their fleet to the fight against the Reapers. In *3* he only attacks the geth because he believes that there is no other way to get back Rannoch and save his race, and also because he believes they're allies of the Reapers. He'll back down if convinced that peace is a realistic option.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): He attacks a geth ship that Shepard's on as soon as the defenses go down. No one else is happy about it. There's even a [Renegade Interrupt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/QuickTimeEvent) to punch him and kick him off the *Normandy* when he tries to rationalize it to Shepard. Paragon Shepard is more understanding, and simply tells Gerrel to give a warning next time.

[Chekhov's Gunman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGunman): Her interest in Rael'Zorah's research. If you keep it hidden, she'll "thank" you in an email and gloat about how she plans to use it on the geth (expose what Rael did and she'll be furious).  (SPOILER)  Her use of Rael's research is what starts the quarian-geth war in *3* .

[Dark Is Not Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkIsNotEvil): She wears a black suit, is voiced by [Claudia Black](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/ClaudiaBlack), is commonly called crazy, suggests dissecting Legion, and has a generally sinister air to her. However, even though she seems [Obviously Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObviouslyEvil), she never actually *does* anything villainous, and is on the same side as Shepard and co. Even if you effectively sabotage her eventual plan to subjugate the geth via making peace between the two sides, she doesn't make a big deal of it and proceeds to serve with distinction in the fight against the Reapers.

[For Science!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForScience): Introduce Legion to her and she'll express interest in experimenting on it, freaking it out a bit. QUOTE **Xen:** It has a *name*. Fascinating. The things I could learn under slightly different circumstances... **Legion:** This platform is not available for experimentation.
    - She'll do so offer twice again in *3*, once with Legion/the Geth VI, where Shepard can either cut her off or tell her to wait until later, and also with the Geth Primes to help Shepard find if they are trustworthy.

[Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius): She's the one who designed the arc pistol in *3*. However, EDI will point out that the way it works on geth would be outright *illegal* if it designed for use on organics.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint):  (SPOILER)  Should the quarians survive the war  and Shepard sides with Xen over Tali in their argument, up to 45 war assets can be added towards the Crucible, much like siding with Gerrel in his clash with Raan.

[Just a Machine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustAMachine): Believes the geth are malfunctioning machines, comparing them to starships (that are superior in various ways but are still just tools), and, if Shepard refers to  (SPOILER)  Legion's  help beating the Collectors, she states that the same could be said of their pistol.  (SPOILER) Thankfully, nothing seems to comes of it to jeopardize peace should you achieve it in *3*; she just gets shipped off to the Crucible, though at least one bit of cut content has her get killed by Hackett's people while trying to re-enslave the geth, an act that costs hundreds of Geth ships .

[Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist): If Tali dies in the suicide mission, she does all the hacking during the dreadnought mission. This includes making geth platforms dance for her (offscreen) amusement.
QUOTE  **Ashley:** She's not all the way sane, is she?

[Non-Action Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionGuy): Understandable, since she's a quarian and an admiral, but if she tags along on the dreadnought mission she takes no part in the fighting. Even when there are geth in the room with her she activates her [Invisibility Cloak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvisibilityCloak) and leaves Shepard and their squad to do all the fighting.

[Only Sane Woman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlySaneWoman): In *2*, she's the only judging Admiral at Tali's trial who's actually performing her duties correctly. While Koris and Gerrel try to score political points against each other, she's more or less objective. Though one could argue that that's only because of her lack of interest in the trial.

[The Sociopath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSociopath): Comes across as one at times, showing a marked lack of empathy towards others and her indifferent tone while discussing how she performed complex surgery on her childhood toys.
[Toy-Based Characterization](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToyBasedCharacterization): Mentions having performed complex surgery on a childhood toy. Tali thinks it explains a lot.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): Her ultimate priority is to recover Rannoch for her people, and wishes for the quarians to regain control of the geth in the process.
[You're Insane!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoureInsane): Tali's opinion of her plan to retake control of the geth, indicating that even among quarians, her views are extreme.

[Anti-Nepotism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiNepotism): Despite being one of the most powerful people in the Fleet, he was apparently a big believer in Tali not being treated differently over it. Case in point: during the escape to Ilos in *1*, if Shepard asks if Rael would protect Tali were they ever caught, Tali states that not only is stealing a ship a *capital* offense for the quarians, but Rael would probably insist on *executing Tali himself*.
[Apocalyptic Log](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ApocalypticLog):  (SPOILER) All we ever see of him , and he uses it to give his only child more orders about what to do with his findings.

[Beyond Redemption](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeyondRedemption):  (SPOILER) His experiments aboard the *Alarai* involved bringing deactivated geth online to test weapons on them. This violates some of the quarians' most sacred laws, laws that preclude their exile from Rannoch. As such, playing evidence of his actions in court causes most of the audience to [Gasp!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Gasp) in horror, he is posthumously [exiled](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheExile) for his actions and the quarians in the background mutter about him being a sick bastard, or that [they don't like the geth, but they think he went too far](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards).

[Boyfriend-Blocking Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoyfriendBlockingDad): In his letter authorising Tali's transfer to Shepard's command, he notes his concern that Tali may be lead astray by Shepard's influence and that [if any harm comes to her whatsoever, he will not hesitate to bring the full wrath of the quarian Admiralty Board down on Shepard's head](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PapaWolf). (SPOILER) He should've put the same thought into his own actions; despite Rael trying to minimize how much Tali sent him so that she won't be linked to his illegal doings, he and his crew end up getting killed and she gets charged with treason. QUOTE **Rael'Zora's letter:** Should any harm come to her due to negligence on your part, [this board will take severe and appropriate action.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpliedDeathThreat)
    - If Tali is romanced, she implies in *3* that (SPOILER) this would have been Rael's reaction to the relationship .
QUOTE **Tali:** I'm having a drink with my boyfriend. My *human* boyfriend! (SPOILER) Ha! My father would have *hated* you!

[Crazy-Prepared](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrazyPrepared):  (SPOILER)  When Tali finds his body on the *Alarei*, she initially thinks he *has* to have an onboard stasis unit in his suit, masked lifesigns, or *something!* He *always* had a plan! When it becomes clear he's really gone, Tali breaks down before realizing that he would have thought to have sent her a message, just in case the worst happened. Turns out she's *right* and what's more, he knew that Tali would be eventually called back to the Fleet and that she'd attempt to mount a rescue. His final message for Tali is a set of instructions on how she can shut down all the geth onboard .
[Disappeared Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisappearedDad): He wasn't as present in Tali's life as he could have been. In fact, she never even got to see his unmasked face.

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): Han's story about their pre-Pilgrimage adventure against batarian pirates tells us he has a reckless side and isn't afraid of bending the rules.  (SPOILER)  Apparently, promotion to Admiral only made this worse .
[Gadgeteer Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GadgeteerGenius): It's implied that Tali got her legendary technical prowess from him.

[Idiot Ball](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdiotBall): Rael decides to run experiments involving live geth and networking them, apparently without either a marine presence or telling the rest of the fleet about what he was doing. This foolish decision gets him and his crew killed and his daughter charged with treason. The only reason that the whole fleet wasn't put in danger is that one of the other scientists managed to lock down weapons and navigation before the geth killed her.
[Karmic Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmicDeath): He was using living geth as target practice. They later escape and kill him.

[Laser-Guided Karma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserGuidedKarma):
    - His plan was to ensure Tali did not know what he was doing to protect her. His actions get her charged with treason, and potentially have her exiled. - If you expose his actions at the trial, this will happen to you; you get Tali acquitted, but it's a matter of luck if she survives the Suicide Mission, and negotiating peace between the Quarians and Geth is impossible even if she does.

[Married to the Job](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MarriedToTheJob): Raan implies he wasn't always that way, but after Tali's mother died, he threw himself completely into [his work](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Workaholic).

[The Mourning After](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMourningAfter): Tali indicates that after her mother died, Rael became even more obsessed with his work, likely as this was the only way he could find to deal with his grief.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): Despite not having been a part of her life as much as Tali would have liked, Rael legitimately cares for his daughter.  (SPOILER) He ended up torturing and performing extremely morally questionable experiments on geth partly in the name of building Tali a house on Rannoch, and it can be inferred ([through the comic series](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual)) that his determination comes out of a need to make up for being so distant to her.

[Posthumous Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PosthumousCharacter): Nobody in the Migrant Fleet knows what became of him after they lost contact with the Alarei.  (SPOILER) By the time we find him, it turns out he's been dead a while .

[Sadistic Choice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SadisticChoice): Once you learn what he was really doing, you have a choice that can impact not just Tali's loyalty, but potentially Mass Effect 3. If you expose what he did, Tali gets acquitted, but any chance she survives the suicide mission is now based on luck, which will make the possibility of peace rendered a luck of the draw as well. Get Tali exiled, and she stays loyal, but peace is ruined because Shepard needs Tali as an admiral to get Han Gerrel to back down. [Taking a Third Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingAThirdOption) prevents his name from being ruined, while keeping Tali loyal and as an admiral.
[Sins of Our Fathers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SinsOfOurFathers): When Rael's experiments go awry, Tali gets caught up in the political fallout.

[The Extremist Was Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheExtremistWasRight): Regardless of whether you expose his wrongdoings or not, his research is used to create the breakthrough that can potentially allow the Quarians to take back the home world.

[Un-person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnPerson):  (SPOILER) If the truth of his actions is revealed to the public, Rael is posthumously exiled, and his name is struck from the register of every ship he served on. As far as anyone else is concerned, Rael never existed.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist):  (SPOILER)  He wanted to build Tali a house on the homeworld, and was prepared to torture sentient creatures and endanger the entire Migrant Fleet in order to do so .

[When You Coming Home, Dad?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhenYouComingHomeDad): Conversations with Tali make it clear that even before Mrs. Zorah died, Rael was barely an emotional presence in her life, and while he did love her, he was appalling when it came to showing it, coming off as remote and distant even when he was there.
QUOTE **Tali:** I wanted a father who would take the sick-leave time and let me see his face without a helmet in the way. Instead, I got *orders*.
[Workaholic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Workaholic): Tali thinks it was his way of coping with his wife's death.

[Break the Cutie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakTheCutie): A young, naive Quarian, much like Tali from the first *Mass Effect*. Having to witness the Collector attack broke Veetor, and it gets even worse if he's turned over to Cerberus.
[Character Witness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterWitness):  (SPOILER)  If you let Tali take him to safety, he and Reegar can be this during her trial.

[I Owe You My Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IOweYouMyLife):  (SPOILER)  If you didn't hand him over to Cerberus and Kal'Reegar is alive, then he'll step up to the plate with him to vouch for Tali during the "Rally the Crowd" option, arguing that she saved his life. Worth noting is that Veetor steps up *before* Reegar, despite having a fear of crowds.
[Madness Mantra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadnessMantra): "Monsters coming back. Mechs will protect. Safe from swarms. Have to hide. No monsters. No swarms. No-no-no-no-no."

[The Paranoiac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParanoiac): He degenerates into this after the Collector attack, with his existing mental health condition and damage to his suit systems making him too terrified to distinguish friend from foe. He turns the colony's defensive mechs on Shepard and even the quarians sent to rescue him since he's terrified of the Collectors coming back to get him.

[Sanity Slippage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SanitySlippage): Tali notes that Veetor's always had some unspecified mental condition, preferring isolation, which is why he chose to go to a quiet human backwater colony like Freedom's Progress for his pilgrimage. The Collectors attacking Freedom's Progress did a number on the poor guy, reducing him to a babbling wreck muttering a combination [Madness Mantra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadnessMantra) and [Survival Mantra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SurvivalMantra) to himself as he controls his mechs from a makeshift bunker.  (SPOILER)  If you hand him over to Cerberus, they stabilize him through brute-forcing medicine into him causing him to slip even harder to the point where he mistakes Shepard for a Husk during Tali's loyalty mission and is traumatized by the sight of them. If you didn't, he gets better — sort of. He states at the trial he's not quite right, but he's coping.

[Ship Tease](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease): A very minor one but  (SPOILER)  if Shepard asks if his burst of courage during the "Rally the Crowd" resolution to Tali's trial was due to being motivated by a pretty woman, he casts a glance over to his doctor Elan'Shiya and bashfully says "Well, maybe." hinting that he's developed feelings for her.

[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): Only makes two appearances. His first is near the start of the game, and informs you of the impending threat posed by the new [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad), the Collectors.

[Third-Person Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThirdPersonPerson): He tends to refer to himself as "Veetor" where "I" would be more appropriate when you meet him on Freedom's Progress.  (SPOILER)  If you didn't hand him over to Cerberus then he drops this tic by the time you meet him again during Tali's loyalty mission.

[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): No known genetic mods, not a member of a species with extreme physical advantages over humans, and yet he successfully distracts an entire geth platoon, including one of their walking tanks, by himself.
[Character Witness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CharacterWitness): During Tali's trial, along with Veetor, assuming he survives and Shepard chooses to "Rally The Crowd".

[Cultured Warrior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturedWarrior): Implied by some of his throwaway comments; Kal's tactical knowledge can be very useful when trying to navigate the last part of [Tali's recruitment mission](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatOneLevel), and if (SPOILER) he survives Tali's recruitment mission, he displays quite a bit of knowledge of the political machinations involved in Tali's trial in her loyalty mission.

[Dropped a Bridge on Him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DroppedABridgeOnHim): In the third game.  (SPOILER)  However, the bridge is far nicer to Kal than most examples of this trope: his death is sudden, but he dies a hero's death; thanks entirely to Kal and his squad, the turians don't get their communications messed up. He also gets a DLC weapon named after his family .

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):
    - (SPOILER) He offers to distract a Geth Colossus with a rocket launcher. Shepard can save him either by refusing to let him do it or by destroying the Colossus before it kills Reegar . - (SPOILER) Fully happens in the third game; he and his squad fix a vital turian comm relay, then hold the position until krogan reinforcements show up .

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths):  (SPOILER)  If you bring Legion along to Tali's recruitment mission, Kal'Reegar does react in surprise, shouting that you've got a geth right behind you... but when Legion explains that Legion is an ally, Kal'Reegar's smart enough not to be picky about having some [additional help](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine) in beating the *Geth Colossus*. Also, if you manage to exonerate Tali without revealing the evidence of Rael's crimes, or if you simply withhold the evidence and allow Tali to be exiled, Reegar manages to figure out that you did in fact have evidence but simply withheld it, although it's not made clear exactly *how* he figures it out. Of course, as a life-long soldier who's used to dealing with the quarian admiralty, it's not hard to imagine he's gotten adept at [recognising bullshit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies) when he hears it .

[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER) Even if you save him on Haestrom, he's doomed to die *off-screen*. An off-screen hero, however, whose squad is single-handedly responsible for the turians not losing an important communications relay .
[Mauve Shirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MauveShirt):  (SPOILER) Dies offscreen in the game after his appearance .

[My Country, Right or Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyCountryRightOrWrong): He thinks that the quarian fleet shouldn't go to war with the geth; nevertheless, he states that as a soldier he will follow any given order. Tali seems to imply that such thinking is common among quarians ("We are expected to be loyal, even when it is difficult").

[Obfuscating Stupidity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObfuscatingStupidity): Insists he's "just a soldier," and he "just shoots things". However, he's smart enough to conclude that attacking the geth for the homeworld would be suicidal, and also that Tali withheld evidence at her trial if you don't use it.
QUOTE  **Tali:** ...I didn't *say* anything about finding evidence, Kal. 
**Kal'Reegar:** Noticed that, ma'am.

[Precision F-Strike](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrecisionFStrike): If you choose '[Rally the Crowd](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GondorCallsForAid)' during Tali's trial, Kal will speak up on her behalf and call out the Admiralty Board.
QUOTE  **Kal'Reegar:** Tali's done more for this fleet than you *assholes* ever will!

[Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero): She has her noble points and her nasty ones. She's a crime boss whose crimes are [All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual), and she allows all manner of crime and misery on her station short of (SPOILER) Collector slaving . [If she really is Wrex's old friend Aleena](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WildMassGuessing), Wrex says Aleena chose to fight him on a station overrun with mercs with no one innocent to get in the way, and fondly says that she was always like that. In the Omega DLC Shepard can either soften her a little or get her to become more vicious.
    - And in Omega you find out (SPOILER) Petrovsky's gambit that resulted in her losing Omega was by threatening to destroy it, and her, in one swoop after he pulled his troops out. Did Aria simply decide to preserve her life to fight another day, or did she leave because nearly 8 million people were at risk of being killed? Or both? They're both certainly possible.
[Asskicking Leads to Leadership](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership): She seized Omega for herself after taking down the krogan who formerly ruled over it.

[Authority Grants Asskicking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AuthorityGrantsAsskicking): In her backstory, she beat a Krogan Battlemaster to a pulp, and is implied to have fought Urdnot Wrex himself to a draw. In-game, all she needs is sheer presence to keep the position even without doing any fighting — although she's quite capable of that, too. As shown in the comics and Omega DLC, being the "queen" of Omega hasn't dulled her battle skills any. A Cerberus scientist expresses amazement at her biotic capabilities.
[Belligerent Sexual Tension](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BelligerentSexualTension): With Paragon Shepard, ironically.

[Blatant Lies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies): She tells Shepard that Petrovsky is a brute who never shows mercy. Going by Nyreen's description of him, his backstory, the way he let Aria live when he took Omega, and his actions throughout the DLC, this couldn't be farther from the truth. That said, there is an audio log indicating that the General’s motives in granting safe quarter to anyone who surrendered, were not out of magnanimity - he contained them, so they could easily be converted  (SPOILER)  into Adjutants  as needed.

[Butch Lesbian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButchLesbian): While she may kiss a male Shepard in the *Omega* DLC, she clearly enjoys it more with a female Shepard, and all of her other mentioned relationships have been women. She's also an iron-fisted ruler who enjoys tearing her foes apart in a straightforward, direct manner and has little interest in subtlety.

[Cultured Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturedBadass): After the events of *Mass Effect: Invasion*, she reads up on human history, if only to catch up with Petrovsky's cryptic historical references. It's only made apparent in the game when she addresses the survivors on Omega: "People of Omega: I have returned." This is a reference to Douglas McArthur's triumphant return to the Philippines after having famously promised that he would do so years earlier. The comics explicitly elaborate on Petrovsky's references, as well as the implication that he's on the losing side if Aria's playing the role of McArthur.

[Damsel in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselInDistress): Unusually frequently in the Omega DLC.
    - [Badass in Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassInDistress): But there is no denying that Aria *is* a badass. She only ends up in distress because she allows her desire for revenge to get the best of her. (SPOILER) And even while bound during the final fight, she *still* manages to start tearing into the Cerberus troops and adjutants as soon as you blow up the first generator .

[A Day in the Limelight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ADayInTheLimelight): She gets a short comic series from her perspective on Omega, *Mass Effect: Incursion*.
    - Stars in another 4 issue series called *Mass Effect: Invasion*. The *Omega* DLC makes a whole lot more sense if you read this first before playing the DLC. - She's also a central character in the Omega DLC for *3* in which she and Shepard take back Omega from Cerberus.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): She has her moments in *3*.
QUOTE **Shepard:** How do you plan on  (SPOILER) taking Omega back ? 
**Aria:** I *think* I'm going to employ violence.
[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): Aria has two moods, "in control" and "pissed." Even when she's in a firefight, she never loses her cool.

tropeName: Does This Remind You of Anything?
tropeNotes: [Does This Remind You of Anything?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoesThisRemindYouOfAnything): In the *Omega* DLC, she's frequently says "It feels *good* to cut loose" or similar statements when hitting enemies with Flare, her most powerful ability.

[Enemy Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine): Invoked by Admiral Hackett in *3* when Shepard gets Aria to commit to helping the Alliance.
QUOTE **Hackett:** Aria T'Loak! There's someone I never thought we'd be in bed with!

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Think that Aria'd be okay with (SPOILER) Collector deals on her station if it doesn't bother her? Think again.
    - Also, when told that an Ardat-Yakshi is in Omega, Aria is quick to point Shepard to the right direction. On the other hand, this may just be because she likes Shepard (and doesn't want a justicar making a scene). She comments that it doesn't matter to her so long as the Ardat-Yakshi doesn't try to seduce *her*. - With all the political maneuvering going on while *the Reapers are invading the galaxy*, Aria's matter-of-fact statement that if Shepard doesn't defeat them "it won't matter where I'm sitting," followed by her freely-given military support and resources, is all kinds of refreshing. [Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure) is not a trope generally associated with the ruthless pirate queen, but at least she doesn't waste time with politics. - She also states that she'd "rather disappear than be forced to kill someone." - While recruiting the Blue Suns, Aria prefers that Septimus Oraka be "bought off" to leave the Suns alone, rather than be assassinated.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): As shown in the *Omega DLC*, Aria may qualify as this to Shepard. She even has her own equivalent to [Garrus Vakarian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLancer), with whom she shares a...complex relationship. Like Garrus, Nyreen is a idealistic turian who felt boxed in by rules and red tape and decided to leave their organisation after meeting a powerful, charismatic person who "didn't let anyone else define [them]".

[Evil Versus Oblivion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilVersusOblivion): Outright invoked by Aria on why she's giving Shepard mercenary fleets and a mountain of eezo: if the Reapers win, there will be nothing to rule over.

[Fatal Flaw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatalFlaw):
    - [Wrath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Wrath). Aria is normally cold and calculating, but when she sees the chance to take back Omega, she lets her rage drive her so much that she makes many mistakes that would have been fatal if Shepard had not been there. (SPOILER) And that's just a *quiet* rage. When Nyreen Kandros sacrifices herself to take out a group of Adjutants, Aria goes into a *berserk* rage and starts wrecking everything in sight, charging into the Afterlife club and accidentally jumping right into General Oleg Petrovsky's trap . - Also, [Pride](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Pride). She's monumentally arrogant and, unlike Petrovsky, underestimates her enemies numerous times. Normally this would get her killed, but Shepard was with her and Petrovsky was unusually merciful the first time around.
[Femme Fatale](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FemmeFatale): How she usurped control of Omega from Patriarch.
