[Fiction 500](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Fiction500): She has an [eezo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Unobtainium) hoard so immense it's worth **300** War Asset points — the same military value as *an entire army of geth or krogan.*

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): In the second game, you can find evidence that the merc groups of Omega are plotting to overthrow her behind her back. The fact that she missed such an obvious plot (the merc leaders literally leave notes containing the plan around their bases) is a hint that she's not quite as meticulous a schemer as she would like everyone to believe. Turns into [Chekhov's Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGun) later, when first the Shadow Broker and then Cerberus manage to run rings around her intelligence efforts. That culminates in her nearly losing everything she has by the end of *3*.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): For the Omega DLC in 3.

[Has a Type](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HasAType): The only person she's confirmed to have had an actual romantic relationship with is [Nyreen Kandros](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParagon). The similarities between Kandros and Shepard go a long ways towards explaining the undercurrent of [Belligerent Sexual Tension](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BelligerentSexualTension) between them and Aria.

[Having a Blast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HavingABlast): Her Flare power allows her to make a biotic *explosion*, much larger than Warp. The effects are comparable to a grenade or a missile burst. And on top of that, it's a combo detonator power, so there may be secondary explosions as well. The best part is that it's a selectable bonus power for Shepard back on the Normandy.

[I Am the Trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IAmTheTrope):
    - For starter: QUOTE **Shepard:** You run Omega? **Aria:** I *am* Omega. - The Paragon Ending of *Omega* has her invert this during her [Rousing Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RousingSpeech); QUOTE **Aria:** We may be bruised, we may be bloodied... but *[we](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeAreStrugglingTogether) are* Omega!
[I Have Many Names](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveManyNames): Aria is just the latest in a long line of names she's had.
[I Knew It!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IKnewIt): Aria's reaction to finding out an Ardat-Yakshi is hiding out in Omega, noting that nothing else leaves corpses so *empty*.  invoked

[Iron Lady](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IronLady): Anybody who can keep power in [Omega](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WretchedHive) for centuries is not to be taken lightly. Also, *Mass Effect 3* shows that she has connections as high as the asari Councilor and can bypass the immigration process of the Citadel simply by asking her.
    - Especially prominent in the *Omega DLC* during the (SPOILER) retaking of Omega .

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): Midway through the *Omega* DLC, she insists that Shepard immediately shut down the barriers they've found themselves trapped in, even if doing so would also destroy several life-support mechanisms on Omega and subsequently kill off many civilians.
[Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam): While much more subdued than most examples, Aria can be quite bombastic for someone played by Carrie-Anne Moss.

[Leeroy Jenkins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins): Aria isn't the most tactical of warriors. She overestimates her own abilities and basically boils down to [Attack! Attack! Attack!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttackAttackAttack).

[Lysistrata Gambit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LysistrataGambit): One of the factors that led to her success in overthrowing the Patriarch for control of Omega was that — as she puts it when telling Shepard the story — the Patriarch's men had gotten used to "certain perks" that came with working with asari.

[Mage Marksman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MageMarksman): Uses shotguns and has heavily offense-oriented biotics. She also can launch [Carnage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire) blasts, like James. In many ways, she's like the Vanguard from Mass Effect 1.

[Mama Bear](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MamaBear): If she sees it as hers, she protects it, whether it's Omega itself, her underlings, or (SPOILER) her actual children .
    - In *[Mass Effect: Retribution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Literature/MassEffectRetribution)* she believes that (SPOILER) Grayson killed her daughter Liselle . Unfortunately, (SPOILER) this made her fall right into Cerberus' plans, since it was actually Kai Leng .

[Morality Chain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralityChain): Nyreen and Paragon Shepard take turns in this role during the *Omega DLC*, curbing Aria's more violent tendencies and suggesting other strategies that don't involve sacrificing troops as cannon-fodder for Cerberus. Renegade Shepard on the other hand [encourages her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ToxicFriendInfluence).

[Mysterious Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MysteriousPast): No one knows where she came from or who she was before she came to Omega, and her name is just a pseudonym. Once Shepard gains her trust (or as much as Aria ever gives), Aria will allude to certain aspects of her past. It's strongly hinted that she's Aleena, the asari commando that Wrex was friends with centuries ago.
QUOTE **Aria:** Sometimes you'd rather disappear than be forced to kill someone. 
**Aria:** Better luck next time.

[Never Mess with Granny](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMessWithGranny): In the novel *Mass Effect: Retribution*, Aria reflects to herself that she's survived for "... over a thousand years." Since this is her internal monologue, there is no reason to suspect she's lying. Being over 1,000 years old puts her clearly in the Matriarch stage of her life and makes her old even by asari and krogan standards. Even though *Mass Effect* takes place in the future, Aria would have been born at least when *Genghis Khan* was alive on Earth.

[N.G.O. Superpower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NGOSuperpower): If Shepard runs errands for her on the Citadel and helps her retake Omega, she provides the war effort with not one but *two* separate fleets which, combined with her aforementioned hoard of element zero, rival the military value of all the ships and commandos contributed by the Asari Republics.

[Noble Demon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleDemon): She's by no means *nice*, but she's forthcoming with vital information Shepard needs, she approves of Mordin trying to cure the plague (that and of Mordin's willingness to resort to shooting people if the doctor route doesn't work), she's quick to try to help Shepard solve the Ardat-Yakshi problem, she gives you a reward if you do her a couple of favors (specifically she tells you the location of a planet with supplies on it), and in the comics  (SPOILER) she becomes extremely angry at the Collectors trying to make deals for live specimens on her station . Also, in *3*, if you do a few errands for her, she gives you a Terminus Fleet with three "updates" each worth 50 War Asset points, which combined with the Fleet itself makes for a whopping *200* War Asset points (which is very noble of Aria because the majority of non-major-plotline War Assets are less than 100). Then, on top of all of that, helping her in the Omega DLC has her give Shepard an additional 375 War Assets minimum (405 if she gets to kill Petrovsky, otherwise Petrovsky gets a deal from the Alliance). Aria T'loak may be ruthless, but when she gives her word to help she means it.

[Not-So-Harmless Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoHarmlessVillain): When she first came to Omega, Patriarch thought she was just another dancer. After crushing a few of his organs and breaking half of his bones, she's been ruling Omega for centuries.

[Not So Stoic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoStoic):
    - Her entire persona consists largely of appearing emotionless and detached, aside from intimating her displeasure when her underlings get out of hand. Her expression when she realizes (SPOILER) Nyreen is going to sacrifice herself is anything but the disaffected mask we've come to expect from her. - In addition, she is genuinely heartbroken by the loss of (SPOILER) her daughter Liselle . It's enough of a character trait that Petrovsky uses it to manipulate her into acting foolishly *twice*. And it works both times.

[Odd Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OddFriendship): She'd never admit it, but by the end of *Omega*, it's clear to everyone she's got a great rapport with Shepard, paragon included.
    - Particularly with Paragon Shepard, who manages to edge her into [Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold) territory.
QUOTE **Aria:** I'd been waiting to kill him for months. I spend a couple of hours running around with you then I go all soft. [You're like a](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContagiousHeroism) [disease.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VitriolicBestBuds)

[One-Man Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneManArmy): In the comics. Put in a [Tailor-Made Prison](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TailorMadePrison), relieved of all weapons, and suspended face-down with restraints on each limb, she frees herself, kills her attendant, and murders her way out of the compound and onto an escape ship with nothing but her biotics and fists. And that's just the second issue!

[Opposites Attract](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OppositesAttract): With her former paramour, Nyreen Kandros; Aria is an unfettered, calculating queenpin who only cares about maintaining absolute control of Omega. Nyreen is [The Paragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParagon) - no less intelligent than Aria, but much more morally upright. This might also explain her subtle-but-persistent [Belligerent Sexual Tension](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BelligerentSexualTension) with Paragon Shepard.

[O.O.C. Is Serious Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OOCIsSeriousBusiness): As noted elsewhere, Aria is normally very cold and calculating, which gives an idea of how enraged she is over the loss of Omega when she goes into a mindless fury when the time comes to retake it.
[Out-Gambitted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutGambitted):  (SPOILER) Over the course of *Invasion*. The Illusive Man is probably lucky Shepard got to him first — Aria wouldn't have made it so quick .

[Person of Mass Destruction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PersonOfMassDestruction): Easily one of the most purely destructive biotics in the series. One of her exclusive powers, 'Flare', is pretty much a biotic artillery strike.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): Has a number of these off-screen, as befitting her [Noble Demon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleDemon) status. She gives out Shepard's contact information to a wannabe-merc (if Shepard stopped him from joining the mercs going after Archangel) so he can thank Shepard and gives Shepard's contact information to a grieving mother for the same reason. It's also implied that her reasons for asking Shepard to defend Patriarch aren't entirely to protect her standing.
    - A minor one in *3*. If Shepard drinks enough in [Purgatory](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodGuyBar) to pass out, they come to next to Aria on her couch, despite the bar being a level and a half above where Aria is sitting. If Shepard then returns to the bar and gets that drunk *[again](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IdiotBall)*, without leaving that level, she opts not to extend that kindness and Shep wakes up in the elevator. - If Shepard talks the Patriarch into attacking the mercenaries by himself and his dies in a blaze of glory, Aria admits that it was better for him to go out that way than rotting away as her "advisor". If Shepard talks the Patriarch into letting Shepard serve as his krantt, then Aria is pleased that her old foe has rediscovered his lost pride. - Much as she tries to hide it, it's clear during *Omega* that she is deeply fond of Nyreen still, nature of their parting aside. She openly states that she bears her old lover no ill will and doesn't wish any harm on the turian, and even makes it clear that she doesn't blame Nyreen alone for their relationship crumbling, despite resenting her code of ethics. Given how revenge-prone she can occasionally be when she's angry, it's a surprising display of empathy.

[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): Unlike the nominally heroic Council and many of Earth's other allies, she decides that her best bet of surviving the Reaper invasion is Commander Shepard, and to that end she willingly commits every resource at her disposal to the cause. Upon learning there's an Ardat Yakshi running loose on Omega, her only reaction is an [I Knew It!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IKnewIt), and dismissing that since Morinth hasn't tried to seduce *her*, she's not going to try to deal with her.  invoked

[Precision F-Strike](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrecisionFStrike): "Omega has no titled ruler, and only one rule. Don't *fuck* with Aria."
    - "[I like it. Easy to remember.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/PiratesOfTheCaribbeanDeadMansChest)" - Alluded to in *3*. ["It looks like there's only one rule on the Citadel."](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallBack) - Mordin's [Self-Insert Fic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfInsertFic) states he broke Aria's one rule — [literally](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoldlyComing). - And appropriately reprised in the Renegade end of the Omega DLC: "Don't *fuck* with Omega!"
[Promoted to Playable](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PromotedToPlayable): For the Omega DLC, and the way Shepard can learn the extremely powerful Lash ability.
[Psychotic Smirk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychoticSmirk): Shepard tends to elicit a few sideways grins from her.

[The Queenpin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheQueenpin): She's the most powerful crimeboss in Omega and somehow has enough pull to influence the Asari Councilor. In *3*, she can even potentially end up controlling three of the biggest mercenary companies in the galaxy.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): She is one of the few leaders in the game to recognize that her political position won't matter if the Reapers kill everyone, so she unhesitatingly commits all her forces to Shepard to help stop them.

[Reclining Reigner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecliningReigner): has a large couch in the Afterlife bar that she gives orders from, making it a kind of unofficial throne. During the events of the *Omega* DLC in the third game, there is an optional quest to recover this couch.

tropeName: A Riddle Wrapped in a Mystery Inside an Enigma
tropeNotes: [A Riddle Wrapped in a Mystery Inside an Enigma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ARiddleWrappedInAMysteryInsideAnEnigma): She says something to this effect about Shepard if Shepard chooses a mix of Renegade and Paragon options during the *Omega* DLC, saying that she cannot tell if Shepard is just trying to jerk her around. Considering how much stock she places in being able to read and predict other people, this a pretty big admission on her part. Shepard can cheekily respond that's how they like it, and they want to keep Aria guessing.

[Roaring Rampage of Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoaringRampageOfRevenge): The Omega DLC.  (SPOILER) Especially after Nyreen dies. Aria takes down Afterlife's defenses with biotics so powerful that Shepard gets knocked off balance... which leads to her getting captured .

[Rousing Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RousingSpeech):
    - Subverted. (SPOILER) She's not using the speech to instill heroism and courage in Omega's populace; she's doing it to manipulate Nyreen with the threat of civilian casualties. Nyreen sees right through it . - Played straight with her final speech, either "We *are* Omega!" or "Don't *fuck* with Omega!" capping it off depending on a Paragon or Renegade Shepard.

tropeName: Screw the Rules, I Have Connections!
tropeNotes:
[Screw the Rules, I Have Connections!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewTheRulesIHaveConnections): In her first scene in the third game, C-Sec threatens to throw her off the station (it only took them three weeks to figure them out she was there illegally). She replies by ringing up the asari councilor (Tevos or Irissa), who waves her through at once.
QUOTE **Shepard:** Looks like there's only one rule on the Citadel, too.

[Slouch of Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SlouchOfVillainy): Spends the entirety of Mass Effect 2 lounging on her couch in the nightclub Afterlife. In Mass Effect 3's core game, she spends her time lounging on a couch in the nightclub Purgatory.

[The Starscream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStarscream): Became this towards the former ruler of Omega, who she later made her [Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon).
    - Although according to Aria, Patriarch betrayed *her*; she simply retaliated. Violently.

[Tattooed Crook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TattooedCrook): Although given that Omega has almost no "rule of law" to speak of and she herself is responsible for there being any "order" on Omega *at all*, she's only a crook "de facto".

[Teacher/Student Romance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeacherStudentRomance): With Nyreen Kandros, who she mentored in both biotics and combat. It didn't end well, and the two of them still aren't on great terms.
[Token Evil Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenEvilTeammate): When paired with Paragon Shepard and Nyreen. They can soften her up though.

[Too Clever by Half](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooCleverByHalf): She is cunning, but she's too arrogant to guard her flanks. This bites her on the ass when dealing with opponents like the Illusive Man, who manages to  (SPOILER)  manipulate her into letting him underrun her and take over Omega, using her love for the station and her inability to recognize a real threat against her until it's too late .

[Under New Management](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnderNewManagement):
    - (SPOILER) As of the end of *Mass Effect: Invasion*, Aria is no longer the ruler of Omega . - (SPOILER) After *Mass Effect 3: Omega*, she's back. And potentially a little gentler if you steered her that way .

[Tranquil Fury](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TranquilFury): If she isn't making a speech, Aria hardly ever raises her voice. She spends most of her DLC mission itching for revenge on Petrovsky, but still keeps the volume low even while she  (SPOILER) slowly and painfully chokes the life from him .

[Unstoppable Rage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnstoppableRage): When her [Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton) finally gets pushed in *Omega*.
QUOTE **Petrovsky:** Now, it's over. 
**Aria:** This isn't over until your next of kin can't identify you!
[UST](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UST): Develops this with Shepard, both Renegade and Paragon.

[Villain Protagonist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainProtagonist): In the *Omega* DLC, where she is perfectly willing to let thousands of innocents die just to save herself and preserve her power. Her level of [Revenge Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RevengeBeforeReason) and chilling brutality is not matched by any other squadmate in the series with the possible exception of Zaeed, and his was on a relatively smaller scale. No matter *what* allegiances the situation has forced her to make, the woman remains a crime lord openly simmering with rage.  (SPOILER) You can potentially convince her to become an [Anti-Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiHero) at the end of the DLC .

[Villainesses Want Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainessesWantHeroes): *Omega* reveals that this was the case with Nyreen, who "[oozes virtue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParagon)" according to Aria. It's explained that the relationship failed when they both realised that they couldn't make [Dating Catwoman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DatingCatwoman) work without changing the other.
    - Likewise implied with a subtle undercurrent of [Belligerent Sexual Tension](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BelligerentSexualTension) in conversations between Aria and Paragon Shepard.
[We Have Reserves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHaveReserves): She's willing to sacrifice millions of Omega's citizens to keep her own power by throwing them at Cerberus machine guns.

[We Used to Be Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeUsedToBeFriends): Aria and Patriarch used to be if not friends then at least allies before Aria made her take-over. Dialogue leaves it a little vague as to who fired the first shot.

[We Will Meet Again](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeWillMeetAgain): What she promises General Petrovsky after he  (SPOILER) forces her to abandon Omega . [They do.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownloadableContent) Petrovsky doesn't much appreciate her keeping to her word.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent):
    - She admits that she has a certain level of respect for the "Patriarch." - General Petrovsky also ends up being one; ruthless, cultured, and just as much of a [Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Chessmaster). - She also comes to respect Shepard, even if she will deride a Paragon for being a "Boyscout/Girlscout".

[You Have Failed Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveFailedMe): The Omega DLC hints that she practices this. After she's informed that Nyreen has slipped away by Bray, whom she'd ordered to keep an eye on her, she glares at him and growls "if I wasn't already short-handed..."

[You Need to Get Laid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouNeedToGetLaid): At one point, Aria will tell Shepard that they should find a "nice girl" (if Shepard is male) or a "nice young man" (if Shepard is female) to keep them warm in the meantime, since Shepard looks like they need to "loosen up a little."
[You Will Not Evade Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouWillNotEvadeMe): Uses the Lash ability previously introduced in the multiplayer.

tropeName: Can't Kill You, Still Need You
tropeNotes: [Can't Kill You, Still Need You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantKillYouStillNeedYou): He states that one of the reasons that he was kept alive was that he was still useful due to his knowledge of the politics of Omega, though those years are likely long gone.

[Defeated and Trophified](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefeatedAndTrophified): When Aria T'Loak usurped his control of Omega out from under him a hundred years ago, rather than kill the krogan she considered a [Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent), Aria decided to further cement her new power by leaving him alive and made an example of what happens to those who think of challenging her. Given that, as mentioned, she's stayed in power for at least 100 years, the gesture fulfilled its purpose.

[Everyone Calls Him "Barkeep"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneCallsHimBarkeep): "Patriarch" is not his real name, and the very few who do remember what it was, i.e. Aria, are not keen to share it. As the asari herself explains, since her people are an [all-female](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SingleGenderSpecies) species that has no real concept of masculinity, naming her defeated rival in a way that is meaningless conveys exactly what his life has turned out to be.

[Face Death with Dignity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceDeathWithDignity): If Shepard manages to convince him to go and face the assassins hired to take him out, Patriarch willingly charges into the storm of gunfire, putting an end to his miserable life in a way befitting of the [Proud Warrior Race Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRaceGuy) he longed to be once more.

[Glory Days](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GloryDays): He harbors great bitterness at Aria's decision to leave him alive, and the most enjoyment he gets out of life is to tell great tales of his warlord days to his "fans" (read: anyone with the patience and/or inebriation to listen to his self-grandizing)

[Throw the Dog a Bone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrowTheDogABone): If Shepard chooses to kill Patriarch's assassins for him, he regains some of his pride through having a Krantt willing to fight for him.
[Call-Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallBack): Looks and sounds exactly like Jenkins from the first game, so much so that they're both voiced by the same actor.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Of Jenkins. It's likely that the irony was not lost on Shepard. A little bit of [Fridge Brilliance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FridgeBrilliance): Same voice, same face. Shepard is remembering Jenkins, and they're not going to [let it happen again](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGreatestSecondChance).
[Good Feels Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodFeelsGood): Stopping him from signing up and later receiving a message from him that he'll make the most of what Shepard did for him.

[Instant Expert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InstantExpert): How he sees himself, thinking that all he has to do is know how to use a pistol. All of Shep's squadmates make varying comments about Jonn's incompetence on this matter.
QUOTE **Grunt:** He's soft and new. Dead in the first wave. 
**Jacob:** So does Archangel. 
**Kasumi:** A five-year-old can figure out how to use a gun. 
**Miranda:** You'll need to know more than that if you want to survive. 
**Mordin:** Don't be stupid. Dangerous work. Clear you're not suited for it. 
**Zaeed:** Yeah, you know enough to get yourself killed!

[Leeroy Jenkins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins): And unlike Jenkins himself, Jonn fulfills this trope completely. If you don't prevent him from signing up, he's the first freelancer to be killed by Archangel during the assault.

[Video Game Caring Potential](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VideoGameCaringPotential): Using the Paragon interrupt to break his gun before he can get himself killed. Since Shepard does this right after he mentions spending a lot to buy the gun, this implies their other reason for jamming the heat-sink was to ensure he got a good refund.

[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): Appears to be this to Omega's vorcha inhabitants, who are evidently suspicious of his "tricks" and refuse to interact with Shepard for fear they are one of his agents.
[Friendly Sniper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendlySniper): He wields an M-97 Viper sniper rifle, and is one of the friendlier faces in Aria's organization that Shepard can interact with.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): Despite being a minor character, he is the focus of three videos in the Shadow Broker's video archives which show him fighting vorcha on Omega and with his apparent boyfriend.
[Interspecies Romance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InterspeciesRomance): Heavily implied to be romantically involved with a male human.
[Straight Gay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StraightGay): No one would have ever guessed his sexuality if not for the video showing his apparent boyfriend.
[Deal with the Devil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DealWithTheDevil): Metaphorically. He traded many of his species to the Collectors for the technology and/or knowledge to produce Grunt.
[Death by Origin Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathByOriginStory): He dies during the mission, leaving Grunt to potentially take his place.
[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): According to Wrex, Okeer is a very old, very hated name amongst the krogan.
[Dub Name Change](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DubNameChange): In some versions, namely the French one, it's spelt Hokir instead, though the pronunciation isn't changed.

[Elite Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteArmy): His end goal is to turn the krogan from a vast horde to a less numerous but more powerful and skilled army.
QUOTE **Okeer:** We will not need the numbers. My soldier is a template. It is a greater threat than all the phantom siblings that would have been at its flank. The galaxy still bears the scars of the horde. But it will learn to fear the lance.
[Evil Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGenius): Serves this role for Jedore, [at first](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonWithAnAgenda), since he produces cloned krogan soldiers for her army.
[Evilutionary Biologist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilutionaryBiologist): He's a geneticist and is more concerned with breeding the "perfect" krogan, rather than curing the genophage.

[Exact Words](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactWords): Much is said about how "flawed" his cloned army of krogan is, but he points out that they are healthy, strong krogan soldiers, which is exactly what Jedore asked him for. The problem as he sees it is that she lacks the ability to command her own men, never mind a krogan.

[The Extremist Was Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheExtremistWasRight): The Shaman and Wrex both acknowledge Okeer was a [Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist), but also say his ideas of a genetically superior krogan was a brilliant stroke. The Shaman will send a letter to Shepard telling them that Grunt is extremely valuable to the krogan race, and to make sure he doesn't die. Imagine an army of Grunts, and anyone can see why.
[Genius Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser): In addition to being a krogan, he's a brilliant scientist and used this to become a feared Warlord.
[Klingon Scientists Get No Respect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KlingonScientistsGetNoRespect): Averted. Being a scientist is one of the reasons he is so feared and hated by the other krogan.

[Legacy Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegacySeeker): Monomaniacally obsessed with creating a legacy in the form of the perfect Krogan warrior, believing that it would make the genophage obsolete and cement his name in history. In the process, he willingly collaborates with the Collectors in order to obtain the necessary materials, allies himself with insane mercenary captain Jedore, and abandons thousands of his creations for not living up to his standards - resulting in numerous deaths when the rejects begin attacking Jedore's troops.  (SPOILER) It ends up costing Okeer his life when Jedore turns on him, but his prototype super-soldier lives on as a member of Shepard's team.

[Not Worth Killing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotWorthKilling): He intends to make the Genophage "ignorable" by changing the krogan to an [Elite Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteArmy), and it starts with creating the perfect krogan soldier.

[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): He is more than glad Saren's "pale horde" of krogan slaves were destroyed by Shepard on Virmire — not even on moral or saving the galaxy grounds, but mostly because they would have been nothing but another mass-produced army who had nothing going for them but numbers, the very thing Okeer has been working to change with his experiments.
[Red Herring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedHerring): Until the very end of the mission, the player is led to believe they are recruiting Okeer instead of bringing Grunt on board.
[Science Hero](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScienceHero): The krogan equivalent. He used his talent for science to become one of the most feared krogan warlords ever.

[The Social Darwinist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSocialDarwinist): Speaking to him reveals this is his basic mindset. He's proud of the krogan, but only so far; the old krogan horde (as well as Saren's horde) was designed to crush everything under weight of numbers, and the current krogan spend resources on making sure every krogan alive lives at least until adulthood. He believes that the current state of affairs enables the kind of coddling that allows "weak" krogan to survive where they should be dying out. His plans to rejuvenate the krogan start at creating a single super soldier that will [serve as a template for other krogan to aspire to match](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheParagon).

[Visionary Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VisionaryVillain): All his actions, morally and scientifically ambiguous as they are, were motivated by his desire to reinvigorate his species.
QUOTE **Urdnot Shaman:** Okeer was a madman, but he was a madman with a plan, and that's more than most have on this ball of rock.

[Warrior Poet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorPoet):
    - Very eloquent, especially when describing Shepard's actions [at Saren's base on Virmire.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect1) QUOTE **Okeer:** Such a tale! Saren, the Spectre traitor, threatens the return of the krogan horde by curing the genophage, undoing the gentle genocide of the turians and the salarians. But before Saren can deliver his endless troops, in rides Shepard, securing victory through nuclear fire. I like that part. It has weight. - It's more than likely that he used neural imprinting to pass this trait onto Grunt, since he similarly demonstrates an exquisite word-choice only seconds after being decanted from his tank.

[We Have Reserves](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHaveReserves): Defied. Oh, sure, he cares very little for his failed krogan subjects and throws them away to buy Shepard time to reach him, but he hates how his species rely on superior numbers to win battles and calls Saren's planned slave army of krogan a "pale horde", opining that numbers alone aren't enough to win battles. He wants to create the perfect krogan as a template for the rest of krogankind to follow, believing they would be better off as an [Elite Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteArmy) than trying to [Zerg Rush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZergRush) everything again.
[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): Willing to strike deals with the Collectors to make his ultimate soldier.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): In *3* it's mentioned by Grunt that he saw the rachni this way, likely for how they were the only other species in the galaxy who threatened the Citadel races like the krogan did.
[And There Was Much Rejoicing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndThereWasMuchRejoicing):  (SPOILER) If Kalros kills him in Mass Effect 3, Wrex isn't sad to see him go .
[Art Evolution](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArtEvolution): Looks pretty much like Wrex's twin brother minus the scarring in *2*. In the third game, he has a darker colour.

[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): Wrex actually seems relieved after his death, calling him "a pain in the ass anyway." Considering his jerkass attitude and  (SPOILER) his intentions as krogan leader if the Genophage is cured , Wrex is probably right.

[Asskicking Leads to Leadership](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership): Standard krogan procedure. He gets the other clans to let him represent them through "a time-honored tradition of intimidation, threats and violence."

[Bitch in Sheep's Clothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BitchInSheepsClothing): During the second game, he acts quite laid back, even downright friendly towards Shepard, before revealing his true colours in the third game.

[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): Far more "[traditional](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DumbMuscle)" than his brother. Whereas Wrex works to create a neutral zone where all clans are welcome, Wreav only co-operates with clan Gatatog because the two are at a stalemate.

[Bullying a Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BullyingADragon): On both the giving and receiving end, with a Renegade Shepard giving precisely zero damns about antagonising him through *3*, but he has no problem antagonising Shepard with threats of revenge when he needs Shepard's help. Javik even notes the stupidity of it.

[Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey): If Wrex is alive then Wreav does nothing but get headbutted by Wrex, pacified by Eve, and finally unceremoniously eaten alive by Kalros...and is promptly forgotten about seconds later.
[Cain and Abel](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CainAndAbel): The Cain to Wrex's Abel.

[The Cake Is a Lie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCakeIsALie): The promise of the genophage cure.  (SPOILER)  Shepard can promise ending the genophage in exchange for Wreav and the krogan joining the fight against the Reapers. However it's possible to sabotage the cure, and Wreav will be utterly oblivious he's getting nothing in return until the very moment he returns home to find no victory party.

[Cultural Posturing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturalPosturing): Tries doing this after the encounter with the Rachni in *3*, boasting to Shepard how they needed a krogan to get out alive. Shepard can shoot right back by pointing out it was Grunt who saved them, not him.
[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): He doesn't appear until the third game if Wrex survived Virmire... and is then killed shortly after.
[Dirty Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyOldMan): If he shows up to Priority: Earth in *3*, he gloats to Shepard that he's late because of all the mating he's been doing lately.

[Dumb Muscle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DumbMuscle): Unlike [Genius Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser) Wrex, he's basically a stupid thug with no greater ambitions beyond power and violence.  (SPOILER) Wrex might be smart enough to see through you if you betray him and sabotage the genophage cure, but Wreav sure isn't, something which Wrex himself makes note of in his confrontation. 
QUOTE  **Wrex:**  (SPOILER) Mordin wasn't my only source in STG. Or did you think I was dumb as my brother, Wreav?
[Eaten Alive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EatenAlive): If Wrex is alive, he gets swallowed by Kalros.

[Enemy Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine): If he's the krogan leader in *3*, then his interactions with any of the other races are this. It's made clear that he's almost certainly going to use the Genophage cure to bolster krogan forces and attack/threaten the rest of the galaxy when they're weak after the Reaper war.
QUOTE **Wreav:** Violence can be a powerful tool, Shepard.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): He apparently disapproves — or would disapprove — of  (SPOILER) Maelon's  experiments, forcing him to turn to Clan Weyrloc. However, like Wrex, [he's angry if Shepard destroys the data](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite).

[Evil Gloating](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGloating): A restrained version in *2*, as he admits that killing Wrex allowed him to take control and crush the reformist krogan that'd started springing up after Virmire.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): He considers the krogan to be the apex race of the galaxy and has nothing but contempt for any of the others. The only non-krogan that he has *any* respect for is [Shepard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemiesEqualsGreatness).

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): If  (SPOILER) Eve dies  he comments with some resignation that it "wouldn't be a war without a funeral", lacking any of his previous eagerness towards violence and death.
[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): Insists the rachni couldn't be trusted not to start a war. Y'know, the thing he wants to do?
[If I Wanted You Dead...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IfIWantedYouDead): Says to Shepard that if he thought they were a threat, *Normandy* would've been shot down the minute it got into Urdnot airspace.

[I Gave My Word](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IGaveMyWord): For what little it's worth, he does try to keep his promise to Shepard in *3*. But, as Primarch Victus notes, his attitude pissed off the other clans, and they wouldn't help.
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): He's pretty much a typical krogan thug, especially in comparison to Wrex.
[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): As Garrus reluctantly admits, he's got a right to be pissed about that giant bomb the turians left behind on Tuchanka.
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER) If Wrex is alive, Kalros destroys his vehicle. Wrex's reaction is a shrug and "He was a pain in the ass anyway."
[Mauve Shirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MauveShirt):  (SPOILER)  If Wrex is still alive, Wreav's tomkah gets consumed by Kalros during the Tuchanka mission in *3* .
[Miles Gloriosus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MilesGloriosus): Wreav will take credit for curing the genophage, claiming he'll be even more famous than Shepard.
[The McCoy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMcCoy): To the salarian dalatrass's Spock and the turian Primarch's Kirk, only he's a lot less nice about it than Wrex.
[Politically Incorrect Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoliticallyIncorrectVillain): Treats the fertile females in *3* like property and makes disparaging remarks about other species.

[Pyrrhic Victory](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PyrrhicVictory):
    - If the genophage is cured to secure his aid Wreav is an invaluable asset in aiding the council races against the Reapers short term but a restored Krogan under his leadership may prove disastrous in the long term. Wreav makes no effort to hide his desire for a return to the warmongering days of old and the fact he knows the council races will be severely weakened by the Reaper conflict. - On the other hand if the genophage is not cured, Wreav ( (SPOILER) unlike Wrex ) is tricked into providing aid in the fight against the Reapers. The krogan partake in the greatest victory in galactic history but are no closer to escaping their extinction and Wreav returns home to zero fanfare. - It's entirely possible for Wreav's and Shepard's actions to result in *the krogan race being wiped out*, leaving Tuchanka in the hands of the rachni. Ouch.
[Red Oni, Blue Oni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedOniBlueOni): The red to Wrex's blue.
[Roaring Rampage of Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoaringRampageOfRevenge): Promises one against those responsible for  (SPOILER) the bomb on Tuchanka if it goes off .

[Rouge Angles of Satin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RougeAnglesOfSatin): An e-mail he sends Shepard in *3* shows he's not got the best grasp of English. He's nowhere near as bad as Grunt, but it's pretty clear grammar is not one of his strong suits.
[Shiny New Australia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShinyNewAustralia): Before the final battle, he tells Shepard he wants "this thing you call Australia" in exchange for his help.
[Shut Up, Hannibal!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpHannibal): By Wrex (with a headbutt), and then by Eve (with her moral suasion).

[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): Spends much of *3* trying to threaten Shepard. He basically exists to tell the player "You screwed up and now you're stuck with this guy instead of Wrex." Despite this, he does have a grudging respect for Shepard, but only [due to the enemies they've made](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemiesEqualsGreatness). Everyone else — squadmembers, NPCs, politicians — he treats like dirt. He also bites his tongue around Eve, but only because she's in a position to cause him trouble if he doesn't play nice with her.

[Suspiciously Similar Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySimilarSubstitute): Comes across as one of these for Wrex at first, but it soon becomes clear that they're very different in some *very* important ways — namely, that Wrex is trying to unite the krogan and revive their long-forgotten culture, whereas Wreav thinks the krogan are just fine the way they are. And more critically, unlike Wrex, he won't notice if  (SPOILER)  you sabotage the cure for the genophage.
[Took a Level in Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInJerkass): Is noticeably kinder and more reasonable in ME2 than ME3.

[Try Not to Die](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TryNotToDie): Before you try to summon Kalros; it's the most concern he ever shows for you and your team (provided he doesn't completely distrust Shepard).
QUOTE  "Try not to get killed up there. Fight like a krogan, and you'll be fine."

[Unfit for Greatness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnfitForGreatness): He's far too obvious about his plans for conquest, lacks any diplomatic tact and Shepard can use him as a mere pawn to secure further assistance for earth. You can even discuss this trope with Mordin in order to  (SPOILER)  convince him it's a bad idea to cure the krogan whilst they're under Wreav's leadship and Eve's not there to temper him. Mordin agrees another war with the krogan isn't worth the risk, so agrees to sabotage the cure and then fakes his own death.
[Ungrateful Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UngratefulBastard): He's much less grateful than Wrex toward Mordin if he cures the genophage  (SPOILER) at the cost of his own life .

[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): Shepard can secure Wreav's help to bring the turians into the fight and get krogan boots on earth too, all without actually providing anything in return.  (SPOILER)  By the time Wreav learns of the fake genophage betrayal, he's in no position to retaliate and has likely lost the support of all who followed him.  What's worse is Wreav's attitude practically *encourages* betraying him for the greater good in the long run, especially if Eve is no longer there to restrain him, as curing the krogan just means another inevitable galactic war on the horizon.  (SPOILER)  In fact, sabotaging the genophage cure also earns the full support of the salarian leadership too. Additionally, if Shepard speaks with Garrus after sabotaging the cure, the latter will even comment that, while Wrex probably would have been insightful enough to see through Shepard's ruse (something proven correct if Wrex is alive in ME3), Wreav is far too stupid to notice that anything is off or that Shepard played both sides.
[Wasteland Warlord](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WastelandWarlord): As the most influential and prominent clan leader on Tuchanka, as well as a complete tyrant and warmonger.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): Gives two to Shepard via e-mail in the third game, one if Shepard  (SPOILER) spares the rachni queen, which causes many krogan in Aralakh Company to die , and another if  (SPOILER) the bomb on Tuchanka goes off , promising a [Roaring Rampage of Revenge](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoaringRampageOfRevenge) in retaliation.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): If Shepard killed Maelon and destroyed the genophage data in *2*, Wreav will actually shrug off an attempt to apologize for it in *3*, saying Shepard's *almost* become a worthwhile enemy.
[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): One of the most sympathetic antagonists in the series.

[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner):
    - (SPOILER) He views his research to cure the genophage as this. Mordin on the other hand, views his experiments as far too extreme. - (SPOILER) If Shepard chooses to cure the krogan, and Maelon is still alive, he will send an ecstatic email to Shepard, revealing that he took Mordin's advice and opened another clinic on Omega. He had to scram when Weyrloc put a bounty on his head, but he's just relieved that something good came out of his work after all . - (SPOILER) He also desires to apologize to the krogan females and beg their forgiveness — which basically amounts to just Eve, since she was the [Sole Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoleSurvivor).
[Back Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BackStory): Maelon's involvement with the STG was examined in *[Mass Effect Foundation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/ComicBook/MassEffectFoundation)*.
[Boom, Headshot!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoomHeadshot):  (SPOILER) Mordin executes him  at point-blank range if you don't choose the Paragon interrupt.

[Broken Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal): He once idolized Mordin, but not anymore.
QUOTE **Mordin:** Assumed... Never argued with necessity of Genophage. 
**Maelon:** How was I supposed to disagree with *the great Doctor Solus?* I was your student! I LOOKED UP TO YOU!

[Chekhov's Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGun): His research data on the genophage. If you save it, Mordin/Padok can synthesize a cure from Eve's tissue with much less trauma, keeping her alive, and making the krogan war assets more valuable.

tropeName: Does This Remind You of Anything?
tropeNotes: [Does This Remind You of Anything?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoesThisRemindYouOfAnything): Maelon's storyline and the decision of whether to keep or erase the data he made on the experimentation is a classic moral quandry for research gained through immoral means, such as Nazi experiments on humans during World War II. Do you keep the research even though it was acquired through torture and genocide?

[The Extremist Was Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheExtremistWasRight): His data proves crucial to the Tuchanka arc of the third game if it's kept, and he himself feels relief knowing that his data helped solve the problem.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil):
    - To Mordin, fittingly enough. Where Mordin doesn't outwardly show guilt over his work on the Genophage modifications Maelon shows his *very* outwardly. Also unlike Mordin, Maelon has something of a [Never My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMyFault) attitude towards the atrocities he commits, even the ones that were entirely within his control. Mordin's entire character arc across ME2 and ME3 involves coming to terms with his guilt over the Genophage modifications and his role in them. - To Aresh, who is Jack's personal mission antagonist. Like Maelon, Aresh was never able to cope with the experimentation going on, and both are killed as a [Catharsis Factor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatharsisFactor) on the Renegade path, and both are spared by a [If You Kill Him, You Will Be Just Like Him!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IfYouKillHimYouWillBeJustLikeHim) argument from Paragon Shepard — and both will be [The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner) in *3* in the background, as Maelon runs Mordin's clinic in Omega for a while, while Aresh dies saving a bus full of children. invoked

[Heroic BSoD](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicBSOD): He has been in one for some time, caused by the cumulative effects of the Genophage on the krogan and especially the fact that his race created the Genophage and he had a personal part in its handling.
QUOTE **Shepard:** You really think anything you've done here is justified? 
**Maelon:** We committed genocide! Nothing I do will **ever** be justified!

[Hero-Worshipper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWorshipper): Prior to his breakdown, he looked up to Mordin. Unfortunately, between the mission to distribute the modified genophage and the effects it had on the krogan, [the relationship fell to pieces](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal).

[Horrible Judge of Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HorribleJudgeOfCharacter):  (SPOILER) Apparently, Maelon thought the krogan would be able to rebuild Tuchanka peacefully with [Weyrloc Guld](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy) in charge. True, he joined Clan Weyrloc because they were willing to go to lengths that Clan Urdnot wouldn't, but Maelon's fantasy of a krogan cultural renaissance sounds a little hollow while he's working for a chief who brags about how he'll take over the galaxy and eat salarian eggs as a delicacy once the genophage is cured .

[Just Smile and Nod](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustSmileAndNod): At the end of the loyalty mission,  (SPOILER)  Mordin loses his temper over the experiments Maelon has performed and puts a gun to his former student's head; in the event that you take the Paragon Interrupt, Shepard begs him not to pull the trigger, as — in spite of everything that Maelon's said about him — Mordin isn't a murderer . Maelon can only smile and nod helplessly.
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER) If you don't take the Paragon interrupt, Mordin blows his brains out .
[Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist): A well-intentioned one, though.

tropeName: My God, What Have I Done?
tropeNotes: [My God, What Have I Done?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGodWhatHaveIDone): He's been wracked with guilt  (SPOILER)  ever since he and Mordin upgraded the genophage , thereby accounting for the worst of his behaviour.  (SPOILER)  The Shadow Broker archives show that it started during their first mission on Tuchanka, when they were discovered by krogan guards and had to fight their way out — unknowingly killing female krogan in the process. When Maelon tried to issue a formal complaint, arguing that it went against the whole point of their mission, Mordin had him sedated. Apparently, the return to "normality" on Tuchanka and the rising stillbirths drove him even further over the edge; Mordin himself confesses that his failure to notice Maleon's distress or do anything about it only worsened the problem . Thankfully, assuming he survives the loyalty mission, Maelon recovers by the third game.

[Never My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMyFault): When asked about why  (SPOILER)  he didn't originally disagree with the upgraded genophage  he blames Mordin's influence on his behaviour. Furthermore, when he's actively confronted  (SPOILER)  over the test subjects killed in his search for a cure  he once again blames Mordin's teachings, even going so far as to claim " (SPOILER) The experiments are monstrous because I was taught to be a monster! " Mordin, who deplores  (SPOILER) the use of live test subjects , *strongly* disagrees.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): Mordin did not mention that Maelon actually *protested* the genophage *during* its employment. According to a Shadow Broker dossier entry from Mordin's report:
QUOTE Specialist Maelon makes formal protest, suggesting actions against female krogan violate mission parameters of maintaining population levels without negatively impacting culture. Specialist Solus requests protest be stricken from record due to Maelon's injured condition. Commander Kirrahe concurs. Maelon given additional sedatives, unconscious for remainder of operation. (Protest stricken from submitted copy of report.)

[Wide-Eyed Idealist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WideEyedIdealist): In spite of everything he's seen and done, Maelon still manages to be both idealistic and shockingly naive, even during  (SPOILER)  a guilt-induced mental breakdown . Case in point:  (SPOILER)  he claims that if Mordin's team hadn't upgraded the genophage, an expanded krogan population would have stopped Saren at Eden Prime, if only because the turian fleets would have been forced to keep an eye on the new krogan colonies in the Traverse. Mordin, on the other hand, believes that the turian fleets would have just declared war on the krogan and killed every last one of them; the third game confirms this by revealing that a turian bomb had been planted under Tuchanka's crust after the Rebellions, to be used if the krogan ever rose up again .
[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): He really does want to cure the genophage and save the krogan.

[Cultured Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CulturedBadass): Not many krogan are known for their poetry skills. His poem dedicated to Ereba is *O Blue Rose of Illium*.  (SPOILER)  Considering that he was sent to scout suspected [rachni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded) territory, then he was *very* high on the "Badass" side of the scale.

[Endearingly Dorky](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EndearinglyDorky): If Shepard helps bring them back together, they point out to Ereba it's obvious that Charr is crazy about her! He's actually written poetry and is serenading her with it! When was the last time anyone saw a *krogan* doing that?!
QUOTE **Shepard:** Awwwwww... look at him. It's obvious he's crazy about you.
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER)  Players will find his body during the Rachni Queen mission in *3*.

[Maligned Mixed Marriage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MalignedMixedMarriage): In 3, he and Ereba have wed. Other asari look down on Ereba for having a krogan husband fighting in the war, with the idea that he won't know who to shoot. Ereba doesn't take kindly to their prejudices.
[No Accounting for Taste](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoAccountingForTaste): Other asari in 3 have this attitude towards Ereba.
[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): A krogan who's an [Endearingly Dorky](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EndearinglyDorky), hopeless romantic.

[The Power of Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThePowerOfLove): If Ereba takes him back in 2 they're shown on Tuchanka, the krogan homeworld. She doesn't like it and is nervous about other krogan not wanting her there — Charr had to talk the chief around, which was probably easier if said chief was Wrex — but he believes that their love will make it okay. Ereba subsequently names her Citadel shop "The Blue Rose".

tropeName: Son of Trope, Daughter of Index
tropeNotes: [Son of Trope, Daughter of Index](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SonOfTropeDaughterOfIndex): Ereba worries that he only wants her as a way to have kids, since with the genophage and all... She also admits that he didn't seem to have been aware that these hypothetical kids would always have been asari, not krogan, and when she explained that to him, "Charr was quiet for a long time, then he said he'd love our girls no matter what color they are."
[Someone to Remember Him By](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SomeoneToRememberHimBy): If Ereba is convinced to take him back, then he makes a poetic reference to their unborn child.

[Warrior Poet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WarriorPoet): A literal example, being a [krogan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRaceGuy) who writes poetry in his spare time.  (SPOILER) His very last act was to write a poem as he lay dying on the Aralakh mission to investigate the rachni rumors.
[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain):  (SPOILER)  As bitter as he is about Miranda keeping him in the dark, he does seem to genuinely believe Oriana will be better off with her father.
[Freudian Excuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianExcuse): He grew up in poverty, so he believes that  (SPOILER) Oriana will be happier with her wealthy father.

[He Knows Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeKnowsTooMuch):  (SPOILER)  He knew Miranda had spy programs in her father's system, so he never mentioned Oriana's exact location. When he admits this, Miranda declares him the only loose end and tries to shoot him. Even if you talk her down, he dies anyway.

[Heel–Face Door-Slam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceDoorSlam):  (SPOILER) If you take the Paragon approach to dealing with him and stop Miranda from killing him, he is convinced to help Miranda keep Oriana safe. Before he can, however, Enyala kills him instead.

[Horrible Judge of Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HorribleJudgeOfCharacter):  (SPOILER) Shepard and Miranda can call him out on that Henry Lawson attempting to kidnap Oriana from her [Happily Adopted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappilyAdopted) family should have proven how terrible a person he was.
[In the Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InTheBack):  (SPOILER) If Enyala is the one to kill him.
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER) By Miranda or Enyala, regardless of what you do.
[Old Friend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OldFriend): Miranda's only pre-Cerberus associate.
[Only Friend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyFriend): One of the few people Miranda trusts and her only friend while living with her father.  (SPOILER) It turns out that trust was misplaced.
[Suicide by Cop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicideByCop): Shepard suggests  (SPOILER)  letting Miranda kill him was this, as a way of apologising for his sins.

[Wham Line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhamLine):  (SPOILER) The revelation that the Eclipse mercenaries aren't hunting Niket down, but that he's working with them. 
QUOTE **Enyala:** Niket has reached the terminal.  (SPOILER) He'll switch the family over to our transport.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero):  (SPOILER) He accuses Miranda of having stolen a child from her father merely for revenge. 
QUOTE **Miranda:**  (SPOILER)  I didn't steal [Oriana], I rescued her!  
**Niket:**  (SPOILER)  From a life of wealth and happiness?! You weren't saving her, you were getting back at your father!

[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): His employer is strongly implied to be a mob boss, and the asari whose associate was skimming from Mr. Thax's shipment is practically shitting herself. There's a reason why forwarding that note grants Shepard a minimum of five Renegade points.

[Beware the Nice Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheNiceOnes): [Krogan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProudWarriorRaceGuy) usually aren't as well-spoken as him. In a galaxy where sentient starships warp reality just by being there, ***this guy*** manages to be a frightening figure.

tropeName: My Species Doth Protest Too Much
tropeNotes: [My Species Doth Protest Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MySpeciesDothProtestTooMuch): His politeness is non-standard for a krogan and he outright hopes a confrontation will not be required. Even Urdnot Wrex reveres fighting to an extent.

[Been There, Shaped History](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeenThereShapedHistory): According to the *Alliance News Network*, turns out that Urz has been travelling across the galaxy to many of the same worlds that Shepard has visited and even been partially involved in several of their assignments.

[Big Friendly Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigFriendlyDog): Very lovable for a mostly hostile creature. According to a [short story](http://blog.bioware.com/2013/03/05/lovable-varren-goes-from-home-to-home-changing-lives/) from Bioware, Urz has [had many adventures throughout the galaxy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Series/TheLittlestHobo), acting as a positive influence to those who met him.

[I Have Many Names](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveManyNames): Apparently Urz is just one of the names he's gone under over the years. He's currently known as "[Prince Grimrender of Gembat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMagnificent)".

[Licked by the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LickedByTheDog): Despite varren usually trying to kill and/or generally being vicious towards Shepard, even a hardass renegade gets nothing but love from Urz.
[Palette Swap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaletteSwap): Of every other varren ever seen.
[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): Is actually a former pit-fight champion. Can be brought back to the ring after you feed him, and has a higher chance of winning as well.
[Team Pet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeamPet): On Tuchanka.

[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim): Tali says it best.
QUOTE  **Tali:** Prazza was an idiot, and he and his men paid for it!

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): Prazza defying Tali's orders, along with the later mission on Haestrom where again, most of her squad is killed, is an early warning that Tali isn't suited to lead either of the fire teams during the suicide mission.
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Abrasive, surly, and openly resentful of Tali's command.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): His hostility towards Shepard is justified by the fact that Shepard *is* working for Cerberus, and Cerberus doesn't have Veetor's best interests in mind. He's also telling the truth when he claims that Cerberus tried to destroy a ship from the Migrant Fleet in the past.

[Karmic Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmicDeath): No tears are shed when he gets ripped apart by a security mech.
QUOTE **Miranda:** [They did want to get to Veetor first.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoneHorriblyRight)

[Laser-Guided Karma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserGuidedKarma): Continually belittles both Tali (by questioning her decisions and disobeying her orders) and Veetor (dismissively calling him "unstable" and "delirious", which is true but doesn't mean he can't defend himself). He disobeys Tali one last time and promptly gets shredded by an YMIR mech that Veetor reprogrammed.
[Leeroy Jenkins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeeroyJenkins): He and his team rush ahead of Tali and Shepard, and get killed by an YMIR mech for their troubles.
[Red Shirt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedShirt): Appears just to get killed.
[Sacrificial Lamb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SacrificialLamb): He's there to set the tone for the game by getting killed.

[Shadow Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShadowArchetype): Prazza is essentially what Shepard would have been if Miranda had her idea of a control chip implanted in Shepard's brain approved: [Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty) to his cause, [Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism) against aliens, and [being an idiot on the battlefield.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneralFailure)
[Too Dumb to Live](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive): Tali sums it up.
[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): In *Redemption*.
[Canon Immigrant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonImmigrant): First appeared in the *Redemption* comic.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Not even two years of imprisonment and [Electric Torture](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElectricTorture) can quite suppress it.
QUOTE  **Liara:** We'll be back for you, Feron. 
**Feron:** *[still restrained]* I'll try not to go anywhere.

[Distressed Dude](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DistressedDude): The whole point of the Shadow Broker mission is finding him, [no matter how many mercenaries, mechs or rogue Spectres](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoaringRampageOfRescue) try to stop you.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): He's more amoral than evil, but works for the Shadow Broker for the money until he learns that he's planning on selling Shepard to the Collectors. He also says it is not in his principles to betray a client or leave a job unfinished.

[Fire-Forged Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FireForgedFriends): With Liara in Redemption. She distrusts him, especially after she learns of his ties with the Shadow Broker, but in the end, she succeeds with his help and devotes herself to rescuing him. After his rescue and recovery, he becomes  (SPOILER) one of Shadow Broker Liara's top lieutenants .

[Implied Love Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpliedLoveInterest): It's left rather vague since it's ultimately an [Anchored Ship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AnchoredShip), but after the completion of the *Lair of the Shadow Broker*, Shepard can ask Liara directly if she has feelings for Feron. She doesn't deny it, simply stating instead that it would be irresponsible on her end to push for a relationship when he's in such an emotionally vulnerable state.
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal): If you don't get the *Shadow Broker DLC*,  (SPOILER) Liara's raid on the Broker's ship still happens, but Feron doesn't survive .
[Knowledge Broker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnowledgeBroker): What he did for the Shadow Broker.
[Number Two](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NumberTwo):  (SPOILER) To Liara as the Shadow Broker , providing he survives.

[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap):  (SPOILER) Upon hearing the Shadow Broker addressing his agents after a confrontation with Shepard and Liara, Feron assumes the worst and immediately rushes to the control room with a pistol drawn. He shows immense relief when he discovers Liara is alive and posing as the Shadow Broker .

[Rescue Romance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RescueRomance): Averted. If you romanced Liara, she clearly states she and Feron are just good friends. If not, she says it would be unethical to take advantage of Feron's gratitude given his state.
[Secret-Keeper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecretKeeper):  (SPOILER) Amongst the Shadow Broker operatives at least, he seems to be the only one who knows that Liara has taken over .
[Stealth Hi/Bye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StealthHiBye): When the power to his torture chair fails, he vanishes in the second it takes a light to flick off and on. Must be a drell thing.

[You Shall Not Pass!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouShallNotPass): Holds off [Tazzik](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon), a burly and heavily armed salarian who is the Shadow Broker's top enforcer, so Liara can escape with Shepard's corpse in Redemption, leading to his capture.

[Broken Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal): Jacob looked up to his father as a role model before his disappearance.  (SPOILER) After he learns what Ronald did during his loyalty mission, however, Jacob effectively disowns him.

tropeName: Daddy Had a Good Reason for Abandoning You
tropeNotes: [Daddy Had a Good Reason for Abandoning You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DaddyHadAGoodReasonForAbandoningYou): Subverted. While initially the fate of the Hugo Gernsback *was* a good reason for him not being in Jacob's life, Jacob makes it clear he was never really there much to begin with. On top of that,  (SPOILER) despite the extreme but understandable control of rations and supplies to fix the beacon, Ronald isn't in much of a rush to go home once he holds all the power.

[Didn't Think This Through](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntThinkThisThrough): Commander Shepard points out that  (SPOILER) he had to have realized his harem fantasy couldn't last forever, but there's no evidence he took any steps to ensure that the inevitable rescue team wouldn't find out about what he did .

[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward): Ronald had  (SPOILER) already fixed the distress beacon years ago and the only reason he activated it now was because the exiled men had turned against him so he wanted someone to come save his hide and when he's confronted on his actions he desperately tries to convince Sheperd and Jacob that it's not his fault to avoid punishment.

[Disappeared Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisappearedDad): As Jacob says, he wasn't around much to begin with. On top of that, before Ronald went with the Hugo Gernsback, he and his son hadn't spoken for three years.

[Drunk with Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrunkWithPower):  (SPOILER)  Originally, the rationing of the food was necessary. If the officers didn't fix the beacon, they'd all be stuck as drooling primitives. Unfortunately, power corrupts and they started taking advantage of the situation. In the end, Ronald killed or drove off anyone that could be competition .

[Good Parents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodParents): For all of his *egregiously* selfish actions on Aeia, Jacob does consistently describe him as having succeeded in raising Jacob into a good man while he was still in his son's life.

[Harem Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HaremSeeker): A very, *very* dark example.  (SPOILER)  After exiling, killing or brainwashing all the other male survivors of the *Hugo Gernsback* crash, he proceeded to rule over the female survivors and used the mind degrading fruit of the planet they were stranded on to keep them docile and stupid. Jacob point blank accuses him of taking advantage of the situation to live in a "juvenile fantasy."
[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite):  (SPOILER) Taught Jacob that a man always admits to his mistakes. He *doesn't* .

tropeName: I Did What I Had to Do
tropeNotes: [I Did What I Had to Do](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDidWhatIHadToDo):  (SPOILER) What he claims about his actions, but he is quite clearly lying .

[I Have No Son!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveNoSon):  (SPOILER)  "I Have No Father" in this case. By the end of Jacob's loyalty mission, Jacob no longer considers Ronald his father .
QUOTE **Jacob:**  (SPOILER)  I don't know who *you* are, 'cause you're no father that I remember .

[It's All About Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllAboutMe):  (SPOILER)  He preserves food rations for only himself and, at first, other officers. Everyone else is forced to eat the local flora, which damages their minds. Eventually, he starts assigning the ship's women to officers as slaves, then killing the other officers when they feel remorse and exiling all men from the village (except the ones he trained as attack dogs) so they don't threaten them. On top of all of that he only activates the distress beacon, which had been ready to activate for *years*, when he feels like he can no longer keep the situation under control.
[Leave Behind a Pistol](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeaveBehindAPistol): If he is left to the mercy of the male members of his crew, Jacob gives him this option.

[Longer-Than-Life Sentence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LongerThanLifeSentence):  (SPOILER)  A Paragon Shepard threatens him with ten years in prison for every year of his decade long stay on Aeia, which would put his theoretical sentence at a *century.*
[Never My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMyFault):  (SPOILER)  When confronted on his actions, he insists that he had no choice, and everything he did was justified .

[Not Worth Killing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotWorthKilling):  (SPOILER)  Jacob thinks he's not worth killing *directly*, but he certainly isn't opposed to leaving him to the mercy of the feral male members of the *Hugo Gernsback* crew. 
QUOTE **Jacob:**  (SPOILER)  He's not worth the fuel to haul him out or the air he's breathing. And he's damn lucky I don't even think he's worth pulling the trigger .

[Playing the Victim Card](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingTheVictimCard):  (SPOILER)  After leaving the village, he contacts the team over an intercom system [telling them that he'd been trapped and only just gotten free and other bold-faced lies about the situation.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlatantLies) Jacob doesn't buy *any* of it.

[Shoot the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheDog):  (SPOILER)  Initially, rationing the food supply made sense. Only a few people were capable of fixing the beacon and if they didn't, then everyone gets to be drooling idiots. Unfortunately, he quickly got [Drunk with Power](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrunkWithPower) and turned the survivors into his own personal kingdom .

[The Sociopath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSociopath): Feels no true regret for his actions, even  (SPOILER) justifying not turning on the beacon ten years ago because the events would made him look bad to society instead of it being immoral.

[Unfit for Greatness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnfitForGreatness): Ronald was promoted to Acting Captain of the *Gernsback* following emergency protocols after the previous captain, Harris Fairchild, was killed in the crash landing. Unfortunately, the position of captain proved to be one he was thoroughly unsuited for. At first, he rationed the uncontaminated food for the scientists working to get them all off the planet. Unfortunately,  (SPOILER) as time went by, he let the power go to his head, and he turned the camp and mindless crewmates into his personal kingdom.  By the time Shepard and crew arrive, things have gotten bad. It's strongly implied no one on the ship, not even Fairchild, thought he was command material in the first place, and was basically Fairchild's assistant. The *Gernsback* was not a military ship, so command structure wasn't by rank.

[Villain Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainHasAPoint): Even as Jacob slowly realizes what his father has become,  (SPOILER) both he and Renegade Shepard acknowledge that rationing the safe food among the officers had to be done if anyone wanted to go home. The evil part was what Ronald did once the crew was under his control.

[Attention Deficit... Ooh, Shiny!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AttentionDeficitOohShiny): [Subverted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SubvertedTrope). During the *Citadel* DLC, Glyph will continue to get distracted by random items and details during the trek through the Citadel archives and storage houses, but always immediately performs any task when called upon. [Justified](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustifiedTrope) in that its supposed to gather as much information as possible to assist the largest information broker in the galaxy, and it just got brought into the *mother lode* of sensitive Citadel Council secrets.
[Exact Words](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactWords): Will serve the Shadow Broker, regardless of who it is. Also see [Literal-Minded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LiteralMinded).

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): An excessively polite and strangely egotistical floating, spherical robot with a voice that characters seem to find annoying? Glyph or [343 Guilty Spark](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/Halo)?
[Fetish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Fetish): In *Citadel*, Glyph seems to have a developed a bizarre fixation on elcor mating totems.

tropeName: Fling a Light into the Future
tropeNotes: [Fling a Light into the Future](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlingALightIntoTheFuture):  (SPOILER) Liara seeds many worlds with copies of Glyph containing an enormously sophisticated universal translator program, records of this cycle's galactic history, records of the war with the Reapers, accounts of Shepard, and blueprints for the Crucible for future cycles in the event that they cannot defeat the Reapers. Glyph is more than pleased to, saying "And it will be a *privilege* to guide future discoverers of these records." .

tropeName: I Just Want to Be Badass
tropeNotes: [I Just Want to Be Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IJustWantToBeBadass): Glyph laments its lack of weapons when it sees CAT6 Disruptor Drones, expressing the desire that  (SPOILER)  Liara  may one day upgrade him to allow him to partake in combat. It seems he's noticed the [sheer amount](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FightMagnet) of firefights his owner gets into and wants to help out. As it is, Liara commands him to "lower their morale".

[I Shall Taunt You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IShallTauntYou): During the battle of the Citadel DLC, Liara will have Glyph demoralize enemy troops. Glyph will respond by blithely telling the enemy troops negative statistics about their survival.

[Insistent Terminology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsistentTerminology): Addresses *everyone* as "Shadow Broker" in *2*.  (SPOILER)  Liara finally manages to program him to identify other people by the time of *3* and avoid calling Liara "Shadow Broker" publicly, although he has trouble dealing with Shepard and their clone during *Citadel* .

[Literal-Minded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LiteralMinded): Comes with being a V.I. When Shepard tells Glyph to "find Shepard" (when referring to their  (SPOILER) clone and failing to be properly specific about the description ), Glyph simply floats in front of Shepard and exclaims that Shepard has been found.
[Ludicrous Precision](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LudicrousPrecision): When calculating life expectancies and odds of survival of CAT6 mercs against Shepard and company.
[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): The worst thing he's ever done is ramble a bit, and is always pleasant, helpful, and eager.
[Number Two](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NumberTwo): His entire purpose is serve as one for the Shadow Broker.
[Ridiculously Human Robot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RidiculouslyHumanRobot): Personality-wise, one suspects Glyph is a true A.I., and not a virtual intelligence.
[Robot Buddy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RobotBuddy): To  (SPOILER)  Liara .
[Romantic Wingman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RomanticWingman): Plays some mood music for Shepard and a romanced Liara at *just* the right time during her visit to your apartment in the *Citadel* DLC.
[Sharp-Dressed Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SharpDressedMan): His idea of being festive is to don a holographic bowtie.

tropeName: You Kill It, You Bought It
tropeNotes: [You Kill It, You Bought It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKillItYouBoughtIt):  (SPOILER) Now assists Liara after she and Shepard killed the previous Shadow Broker .
[Abnormal Ammo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbnormalAmmo): One of his powers is [Incendiary Ammo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillItWithFire).
[Abusive Parents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbusiveParents): His father, as seen in the *Mass Effect: Homeworlds* comic.
