[Big Bad Duumvirate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadDuumvirate): Shares this status alongside the Shepard clone in the Citadel DLC.
[Big Bad Friend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadFriend): Turns out to be one of the main villains of the Citadel DLC.

[Bifauxnen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Bifauxnen): In the first issue of the *[Mass Effect Foundation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/ComicBook/MassEffectFoundation)* comic, she looked like a boy when she was a kid and was treated as one when she worked as a child laborer. None of the characters or even the readers knew her true gender until she shot the woman who saved her earlier at the back and tells her that she's a girl.

[Bitch in Sheep's Clothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BitchInSheepsClothing): You thought that she's a dorky, clumsy Alliance officer who rarely went into combat. Then, it turns out that it's just an act.

[Captain Obvious](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CaptainObvious): Warns Shepard that someone wants to kill them. Shepard and Joker's response is a [blank stare](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Beat) and a reply that they're generally aware of that. She then clarifies that she means someone *new*. She also felt the need to point out that it's bad to land troops on a gas giant.
[Cloud Cuckoolander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CloudCuckoolander): She overdoses on medi-gel after taking shots. Resulting conversations have her high as a kite. It's an act.
[Dare to Be Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DareToBeBadass): Shepard gradually nudges her out of her shell as the mission progresses. Then it turns out that she was perfectly competent all along.

[Death by Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathByIrony): She stabs the real Shepard in the back for the cloned one. And if you decide to take the Renegade interrupt, you can pay her back by shooting her in the back as she's walking away. Just as Shepard didn't see the betrayal coming, Brooks won't see her death coming.
QUOTE **Brooks:** Admit it, you'll miss me. 
*[BANG!]* 
**Shepard:** [Not from this distance I won't.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BondOneLiner)

[A Day in the Limelight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ADayInTheLimelight): She's a major character in the *[Mass Effect Foundation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/ComicBook/MassEffectFoundation)* comic series, where the first issue reveals her backstory. She made recurring appearances in the later issues where she studies the dossiers of Shepard's crew and ends up  (SPOILER) leaving Cerberus with Shepard's clone to carve identities for the two of them .

[Dark and Troubled Past](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkAndTroubledPast): Her backstory in the comics isn't really pleasant where she was a child laborer. She even shot the woman who saved her because she refused to accompany her. This explains her trust issues.
[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): To Clone Shepard.
[Dragon-in-Chief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonInChief): One gets the impression that despite Clone Shepard supposedly being in charge, she's the one really pulling the strings.

[Dragon Their Feet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonTheirFeet): Brooks did originally fight against Shepard side-by-side with the Commander's Clone, but once Clone Shepard is at risk of falling out of the *Normandy*, Brooks hangs back rather than risk her life to save her boss.

[Escort Mission](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EscortMission): The one time she's a [Required Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RequiredPartyMember), she's a non-combatant and you have no access to her stats; you're just there to help her accomplish various tasks without arousing suspicion.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Reveals that she left Cerberus because she disapproved of their slide into indoctrinated fanaticism.
QUOTE **Brooks:** The Illusive Man and I no longer see eye to eye. He's a ruthless madman, whereas I'm just ruthless. He's indoctrinated, and I prefer the only voices in my head to be my own.
[Evil All Along](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilAllAlong): Revealed to have been in league with Clone Shepard the whole time.
[Evil Brit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilBrit): Her accent, anyway.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart):
    - To Miranda, which Clone Shepard [highlights](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging). When she's in her blue Alliance combat armor, she also bears more than a striking resemblance to Ashley. While Miranda and Ashley are more pro-human than anti-alien, Brooks is completely the latter. There's another parallel to Miranda in that she initially plotted to use a [Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindControl) chip to keep Shepard in line before the Illusive Man overruled her, while Brooks absconded with Clone Shepard to escape his oversight, and is strongly implied to have manipulated them into following her own ideology. - She's almost a clone to Samantha Traynor, being a cute and dorky [Ambiguously Brown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyBrown) Alliance analyst with an English accent — up until she drops the dorky act.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): She's an ex-Cerberus operative who put together the dossiers you used in *2*, but disapproved of hiring aliens to help humans. Part of her motive for going after Shepard is that they're spending too much time helping other species rather than their own.

[Femme Fatale](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FemmeFatale): Views herself as one, and dives into the role to the point of [Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam). While she's right, she's also nowhere near as good as she thinks she is.

[Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): Once she's revealed her true colors, her smugness and racist attitude makes her a nasty piece of work. Even the Clone Shepard had a tragic element to them, especially once Brooks abandons them. The fact that she has the gall to taunt Shepard even when she's beaten makes you hate her even more.
[Hero-Worshipper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWorshipper): "You're the crew of the Normandy! You're legends to the rest of the Alliance." Subverted — she prefers Clone Shepard to the real one.

[I Have Many Names](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IHaveManyNames): "My name doesn't matter. I never keep the same one for more than a few days." Miranda knew her as "Hope Lilium" back when they were in Cerberus. In the *[Foundation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/ComicBook/MassEffectFoundation)* comics, she goes by the name, "Rasa".

[In the Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InTheBack): If Brooks tries to escape, Shepard has the option of shooting her in the back while she runs. If Shepard doesn't do it, one of their squadmates is more than happy to.

[Intoxication Ensues](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IntoxicationEnsues): Maya notes that she took a little too much medi-gel taking care of a wound, and starts acting like she's stoned off her gourd. Whether she's telling the truth or just pretending, it's unknown.

[Karmic Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmicDeath): Her origin story in *Foundation* reveals that she shot the woman who saved her in the back when she attempted to abandon her. Shepard or one of their squadmates will shoot her in the back if she tries to run.

[Know When to Fold 'Em](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnowWhenToFoldEm): It takes a little... [persuasion from Shepard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TerrorHero), but if they let Brooks know that their wanting Brooks to cooperate is not an attempt to save themselves but to save *Brooks*, she gets the message.

[Last-Second Chance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastSecondChance): Paragon Shepard coldly tells her why she shouldn't attempt to escape custody. She takes the hint.
QUOTE  **Brooks:** Is the great Commander Shepard pleading for his/her life? 
 **Shepard:** *[in a low, menacing tone]* [I'm pleading for](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodIsNotSoft) *[yours](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodIsNotSoft)*.
[Letting Her Hair Down](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LettingHerHairDown): Initially has her hair in a ponytail. She lets it down from the casino infiltration onwards.
[The Man Behind the Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMan): To Clone Shepard, whether they realize it or not.
[Mission Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissionControl): For the first few missions of the DLC.
[The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole): She's in league with Clone Shepard, who likens her to Miranda during the events of *2*. "Mine has more bite."
[Obfuscating Stupidity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObfuscatingStupidity): Is far more capable than she lets on.
[Ooh, Me Accent's Slipping](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OohMeAccentsSlipping): This is a pretty tell-tale sign she's not who she says she is.

[Pragmatic Villainy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy): Nope, she's not indoctrinated, although she's well aware that the Illusive Man is. Taking out Shepard and replacing them with the clone is just the best way to help further humanity's interests.
[Shotguns Are Just Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShotgunsAreJustBetter): Borrows the N7 Crusader when she and the clone fight you.

[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): Her plan is actually pretty good and her act as a dorky [Hero-Worshipper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWorshipper) is quite convincing, but once she reveals her true nature, her every word is filled with such raw, unbridled arrogance. She also succumbs to pointless sadism and [Bond Villain Stupidity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BondVillainStupidity), leaving Shepard and their friends alive in an easily escapable [Sealed Room in the Middle of Nowhere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SealedRoomInTheMiddleOfNowhere) instead of just trying to kill all of them when they're at her mercy. [Shepard even notes that a bullet would be easier and more reliable before this plan is even carried out.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging) Even when she's captured, she doesn't drop the smug act and has the gall to insinuate that Shepard's threats against her are nothing more than cowardly bluster.
[Spy Catsuit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpyCatsuit): For the archive mission, she's basically wearing Ashley's "From Ashes" DLC outfit.

[Suicidal Overconfidence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuicidalOverconfidence): She ends up surviving the final fight, albeit she gets detained. She begins hacking her omni-handcuffs to escape. Note that she's on the Normandy which at this point is still in the air, with at least three armed people on board, each of whom may be among the galaxy's strongest biotics, not to mention an AI that can practically see everything going on inside the ship. And that's not counting the actual Alliance arresting officers.

[Suspiciously Similar Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySimilarSubstitute): She has some similarities to Tela Vasir from the previous game's Lair of the Shadow Broker DLC, in that she is initially presented as an ally, but subsequently turns out to be in league with the mission's [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad).
[Taking the Bullet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingTheBullet): Saves Shepard from a sniper, getting wounded in the process.

[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): Her role in the primary conflict of the *Citadel* DLC is extremely difficult to talk about without bringing up the fact that she's actually the [Dragon-in-Chief](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DragonInChief) to your clone.

tropeName: What the Hell Is That Accent?
tropeNotes: [What the Hell Is That Accent?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellIsThatAccent): When you first meet her, her accent switches rapidly from American to British to Australian. Turns out she's faking it and her real accent is British.

[All There in the Manual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllThereInTheManual): Most of his background is covered in the books, where playing just the game you would think he's just another baddie. His backstory is alluded to if you dig, but not in much detail.

[Arch-Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchEnemy): He considers himself to be Shepard's. In reality, while Shepard despises him, they see him as more of a cowardly roadblock and attack dog. Certainly not the level of threat as the Reapers, Saren before, or his boss The Illusive Man for his influence.
[Arrogant Kung-Fu Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArrogantKungFuGuy): They don't get much more arrogant than Kai Leng.
[Backstab Backfire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BackstabBackfire):  (SPOILER) How his boss fight ultimately ends.

[Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassNormal): No biotics, no cybernetics, and still manages to kill a *[krogan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron)* (who, remember, have [redundant organ systems](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpareBodyParts) and an innate [Desperation Attack](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesperationAttack)) in a [Bar Brawl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarBrawl) with just a knife. And then 6 turians, with just a knife and a pistol. Then, in *Deception*, manages to  (SPOILER) kill über-biotic Gillian Grayson with a shiv  while injured.  (SPOILER) Averted in the game proper, where he's been augmented with Reaper tech, [and it's still not badass enough to beat Shepard.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysABiggerFish)
[Blood from the Mouth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodFromTheMouth):  (SPOILER) Happens when he's finally killed by Shepard .

[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight):
    - He enlisted in the army at 16 using a false ID, only to be discharged for murdering a krogan the same year he was made N7. Hints of social darwinism aside, he just loves violence, and relishes the idea of going up against Shepard. QUOTE **Shepard**: Three-on-one, pal. It's over. **Kai Leng**: [No. Now it's](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ILikeThoseOdds) *[fun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ILikeThoseOdds)*. - Despite his love of violence, it quickly becomes apparent that he can't handle any situation where he doesn't have the advantage. When faced with an opponent he can't just steamroll, he ends up calling in backup to cover his retreat.

[Boisterous Weakling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoisterousWeakling): He keeps acting like he's an unstoppable badass right up until the end, even though he's comprehensively lost every fight he's been in and only survived by running away after a save by allies. Shepard actually calls him out on this in their last fight. Mechanically he's the opposite of an [Elite Mook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteMook); a Cerberus Phantom but not as good.
[Boxed Crook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoxedCrook): The Illusive Man recruited him when he was imprisoned for the aforementioned incident with the krogan.

[Braggart Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BraggartBoss): With the sole exception that his actions and behavior aren't played for laughs, he fits this almost exactly, right down to the [fancy flashy outfit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpossiblyCoolClothes).
[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy):  (SPOILER) It's implied on Thessia that he's indoctrinated . If true, then it doesn't seem to have changed his personality much.
[But Not Too Foreign](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButNotTooForeign): According to the novels, he has both Chinese and Russian/Slavic heritage, with the Chinese being the dominant of the two.
[Canon Immigrant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonImmigrant): First appeared in the *Retribution* and *Deception* novels.
[Climax Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClimaxBoss): He's the game's final proper boss.

[Combat Pragmatist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatPragmatist): He's more than happy to call in reinforcements to help him or even have a *gunship* cover him while he "recharges".
    - The pragmatism is more evident in *Retribution*, where he generally behaves like a real assassin: Altering his appearance for a job where the risk of him being recognized is too great, and his personal preference for either poisoning Grayson or sniping him from afar. He starts developing a flair for [Awesome, but Impractical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AwesomeButImpractical) after his indoctrination. - In the original concept for the Thessia boss fight, Kai Leng would have planted explosives throughout the temple before Shepard got there, instead of relying on a gunship to back him up.
[Contractual Boss Immunity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContractualBossImmunity): He's immune to Stasis, even when other enemies would be affected.

[Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle):
    - His utter slaughter of a squad of six turian soldiers in "Retribution" using nothing but a pistol and a knife is probably the best example. The Illusive Man bears witness to it and is shocked by how easily they go down, describing Leng's decimation of them as a work of art. - In Leng's introductory cutscene, Shepard will find the body of [the Executor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DaChief) and three of his armed and armored bodyguards, having been casually disposed of by Leng seconds beforehand, after which he proceeded on to his *actual* target. - On Sanctuary, he runs into Miranda and beats her nearly to death seemingly without getting a scratch in turn, despite her being armed and a powerful biotic. The wounds she sustains will actually *kill* her unless Shepard [jumps through a lot of specific hoops beforehand.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuideDangIt) - On the other hand, in the "Foundation" comics, Jack casually one-shots him with a biotic blast when he gets caught out in the open. If not for his cybernetic enhancements (which Jack didn't know about), he almost certainly would've died. - Gets turned on him in his final clash with Shepard. Leng has the element of surprise and thirteen [heavily armed commandos](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss) behind him, giving him a nearly 5-1 numbers advantage over Shepard's team. Despite this, the fight does *not* go well for him; all of his troops end up dead with him heavily wounded, and neither Shepard nor their [squadmates](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassCrew) are even breathing hard or showing signs of injury in the subsequent cutscene. This culminates in Shepard dealing the [Coup de Grâce](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoupDeGrace) to a wounded Leng after breaking his sword with a backhand. [The fight is considered to be one of the easiest final battles in the game.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GameplayAndStoryIntegration) QUOTE **Shepard:** No gunship this time, you son of a bitch!

[Cutscene Power to the Max](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutscenePowerToTheMax): In cutscenes, he displays many nifty abilities, like Tactical Cloak, a bullet-proof barrier, and the ability to kill anyone with a single backhanded stab from his sword, even being able to put the monomolecular blade through several layers of armor. He can't do any of that in-game. Notably, generic [Elite Mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteMooks) can. Even in cutscenes he's only a threat because his enemies suffer from [Cutscene Incompetence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutsceneIncompetence).

[Cyborg](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cyborg): In *Mass Effect 3*, he's been physically augmented with Reaper cybernetics. According to the dossier Anderson sends Shepard, he was given "Phantom-class implants".

[Death by Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathByIrony):  (SPOILER) Shepard guts him with an omniblade. Four of the six classes will use the omniblade once in the entire game just to [invoke this](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvokedTrope) .

[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): Near the end of *Retribution*,  (SPOILER) Anderson shoots him in [both legs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Kneecapping) to slow down his escape while he and Kahlee tend to a wounded boy . Leng still manages to  (SPOILER) get away by using his arms to climb up a ladder and swinging from bars along the ceiling to get to his shuttle before security can find him. And yes, dropping from the ceiling onto legs that are bleeding out *is* painful as hell.  Also,  (SPOILER) after being beaten by Shepard at the Cerberus HQ, he will muster up all his remaining energy to try and stab Shepard while they're busy looking through the Illusive Man's files, though Shepard will simply counter him with an omniblade stab to the gut that finishes him off for good.

[Dirty Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward): For all his smugness and boasting, he's either forced to retreat or rely more on overwhelming force than anything else in combat. The main reason he is not beaten on Thessia is he calls in a [Gunship Rescue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GunshipRescue) for himself, keeping Shepard's team pinned down and finding difficulty to strike back, and he just runs away as soon as he can anyway. Shepard calls him out on this in their last fight.
QUOTE **Shepard**: I'm only slow because I'm not running. You ran away at the Citadel, on Thessia, all you can do is run! 
**Kai Leng**: Shut up!
[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): He serves as the main physical threat of Cerberus and is even described as the Illusive Man's "personal attack dog".

[Empowered Badass Normal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EmpoweredBadassNormal): Likely because of the grievous injuries he sustained at the end of *Retribution*, Kai Leng sports some serious cybernetic upgrades in *ME3*. These grant him abilities including, among others, low level [Super-Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperStrength), an [Invisibility Cloak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvisibilityCloak), [Super-Toughness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperToughness), a spherical power-blocking [barrier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BarrierWarrior), and [Power Palms](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerPalms).

[Enemy Eats Your Lunch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyEatsYourLunch): Due to being "an adrenaline junky", as described by the narration, he not only bugs Anderson's apartment, he  (SPOILER)  eats Anderson's cereal.
[Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment): In *Retribution*, personally killing Liselle [for being an asari](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism).

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): Not from him, but the others' reaction to him, in that even before ME3 he was regarded by other Cerberus agents such as Miranda and  (SPOILER) Maya Brooks  as TIM's pet psycho.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): Shepard and Leng are both former N7 operatives and the best fighters of their respective organizations (the Alliance/Council for Shepard and Cerberus for Leng). Also, while Leng hates aliens, the fate of the galaxy hangs on Shepard's ability to rally the other races to fight together against the Reapers. His cybernetic upgrades further parallel them. [Lampshaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging) by the Illusive Man in-game.

[Evil Gloating](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGloating): He is not above rubbing his enemy's failures in their faces, even when it comes off as unwarranted (for example, claiming that Shepard can never defeat him, to which Shepard responds that Leng runs from every fight he's in).

[Evil Is Petty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsPetty):
    - In the canonically suspect *Deception*, he (SPOILER) sneaks into Anderson's house to plant some bugs. Before he leaves, he sits down, takes out a bowl and eats at Anderson's cereal. And he also peed in a vase. - In the game proper, he (SPOILER) sends an email taunting Shepard about the fall of Thessia under the guise of Asari Military Command, with the subject "Evacuating Thessia". The first thing it says is "Good, you opened this message. This isn't actually asari military command." You can almost hear the smug laugh that would follow that sentence . Taken over the top when Fridge Logic sets in (SPOILER) to make that email he likely had to use a real asari military command computer, so at the end of that mission he had to stop and take the time to hack into a computer to effectively do some internet trolling .
[Evil Sounds Deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSoundsDeep): It's [Troy Baker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/TroyBaker), after all.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): He *really* doesn't like aliens to the point of being physically repulsed by their presence. In *Retribution* he considers the asari "whorish" and regularly gets urges to "teach (the alien/s) a lesson" whenever they try and lord it over a human. Due to the fact that Shepard doesn't interact with him outside of boss fights with limited dialog, it's more of an [Informed Attribute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAttribute) in 3.
[Fatal Flaw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FatalFlaw): His [pride](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Pride).

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): To Miranda. The scenes in which they are introduced are very similar and they're both among the most talented Cerberus operatives TIM ever employed. Whereas Miranda ends up being fairly heroic by the time the Reapers show up, Kai Leng is solidly villainous.
[Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBoss): Of the Cerberus plot arc. In fact, he's the last traditional boss fight in the entire trilogy.

[Final Boss Preview](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FinalBossPreview): The first fight with him during Priority: Thessia, which overlaps with [Heads I Win, Tails You Lose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadsIWinTailsYouLose).

[Fission Mailed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FissionMailed):  (SPOILER) No matter what you hit him with during the fight on Thessia, he's unharmed and has his gunship blow up the temple while he steals the Prothean VI you're after .
[Flash Step](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlashStep): He can leave after-images behind him too.
[Flunky Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss): During the second fight.

[General Failure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeneralFailure): Provided you play your cards right he spectacularly screws up the Citadel coup.  (SPOILER) Not only does he fail to assassinate the Salarian councilor despite having him dead to rights, but he gets his ass kicked by a terminally ill drell for good measure.

[Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): [The Reapers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination) are implacable beings dedicated to wiping out all life but are more akin to forces of destruction than actual characters,  (SPOILER) and even their master has understandable motivations,  while the other [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad), the Illusive Man, still retains some grandiosity and [Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist) goals. [Kai Leng](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeavy), however, is completely unlikeable by being a cruel, cowardly, petty, racist [Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake) who spends most of his screen time either being a douchebag or potentially killing fan favorite characters. Heck, the devs even have Kai Leng send a mocking email to twist the knife in when Shepard suffers [My Greatest Failure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGreatestFailure). The prompt where Shepard  (SPOILER) guts him like a fish with an Omni-Blade  is widely considered to be one of the most popular in the series.

[The Heavy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHeavy): To the Illusive Man's [Non-Action Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionBigBad). Kai Leng is a greater threat in combat than the Illusive Man and is the one who shows up in person to carry out his orders.

[Hero Killer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroKiller): Along with  (SPOILER) killing Gillian with a [sharpened toothbrush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableWeaponUser) (its canonicality is disputed though) in *Deception* , Kai Leng can potentially end up killing any combination of  (SPOILER) Kirrahe/Thane/the Salarian Councillor and/or Miranda , and he *will* kill at least one of them.  (SPOILER)  If he kills Thane, it's subverted, the latter will mock him for barely beating a terminally ill Drell and failing to kill his target. However, in the worst case for him he still kills Thane, *nearly* kills Miranda in a [Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle), kills the new Executor and his two bodyguards off-screen, and puts up a decent fight against Shepard.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): If Thane thwarts his assassination attempt, he later rather tastelessly mocks him for supposedly dying like a coward. Then,  (SPOILER)  come the end of the final fight against him...

[I Shall Taunt You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IShallTauntYou): After the  (SPOILER) fall of Thessia at the hands of the Reapers , [you receive an email from him telling you about how your failure has caused millions to die](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog) and that he looks forward to killing you next time you two meet.

[Impaled with Extreme Prejudice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice):  (SPOILER) How he ends up fatally wounding Thane (but not Kirrahe, who [takes a bullet](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingTheBullet) instead). And then the climax comes, [wherein Shepard kills him the exact same way](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathByIrony).

[Implacable Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImplacableMan): Gets the drop on Shepard's team by landing on top of their [Flying Car](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlyingCar). A car that *[Shepard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivesLikeCrazy)* [is driving](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivesLikeCrazy). While shooting at him. He manages to disable it and escape.
[Improbable Weapon User](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableWeaponUser): He killed  (SPOILER) the most powerful human biotic alive  with a shiv fashioned from a toothbrush.

[Informed Ability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAbility): On the one hand, he's clearly meant to be a hyper-skilled and hyper-dangerous cyborg assassin, with one or two secondary characters getting [worf'd](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheWorfEffect) by him to establish his credibility. On the other hand, he spends most of the game getting his ass kicked and running away, coming across as a whiny wanna-be, with Shephard even openly mocking him in their final battle - which is considered by players one of the easiest boss fights in the game. Most of Kai Leng's more competent and impressive feats are found only in the Mass Effect novels (which very few players ever read).

[Informed Flaw](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedFlaw): He’s supposedly violently racist even by Cerberus standards but we never see anything to suggest special disdain for aliens. While he’s certainly a smug asshole, it’s directed in a more general sense. This is averted in his debut appearance, where he has to almost contain himself to keep from murdering aliens on basic principle.

[Insult Backfire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsultBackfire): He taunts Shepard frequently in their final battle, but he flies off the handle when Shepard responds in kind.
QUOTE **Leng**: Even if you win, you're too late to stop what's coming! 
**Shepard**: Maybe, maybe not...but ***YOU*** won't be there to see it.

[It's Personal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsPersonal): Shepard invokes this trope when they finally kill Leng by stating the deed is in the name of all their compatriots who Leng has killed.
QUOTE **Shepard**: *[running Leng through] That* was for  (SPOILER)  Thane/Miranda/Kirrahe , you son of a bitch!
[Invisibility Cloak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvisibilityCloak): Has an Infiltrator/Kasumi-style tactical cloak.

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Let's see... killing  (SPOILER) Thane/Kirrahe , and [calling them cowards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite), [relying on a gunship for assistance against Shepard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessBossFight), [ordering the gunship to level the building you're in, so he can get what he needs](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RageQuit), sending Shepard a message mocking them, potentially killing  (SPOILER) Miranda , and [generally running from battles where the odds aren't in his favor?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewThisImOuttaHere) Yep, he definitely fits.

[Karmic Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmicDeath):  (SPOILER) After fatally wounding at least one of Thane, Miranda, Kirrahe & the salarian councilor, along with the new Executor and his bodyguards; Shepard winds up killing Leng in return, [running him through with an omniblade](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice).

[Katanas Are Just Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KatanasAreJustBetter): With a [Hand Wave](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandWave) as to why it's effective in a game where kinetic barriers are standard.  (SPOILER) Subverted in his final appearance in *ME3*. You can take a Renegade interrupt in order to break it before delivering the coup de grace.

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog):
    - In *Retribution* he kidnaps Paul Grayson, a recovering drug addict, and immediately drugs him up again. When the Illusive Man's Reaper tech experiments turn Grayson into a Husk that attacks the Grissom Academy, Kai Leng uses 12-year-old biotic Nick Donahue as [Cannon Fodder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CannonFodder), resulting in the child receiving life threatening injuries. This leads to a *Lair of The Shadow Broker* style standoff where Leng borrows from Vasir's playbook, telling Anderson "Let me go or the kid bleeds out." - Shepard is emotionally devastated after (SPOILER) the loss of Thessia , [putting the blame on themself entirely](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllMyFault). Kai Leng rubs it in by sending a message to Shepard afterwards telling them that (SPOILER) Thessia fell because they simply weren't good enough. - During the fight with him on (SPOILER) Thessia , he'll trash talk whoever he got a chance to kill previously when they met on the Citadel. The reactions of [your squaddies](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3M1LGpqTNaI&) say it all. QUOTE **Javik:** If I kill no one else but him, it will be worth it!

[King Mook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KingMook): He's basically a powered-up Cerberus Phantom with enhanced durability and some additional abilities. But he lacks many of the Phantom's normal abilities outside of cutscenes.

[Made of Iron](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadeOfIron): Takes no damage whatsoever from whatever shots manage to hit him in his [Heads I Win, Tails You Lose](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeadsIWinTailsYouLose) encounter (he also benefits from shields that recharge almost instantaneously, so it's unlikely that much of anything will hit him at all). However, during his actual boss fight, when his shields come down, he goes down easily due to only wearing light armor. Plus, his shields aren't substantially stronger than shields used by other bosses in the last game, they just recharge quicker.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): "Leng" means "cold" in Chinese.
[Ninja Pirate Zombie Robot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NinjaPirateZombieRobot): Well, he's a racist cyborg ninja come ME3.
[Oh, Crap!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OhCrap): Hard to catch, but he makes one right after  (SPOILER) Shepard shatters his sword and right before they fatally stab him in the side .

[One-Man Army](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneManArmy): Almost certainly, seeing as he killed six turians with a knife and, in a separate incident, killed a krogan singlehandedly with a knife. As a boss fight, however, he has no problems with calling a gunship for cover fire while he recharges his shields or [summoning mooks to his side](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlunkyBoss).
[Phrase Catcher](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PhraseCatcher): Tends to be referred to as a "bastard" by several characters. The player will probably come to echo this soon enough.
[Power Palms](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerPalms): Most likely due to his cybernetic nature.
[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): Twice. First is a [Hopeless Boss Fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessBossFight), though.

[Replacement Goldfish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReplacementGoldfish): While he was working for Cerberus long before we meet him, Liara still notes in *3* that it probably isn't a coincidence that after Shepard left, the Illusive Man just so happens to start using former N7 Kai Leng as his chief minion.
[Reverse Grip](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReverseGrip): With his sword, like the Cerberus Phantoms, with whom he shares a lot of combat animations.

[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): Believes himself to be completely superior to Shepard, underestimating them at every turn and even berating the Illusive Man for saying that [Shepard is to be admired for their skills and danger.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent)  (SPOILER)  He learns the hard way that underestimating Shepard is asking for a quick and painful death.
[The Social Darwinist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSocialDarwinist): He firmly believes in the Illusive Man's vision of "uplifting" humanity via Reaper tech.

[Sociopathic Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SociopathicSoldier): Type 2. Started off with looting medals from enemy corpses and eventually escalated to premeditated murder, which caused the Alliance to discharge and imprison him. Then he joined [Cerberus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfettered) and was allowed to run amok while completing his objectives.

[Super-Strength](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperStrength): Subtle but present. The dossier Anderson emails to Shepard credits any superhuman prowess of his to "Phantom-class implants", meaning that [Phantoms](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteMooks) have this too, even if they don't really show it.
    - In his introductory scene, [he casually leaps over ten feet vertically](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InASingleBound) despite being fully armored. The world record for an unassisted vertical jump is five feet. note  Assuming Leng in full armor weighs about 225 pounds (180 lbs being the weight of the average American man and 40-50 lbs being the weight of a suit of high medieval plate armor), a 10-foot vertical jump [would require](http://www.dunkcalculator.com/verticalcalculator) his legs to push against the ground with over 21,000 newtons of force. Assuming he was 5'10 tall and using standard 60-degree jump form. For comparison, the 6'5, 200 lbs Michael Jordan pushes against the ground with 7,000 newtons to obtain his famous 4-foot vertical. A jump like this is [directly translatable](http://www.higher-faster-sports.com/verticaljumpcalculator.html) to a 1,600-1,700 lbs squat. The world record for a raw squat is 1,005 lbs, done with enormous effort by a man twice Leng's size. - He overpowers Thane in their brief grapple and punch-up with relative ease. Thane being strong enough to [casually snap a muscular man's neck with no mechanical leverage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeckSnap) or kill a man in plated body armor with one punch to the chest. Of course, Thane is [so ill he can barely stand](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorfHadTheFlu) at this point.

[Super-Toughness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperToughness): In his final battle against Shepard, he takes a full-force front kick to the chest from the [Super-Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperSoldier) without injury. That may not seem like much at first, but note that in earlier scenes Shepard is able to *kill* (or at least incapacitate) [an armored](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=krQwYN90BZw&feature=youtu.be&t=690) [soldier](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mLRR6y6t5iI&t=4m20s) with a single quick jab to the chest, a feat they repeat later. A kick is many times more powerful than a jab.

[Sword and Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordAndGun): His preferred weapons in the books, as befitting an assassin, are a knife and silenced handgun. In-game, he uses an actual sword and utilizes [Power Palms](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerPalms).
[Sword Beam](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordBeam): The horizontal crescent-wave version.
[Sword Drag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SwordDrag): Reduced to this after being beaten by Shepard in their final fight.
[Tattooed Crook](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TattooedCrook): Sports an [ouroboros](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Ouroboros) tattoo on the back of his neck.
[Troll](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Troll): To the point that he sent an email impersonating the Asari Military Command just to gloat at Shepard.

[Underestimating Badassery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnderestimatingBadassery): As opposed to the Illusive Man and despite his warnings, Kai Leng refuses to show any respect for Shepard as a dangerous and very skilled enemy and even takes being compared to them by the Illusive Man as an insult.  (SPOILER) This ends up being his undoing.  Despite this however, he does at least rely more on superior firepower/manpower when fighting Shepard's team rather than simply personal skill.
[Villainous Rescue](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousRescue): Saves the Illusive Man from a turian Blackwatch squad in *Retribution*.

[Virtue Is Weakness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VirtueIsWeakness): As mentioned above, he scoffs at the Illusive Man's admiration towards Shepard and never considers them to be his equal.  (SPOILER)  He's right. Shepard surpasses him.

[With This Herring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithThisHerring): Kills a squad of six [turian commandos](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassArmy) with a knife, and kills  (SPOILER) the most powerful human biotic in the galaxy  with a [shiv fashioned from a toothbrush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprovisedWeapon).

[You Fight Like a Cow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouFightLikeACow): Engages in this with Shepard,  (SPOILER) especially during their final showdown. He doesn't take kindly when Shepard does it right back. 
QUOTE **Leng**: You're still slow, Shepard! 
**Shepard**: I'm only slow because *I'm* not [running](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyCoward)! 
**Leng**: SHUT UP!

[Batman Can Breathe in Space](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BatmanCanBreatheInSpace): During her escape, she doesn't don any kind of breathing apparatus while outside in the harsh Martian atmosphere. Justified, as she's not even organic.

[Canon Immigrant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonImmigrant): Subverted; *this* Eva Coré is not the Eva Coré from *Evolution* (the fact that the Eva Coré from *Evolution* dies at the end of the comic should be a pretty big hint). She was named after her by the Illusive Man.

[Cutscene Power to the Max](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutscenePowerToTheMax):  (SPOILER) EDI ends up wearing her robotic body after it's recovered, and is a party member, but she never displays the kind of physical strength that EVA does in her cutscenes, instead relying on firearms and tech attacks.

[Dark Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkActionGirl): She’s fast and elusive, leading Shepard on a wild chase across a Mars station when she’s acquired some data for Cerberus; she’s much stronger than she looks as when her shuttle is brought down by James she emerges from the wreck and utterly brutalizes  (SPOILER) Ashley/Kaidan  to the point they need to be hospitalized.
[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): To EDI. Footage from Cerberus headquarters reveals that Eva was specifically built to replace her after her defection to Shepard's crew.
[Fembot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Fembot): As seen in her [Robotic Reveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoboticReveal).
[Femme Fatale](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FemmeFatale): Built to be one.
[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): Her hair seems artificial and stiff. There's a reason for that.
["Get Back Here!" Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GetBackHereBoss): At first.

[Grand Theft Prototype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrandTheftPrototype):  (SPOILER) When EDI starts scanning for the Prothean info it downloaded, Eva comes back online and tries to attack. EDI spends the rest of the game "wearing" her body .

[Hopeless Boss Fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessBossFight): The [Chase Scene](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChaseScene) at the beginning of her boss fight. Shepard is allowed to shoot her or fire off powers to their content, but they won't do more than [Scratch Damage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScratchDamage) to her shields. Even if her shields are somehow depleted, she'll just use Shield Boost to restore them in full capacity.
[The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole): She arrives at the Mars Archives science team a week before the Reaper invasion but is actually working for Cerberus.

[Out of the Inferno](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutOfTheInferno): Steps out from the flaming wreckage of a shuttle in a manner reminiscent of the [Terminator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/Terminator), revealing her synthetic nature.
[Painted-On Pants](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaintedOnPants): Literally painted on. This trope is so ubiquitous in the setting that nobody notices.

[Replacement Goldfish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReplacementGoldfish): For EDI (Cerberus synthetic minus self-awareness) and her namesake (one of two friends the Illusive Man lost before founding Cerberus).
    - She's also a replacement for Miranda in some respects; she wears similar clothes before they're burned off, was designed and created to be attractive, powerful and intelligent, and acts, as Miranda once did, with nothing but complete loyalty for Cerberus in mind.
[Robotic Reveal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoboticReveal): When she emerges from the shuttle crash with her synthetic skin burnt away, revealing her metallic body and glowing eyes.

[Rush Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RushBoss): For the second part of the fight, you only have to shoot at her with your pistol for a few seconds, but she'll kill Shepard in one hit if you don't kill her before she gets to you. Certain pistols, either carried over via [New Game Plus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NewGamePlus) (Paladin, Scorpion) or from DLC (Acolyte, Executioner), can't deal damage fast enough to kill her during this time, making the fight unwinnable.
[We Hardly Knew Ye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHardlyKnewYe): Appears during the first mission on Mars before getting destroyed.
[Abusive Parents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbusiveParents): He takes it to [Norman Osborn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/ComicBook/NormanOsborn) levels.
[Archnemesis Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArchnemesisDad): To Miranda.

[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): Of Miranda's loyalty mission in the second game, having hired a small army of mercenaries to kidnap Oriana. Though he doesn't show up on-screen until the third.

[Asshole Victim](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AssholeVictim):  (SPOILER) He can either be defenestrated by one of his daughters or shot by Shepard, not to mention that he's essentially been left to hang out and dry by his employer.

[Bad Samaritan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadSamaritan): They don't get much worse than  (SPOILER)  disguising a research factory into husks and indoctrination as a refugee camp, using refugees as bulk test subjects.

[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): You'd figure being  (SPOILER) surrounded by Reaper tech supplied by Cerberus  would turn the guy into another one of their pawns. It's not clear whether or not he is, or perfectly in control of his actions, which, if that's the case, just makes him all the more horrible.
[Control Freak](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ControlFreak):  (SPOILER)  Miranda is incapable of having children due to a neoplasm he likely engineered, just to maintain total control of his "legacy."

[Corrupt Corporate Executive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CorruptCorporateExecutive): One of the wealthiest businessmen in the galaxy, though we don't know what field he's in when he's not manufacturing [Designer Babies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesignerBabies).  (SPOILER)  Or running a husk factory disguised as a refugee camp.
[Destination Defenestration](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DestinationDefenestration): If Miranda has lived long enough to confront him,  (SPOILER) she biotically throws him through a window to his death.
[Disney Villain Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisneyVillainDeath):  (SPOILER) Courtesy of Miranda or Oriana.
[Evil Cannot Comprehend Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCannotComprehendGood): He doesn't get why Shepard might be unwilling to let him walk because he hasn't done anything to *them*.

[Evil Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGenius): To  (SPOILER) the Reapers' [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad) and the Illusive Man's [Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon). He manages to find a way to control husks independently of Reaper influence, to a limited extent.

[Evil Is Not a Toy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsNotAToy):  (SPOILER) By the time you catch up with him, his base has been trashed by a Reaper attack that caused all of the husks that he thought he had under control to go berserk. He's still alive, but probably wouldn't have lasted much longer if you hadn't shown up.

[Evilutionary Biologist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilutionaryBiologist): He seeks to create the perfect human through his lineage.  (SPOILER) It then becomes worse once it's revealed that he's experimented on countless inhabitants on Horizon for Cerberus.
[The Ghost](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGhost): In *Mass Effect 2*.

[Glory Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlorySeeker): Unlike most of the others in Cerberus, [who truly want to make the galaxy better for humanity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist), he only does what he does to save himself and so future generations will idolize him.
[Gone Horribly Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoneHorriblyRight): Definitely happened with Miranda, who became a constant thorn in his side.

[Hand Cannon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandCannon): When you finally confront him, he's holding  (SPOILER)  Oriana  hostage with a Paladin pistol. Which makes sense, since the Paladin is a *very* expensive pistol, and Henry is one of the richest men in the galaxy.

[Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): Most major villains in *Mass Effect* are either [Well-Intentioned Extremists](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist) or have major badass points to make them more likable to the player. Henry Lawson, on the other hand, is a sociopathic, petty, child-murdering war criminal without a single redeeming or likable quality in sight.
[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite): Sterilizing your daughters isn't exactly the best way to maintain a legacy.
[It's All About Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllAboutMe): Obsessed with his legacy.
[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini):  (SPOILER) Only if Miranda died at the Collector base and you decide to let him walk.

[Lack of Empathy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LackOfEmpathy): As opposed to his daughter who suffers from guilt over many past actions, the absolute closest he comes to showing any hint of remorse for his actions is when  (SPOILER)  he calls Sanctuary's deception of refugees an "unfortunate necessity".

[Legacy Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegacySeeker): Obsessed with engineering a genetically perfect bloodline that will excel in his name long after his death, and like Okeer, he's willing to manipulate the lives of his daughters to a frightening degree - even disposing of those that don't measure up to his standards. However, *Mass Effect 3* reveals that a genetic heritage isn't the only legacy Henry plans to leave:  (SPOILER)  in order to make a name for himself as the man who "saved" humanity, he's partnered with Cerberus and is conducting experiments on how to control the Reapers - even setting up the utopian Sanctuary on Horizon in order to lure in unsuspecting refugees for use as test subjects.
[Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist):  (SPOILER) He used a refugee camp called [Sanctuary](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NamesToTrustImmediately) as a front for a husk facility.
[Narcissist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Narcissist): When you create [Designer Babies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesignerBabies) based *solely* on your DNA, you definitely qualify.
[Necessarily Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NecessarilyEvil): "I will be regarded as the savior of the human race!" [Uh-huh.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SarcasmMode)

[Never My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMyFault): Seems convinced Miranda has "poisoned" Oriana against him. The fact he had her abducted from her adoptive family and brought to his death camp doesn't seem to register to him *at all*.

[Offing the Offspring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OffingTheOffspring): He's really not too concerned about Miranda's welfare. He's also "discarded" the [Designer Babies](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DesignerBabies) that didn't live up to his expectations.  (SPOILER) If you can't talk him down or miss the Renegade interrupt, he'll shoot her in the stomach before she kills him. 
QUOTE **Miranda:** I wasn't the first [child] he made. I was only the first one he kept.

[Older Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanTheyLook): When you meet him, aside from slightly greying hair, he really doesn't look like someone who has a 35-year-old daughter. Of course, given the state of medical technology in the 22nd century, his talent for genetic engineering, coupled with his extreme narcissism, you can see why he doesn't look his *actual* age.
[The Sociopath](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSociopath): Just look at all the other tropes in this section.
[Truly Single Parent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrulySingleParent): His "daughters" were made by mixing his genes with specifically chosen female DNA to produce "perfect" children for his dynasty.

[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): The only time he shows up personally is in a cutscene,  (SPOILER)  near the end of the Sanctuary mission. He can be killed by Miranda via a biotic blast if she's alive, be shot by Shepard, [killed by Oriana sacrificing herself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingYouWithMe) or escape.

[Villains Want Mercy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainsWantMercy): The guy  (SPOILER) tricks people of multiple species into coming to "Sanctuary", a place where they will be safe from the Reapers only to slaughter them all and/or turn them into husks and send the ones that fall in between off to become Cerberus [mooks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Mooks).  And he wants Shepard to just let him *walk*.

[Would Hurt a Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WouldHurtAChild):  (SPOILER) Entire families went to Sanctuary. There was no discrimination in that regard. There's also the fact that he kills any child of his that doesn't meet his expectations.

[You Have Outlived Your Usefulness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouHaveOutlivedYourUsefulness):  (SPOILER)  Despite all his efforts for Cerberus, when Sanctuary comes under attack, the Illusive Man sends Kai Leng in only to retrieve the data Lawson collected on the Reapers, not the man himself. When confronted by Shepard, Lawson outright says Leng and the Illusive Man have left him to die .

[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): When finally confronted, he's polite and forthcoming, complimenting Shepard for their success and offering to use his knowledge to aid the Alliance against Cerberus. [He also tells Shepard that he respects their accomplishments.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent) On the other hand,  (SPOILER) he turned Omega into a prison camp and used hundreds of civilians in Adjutant experiments.

[Ain't Too Proud to Beg](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AintTooProudToBeg):  (SPOILER) As Aria is strangling him at the end of the DLC he panics and says he can give information on the Illusive Man to the Alliance and that he deserves mercy for sparing Aria once. Depending on Shepard's actions, Aria will either spare him or slowly choke him to death.

[Antagonist in Mourning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntagonistInMourning)
QUOTE **Petrovsky**:  (SPOILER)  Nyreen Kandros was a good soldier. It's a shame she had to die for Aria's petty ambitions.
[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): For the Omega DLC.
[Beard of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeardOfEvil): As seen in the above image.

[Boom, Headshot!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BoomHeadshot):  (SPOILER) If Aria doesn't kill him, Shepard can execute him at the end of the DLC, just as Petrovsky confidently states Shepard wouldn't kill an unarmed prisoner.

[Break Them by Talking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakThemByTalking): Delivers one to Shepard for working with Aria. He [makes a lot of good points](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainHasAPoint), namely that Aria doesn't have any moral superiority over Cerberus. It's possible for Shepard to shut him up. What's unique about the situation is that Shepard has to be an Engineer to do it: the only time in the series where Shepard's class has an impact on the plot.

[Broken Pedestal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrokenPedestal): Petrovsky by the time of the Omega DLC is having doubts about the Illusive Man, which makes it easier for him to genuinely surrender to the Alliance and defect.
[Canon Immigrant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonImmigrant): From the *Invasion* comic to the Omega DLC.
[The Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster): Just to drive the point home, he's repeatedly shown playing on a holographic chessboard. Which Shepard gets to keep in their cabin post-DLC.

[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): Aria implies that once Petrovsky sets his sights on something, he'll stop at nothing to achieve it.
QUOTE **Aria**: He's like his boss, in that no matter the consequences, he stops at nothing.

[Even Evil Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards): He's not indoctrinated, and he's only serving the Illusive Man at the point Shepard comes into the picture because [I Gave My Word](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IGaveMyWord).
[Everyone Calls Him "Barkeep"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneCallsHimBarkeep): Shepard usually just calls him "the General".
[Evil Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilGenius): Cerberus's chief strategist.

[Expy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Expy): Could be seen as one to [Grand Admiral Thrawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StarWars). He wears a very similar outfit, has a similar high-culture approach to villainy, and plays a similar role to the Illusive Man as Thrawn plays to Emperor Palpatine.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): No matter as to how honourable he presents himself; he still willingly instigated a plot to basically turn every alien citizen of Omega into the horrible Adjutants. Once he realized how that backfired, he sealed off an entire district to be slaughtered by them and then put draconic restrictions on the alien population, like being shot on sight if they carried a weapon.
[A Father to His Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen): In the *Invasion* comic.

[Graceful Loser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GracefulLoser):  (SPOILER) Once it becomes clear that he's gonna lose, he calmly surrenders, orders his soldiers to surrender so the conflict doesn't get dragged out and result in more pointless deaths, and offers to give Shepard information about the Illusive Man. Granted, this is because he knew he had a decent chance of survival.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite):  (SPOILER)  He tells Shepard that trying to fiddle with the reactor powering the plasma force fields while Nyreen and Aria are still trapped. "This is who you're working for, Shepard. She doesn't care who gets hurt." "She'd just throw thousands of lives away..." The same could be said to Petrovsky himself about his associates.

[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): To an extent if  (SPOILER)  he lives. High ranking Alliance prisoners are given very good treatment, and his War Asset entry mentions that he'll probably be granted asylum. Though you can take a Renegade interrupt to inform him that if he's not *completely* forthcoming with his information, Shepard will hand him to Aria.
[Know When to Fold 'Em](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnowWhenToFoldEm): At the end of the Omega DLC,  (SPOILER) he surrenders after Shepard and Aria kill all of his defenders.

[Mutual Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MutualKill): Banishes Aria with this in the *Invasion* comic. Standing right next to her on Omega, he threatens to blast it to bits level by level unless she leaves, willing to die himself if it means she loses too.
[Noble Demon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleDemon): Nyreen notes that Petrovsky offered amnesty to anyone who would willingly surrender — and he honored his word, with no conditions or fine print.
[No Celebrities Were Harmed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoCelebritiesWereHarmed): Oleg bears a strong resemblance to [Tom Selleck](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Creator/TomSelleck).

[No Good Deed Goes Unpunished](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoGoodDeedGoesUnpunished): Potentially, if  (SPOILER)  Aria kills him. Aria will openly admit that Petrovsky let her go during the initial conquest of Omega, yet she still strangles him to death after he surrenders.

[Out-Gambitted](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutGambitted): Did this to Aria before the events of the Omega DLC. Almost did it again three times over during the DLC itself; Aria would certainly have died trying to retake the station if Shepard wasn't there to intervene, either  (SPOILER)  in space, due to underestimating Petrovsky's defenses, on the streets, due to walking right into Petrovsky's force field, and/or in Afterlife, due to literally jumping into Petrovsky's electric containment prison.

[Palette Swap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaletteSwap): His uniform comes off as this, being the uniform worn by Alliance leaders like Anderson and Hackett, only in Cerberus colors. [Makes sense](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FridgeBrilliance), as Cerberus is, of course, very human-centric.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): Several of these are shown to demonstrate that he's more deserving of respect than any of his Cerberus colleagues. He doesn't pointlessly endanger civilians, keeps his word such as his offer of amnesty to gang members on Omega, showed mercy to Aria when she was fleeing the station, shows respect to his enemies, despised the Illusive Man's plan  (SPOILER) to release the Adjutants , and repeatedly calls Shepard out on working with a criminal like Aria.

[Remember the New Guy?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RememberTheNewGuy): Shepard invokes this trope by lampshading how they've never heard of Petrovsky prior to *Omega* despite the General supposedly being the Illusive Man's top strategist. According to Aria, this is because the Illusive Man prefers to keep Petrovsky's identity a secret. Despite this lampshading and trope invoking, Petrosky isn't actually an example, as he appeared in the *Invasion* comics and there was a passing reference to Cerberus having a General in [the first game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect1).
[Retired Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RetiredBadass): He took on hundreds of turian troops in the First Contact War and didn't stop fighting until the war was over.
[Shoot the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShootTheDog): In the Invasion comic, shoots  (SPOILER) Ashe when he's about to turn into an Adjutant .

[Shut Up, Kirk!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpKirk): After Petrovsky lures Aria and Shepard into a trap:
QUOTE **Shepard**: It's a shame you're on the Illusive Man's side, Petrovsky. 
**Petrovsky**: I'm on *humanity's* side. You're the one who's trying to start a war for the glory of Aria.

[Smart People Play Chess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmartPeoplePlayChess): He has a chessboard which is frequently used to indicate his status as [The Chessmaster](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChessmaster).

[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): Comes across as one at times, particularly when taunting Shepard throughout the Omega missions and mentioning that Alliance prisoners with leverage such as he has are generally treated quite well. He muses that he and Shepard may even become friends.
[The Strategist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStrategist): He's the Illusive Man's top strategist.
[They Call Me MISTER Tibbs!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheyCallMeMisterTibbs): Insists that Ashe call him "General" and respect him as such in *Invasion*.

[Token Good Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenGoodTeammate): The only decent-ish member of Cerberus encountered that doesn't defect in *Mass Effect 3* — and that ends the second he requests amnesty. It's clear he's disillusioned by the Illusive Man and was looking for an out.

[Unwitting Pawn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnwittingPawn): Shown in *Invasion*. Cerberus breaks into Omega by letting [adjutants](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EliteMook) get free of their facility and make for Omega, the closest station. Petrovsky is sent in to rescue Omega, and takes it as an opportunity to take it over. But when discussing it with the Illusive Man, it becomes clear Petrovsky has no idea that TIM engineered the escape, and even thinks TIM would never sacrifice so many personnel for that. [Aria](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCynic), in contrast, sees through it instantly.
[Villain Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainHasAPoint): In his lecture towards Shepard; Aria really isn't much better than Cerberus.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): In addition to the usual Cerberus doctrine, he honestly believes he's a better ruler for Omega than [Aria](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDon). Notably, he's also *not* indoctrinated.

tropeName: What a Senseless Waste of Human Life
tropeNotes:
[What a Senseless Waste of Human Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatASenselessWasteOfHumanLife): After he traps Aria, Nyreen, and Shepard in a force field and urges them to give up, Aria starts trying to tear open the force field:
QUOTE **Petrvosky**: Stop it, you're forcing my hand! Fine, we'll do it your way. *(unleashes dozens of Rampart Mechs on them)*
[Wicked Cultured](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WickedCultured): In *Invasion*, he not only likes chess, but he's also a history buff, and he likes reading Tolstoy in the original Russian text.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): Aria, Nyreen and Shepard all admit to viewing him as this. Petrovsky in turn views Nyreen, Aria and especially Shepard the same way.
QUOTE **Shepard**: It's a shame you're on the Illusive Man's side, Petrovsky.

QUOTE **Aria**: He's not like other Cerberus operatives I've seen. He's smart, he thinks outside the box, and he's very hard to predict.

QUOTE **Nyreen**: He's an adversary worthy of respect, and he's got a [code](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NobleDemon), [one that's a lot different than the Illusive Man's](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvenEvilHasStandards).

[You Wouldn't Shoot Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouWouldntShootMe): If Aria spares him, Petrovsky comes off as rather smug about the whole thing, saying that he's heard Alliance prisoners are well cared for. However, Shepard can take a Renegade interrupt telling him that things might not go the way Petrovsky believes. Petrovsky will confidently say that Shepard wouldn't shoot an unarmed captive,  (SPOILER) and they'll be his last words if the player takes the second Renegade interrupt.

[Alas, Poor Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlasPoorVillain):  (SPOILER) The clone of Shepard realizes they're all alone when Brooks abandons them to die while the real Shepard is rescued by their friends. This leads to either Shepard killing the clone, or the clone committing suicide after realizing they have no friends and no purpose.

[And Then What?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndThenWhat):  (SPOILER) If Shepard attempts to [Save the Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SaveTheVillain), s/he responds by asking what happens afterward. When Shepard points out that they will live, the clone asks, "For what?" and throws themself out of the *Normandy's* shuttle bay to their death.
[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): For the "Citadel" DLC.

[Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss): Constantly threatens their mercenaries with death and flat out tells them that they have no chance against Shepard. This serves to reinforce their status as Shepard's [Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart), who is always [A Father to His Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen) even at their worst.

[Big Bad Wannabe](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBadWannabe): Despite being the [Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain) of the Citadel DLC, they are ultimately small fry compared to the Reapers or even the Illusive Man. As the original Shepard points out, even if they succeed in taking over the *Normandy*, it's unlikely that their plans will really get off the ground. Heck, Shepard doesn't even take them completely seriously, even making casual talk when they are supposedly trapped in the iridium vault.

[Borrowed Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BorrowedCatchphrase): "I should go." The best part? All this time, the real Shepard had *no idea* they [sounded like that](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoIReallySoundLikeThat).

[Brick Joke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrickJoke): As Wrex is quick to note about [the first game](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect1), his [hypothetical fights](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UltimateShowdownOfUltimateDestiny) of Shepard versus random teammates [finally pans out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MirrorBoss).

[Cannon Fodder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CannonFodder): This is how they see the mercs under their command. Notably lampshaded when she specifically orders said mercs to "Slow [Shepard] down", not expecting them to survive. The real Shepard notes this as the difference between them. The clone has disposable minions, whereas Shepard has loyal friends.
QUOTE **Shepard**: A team? *You have minions!* ***And you're running out!***

[Clone Angst](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CloneAngst): Originally created by the Illusive Man to serve as "spare parts" for Shepard during the Lazarus Project. Thus, they have none of real Shepard's memories and weren't meant to even wake up.

tropeName: The Computer Is a Cheating Bastard
tropeNotes: [The Computer Is a Cheating Bastard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheComputerIsACheatingBastard): Whereas Vanguard Shepard's use of Nova depletes their shield, the clone has no such issue. On the flip side, Charge doesn't replenish them either.
[Diabolical Mastermind](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiabolicalMastermind): Although it can be argued that  (SPOILER)  Brooks  is actually the one pulling the strings.

[Didn't Think This Through](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntThinkThisThrough):
    - The clone wants to replace Shepard, but they have only the most superficial idea of who Shepard is. The clone is intensely xenophobic when several of Shepard's closest allies and potential love interests are alien. The clone is very much a [Bad Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadBoss) who has no interest in preserving the lives of their followers, an attitude which would have gotten Shepard killed in the Suicide Mission. The clone mocks Shepard for being "worn-out Cerberus tech" but said cyborg implants have carried and will continue to carry Shepard through near-death of all types and ultimately allow them to activate the Crucible, saving the galaxy. - There's also the fact they have Traynor thrown off the ship for "fraternization" or "conduct unbecoming" and orders Shepard's space hamster [disposed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog), simply because they were not in line with Alliance [military protocol](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MildlyMilitary). The clone also displays a rather narrow-minded world view in contrast with Shepard's outside-the-box style of thinking, forgetting that Shepard's unorthodox methods are part of the reason they are so successful. This was the reason why Shepard accepted aid from Cerberus when it became clear they were the *only* ones willing to fight the Collectors and *why* Shepard often [recruits](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChooserOfTheOne) from [alien races](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheXenophile), recognising talented *individuals* regardless of their species, who would contribute to the success of the mission. - Furthermore, if the clone *had* managed to successfully steal Shepard's identity and the *Normandy*, what exactly [was their plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndThenWhat) to save the galaxy from the Reapers? Did they even think that far ahead? - Shepard can actually call the clone out on this: QUOTE **Clone**: I've taken your name, your Spectre rank, even your fingerprints! **Shepard:** And then you left me to die... only I didn't. You think fake fingerprints are going to fool the Council? Or Hackett?

[Disney Villain Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisneyVillainDeath):  (SPOILER) Falling a very long way from a *very* fast moving ship into the Wards, possibly slamming into a skyscraper. That is... if the lack of oxygen and [exposure to the vacuum of space](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrownOutTheAirlock) didn't kill them *first*.  <sup>note </sup>   The Citadel only extends its atmosphere 7 metres above the Ward arms.

[Driven to Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide):  (SPOILER) After Brooks abandons them while Shepard's teammates save them, they refuse a [Take My Hand!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeMyHand) .

[Entertainingly Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EntertaininglyWrong): Shepard had previously mused in the beginning of the second game whether or not they had been brought back to life as a clone. Turns out Cerberus really *did* clone them, but they were the original, not the clone.
[Evil Is Hammy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsHammy): Male or female, they can absolutely devour the scenery at times.

[Evil Is Petty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilIsPetty): When they take over the *Normandy*, they dump Shepard's pets and ship models in the trash for disposal. At the sight of this, the real Shepard declares "[Oh, now it's personal!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsPersonal)"
[Evil Knockoff](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilKnockoff): It was originally intended simply as spare parts for the main Shepard.
[Evil Twin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilTwin): Shepard's appearance, powers and skill without the comrades, experience or morals.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Clone Shepard hates aliens more than any other character in the game (except Kai Leng, but that's only depicted in the EU novels). They actually chew out Shepard for saving more alien lives than human lives, accusing them of having forgotten about their own species. EDI gets singled out for being "[nothing more than electrons pretending to be alive](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustAMachine)". They're basically Shepard if they were raised by the Illusive Man.
[Felony Misdemeanor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FelonyMisdemeanor): Attempting to throw away their hamster is what makes it *[really](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsPersonal)* personal for Shepard.
[Freudian Excuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianExcuse): Being created merely for [spare parts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanResources) and living in Shepard's shadow.

[Hair-Trigger Temper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairTriggerTemper): Normally calm and collected, there are a few points on the radio and in front of Shepard where they will explode into a fit of childish anger.
[Human Resources](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HumanResources): Their original purpose. They weren't even supposed to wake up.

Hypocrite: Shows traits of this.<dl><dd>
QUOTE  **Clone**: You're a figurehead! A decent soldier with a lucky streak! 
**Shepard**: Then how come you want to be me so badly?
</dd></dl>

tropeName: I Just Want to Be Special
tropeNotes:
[I Just Want to Be Special](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IJustWantToBeSpecial): Heavily implied that the *[real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianExcuse)* reason they are doing everything is because they are unable to handle the fact that as long as Shepard is around, they will *[always](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysSecondBest)* be stuck in their shadow.
QUOTE  **Clone**: Look at you. What makes you so [damned special?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChosenOne) Why you and not *[me?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CloneAngst)*

tropeName: I Just Want to Have Friends
tropeNotes: [I Just Want to Have Friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IJustWantToHaveFriends): The sudden realisation that Shepard's [friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueCompanions) are part of what makes them special, is what causes them to refuse  (SPOILER) [Shepard's hand](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeMyHand) and [fall to their death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide) .
[Inferiority Superiority Complex](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InferioritySuperiorityComplex): Clone Shepard has developed a *major* case of this towards the original Shepard.

[Insistent Terminology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsistentTerminology): While fully admitting to being a clone, nonetheless, wants people to call them the "[Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfettered)" Shepard.
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): A complete asshole to enemy and ally alike.

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): Seems fond of doing this.
    - When first encountered, a different insult is fired at one of the squadmates that's with Shepard at the time. For example, in the case of the Virmire Survivor, it's a quite simple "I would have saved the other one, Kaidan/Ashley... Something." - Tries to throw away Shepard's space hamster. The fiend! - It gets so bad at times that even a Paragon Shepard will say "[I'm looking forward to killing myself](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PreAssKickingOneLiner)."
[Kill and Replace](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillAndReplace): Their goal. They're so bad at it one would think they didn't even look at a copy of the Shepard VI for some idea.

[Knight of Cerebus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KnightOfCerebus): [Inverted Trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvertedTrope). While Clone Shepard is a genuinely dangerous villain, the *Citadel* DLC is pretty lighthearted when compared to the rest of the series.  (SPOILER) They're actually defeated less than half-way through it .

[Mirror Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MirrorBoss): During their final battle, the clone uses the same class abilities as Shepard. They also trade in their CAT6 merc suit for Shepard's iconic N7 Armor, only in white with a blue arm stripe instead of red.  <sup>note </sup>   Except if you're using customized armor. If so, then the clone dons the iconic N7 Armor with the original red stripe.  
QUOTE **Shepard (Paragon)**: Well, that's creepy... 
**Shepard (Renegade)**: Unacceptable!

[No Cure for Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoCureForEvil): Averted. You have to exhaust their supply of medi-gel before you can go for the kill. So *that's* how it feels for enemies! And at the same time played straight. There's an infinitely refilling pallet of medi-gel refills on the deck that they appear completely oblivious to.

tropeName: The Only One Allowed to Defeat You
tropeNotes: [The Only One Allowed to Defeat You](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheOnlyOneAllowedToDefeatYou): Your squad mates usually do a pretty good job at keeping  (SPOILER) the clone  on their toes, often depleting their entire medi-gel reserves in seconds if  (SPOILER) the clone  gets caught in an armor-piercing crossfire, but no matter how much overkill they throw at  (SPOILER) the clone  once the medi-gel count hits zero, it won't put them down for good - the killing blow always has to be dealt by the player and, by extension, Shepard.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): When stealing the *Normandy*, elects to fire Traynor for "[fraternisation or conduct unbecoming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MildlyMilitary)" and kick her off the ship, instead of simply killing her. Of course, one wonders if they'd have been so merciful if Traynor wasn't *[human](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism)*.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): Has a number of fire abilities regardless of Shepard's class. This also contrasts with Shepard's own numerous ice abilities.
