[Politically Incorrect Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PoliticallyIncorrectVillain): They not only criticize Shep for saving so many alien lives, but they also do so in a way that sounds like nothing so much as a White Nationalist calling a non-racist Caucasian a race traitor.
[Pretender Diss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PretenderDiss): No matter which squadmate they insult, they're told in response that they're "a pale imitation of the real thing".
[Psychopathic Man Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychopathicManChild):  (SPOILER)  Comes off as this, which makes sense, since the clone really is just a child in an adult's body.
[Purely Aesthetic Gender](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PurelyAestheticGender): Notice how, like Shepard (minus the spoilers), they are never referred to with gender-specific pronouns.

[Rhetorical Question Blunder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RhetoricalQuestionBlunder): As both Shepard and it are holding on the Normandy’s cargo ramp, the clone asks one last time what makes Shepard better than them. This is immediately and non-verbally answered by Shepard’s squad coming to rescue their leader: Shepard has *[friends](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueCompanions)*.

[Sanity Slippage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SanitySlippage): They start out as being murderously vindictive towards Shepard and wanting to replace them at any cost and become increasingly unhinged and unstable as their plans fall apart.  (SPOILER) Brooks  really did a number on the clone.

[Schrödinger's Gun](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SchrodingersGun): During their introduction scene, they mock one of Shepard's squad mates. If you bring the Virmire Survivor along, they can mock them by saying they would have chosen [their dead counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MutuallyExclusivePartyMembers). The clone says this regardless of whether you chose Ashley or Kaidan and goes so far as to not remember the dead character's last name in both situations.

[Shadow Archetype](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShadowArchetype): Throughout *Mass Effect 2*, Miranda, Jacob, and the Illusive Man will all reiterate that Shepard was brought back as they originally were, with no alterations. Clone Shepard is effectively what would have happened if Cerberus went through with "reprogramming" Shepard to be loyal to them, or Miranda getting her way and putting a control chip in their brain. Rather fittingly, Brooks, who is responsible for making Clone Shepard the way they are, compares herself to Miranda at one point.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut):
    - The climax of the arc is *very* reminiscent of *[The Mummy Returns](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/TheMummyReturns)* (SPOILER) when Imhotep is abandoned by Anck-Su-Namun, just as Brooks did to them, and both respond by [voluntarily casting themselves off a lethal fall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide), while the hero (Shepard/Rick) is rescued from the same peril by their friends. - If Shepard is an Adept or a Vanguard, their melee conflict will result in both using a biotic field in a similar manner to how [Anakin and Obi-Wan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Franchise/StarWars) used [Force Push](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Telekinesis) [against each other](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BeamOWar) during the duel in *[Revenge of the Sith](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Film/RevengeOfTheSith)*, with [similar outcomes.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlownAcrossTheRoom)
[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): Very, *very* smug, enough to make Renegade Shepard look downright *charming* in comparison.

[Save the Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SaveTheVillain):  (SPOILER) Paragon Shepard [repeatedly attempts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCouldHaveUsedYourPowersForGood) this, [but it doesn't work.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide)

[Stalker with a Crush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StalkerWithACrush):  (SPOILER) Despite repeatedly dismissing Shepard and their accomplishments, a lot of their dialogue, and indeed their [entire goal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KillAndReplace), make it *obvious* that they have somewhat of an unhealthy obsession towards them.

[Tyrant Takes the Helm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TyrantTakesTheHelm):  (SPOILER) [Downplayed Trope](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DownplayedTrope). When the clone takes over the *Normandy*, it seems that they take Alliance regulations much more seriously than Shepard does. They fire Traynor for "fraternization" or "conduct unbecoming" and tries to dispose of Shepard's space hamster. Of course, the clone isn't trying to take over Shepard's crew, just steal the *Normandy*.

[Underestimating Badassery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnderestimatingBadassery): The latest in a long line of people who make the mistake of underestimating Shepard. As a clone of Shepard, you'd *really* think they'd be [aware of this](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenreBlind) and have done their homework first.
[Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown): "I'm Shepard. Do you hear me, asshole/bitch? I'm Shepard!"
[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): There's really no way to talk about them without spoiling that they're a clone of Shepard. Hence, the entire folder is marked.

tropeName: We Could Have Avoided All This
tropeNotes: [We Could Have Avoided All This](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeCouldHaveAvoidedAllThis): Shepard at one point asks the clone why they just didn't reveal their existence? The clone retorts that it would have been torture being a shadow to the real thing.

[Wrong Genre Savvy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrongGenreSavvy): Despite being [a clone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilTwin) of Commander Shepard, they seem to forget that they're dealing with *[Commander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneManArmy) [Shepard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded)*. They also don't truly realise what *makes* Shepard, Shepard.

tropeName: You Are Better Than You Think You Are
tropeNotes: [You Are Better Than You Think You Are](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreBetterThanYouThinkYouAre): Paragon Shepard repeatedly invokes this.

tropeName: You Could Have Used Your Powers for Good!
tropeNotes: [You Could Have Used Your Powers for Good!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouCouldHaveUsedYourPowersForGood): Paragon Shepard tries to claim that they should be on the same side. It doesn't fly.

[You Fight Like a Cow](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouFightLikeACow): The real Shepard points this out during their final fight.
QUOTE **Clone**: *I* am Commander Shepard! 
**Shepard**: Are you kidding me? *[Conrad Verner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey)* is better at being me than you are!
[Younger Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungerThanTheyLook): The clone is physically Shepard's age but is actually only a few years old. Makes sense, since they're a clone.

VGDCName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
TvTName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
tropeNotes: [The Bad Guy Wins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBadGuyWins): If Kasumi doesn't live through to *3*, and Shepard chooses to save Jondum Bau instead of stopping Zymandis, he succeeds in his plot to sabotage Khaje's defenses, allowing the Reapers to roll right in and harvest them.

VGDCName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
TvTName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
tropeNotes: [Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): Zymandis is completely indoctrinated. And unlike some, its brain is now completely fried.

VGDCName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
TvTName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
tropeNotes:
[Insane Troll Logic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InsaneTrollLogic): Thanks to the indoctrination. Regard: Hanar worship the Protheans, the Reapers turned the Protheans into the Collectors, therefore the hanar must serve the Reapers. A frustrated Shepard speaks for us all.
QUOTE **Shepard:** You big, stupid jellyfish!

VGDCName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
TvTName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
tropeNotes: [Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal): There's no outcome to his confrontation with Bau and Shepard that ends with him floating away.

VGDCName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
TvTName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
tropeNotes: [Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): There's a reason for the Soul Name, aside from it being being an important clue — Zymandis = Ozymandius. Regard the Enkindlers' works, ye mighty, and despair!

VGDCName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
TvTName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
tropeNotes: [Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): Only appears at the end of one short quest acquired right at the beginning of the game, but if you haven't played your cards right, he causes the extinction of *two* races.

VGDCName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
TvTName: Zymandis / Regards The Work of The Endkindlers With Despair
tropeNotes: [Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): Amazingly, manages to do this despite the hanar monotone.

[Ace Pilot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AcePilot): A former fighter jock who spends nearly as much time tinkering with his birds as flying them. He's not so attached to them that he'll risk pissing off an 800-pound krogan with a shotgun, though. His skill at flying is further highlighted in *Citadel*, where he reveals that he prefers flying with the inertial dampeners *off* and pulling a few G's, even doing a *barrel-roll*.
    - [Falling into the Cockpit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallingIntoTheCockpit): He has experience flying and obviously does a fine job, but on paper he is actually your logistics officer, and ended up running the shuttles because no one else on the *Normandy* could. Further, like Samantha Traynor and [Those Two Guys](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThoseTwoGuys) guarding the doorway to the War Room, he was de facto kidnapped by EDI and Joker when they took the *Normandy*, so he segued from retrofitting the *Normandy* to maintaining and flying the shuttles and managing requisitions. - He and Joker recognize each other as such, and both will admit that neither could take the other's job — Steve's skills with the Kodiac wouldn't translate to the *Normandy*, and vice versa with Joker.
[Ambiguously Brown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyBrown): Steve is Latino, with a Hispanic last name, but also has [Icy Blue Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IcyBlueEyes).

[Anger Born of Worry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AngerBornOfWorry): Shows this a few times, though with a snippy tone rather than something more drastic. He sees Shepard step out of that shuttle and into hell a *lot*. In *Citadel* he admits that this is because while on the battlefield Shepard is [invincible](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneManArmy) but the moment they step into the evac shuttle, they are vulnerable and it's *his* responsibility to get them out of there alive.
[Bilingual Bonus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BilingualBonus): James call Steve "Esteban", which is "Steve" in Spanish.

[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): Despite being one of the nicest and most reserved members of the *Normandy's* crew, he's oddly thrilled by the chance to take the Kodiak into a dogfight and is positively delighted watching a Cerberus cruiser "gracefully and silently disintegrate" during one mission on Tuchanka.
QUOTE  **James:** Sometimes I worry about you, man.
[Cartwright Curse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CartwrightCurse): Possible to inflict on him by romancing him  (SPOILER)  and choosing an ending where Shepard dies.

[Covert Pervert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CovertPervert): James jokingly accuses this of Steve. "You know you love the show!"
    - He gets to prove James right in the *Leviathan* DLC during the [Anger Born of Worry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AngerBornOfWorry) dialogue if you romance him. While he does deliver the sappy lines about how worried he was and how much he loves Shepard, he *then* adds that he would've joined Shepard on the diving expedition, [but might've gotten...uncomfortable being in such tight quarters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SomethingElseAlsoRises).

[A Day in the Limelight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ADayInTheLimelight): While the *Leviathan* DLC far from focuses on him, he receives a more prominent supporting role in it and  (SPOILER) even gets to pick up a rifle and participate in the battle against the Reapers alongside Shepard once they get stranded at Leviathan's lair.

[Do-Anything Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoAnythingSoldier): stands out for multi-disciplinary excellence. He started out as an [Ace Pilot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AcePilot) flying an F-61 Trident [Space Fighter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpaceFighter); he transitions into an [Armchair Military](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArmchairMilitary) support role managing logistics; he takes on a second hat as your *[Drop Ship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DropShip)* pilot simply because he's the [Closest Thing We Got](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClosestThingWeGot) to it; and — during the *Citadel* and *Leviathan* DLC missions — he actually takes to the field with an assault rifle, though never as a controllable member of the [Player Party](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayerParty).
[Dropped a Bridge on Him](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DroppedABridgeOnHim):  (SPOILER) If you didn't befriend or romance him, he dies when his shuttle is shot down during the last level.

[Eating the Eye Candy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EatingTheEyeCandy): Enjoys watching the male dancers at Purgatory. James will tease that Steve enjoys watching *him* too. Steve won't deny it.
QUOTE **James:** You know you love the show, Esteban!

[Gay Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GayOption): For male Shepard. If Shepard is already dating Kaidan, he'll chuckle and say that he knows Shepard is dating Kaidan and not try to pursue Shep himself.
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal): If Cortez isn't befriended or romanced, he'll die at Earth when the shuttle crashes, thanks to his lack of regard for his own safety.

[Lampshade Hanging](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LampshadeHanging): The first retrofit he did was move the armory back down to the shuttle bay like the original *Normandy* ("I'm not sure what Cerberus engineers were thinking"). He also indirectly explains [Space Is Noisy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SpaceIsNoisy) by bringing up audio emulators (he likes to mute them while watching Cerberus ships get cut in half). If flirted with, he will refer to the [large number of women](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChickMagnet) players waiting for a proper [Gay Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GayOption) have had to fend off.
[Last Guy Wins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastGuyWins): If romanced. For a male Shepard, he's the last new romance option to be introduced in the series.
[The Lost Lenore](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLostLenore): Robert. Shepard will be instrumental on whether he gets over it or not.

[Moving Beyond Bereavement](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MovingBeyondBereavement): Steve Cortez lost his husband during the Collector attack on Ferris Fields and has spent much of the time since then absorbed in his work - to the point that Shepard has to talk him into taking shore leave. He's also prone to risk-taking behaviour in combat, his guilt and grief having essentially disabled his self-preservation instincts. However, in the event that Shepard befriends him or (if male) romances him, he's eventually able to move on and find happiness in the present.

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): One of his most defining traits is how exceptionally polite he is. His voice never raises above a low yell, and that's only in the most extreme of survival situations.

[Not Afraid to Die](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotAfraidToDie): He's not actively trying to kill himself, but his husband's death effectively wiped out his self-preservation instinct. Shepard can knock him out of this, but [if they don't](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BuryYourGays) ...

[Palette Swap](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PaletteSwap): Blink and you miss it, but at the conclusion of his romance, Steve and male Shepard have the same body model; the freckles on the back are in the exact same places.

[Romancing the Widower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RomancingTheWidow): His husband Robert died during the Collectors' abduction of Ferris Fields, and he can be romanced by male Shepard during the course of *[Mass Effect 3](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect3)*.
[Say My Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SayMyName): Shepard will scream "STEVE!" when his shuttle goes down, regardless of relationship or whether he survives after.
[Second Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecondLove): With male Shepard, if romanced.

[Sensitive Guy and Manly Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SensitiveGuyAndManlyMan): The sensitive guy to James' manly man. While he firmly fits as a [Straight Gay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StraightGay), he's not afraid to talk about his feelings, his problems letting go of his dead husband, and even cry in front of others. This is all presented in a very serious light, without a hint of camp.

[Straight Gay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StraightGay): Displays no stereotypical mannerisms. They even put him in the same garage as the resident bodybuilder, but not only does Steve not flirt with him once, the two actually have an outright [Friendly Rivalry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendlyRivalry) (though Vega does at one point *accuse* Cortez of enjoying watching him work out all day, to which Steve doesn't respond).
[Survivor's Guilt](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SurvivorsGuilt): Feels incredibly guilty over escaping Ferris Fields while his husband was there.
[Sweet Tooth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SweetTooth): A self-confessed dessert guy (he also likes fish and chips and feels sorry that the dextro crew have to miss out on bacon).

[Thrill Seeker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThrillSeeker): Steve loves to pilot, and during the Citadel DLC, will turn off the inertial dampeners to allow Shepard to feel actual G's as he flies the skycar.

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): In the Leviathan DLC, he became one of the few *Normandy* crew who is not a party member to actively participate in a fight against the Reapers, handing you parts  (SPOILER)  to power up a deep-sea exploration mech  in the middle of a firefight and even holding his own against the Reaper ground forces with an assault rifle. In the Citadel DLC, he joins in the big Archive fight and keeps up with your veteran squaddies without any hassle.
[Twofer Token Minority](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwoferTokenMinority): Gay and Latino.

[Vitriolic Best Buds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VitriolicBestBuds): He and James knew each other before they both ended up on the *Normandy* and spend most of their time heckling each other. That said, there is never a single hint of true animosity between them; apparently, they just like making fun of each other.
[Workaholic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Workaholic): Half of his subplot is just persuading him to take some shore leave when he has the chance. It's his way of distracting himself from his grief.

[Ambiguously Brown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmbiguouslyBrown): At first. In the base game, there was no indication of what her ethnicity was, which would be [appropriate for this setting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InTheFutureHumansWillBeOneRace). In the *Citadel* DLC though, she's confirmed as ethnically Indian, albeit born on a different planet than Earth. Traynor, on the other hand, is an English/Irish surname, so she may be mixed race, too, especially since she speaks with a Received English accent.

[All Gays are Promiscuous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllGaysArePromiscuous): Downplayed, but she has a fair share of moments being a shameless flirt with Female Shepard, and she makes little attempt to hide how attracted she is to EDI, especially in the *Citadel* DLC where the latter can even send her some synthetic-human porn.

[...And That Would Be Wrong](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndThatWouldBeWrong): When Shepard asks what's in the turian messages involving the bomb on Tuchanka...
QUOTE **Traynor:** Sorry, it's encrypted. Cracking it would take at least a week. And it would be wrong.

[Aroused by Their Voice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArousedByTheirVoice): Found EDI's voice *very* attractive to the point of fantasizing some very naughty things she wanted to do with it.
QUOTE **EDI:** On one occasion, you said that you wanted to, quote, pin my voice against the wall and run your tongue along its collarbone.

QUOTE **Traynor:** Well, there's a context there that... you were talking about quantum entanglement, and... I didn't know you were an AI!

[Berserk Button](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BerserkButton): Kaidan trying to bring her into an argument over curry sends Traynor into a rant over Indian stereotypes, her loathing of curry, and [allergies to it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag). Kaidan [just wanted backup from another person with taste buds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MistakenForRacist).
[Chekhov's Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGag): In the Citadel DLC,  (SPOILER) *her toothbrush saves the Normandy*. Seriously .

[Covert Pervert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CovertPervert): Shy and socially awkward, but that doesn't stop her from attempting to seduce a female Shepard (and if not flirted with, she'll still take a moment to check out Shepard's butt). It's also revealed in the *Citadel* DLC that she has lesbian fantasies of EDI and is into extranet porn (organic on synthetic, no less. See [Robosexual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Robosexual) below). She even mentions that she can show Joker, who's anything but covert, how to hide his porn search history (all seven zettabytes of it).
[Crush Blush](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrushBlush): If a romancing Shepard compliments her, at some point she can say "And now I'm blushing" and be told "You do that fairly regularly."

[Distracted by the Sexy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DistractedByTheSexy): Is mortified to find out EDI is actually an AI, quickly apologizing for all the times she commented on her *[sexy voice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArousedByTheirVoice)*.
[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart):  (SPOILER) Maya Brooks  is almost a clone of Samantha, except for the fact she's a bad guy.
[Eyed Screen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EyedScreen): When she meets [Polgara T'Suzsa](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SitcomArchNemesis) again.

[Falling into the Cockpit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallingIntoTheCockpit): She happened to be working aboard the *Normandy* as a Communications Specialist when the Reaper attack hit. Having only ever served in an R&D lab before, takes to the role of shipboard Communications and Strategic Intelligence officer like a duck to water.
[Gay Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GayOption): For female Shepard.

[Hero-Worshipper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroWorshipper): She's quite nervous around Shepard at the beginning and very eager to prove herself to them. Part of this is also implied to be gratitude, as she was on Horizon, visiting her family, when the Collectors hit and when Shepard saved the colony.
[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): She tended bar in college and can make cocktails during the house party in the *Citadel* DLC.

[Hypercompetent Sidekick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HypercompetentSidekick): Unlike Kelly Chambers from *ME2*, Traynor doesn't exist simply to serve as a [Bridge Bunny](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BridgeBunny) to inform Shepard when they have mail. From the moment she's aboard the ship, Traynor's immediately sets to work as the *Normandy's* Communications and Strategic Intelligence officer and manages to save the day on more than one occasion, by discovering key intel that was initially missed.

[Hypochondria](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypochondria): At least one of the medications she's on is actually a placebo. Even if it wasn't, the sheer quantity of the medicines she intakes should be an obvious hint.

[Incompatible Orientation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IncompatibleOrientation):
    - If you try and hit on her as male Shepard. She's still flattered though. - Referenced in Ken/Gabby banter. QUOTE **Gabby**: And you're barking up the wrong tree, Kenneth. You're not her type. **Kenneth**: Ohhh... well, perhaps you should go and talk to her, then. **Gabby**: Maybe I should. Nobody's barking up *my* tree. **Kenneth**: [If it works out, be sure to take video](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlOnGirlIsHot).

[Innocent Fanservice Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InnocentFanserviceGirl): She gets into a hot-tub in Anderson's apartment (albeit still in her lingerie—although granted, that bathroom doesn't actually *have* a door). This ends up leading to a [highly awkward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyEyesAreUpHere) conversation with male Shepard. It's a little odd since she keeps her black bra on, meaning Shepard really didn't have to avert any eyes.

[I Owe You My Life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IOweYouMyLife): One of the reasons she is so loyal and nervous around Shepard is because she was visiting her parents on Horizon when the Collectors hit, and Shepard saved the colony.
[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): Your communications specialist is socially awkward.
[Last Girl Wins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LastGirlWins): If romanced.
[Lipstick Lesbian](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LipstickLesbian): Very feminine and only into women.

[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): Gets a shower scene in the vanilla game, and a scene in the hot tub during *Citadel*. That, and only [female Shepards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlOnGirlIsHot) can romance her.

[Mundane Utility](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MundaneUtility): Her toothbrush. It uses mass effect fields, the miracle technology that makes faster-than-light travel possible, to floss between the teeth, break up plaque and massage the gums. It costs over six thousand credits, so needless to say, Shepard isn't putting in a requisition order to replace the one she lost. For perspective, six thousand credits are about the cost of a military-grade assault rifle. Then again, since it ends up being [the key](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGag) to preventing (SPOILER) Clone Shepard from stealing the *Normandy* in the *Citadel DLC*, [it seems this was definitely money well spent.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HilariousInHindsight)

[Nipple and Dimed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NippleAndDimed): Apparently Miss Traynor likes to take her showers while wearing her lacy bra and panties. And with the door open (of course, she *is* trying to seduce a female Shepard).

[Once Done, Never Forgotten](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnceDoneNeverForgotten): During the Citadel DLC party. EDI is practically [Trolling](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Troll) Samantha about her attraction to the AI. Tali would rather be anywhere else than listen to the conversation.

[Opposites Attract](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OppositesAttract): Traynor and Shepard are like night and day: One is a [charismatic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagneticHero), [almost invincible](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneManArmy) front-lines commander who can soldier on  (SPOILER)  even after being hit at point-blank range by a Reaper Beam . The other is a socially awkward, hypochondriac communication officer who shines **away** from the front-line. From start to finish, their romance [looks like an extended honeymoon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SickeninglySweethearts).

[Placebo Effect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlaceboEffect): Her doctor prescribed sugar pills for her. Shepard accidentally reveals the truth, which pisses Traynor off. Not because they are placebos, but because that now when she knows *they won't work anymore!*

[Platonic Life-Partners](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlatonicLifePartners): With a male Shepard. The scenes where she attempts to seduce a female Shepard (like the shower scene in Shepard's cabin) don't happen in the same way - she really *does* want to play a game in order to get to know a male Shepard and gently turns him down if the player attempts to hit on her. The hot tub scene from the *Citadel* DLC makes her more of an [Innocent Fanservice Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InnocentFanserviceGirl), as she dorkily squees over the hot tub and still jumps in wearing lingerie, though male Shepard gamely stands outside the door and they have a fun, genial chat.

[Robosexual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Robosexual): In the *Citadel* DLC it's revealed she has a thing for organic/synthetic porn, which EDI helps her out with. A suitably hammered Joker tells her that a female Shepard in a romance with her is 30% cybernetic. Samantha is very intrigued to hear it's a full 30%.
[Robo Ship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RoboShip): invoked  She thinks EDI has a sexy voice, then definitely approves of EDI's new body.
[Sexy Secretary](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SexySecretary): Unlike Kelly, it's entirely coincidental.
[Serious Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SeriousBusiness): The Kepesh-Yakshi game, in the Citadel DLC.
[Shower of Love](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShowerOfLove): Her romance scene.

[Sitcom Arch-Nemesis](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SitcomArchNemesis): With Polgara T'Suzsa, an extremely condescending asari who plays and teaches asari chess tactics professionally, and keeps knocking Traynor out of tournaments. She's also a very unsportsmanlike winner.

[Smart People Play Chess](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmartPeoplePlayChess): Either she is very very good at it, or Shepard plays chess about as well as they dance.
    - According to the dialog afterwards, Shepard couldn't get out of thinking like a soldier and tried to use [real-world tactics](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WrongGenreSavvy), like using an infantry line to break a charge, since it's what *would* have worked in reality. So it's probably like dancing. Traynor openly mocks them for this. - She also is incredibly skilled at the asari version of chess.
[Sorry, I'm Gay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SorryImGay): How she rejects male Shepard if he hits on her.
[Straight Gay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StraightGay): Displays no stereotypical mannerisms.

[Teach Her Anger](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TeachHerAnger): During the fight with the Reaper Destroyer on Rannoch, she states that for the first time, she felt *angry*. She didn't want to simply defeat that Reaper, she wanted to *kill* it. Shepard congratulates her on finding her fight-or-flight response. A romanced Traynor is much more furious after Sanctuary, to the point where Shepard is actually a little concerned. Very much justified though- Sanctuary  (SPOILER) and the atrocities committed within the facility  is located on Horizon, *her home planet*.
[Twofer Token Minority](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwoferTokenMinority): Lesbian and Space!Indian (She was born on another planet but identifies as ethnically Indian).
[Actor Allusion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActorAllusion): Allers and Chobot are both television reporters.

[The Alcoholic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAlcoholic): There are a *lot* of wine bottles scattered about her room on the *Normandy*. Given the [subject matter she's covering](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HopelessWar), hard to blame her.

[Classified Information](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ClassifiedInformation): Visiting her after recruiting [Javik](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Precursors) reveals that he's explicitly off-limits to her reports.

[Doomed Hometown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoomedHometown): She mentions in passing that her homeworld is the colony of Bekenstein.  (SPOILER)  Towards the end of the game, her colony is razed and her family killed, because the Reapers target industrial areas and her hometown had a factory that made binoculars .
[Dropped a Bridge on Her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DroppedABridgeOnHer):  (SPOILER) If you refuse her, she puts herself on another ship, which is blown up, and she dies.

[Don't Like? Don't Read!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DontLikeDontRead): Her attitude regarding her opinion piece about abandoning Terra Nova in her argument with Copeland. Shepard can choose whom to support.
[Dull Surprise](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DullSurprise): Thanks to her limited facial animations and the voice actress' delivery, her tone doesn't change even when she's upset or surprised.
[Flat Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FlatCharacter): There really isn't anything to explore in depth about her.
[Gay Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GayOption): For female characters, although she doesn't grant the Paramour achievement.

[Girly Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GirlyGirl): To female Shepard's [tomboy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Tomboy), if you so choose. Deliberately cultivated after focus group testing; asari identify more with women than men, salarians respond well to higher voices, and turians are fans of any war programs and send the creepiest fan mail.

[Going for the Big Scoop](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoingForTheBigScoop): She was assigned to embed in her choice of Alliance ships, and she specifically has the *Normandy* as her first. Shepard has veto powers at the end of the day over her stories, but it's worthwhile to allow her some interviews; despite not being worth many War Assets on her own, her interviews will bolster other Assets.
[Ink-Suit Actor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InkSuitActor): Her appearances are based on her voice actress.

[Ms. Fanservice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MsFanservice): Her outfit is a form-fitting dress that accentuates her features. [Invoked](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InvokedTrope) for her show, purely because [Sex Sells](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SexSells).

[Non-Answer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonAnswer): You have the option to kick Diana off the ship at literally *any* time just by repeatedly talking to her; if you choose to invoke it, she asks for a reason. Shepard merely replies, "What do *you* think?"

[Only Friend](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyFriend): Only Samantha Traynor ever bothers to really talk to Diana when Shepard's not around, mostly inquiring about her Alliance News Network duties and presentation; she otherwise just stays cooped up in her corner of the ship. Ensign Copeland gets into a pretty heated argument with her, and Shepard might have their own reasons for disliking Allers depending on player input.
[Out of Focus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutOfFocus): Unlike Cortez and Traynor, Diana does not return for the Citadel DLC.

[Satellite Love Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatelliteLoveInterest): Reciprocating her growing interest in you doesn't lock you out of any other romance options and is treated as an incredibly brief fling, to the extent that her dialogue if you kick her off the Normandy doesn't even change afterwards. <sup>note </sup>  Only Liara ever finds out, being the Shadow Broker and all.
[Secret Relationship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SecretRelationship): In her final romance scene, she says no one else can find out about their relationship or else her career will be jeopardized.

[Surveillance Drone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SurveillanceDrone): She doesn't need a camera crew; she has a fully automated hovering camera she controls from her omni-tool. The viewpoint [switches to its feed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InUniverseCamera) when she's conducting her interviews.
[Tagalong Reporter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TagalongReporter): [She's a reporter who tags along on the Normandy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactlyWhatItSaysOnTheTin).

VGDCName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
TvTName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
tropeNotes: [Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): Campbell expresses some pretty bloodthirsty views. Shoot an ex-friend? No problem, the bastard joined Cerberus, so he's dead to her anyway. She'd put a bullet in his head if she saw him. Other species ignored Earth's initial pleas for help? Once the Reapers are gone, let's declare war on them for revenge. Of course, one has to wonder how much, if any, field experience she actually has, and how much of it is just bluster.

VGDCName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
TvTName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
tropeNotes: [Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Very much so; they'll usually toss banter about [like Cerberus throw frags](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrenadeSpam) about the previous mission.

VGDCName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
TvTName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
tropeNotes:
[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards): For all her distrustful views regarding aliens, Campbell takes exception to being compared to racist xenophobes like Cerberus.
QUOTE **Westmoreland**: I just thought you'd be more open... you've never been fond of aliens. 
**Campbell**: Hell yeah, I joined up to kick ass like everyone else, but I need more of a reason than "It has scales" to go kill someone. And if Cerberus is taking our dishonorable discharges and Cat-6 washouts, that's just another reason why they're not worth a damn!

VGDCName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
TvTName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
tropeNotes: [Falling into the Cockpit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FallingIntoTheCockpit): They were Joker's guards (in the "legal custody" sense, not the "Very Important Person" sense) before the Reaper attack, keeping watch over him while he worked with EDI <sup>note </sup>   who convinced the Alliance officials that she was a VI rather than an AI, and that she was programmed only to respond to Joker's inputs  during the *Normandy's* retrofit. When the Reaper attack happened, they accepted Joker and EDI's offer of a ride. Now they guard the War Room, evidently for lack of anything else to do with their skills. Joker lampshades this by saying "it didn't seem right to kick 'em out of the airlock" as the *Normandy* headed to pick up Shepard.

VGDCName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
TvTName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
tropeNotes: [Greek Chorus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreekChorus): They provide commentary as Shepard goes in and out of the war room.

VGDCName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
TvTName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
tropeNotes:
[The Guards Must Be Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheGuardsMustBeCrazy): Averted. They evidently check *everybody* before allowing them in or out of the War Room, including Shepard, the ship's commander. Every time they walk through. [The Doylist explanation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WatsonianVersusDoylist) is that they keep the player still as the next area loads, since Shepard is scanned even if they turn back around immediately after entering. The Watson one is due to fears of indoctrination and sabotage.
    - The in-universe reason given in a segment of Westmoreland/Campbell banter is the Collectors storming the Normandy and abducting the crew in the previous game, which Joker informed them of at some point prior to the escape from Earth. At least part of the reason they take their duties so seriously - incessant banter aside, anyways - is because they're aware that they're the first line of defense in case a similar incident occurs. To emphasize the point that they need to be ready for anything, they have assault rifles close at hand.

VGDCName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
TvTName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
tropeNotes:
[Moral Myopia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralMyopia): They discuss this regarding (SPOILER) the Council refusing to help Earth. Sarah is outraged but Bethany says that if Thessia were in this position, the Alliance would look to their own interests first .
    - On the whole, Westmoreland is far more circumspect, reasonable, and reserved than Campbell. QUOTE **Campbell:** [When this war is over, I hope we find every race that sat back as we bled and get some payback](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RevengeBeforeReason). **Westmoreland:** [Yeah, that's a great plan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SarcasmMode). Follow war with more war.

VGDCName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
TvTName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
tropeNotes: [Red Oni, Blue Oni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedOniBlueOni): Campbell and Westmoreland, respectively.

VGDCName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
TvTName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
tropeNotes: [Revenge Before Reason](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RevengeBeforeReason): Campbell shows shades of this, stating that she wants payback for all the races that "sat back as [humans] bled". Westmoreland shuts her down immediately.

VGDCName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
TvTName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
tropeNotes: [Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): Westmoreland and Campbell both share the same last names as two prominent U.S. Military generals: William Westmoreland (Commander of U.S. Forces in Vietnam from 1964 to 1968) and John F. Campbell (The final Commander of the ISAF coalition of NATO forces in Afghanistan from 2014 to 2016). Their personalities are an inversion of their namesakes however, with Westmoreland being the calmer and more rational of the two and Campbell being more of a [Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight).

VGDCName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
TvTName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
tropeNotes: [Those Two Guys](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThoseTwoGuys): They pass the time by idly bantering about whatever mission Shepard has just returned from.

VGDCName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
TvTName: Privates Bethany Westmoreland and Sarah Campbell
tropeNotes: [With Us or Against Us](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WithUsOrAgainstUs): Campbell states that she's totally fine with killing one of her ex-friends, simply because he joined Cerberus.

[Air Vent Escape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AirVentEscape): Shepard meets him hiding in an air vent. Deciding to keep hiding in the vent and leaving later instead of escaping with Shepard gets him killed.

[My Greatest Failure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MyGreatestFailure): Shepard sees the boy as a symbol of all the people they could not save, and has nightmares in which they run after the boy while hearing the voices of the dead.
[No Name Given](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNameGiven): There is no information on the child's name in-game or out.
[Sacrificial Lamb](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SacrificialLamb): His main purpose is to die so that Shepard has something to feel bad about.
[Stealth Hi/Bye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StealthHiBye): Anderson calls out to Shepard. A moment later, when Shepard turns back, the boy is gone.
[We Hardly Knew Ye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHardlyKnewYe): Shepard's only interaction with him in-game is in the beginning.  (SPOILER) That is until the Catalyst takes the kid's form somehow.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): Quentius is a [Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy) compared to Sparatus's [Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass), while Irissa is even colder and more brutally honest than Tevos. Esheel, comparatively, is a mix of both. She's less visibly upset at Shepard should they choose to cure the genophage than Valern, and is quick to accept Shepard's suggestion that they use it to bolster salarian support for the war effort. However, she's also more pragmatic and Machiavellian than her predecessor, willing to allow harsher actions if it means getting the desired result.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): Irissa brings up the fact that Shepard sacrificed the old council to protect human interests when pondering whether to trust them, giving the New Council's mistrust of Shepard some basis. Esheel does off-handedly point out  (SPOILER) if you cure the genophage , however, that she wouldn't have her job if not for Shepard, so she can't be *too* indignant with their actions overall.
[No Name Given](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoNameGiven): Until *3*.
[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): Despite Irissa's rather curt personality,  (SPOILER)  if Thane dies protecting her from Kai Leng, she'll show up to his funeral in the Citadel DLC.
[Two Girls and a Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TwoGirlsAndAGuy): Albeit having one of the "girls" from a [One-Gender Race](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneGenderRace).
[The Chains of Commanding](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheChainsOfCommanding): He and Shepard have quite a few conversations about this.

[Everyone Has Standards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneHasStandards): While he tries to play the mediator between the krogan representative and the salarian dalatrass, he loses all patience and is outraged at the revelation that the dalatrass was holding female krogan prisoner.
[A Father to His Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen): Cares deeply about the well-being of his people and refuses to simply leave them to their fates.

[Frontline General](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FrontlineGeneral): He's right there on the frontlines on Menae battling the Reaper forces and is extremely reluctant to leave his men when he learns of his promotion to Primarch.
[The Kirk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheKirk): Along with Paragon Shepard to Linron's Spock and Wrex/Wreav's [The McCoy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMcCoy).
[The Men First](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMenFirst): He's hesitant to leave his men behind when his presence is needed on the *Normandy* to coordinate an alliance.
[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Victus in Latin means "living" and "survive".

[Military Maverick](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MilitaryMaverick): He has this reputation thanks to his unorthodox tactics. Liara and Garrus relate one [notable example](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NoodleIncident) from earlier in his career that emphasises his unorthodox methods; during efforts to put down an uprising by turian separatists on the planet Taetrus, Victus discovered a salarian spy ring operating on the planet. Rather than neutralise the ring, he fell back, even surrendering valuable fortifications to the rebels...but then the rebels and salarians attacked each other, allowing Victus to reclaim the fortifications without a single casualty once both sides had wiped each other out, an action that made him a hero amongst the rank and file, but got him censure from the turian high command.

["Not So Different" Remark](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotSoDifferentRemark):
    - He's not a "by-the-book kind of guy" and he has a tendency to piss people off but also cares deeply about the people under his command. Sound *familiar*, Shepard? Fittingly, both of them play [The Kirk](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheKirk) between Dalatrass Linron and Wrex or Wreav, particularly if Shepard is a Paragon. QUOTE **Victus**: You never asked to be a leader, yet your people will die if you don't step forward. We find ourselves in similar circumstances. - Also manages to get one on Renegade Shepard, when they try calling him on his lack of transparency, he asks them if they wouldn't do the exact same with Earth, a fact Shepard has to concede to.
[Outliving One's Offspring](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutlivingOnesOffspring):  (SPOILER)  His son sacrifices himself to disable a turian bomb planted on Tuchanka.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): By far the most cooperative ally Shepard has in the first act of the game. That said, he has a tendency to be very conservative with information at the worst times, leading to a situation where  (SPOILER)  his son dies defusing a bomb on Tuchanka.

[Reluctant Ruler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReluctantRuler): Not particularly happy about being Primarch. Not in the least bit because he's not very high up on the chain of command, meaning he had to step over the corpses of a lot of people, including ones he liked and respected. He gains respect for Shepard as he finds that they are similar in their reluctance of their roles yet do their duties regardless.

[Unexpected Successor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnexpectedSuccessor): He is undeniably skilled and loved by his men, but his unorthodox methods lead to him being held back promotion-wise by the very conservative turian hierarchy. He finds himself as the leader of the entire Turian people due to the deaths of everyone who outranked him in the opening days of the war.
[Vitriolic Best Buds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VitriolicBestBuds): With Garrus. The duo trade friendly snark back and forth on the battlefield.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): He admits to having a certain respect for the sheer power of the Reaper fleet. This doesn't stop him from being horrified and [enraged](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TranquilFury) by what they are doing to his people.
QUOTE **Victus:** The strategist in me respects their brutality. The turian in me knows I'm watching the destruction of fifteen thousand years of civilization. *My* civilization.

[You Are in Command Now](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouAreInCommandNow): His predecessor and all between the two in the line of succession were killed not long after Palaven was besieged. He's actually very bitter about the promotion, partly because he hates politicians, and partly because *a lot* of people had to die in order for the line of succession to get all the way down to him.

[Can't Take Criticism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantTakeCriticism): According to Wiks, if someone talks back to her, she'd have them stranded on Tuchanka with raw meat strapped to their back, then film the ensuing violent death as an example to others.

[The Extremist Was Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheExtremistWasRight): Convincing Commander Shepard to  (SPOILER) sabotage the genophage cure in order to secure krogan military aid under false pretenses is undeniably underhanded and vicious, but if Wreav is in charge and Eve isn't around to check him then her betrayal of the krogan ends up preventing or neutering the second Krogan Rebellions .

[Face Palm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FacePalm): Makes one when Victus threatens "And this will be the last friendly turian face you'll ever see!", before giving up the location of the cured krogan females.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): She refuses to believe that the krogan can be anything but brutish thugs. If Wreav is leading them, there's at least some reason for her to be worried, but keeping Wrex alive makes her attitude come off even worse. Eve makes Linron sound even *more* foolish.

[Hate Sink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HateSink): Except in one *very* specific circumstance, she just exists solely to be wrong and act as another example of a [space racist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism) oppressing the krogan.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite):
    - She preaches that Shepard is repeating the salarians' mistake of using the krogan to fight a war, ignoring the inevitable fallout that will follow an unchecked krogan population boom. (SPOILER) We then learn that the salarians are planning on secretly uplifting the *yahg*, a species even stronger, smarter, more brutal, and more vicious than the krogan. - There's also her quote from above - her veiled threats and disdainful approach towards the krogan paint her as a bigger bully than them, especially given how she's willing to let the krogan die which would then result in the deaths of millions of turians on Palaven and leave the turians unable to fight for Earth. All because of her [Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism). Also, calling a *Paragon* Shepard a "bully" is a hollow accusation.

[I Gave My Word](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IGaveMyWord): If Shepard  (SPOILER) takes her deal by sabotaging the genophage cure , Linron fully lives up to her promise of salarian assistance, and also  (SPOILER) provides falsified data proving that the cure was flawed from the get-go in case the krogan become suspicious.

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Hides the fact that she's holding the cured female krogan, constantly impedes the alliance peace talks, and ultimately  (SPOILER) asks Shepard to sabotage the genophage cure.  She never shows a second of remorse for anything that she's done.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): The source of Linron's behaviour is that she's worried that after the krogan help fight the Reapers, they'll then turn on the rest of the galaxy just like they did after helping to defeat the rachni. If Wrex is the leader, this worry turns out to be unfounded since Wrex is too smart to allow that to happen again (*especially* if Eve survives as well), and Linron comes off as prejudiced and closed-minded. But if *Wreav* is the leader (and *especially* if Eve *doesn't* survive), he threatens to get "payback" for the krogan the entire game. Guess what happens if the genophage is cured with Wreav as the leader?  (SPOILER) Wreav *gathers a humongous krogan army* just like he threatened he would.  In that scenario, Linron suddenly comes off as prescient.

[Laser-Guided Karma](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaserGuidedKarma): She claims that a bully is the last person to have friends when they really need one. If the genophage is cured, she finds herself abandoned by the salarian STG and military, who aid Shepard anyway.

[Moral Myopia](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralMyopia): An extremely [selfish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllAboutMe) case. In her mind she can pressure, threaten and guilt Shepard all she wants by holding promises of Salarian military aid over their head, but the *second* Shepard doesn't do what she wants they're a "bully" who won't have allies when they need them most.
[Obstructive Bureaucrat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObstructiveBureaucrat): She puts Udina and the Citadel council to shame in this category.

[Properly Paranoid](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ProperlyParanoid): If Wreav is the leader of the krogan,  (SPOILER) her fears of a new krogan rebellion are proven to be very wise since Wreav makes it clear he intends to build a new krogan empire after the Reaper war .
[Smug Smiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSmiler): She looks *way* too cheerful when informing Shepard about the sabotage than anyone has any right to.

[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): And how. She *clearly* thinks she's a [magnificent bitch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagnificentBastard), but by the end of Act I, (SPOILER) if the genophage is cured, everyone is tired of her crap and (SPOILER) if Kirrahe survives, the *entire STG* goes AWOL to fight Reaper forces despite the genophage being cured. In addition, if you manage to save the salarian Councillor's life literally during the mission right after Tuchanka, the Councillor pledges a salarian fleet to the war effort anyway.

[The Spock](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSpock): Compared to Wrex/Wreav's [The McCoy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMcCoy), and Victus and Paragon Shepard's Kirk. Not that they necessarily take her opinion seriously.
[The Atoner](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheAtoner): He helps Eve in order to make amends for a career of interfering with the natural order.

[Brain Bleach](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainBleach): Inflicts this upon Shepard and [himself.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dr9k2ywHWL4) The picture you see is his reaction when pondering exactly how Krogans breed (though Eve simply gives the answer of "Very clumsily").
[Bunny-Ears Lawyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BunnyEarsLawyer): "It's the odd ones - the mutations - who move life forward."
[Call to Agriculture](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallToAgriculture):  (SPOILER)  If he decides not to cure the Genophage.

[Crisis of Faith](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrisisOfFaith): Due to the [nature of his work.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DirtyBusiness)
QUOTE "We all fracture in different ways. Mordin's conscience haunted him. Maelon crossed the line into barbaric experiments. And myself... I went searching for whatever gods created the rules for this unfortunate universe."

[Demoted to Extra](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemotedToExtra): If he's not taking Mordin's place, his presence in the story is *wildly* reduced, even to the point of losing 80% of conversation options during your single remaining interaction with him.

[Face Death with Dignity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceDeathWithDignity):  (SPOILER) After fixing the sabotage and allowing the dispersal of the genophage cure, he crosses his arms behind his back, stands tall and waits for death. Unlike Mordin, he doesn't even glance at the exit behind him.
[For Science!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForScience): Why he wants to know how krogan mate.
[Go Out with a Smile](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoOutWithASmile):  (SPOILER)  Dies with pride as he cures the genophage and restores the future of the krogan.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):
    - (SPOILER) He goes out the same way as Mordin . - (SPOILER) You can even prevent the heroic sacrifice the same way as you would for Mordin, if Wreav is the Urdnot leader and Eve is dead. You can then "Charm" or "Intimidate" Padok into realizing a cure isn't the best idea for now. However, unlike Mordin, if you save Padok he does *not* become a War Asset; he retires to a farm so he can take the secret of the genophage with him to his grave.

[Leaning on the Fourth Wall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LeaningOnTheFourthWall): His spiel about how all of our actions are being recorded for eternity "somewhere in the deep fabric of the universe" sounds a lot like describing how the game works.

[The Mole](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMole): If Mordin died in the suicide mission, he lets the krogan know about the females the STG recovered. It cost him a lot of friends on Sur'Kesh, but it was the right thing to do.

tropeName: My Species Doth Protest Too Much
tropeNotes: [My Species Doth Protest Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MySpeciesDothProtestTooMuch): Padok is even more enthusiastic about curing the genophage than Mordin is, since Mordin is mostly doing it to atone for having modified the genophage previously. But in Padok's case, Padok thinks salarian arrogance didn't begin with the genophage, it began with *uplifting the krogan in the first place*, since that interfered with natural krogan evolution. Padok is far more critical of his own species than Mordin is due to Padok's own experience in "uplifting"; Mordin was mainly critical of himself and of the dalatrass.

[Odd Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OddFriendship): If Padok had any doubts about the cure, meeting Eve erased them completely.
QUOTE **Shepard:** Padok! This is a one way trip! 
**Padok:** And has been since the day I met Eve.

[Suspiciously Similar Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySimilarSubstitute): Joker takes to calling him "[not-Mordin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuckSessor)" until  (SPOILER) he sacrifices himself , but talking to him reveals that he's more spiritual (and detests Gilbert & Sullivan). He's also slightly less violent than Mordin: in the Sur'Kesh mission, when a staff member refuses to release the "Eve" specimen due to protocol against doing so during emergency lockdown, Mordin decides to electrically shock the staff member into releasing the krogan, while Padok accomplishes the same thing merely by informing the staff member at gunpoint that "...the protocol has changed!".

[Vitriolic Best Buds](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VitriolicBestBuds): Padok and Mordin used to be colleagues but had severe disagreements about the nature of evolution. Specifically, Padok thought evolution must have had a design in mind, while Mordin insisted that evolution occurred because of random mutation. In a drunken moment Padok punched Mordin in the face, breaking his fingers and giving Mordin a black eye. That's the "Vitriolic" part. The "Best Buds" part is because even after the punch, since they both suffered equal pain they both decided to "call it even" and go right back to drinking.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero):  (SPOILER) If Shepard chooses not to tell Wrex/Wreav and Eve about the cure being sabotaged, then just like Mordin, Padok will intelligently figure it out and call Shepard on it. Padok adds another wrinkle, though: he's convinced that somewhere in the universe our actions are recorded for eternity, and the decision Shepard makes will be no different.

[Wide-Eyed Idealist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WideEyedIdealist): Is utterly convinced that the krogan will prosper and be peaceful after the genophage is cured and will have a role to play sometime in the future. Judging by the images in the Extended Cut, provided that Wrex is alive, he has a point.
[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): Toward krogan. He thinks trying to save any of them is a waste of time.
[Handshake Refusal](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HandshakeRefusal): Shepard tries to shake his hand, but he doesn't return it, the first indicator of his general jerkiness.

[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): He's just there to be rude and awful, not even showing basic niceties, and to counterpoint Kirrahe, showing players they screwed up by not saving him on Virmire. Garrus even dryly notes he'd probably fit right in with the Reapers.
[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint): If Wreav is the krogan leader, EDI will admit that as unpleasant as Tolan is, Wreav isn't disproving his point.

[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): Seriously wanted to just kill the krogan females. The sick, dying, non-combatant krogan females who'd been experimented on by a salarian scientist. The only reason he didn't was orders from higher up the food chain.

[Uncertain Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UncertainDoom): Unlike Kirrahe, when the facility is attacked, he isn't seen fighting off Cerberus troops later, making it likely that, since he's not as capable as the major, he got taken out.

[Video Game Cruelty Punishment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VideoGameCrueltyPunishment): He *is* the punishment. Didn't save Kirrahe? You've got this guy instead. And you don't get covert STG support either. Enjoy.

[Action Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionSurvivor): He spent three days holed up in the Westminster clock tower while Reapers were landing around him, sniping at any husk that moved. He survived that, and in most endings manages to survive the entire Reaper invasion of Earth.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Particularly in the trailer, where inbetween scopin'-and-dropin' husks from Big Ben, he's half-complaining that Shepard hasn't shown up with [The Cavalry](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCavalry) yet.
[Friendly Sniper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendlySniper): Very friendly with Shepard in what little interactions they have. He spent three days in Big Ben sniping husks left and right.
[Majorly Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MajorlyAwesome): A major in the Alliance.
[Sniper Rifle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SniperRifle): His preferred weapon. Specifically, an M-29 Incisor in the trailer.
[Undying Loyalty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UndyingLoyalty): Appears to have this to Anderson, claiming he's the only reason *anyone* on Earth is still alive.
[Crouching Moron, Hidden Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrouchingMoronHiddenBadass): He earns the respect of his troops the hard way:  (SPOILER) Posthumously.

[Dare to Be Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DareToBeBadass): How Shepard can inspire him to gain the loyalty of his troops, reminding him that they are *turian*, they swore an oath of service and should be willing to give their lives to secure the mission's success. They do not just get to *quit*. [And it works.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RousingSpeech)
[Deader than Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeaderThanDead):  (SPOILER) No way he survived the explosion, even if he managed to dodge getting crushed by that machine.
[Dying Moment of Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DyingMomentOfAwesome):  (SPOILER) Dies disabling the bomb on Tuchanka , redeeming himself in the eyes of his people.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): He's a gender-flipped, turian one to Liara: both are the only children of high ranking, well respected figures amongst their species (Adrien Victus and Benezia) and as a result, both are expected to live up to the legacy of their parents.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):  (SPOILER) Falls to his death to make sure the bomb gets disabled .

[It's All My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllMyFault): He decided to play it safe and take a less dangerous route to safeguard his men, only for it to go *horribly* wrong when they flew into an ambush, leading to the death of most of his squad.

[Nepotism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Nepotism): Garrus speculates he got his rank on account of his father's position in the turian military (A practice that is *deeply* frowned upon in turian culture). Garrus is right, but for the wrong reasons. Primarch Victus had him in charge because he was the only one the Primarch could trust with the secret mission that could result in a war between the krogan and turians if the former ever found out about it.

[Redemption Equals Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedemptionEqualsDeath):  (SPOILER) At least in turian eyes, he needed redemption. And by the spirits, he got it — maybe. Garrus notes that turians are "hard to please."

["Shaggy Dog" Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShaggyDogStory): If the player holds off following up his quest.  (SPOILER) Tarquin and his squad fail to reach the bomb in time, and it goes off, wiping out a massive chunk of the civilian krogan population.

["Well Done, Son" Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellDoneSonGuy): Garrus invokes this about Tarquin, stating that great things are expected of him because he's the son of a respected war hero and comes from a long and prestigious military family.

[Ambadassador](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Ambadassador): Approaches it from the opposite direction of most examples; Bau is the official unofficial representative of the Spectres to the Council and the galaxy as a whole, so he becomes involved in politics and managing PR far more often than many of the others.
[Blood from the Mouth](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodFromTheMouth):  (SPOILER) Happens to him if you don't have Kasumi and didn't use the Renegade interrupt .

[Cutscene Incompetence](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutsceneIncompetence): Apparently salarians become utterly paralyzed if you get them in a chokehold, because that's all it took for  (SPOILER)  Zymandis'  goon to stop him, a *highly trained* Spectre agent. Shepard has to punch the guard to get him out of it. It is sort of justified considering salarian physiology. Salarians have mostly cartilage, which makes it hard for one to get out of a chokehold or win a wrestling match, which is why they move in a catlike fashion when fighting. Bau was also distracted at the time with the virus.
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Although it's only [apparent](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6qRZ0ZluAf4&t=4m24s) if Kasumi is not present.

[Failed a Spot Check](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailedASpotCheck): Doesn't notice a cloaked Kasumi hanging around near him waiting for Shepard to show up. (SPOILER) Also completely misses the fact that Zymandis/Regards The Works Of The Enkindlers With Despair had a guard.
    - This also appears when (SPOILER) he doesn't even *check* to see if Kasumi is really dead. The blast throws her back, she becomes invisible and that's it. He doesn't even bother to wait for her invisibility cloak to power down to confirm her death or touch the floor where she fell to locate her body. Possibly justified in that he might figure that if she's dead, then she died a hero; if she survived, then she's still a hero this time around, and he can simply let her go this once without needing to actually say to Kasumi herself that he's doing it .

[Friend on the Force](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendOnTheForce): Jondum Bau lets Shepard know that unlike the Council, some of the Spectres *did* listen to their warnings about the Reapers and are ready to offer their help, as well as informing Shepard of some contacts in the STG who might be useful.

[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): Of great magnitude.  (SPOILER) If you don't have Kasumi and don't save him, he basically sacrifices his life to prevent the *extinction* of drell and hanar. If you do save him, the Citadel news report says that the Reapers totally annihilated Kahje's population.
[Hero of Another Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroOfAnotherStory): As a Spectre, he has plenty going on offscreen and an enduring rivalry with Kasumi.

[Inspector Javert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InspectorJavert): Tasked with hunting down Kasumi. He's been after her for years. Subverted in that he really [admires her](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent). Plus, the feeling's mutual.

[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER) If you don't have Kasumi, you have to choose between saving him or stopping the virus from disabling the hanar homeworld's defenses.

[Non-Action Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionGuy): More of a detective and technician than a straight-up fighter, though presumably he can use a gun well enough. Regardless, he's never seen in a firefight and he's nearly overpowered in hand to hand combat by a regular human thug, requiring Shepard's intervention to survive the encounter.

[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): Unlike the Council, he and his fellow Spectres have always taken Shepard's warnings of the Reaper threat seriously. He's also one of the few Spectres that Shepard meets that neither tries to betray or kill them.

[Worthy Opponent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorthyOpponent): He and Kasumi have this going. She's so good it's "almost salarian", apparently.
    - The feeling is mutual: Jondum Bau is so awesome, apparently, that Kasumi is convinced that the galaxy needs more men like him. He's such a worthy opponent that she doesn't even mind him trying to *arrest her*. "Well, nobody's perfect."

[Action Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionSurvivor): Of the *Mass Effect* novels. She only got relatively basic combat training, as she served in a non-combat role, but she ends up being thrown into several firefights where she holds her own. When she shows up in the games, she's first seen popping up from behind a desk and shooting an Assault Trooper in the face a couple times with a shotgun as he hacks open a door.

[Batter Up!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BatterUp): In *Ascension*, killed a batarian pirate by swinging a heavy rifle at his head like a bat (she even says the trope name before doing so). She ended up beating his head in so hard that the rifle broke.
[Canon Immigrant](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CanonImmigrant): Was a major character in the novels, before having a minor appearance in the third game.
[A Father to His Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen): She is devoted to protecting her students at Grissom Academy when Cerberus attacks.

[Friends with Benefits](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendsWithBenefits): In the *Citadel DLC*, it's revealed that while they've never gotten serious, the two have maintained a casual relationship over the years. She was apparently present when Anderson was answering questions for his biography, and she left her overnight bag in his bathroom.

tropeName: Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Hair of Gold, Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairOfGoldHeartOfGold): The books specifically mention her natural blonde hair, as such a feature is very rare in the future.

[Older Than They Look](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OlderThanTheyLook): She's 47 in *Mass Effect 3*, but she looks, at worst, in her early 30s, if not her late 20s. Though in the game's setting, humans last longer and age slower due to medical advances, making it justifiable.
[The One That Got Away](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheOneThatGotAway): Both Anderson and Sanders express a mutual desire to rekindle their former romance after the war is over.
[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): She knows how to deal with Jack as her commander. That says enough.
[Shotguns Are Just Better](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShotgunsAreJustBetter): She's seen wielding a Scimitar shotgun. In the books, she usually uses a pistol.

[Uncertain Doom](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UncertainDoom): If the player avoids doing the Grissom Academy mission, she and everyone else there is either captured (and then experimented on) or killed. It's never made clear which befalls her.
[Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionGirl): Being accepted into the N7 program automatically makes her one.
[The Captain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCaptain): Leads her own engineering team.

[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): She is fully prepared to [hold the fuel facility](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoldTheLine) against all hostiles, and while she is realistic about their odds, she is not daunted by them. Considering the amount of hell the Reapers have thrown at her team so far, she's more or less kept her squad together and the plant intact by *sheer willpower*, because she will be *damned* if it falls on her watch. This also applies to her squad by proxy.
[The Engineer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEngineer): A damned good one, too.
[The Faceless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFaceless): Due to the circumstances of her appearance, the player never sees her without her helmet.

[A Father to His Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFatherToHisMen): She cares about the soldiers under her command and has the unquestioned loyalty of her team, which is made all the more impressive considering it's a multi-species squad.  (SPOILER) She also sacrifices herself to save them if Shepard does not send someone to provide support.
[Hero of Another Story](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroOfAnotherStory): She's basically a [cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCameo) of one the multiplayer characters.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):  (SPOILER) Gives her life to save her squad if Shepard does not send a squad member to help them.
[Hold the Line](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoldTheLine): Word-for-word, even.  (SPOILER) She will die doing it without Shepard's help .
[The Men First](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheMenFirst): She is more concerned about her squad's safety than her own.

[Overranked Soldier](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OverrankedSoldier): She'd be this as a Marine even today, but the codex mentions that the Alliance's fictional ranking system places "Captain" as the highest rank below the general/admiral ranks, making it equivalent to a full colonel in the USMC today. She definitely shouldn't be leading a simple 4-man squad on the front lines.
[Training from Hell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrainingFromHell): She's an N7. 'Nuff said.
[Agent Mulder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AgentMulder): His actual job with the Alliance is to discover the truth behind [myths and legends.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AllMythsAreTrue)

[Collector of the Strange](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CollectorOfTheStrange): By the very nature of his job, he has a lot of unusual artifacts in his lab, including a piece of Sovereign, the living head of a husk and a skeleton of a plesiosaur.
[Cool Old Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolOldGuy): Has this vibe.

[Dramatically Missing the Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DramaticallyMissingThePoint): He invokes this trope in regards to the batarians who recovered the 'Leviathan of Dis' (the carcass of a Reaper found on the planet Jartar), noting that the batarians were so hasty to reverse-engineer from the Reaper ([regardless of the risks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TooDumbToLive)) that they never stopped to wonder about the little matter of [what killed it in the first place](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysABiggerFish).
[He Knows Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeKnowsTooMuch): Why the Leviathan had him killed.

[Ignored Expert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IgnoredExpert): He'd long-since uncovered numerous evidence that pointed to a race of [Precursor Killers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PrecursorKillers), but it was only after Shepard encountered the Prothean Beacon and the attack by Sovereign, that the Alliance brass began to take it seriously.
[We Hardly Knew Ye](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeHardlyKnewYe): He's on-screen for at most two minutes before he's killed off.

[When You Coming Home, Dad?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhenYouComingHomeDad): Ann describes him as being distant and extremely passionate about his work (According to her, he almost missed her high school graduation because he was out on a dig, and showed up at the ceremony still wearing his field gear). However, despite his [workaholic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Workaholic) tendencies, it's clear that he deeply cared about his daughter.
[Demonic Possession](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DemonicPossession): By Leviathan.

[Disappeared Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisappearedDad): A variation; her father was always in her life, and it's clear that Ann loved him, but she relates that he was absent for a lot of her childhood and that at times, she resented him for making her feel like an inconvenience growing up while he was focused on his work. He showed up to her graduation in a still-grimy archeological work outfit.
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER) Can happen if you don't save her in time .

[Omnidisciplinary Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OmnidisciplinaryScientist): Once she finishes with finding Leviathan  (SPOILER) assuming she lives through the experience , she goes to work on the Crucible. The first problem she tackles? Synchronization of the Crucible's energy bursts.
[Parting-Words Regret](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PartingWordsRegret): She laments that her last conversation with her father was an argument over something petty.
[Possession Burnout](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PossessionBurnout):  (SPOILER) If Shepard stops Vega from severing her connection to Leviathan, she dies from the strain.
[Ship Tease](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShipTease): Has some with Vega.

[Shout-Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShoutOut): From *[The X-Files](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Series/TheXFiles)*: "The truth is out there." It was the show's myth-arc tag-line. Doesn't help that her dad is an [Agent Mulder](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AgentMulder).
[Take Up My Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeUpMySword):  (SPOILER) If recruited by Shepard to continue her father's research.
[Willing Channeler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WillingChanneler): Chooses to be possessed by Leviathan so that EDI can locate its whereabouts.
[Dead Person Impersonation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadPersonImpersonation):  (SPOILER) The man you meet is not Garneau, the real one has been dead for a week.
[He Knows Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeKnowsTooMuch):  (SPOILER)  Leviathan forces him to blow himself up with a grenade, taking out the artifact and some husks.
[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): Like Dr. Core, he runs and is impossible to catch up too.
[Voice of the Legion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoiceOfTheLegion):  (SPOILER) As does anyone under Leviathan's control
