[Badass Bookworm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBookworm): Her profile reveals that she's an N7 Demolisher Engineer. [Her handle is "De-Mel-Isher".](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IncrediblyLamePun)
[Bunny-Ears Lawyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BunnyEarsLawyer): She's pretty eccentric and crude, but she's not an N7 for nothing.
[Covert Pervert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CovertPervert): Completely and totally averted. She's very openly perverted.

[Crouching Moron, Hidden Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrouchingMoronHiddenBadass): Though she is a wild partier and extremely crass, interactions with her teammates in [Profiles in Courage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ViralMarketing) indicates that she is an [N7 Demolisher](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GeniusBruiser).

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Check out her reaction to her male friends being intimidated by her personality because she's a woman.
QUOTE "I'm a woman? Holy crap! I'm a woman! Where did these tits come from? Are they infiltrator tits? Could there be more of them hiding?"
[Elites Are More Glamorous](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElitesAreMoreGlamorous): She's an N7, considered an elite among elites.

[Extreme Omnisexual](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExtremeOmnisexual): She really likes [asari](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreenSkinnedSpaceBabe), especially ones who indulge her commando fetish. Adores all things raunchy, as long as there's a [hanar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StarfishAliens) hanging off of it. In [Profiles in](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ViralMarketing) [Courage](http://masseffect.wikia.com/wiki/Alliance_News_Network/Profiles_in_Courage) she gets a date with Thax, a *krogan warlord*.
[Hard-Drinking Party Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HardDrinkingPartyGirl): She wants to get smashed, then watch some good asari strippers dance.
[The Lad-ette](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLadette): She intends to find the raunchiest thing you can imagine and hang a [hanar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StarfishAliens) off it.
[One of the Boys](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneOfTheBoys): Seeks this honorific amongst her squadmates.
[Screw the War, We're Partying](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewTheWarWerePartying): She intends to cut loose on shore leave from fighting the Reapers. Really, *really* loose.
[Semper Fi](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SemperFi): A Marine. A dirty minded, [Hard-Drinking Party Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HardDrinkingPartyGirl) of a Marine, but a Marine nonetheless.

[Action Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActionSurvivor): She has no actual fighting ability (because it would be *damn stupid* to teach Ardat-Yakshi how to fight). She only survived the Reaper attack on the monastery by hiding.
[The Baby of the Bunch](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBabyOfTheBunch): The youngest of the three sisters, and generally the most vocal in her opinions.
[Brutal Honesty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrutalHonesty): When Samara announced her plan to become a Justicar, Falere did not mince words about how this would impact her and Rila.
[Calling the Old Man Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallingTheOldManOut): She was not happy when she learned that Samara planned to become a Justicar and told her so.

[Can't Have Sex, Ever](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantHaveSexEver): As an Ardat-Yakshi, and one of only three with the most severe form no less, Falere would kill anyone she melds with, and willingly isolated herself to avoid temptation.
[Disappeared Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisappearedDad): It is implied in *Lair of the Shadow Broker* that Falere's father died prior to her diagnosis.

[The Dutiful Daughter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDutifulSon): Unlike Morinth, Falere agreed to every legal restriction placed on Ardat-Yakshi and is clearly grateful when Samara expresses pride for this.
[Face Death with Dignity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceDeathWithDignity):  (SPOILER) If Shepard decides to kill her, she just calmly accepts it.

[The Fettered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFettered): As she points out to Samara, she's spent four hundred years in a monastery, but if she really, *really* wanted out, there wouldn't be much stopping her from trying. Judging by Morinth, there wouldn't be much stopping her from succeeding, either.

[Hot-Blooded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotBlooded): Falere seems to be the most outspoken of the three sisters and acknowledges that her lack of emotional control is the reason why she hasn't had the chance to reintegrate into asari society.

[I Choose to Stay](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IChooseToStay):  (SPOILER) At the end of the mission of Leuss, she can opt to stay with the remains of the monastery, especially since it will prevent any Justicar from trying to kill her.

[Locked Away in a Monastery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LockedAwayInAMonastery): Falere willingly submitted to monastic seclusion so she would not be tempted to meld with anyone. She has also not sought permission to reintegrate into asari society due to her lack of emotional control.

[Not Helping Your Case](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NotHelpingYourCase):  (SPOILER) If Samara doesn't make it, then Falere rages at Shepard for showing no regard for Rila's sacrifice, before calming down and admitting that while she isn't a danger, her lack of control is proving the justification for sending the commandos to the monastery right, and giving Shepard all the excuse they need to finish the job.

[Out with a Bang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutWithABang): Were Falere to meld with anyone, she would fatally hemorrhage her partner's brain, and has isolated herself to avoid doing so. Falere is one of only three Ardat-Yakshi with the most extreme form of their condition; the other two are her older sisters.
["Well Done, Son" Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellDoneSonGuy): She clearly yearns for Samara's approval and is visibly grateful when Samara expresses pride in Falere following the monastery's rules.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): If Samara is present on the Leuss mission, she's pissed at her and Shepard for only showing up to deal with the Reapers, not to help the monastery's occupants. She doesn't do this if Samara isn't present.
[Youngest Child Wins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YoungestChildWins): If Shepard allows it, Falere is the only one of her sisters to survive the Reaper War.
[Beware the Quiet Ones](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BewareTheQuietOnes): Rila is the most softspoken sister but resisted indoctrination and conversion into a Banshee for a remarkable length of time.

[Big Sister Instinct](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBrotherInstinct): In her last moments, Rila's main focus is to make sure her youngest sister can escape safely. She was even able to briefly resist indoctrination.
[Black Eyes of Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BlackEyesOfEvil): While under the effect of indoctrination, Rila's eyes go black.
[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): By the time Shepard visits the Monastery, Rila has been indoctrinated and begun conversion into a Banshee.
[Cannot Spit It Out](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CannotSpitItOut): In their last call with Samara, Falere believes that Rila wanted to say that she loves their mother but couldn't bring herself to.

[Can't Have Sex, Ever](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantHaveSexEver): Rila is an Ardat-Yakshi and posesses the most severe form of the condition, which would cause her to kill anyone she melds with. She has chosen isolation to prevent that.

[Defiant to the End](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefiantToTheEnd): Even when indoctrinated and undergoing transformation into a Banshee, Rila was able to resist and destroyed the Reapers' largest source of Banshees.
[Disappeared Dad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DisappearedDad): *Lair of the Shadow Broker* implies by mention of a memorial sphere that Rila's father died prior to her diagnosis.
[The Dutiful Daughter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDutifulSon): Unlike Morinth, Rila voluntarily submitted to the legal restrictions placed on Ardat-Yakshi.
[The Fettered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFettered): Same as her sister, but more so.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice): Rila sacrificed herself to destroy the largest collection of Banshees and prevent herself from becoming one.
[Heroic Willpower](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicWillpower): Rila is one of the incredibly few individuals to resist advanced indoctrination, enabling her to save her family and Shepard's squad.

[Icy Blue Eyes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IcyBlueEyes): Rila inherited Samara's incredibly bright blue eyes, helping to emphasize her position as [The Quiet One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheQuietOne) among her family.

[Locked Away in a Monastery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LockedAwayInAMonastery): Rila voluntary submitted to monastic seclusion so she would not be tempted to meld with anyone and has not sought reintegration into asari society.

[Out with a Bang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutWithABang): Anyone Rila melded with would suffer a fatal brain hemorrhage, so she has isolated herself to resist temptation. Rila is one of three Ardat-Yakshi to possess the most severe form of their condition, the other two being her sisters.
[The Quiet One](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheQuietOne): Unlike her sisters, Rila generally remains in the background and keeps her own feelings close to the vest.
[Taking You with Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakingYouWithMe): She was able to destroy the largest stock of Banshees by blowing herself up.

[Babies Ever After](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BabiesEverAfter): If Wrex is the leader, and the genophage is cured, then Wrex will let you know Eve is pregnant in an email and tell you about it during the final mission.

[Damsel out of Distress](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DamselOutOfDistress): She spends most of a mission locked in a pod, being escorted and protected by Shepard and co. But once she gets free, the first thing she does is yank a shotgun out of an ally's hands and blast two Cerberus troopers to kingdom come. She even wields it *one-handed*.
QUOTE **"Eve":** I can handle myself, Wrex./I'm not your property, Wreav. 
**Wrex:** ([Beat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Beat)) *Women*.

[Dead Guy Junior](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadGuyJunior): If she and Wrex have a child together, she decides to name it  (SPOILER) Mordin  after the doctor who made it possible. Wrex is less sold on the idea.

[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): Occasionally. One example if your Shepard referred to her as "too valuable" to lose earlier: QUOTE **Shepard:** Are you okay? **Eve:** Your "bargaining chip" is still alive.
    - Another incident is after Mordin sings to her, she says she really had to twist his arm to get him to sing.

[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): The trial for female krogan to become a Shaman involves being sealed in a cave with enough food to last them a week, leaving them to either dig themselves out or starve to death. Eve did so using a simple crystal as a chisel to dig her way out, which she gives to Shepard if they befriend her.
QUOTE  **"Eve":** Take it as a reminder, Commander, in the darkest hour, there is *always* a way out.

[Does Not Like Men](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DoesNotLikeMen): Krogan men. She has no problem with males of other species. Speak with her further, and she reveals that her dislike is more out of frustration than hatred, and admits that, with the Genophage, there is little else for them to do other than shoot someone over a petty grudge. She wishes that they could be more.

[Driven to Suicide](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DrivenToSuicide): Discussed: Eve admits that she was left suicidal after her first stillborn, and states that while she overcame it, plenty of her fellow female krogan have killed themselves because they couldn't cope with the grief caused by being unable to carry infants to full term.
QUOTE **Shepard**: If you don't mind me asking, what is it like, living with the genophage? 
**"Eve":** I knew sisters who could not bear the shame of being infertile. They would wander off into the wastelands, hoping a thresher maw would kill them and end their torment. 
**Shepard**: Did the thought ever cross your mind? 
**"Eve":** Yes.
[The Faceless](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFaceless): About the only part of her you really see are her eyes. The rest is covered up by the robe she wears.
[Firing One-Handed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FiringOneHanded): With a shotgun. Given that she's a krogan, she's got the size to support it.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): She's contemplative, philosophical and damn near *poetic*, with no illusions about why krogan hold the status (or lack thereof) they do in the galaxy. For a [Living Macguffin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingMacguffin), she's one of the most insightful characters in the series.
[The High Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheHighQueen): Basically takes this role, as by far the most powerful and influential female krogan on Tuchanka.

[Hooked Up Afterwards](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HookedUpAfterwards): Implied to have done so with Wrex, who mentions she's pregnant by the time you take back Earth. Wrex jokes that it's one of [the perks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FriendsWithBenefits) of his being clan chief, even if she does want to name the firstborn child after Mordin.
[Incurable Cough of Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IncurableCoughOfDeath): Depending on the choice you made regarding Maelon's data. If she's coughing, she's screwed no matter what you do.

[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER) If Maelon's data was not saved in *Mass Effect 2*, she will die, and if you don't stop the turian bomb, she'll die in the resulting explosion.
[Lady of War](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyOfWar): If Wreav is the Urdnot leader and the genophage is cured, a healthy "Eve" will command her *own* army to face off against Wreav. Bad. Ass.

[Like an Old Married Couple](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LikeAnOldMarriedCouple): Her above interaction with Wrex has this vibe.  (SPOILER) There are subtle hints that Wrex and Bakara are/were married, and separated over a disagreement.

[Living MacGuffin](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LivingMacGuffin): She is the only  (SPOILER) test subject of Maelon's to survive, the only krogan to ever be cured of the genophage and live. This makes her insanely valuable, as a cure can be synthesized based on her new-found immunity — which makes her a target for Cerberus, who don't want the krogan to join the battle against the Reapers.
[Lysistrata Gambit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LysistrataGambit): This is what she plans for Wreav after the genophage is cured.

[Meaningful Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MeaningfulName): Invoked; because she did not share her true name, Mordin chose to call her "Eve", as he believes that human mythology would be appropriate, considering that she's currently on a human vessel.

tropeName: Men Use Violence, Women Use Communication
tropeNotes:
[Men Use Violence, Women Use Communication](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MenUseViolenceWomenUseCommunication): Prevalent throughout her story arc, where she's easily the most pacifistic krogan and most sharply critical of her own species too. Wrex lampshades this. Also subverted in that, as Wrex adds, they still *do* have a temper.
    - Discusses this with Female Shepard, noting she's glad to see that humans treat their women with the respect and honor they deserve.

[Morality Chain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoralityChain): If Wrex is krogan leader, he only needs a bit of prodding from her. If Wreav is leader, most of the cast agree she's the only thing keeping him from repeating history.  (SPOILER) If she dies, leaving Wreav unchecked, you can convince Mordin/Padok to sabotage the genophage cure for the sake of galactic stability .

tropeName: My Species Doth Protest Too Much
tropeNotes: [My Species Doth Protest Too Much](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MySpeciesDothProtestTooMuch): She believes that while the genophage was an atrocity, the fact that the krogan had already nuked their own planet prior to the Rebellions, and that in its wake, they turned from a once-proud race to a raving band of mercenaries who resort to petty thuggery and barbarism to solve problems and claim 'honor', means she can see *why* it was done.

[Odd Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OddFriendship): With Mordin, and Shepard if you're kind to her. She even says she wants to name her first born child after Mordin, (SPOILER) in memory of his sacrifice.
    - If Mordin died in the Omega-4 Relay and was replaced by Padok Wiks, she develops an odd friendship with him, too. She even tells Padok how krogan get their names, although she might be joking, we can't be sure: (SPOILER) apparently the adult krogan drink a special kind of juice and start belching, and the first belch that actually sounds like a name is then attached to the baby krogan. When Padok asks for clarification, she confirms that yes, indeed, Wrex/Wreav was also a belch and it's not a good idea to tell them that.

[Only Known by Their Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OnlyKnownByTheirNickname): She's the female clan's shaman; like the Urdnot shaman who oversaw Grunt's rite, she explains that she gave up her name the day she took the title. The *Normandy* team takes to calling her Eve.
    - However, complete the Tuchanka arc (by doing all missions, keeping her alive, and releasing the cure) and Eve will deem Shepard a friend worthy of knowing her true name: (SPOILER) Urdnot Bakara .

[Radish Cure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RadishCure): "Eve" likes Wrex, but does think he's [a bit too horny for his own good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChivalrousPervert). If everything goes well, how does she deal with it?  (SPOILER)  She *encourages* all the excited lady krogan who want the great hero of their race to father their first new batch of children once the Genophage is cured, until, by the *Citadel* DLC, poor Wrex is applying ice-packs to his sore and aching quad and sneaking out of his own house through the bathroom just to escape them.
[Reasonable Authority Figure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ReasonableAuthorityFigure): By far the most reasonable krogan in the series, and one of the best in the whole series. Even moreso than Wrex.

[Red Oni, Blue Oni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedOniBlueOni): Although Wrex is very Blue compared to the typical krogan, he is still Red to Eve. Mordin considers her to be a good moderating influence on Wrex.

[Rousing Speech](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RousingSpeech): Very capable of making these. It's actually quite fascinating and inspiring listening to her dialogue.
QUOTE **Eve:** [ENOUGH!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BattleInterruptingShout) [You can stay here and let old wounds fester as krogan have always done...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheReasonYouSuckSpeech) [or you can fight the enemy you were born to destroy, and win a new future for our children!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StopBeingStereotypical) *I* choose to fight. [Who will join me?!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DareToBeBadass)
[Sole Survivor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SoleSurvivor): Out of all the test subjects, she is the only one who survived the process.

[Stop Being Stereotypical](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StopBeingStereotypical): She will deliver a speech of this theme to her people on  (SPOILER) Tuchanka before the krogan armies hit the Shroud , telling them that their picking fights with each other over petty grudges is doing them no favours with anyone.

[Tsundere](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Tsundere): Toward Wrex. The "tsun" part is that Eve thinks Wrex is too arrogant and big-headed for his own good, and Wrex is a "mutant" to boot. The "dere" part is that Eve also thinks Wrex being a "mutant" is a *good* thing: she thinks Wrex is "the best thing to ever happen to the krogan." But don't tell Wrex she said that (you can tell Wrex that she called him a "mutant", though).

[Women Are Wiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WomenAreWiser): Garrus lampshaded that female Krogan are the species' true brain. Liara even compared Eve with an *asari matriarch*.  <sup>note </sup>  Asari matriarchs are considered by many, including Shepard, as the most powerful and intelligent people in the galaxy, but krogan are the only race with comparable lifespans so as one of the older and wiser of her race she might not be far off the mark.
[Asskicking Leads to Leadership](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership): How he became the leader of Aralakh Company.
[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): Enough that he assumes Shepard's one as well. In fact, he's *jealous* that Shepard has Reapers personally looking out for their death.

[Enemies Equals Greatness](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemiesEqualsGreatness): Like most krogan, a firm believer in this. This is why he has so much respect for Shepard, despite the fact that they are a soft human. Anyone who has enemies as powerful as the Reapers has earned it without question.

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): When you can personally overlook a fight between the krogan and rachni, you'll notice that Dagg has a harder time fighting them than Grunt would. This is the clue that  (SPOILER) he won't survive the mission.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):  (SPOILER) Held off the Ravagers to keep them off Shepard.
[Impaled with Extreme Prejudice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpaledWithExtremePrejudice):  (SPOILER) Gets repeatedly stabbed by Ravagers as he dies.

[In Love with Your Carnage](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InLoveWithYourCarnage): Knowing Shepard's reputation and the enemies that they have made, he is very enthusiastic about fighting alongside them, and is even a little jealous of that reputation.
[In the Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InTheBack):  (SPOILER) How he dies as unlike Grunt, he gets immediately overwhelmed.
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER) His death is unavoidable.

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): For a [Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight). Compare with Wreav who treats Shepard with a grudging respect at best, whereas Dagg is clearly eager for a chance to fight alongside Shepard. He's even politer towards Shepard than Grunt is.
[Suspiciously Similar Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySimilarSubstitute): More or less, for Grunt.

[Fantastic Racism](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FantasticRacism): He's still bitter about the genophage, so he immediately objects to Padok or Mordin (whichever goes with you) accompanying Shepard once he sees them. He even (subtly) called his boss a dumbass for trusting salarians, even though Padok and Mordin are working to *cure* the genophage.
[Hair-Trigger Temper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HairTriggerTemper): He was *this* close to shooting *his own boss* before Eve forced him not to.
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER) He's sucked beneath the earth in his Tomkah by Kalros, the same way Wreav would've if Wrex was in charge.
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Dude's pretty damn unpleasant.
[Smug Super](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSuper): He thinks his clan has more "wisdom" and "experience" than Clan Urdnot, even though Urdnot is the one in charge.

[Stupid Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StupidEvil): For all of Wreav's many flaws, he at least has the [rationality](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PragmaticVillainy) to set aside the grudges he plans to avenge until the giant metal squid monsters are all gone. Thurak doesn't even have that going for him.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes: [Always a Bigger Fish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysABiggerFish): The first two games make us believe that the Krogan are Tuchanka's bigger fish. Mass Effect 3 introduce Kalros and show us who's really the ultimate fish on the planet.  (SPOILER) She proves this to the Reaper Destroyer when Shepard summons her to 'distract' it.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes: [Brick Joke](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrickJoke): Kalros is a living example. An early Codex entry mentions that one way to take out Reapers is to execute a precision lightspeed jump behind them and attack from the rear, since their sheer size means they can't turn around quickly without lowering their mass to an extent which leaves them highly vulnerable.  (SPOILER) This is exactly how Kalros takes out the Destroyer on Tuchanka after an initial head-on assault fails.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes: [Cool Versus Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolVersusAwesome): She fights a freaking *[Reaper](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination)*.  (SPOILER) And *wins*.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes: [Curb-Stomp Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbStompBattle): When she enters the fray,  (SPOILER)  it’s the Reaper that finds itself horrendously outmatched, and although it manages to fend her off momentarily, she just blindsides it, wrestles it to the ground with ease, and by then it’s all over for the Reaper.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeName: Did You Just Punch Out Cthulhu?
tropeNotes: [Did You Just Punch Out Cthulhu?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidYouJustPunchOutCthulhu):  (SPOILER) Yes she did.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes:
[The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded): Even *[krogan](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight)* try to stay out of her way. Garrus puts it best:
QUOTE  **Garrus:** When the krogan name a thresher maw, you know you're in trouble. They don't think *anyone's* going to kill it.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes:
[Gaia's Vengeance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GaiasVengeance): Wrex invokes this.
QUOTE  **Wrex:** If [Tuchanka](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeathWorld) has a temper, Kalros is it.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes:
[Kaiju](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Kaiju): It's simply *enormous*. The surfaced part of its body alone towers over the Reaper Destroyer, putting that section of its body at about 200 meters long. Most of it is still underground!
    - Kalros is a kaiju even by Thresher Maws' standards. A Thresher Maw can grow in excess of 30 meters above the ground, with a body nearly twice that size beneath the surface, note  That's nearly 100 meters long. meaning that Kalros' surfaced part alone is over *twice* of a common Thresher Maw's *full length*.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes: [Let's You and Him Fight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LetsYouAndHimFight): Let's sic the mother of all thresher maws on a Reaper.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes: [Monster Progenitor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MonsterProgenitor)/[Mother of a Thousand Young](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MotherOfAThousandYoung): She's said to be the mother from whom all thresher maws spawn. This is probably an exaggeration. We think <sup>note </sup>   Thresher Maws start off as spores, then transfer from planet to planet via starships . It may be true for all the ones on Tuchanka though; the place is apparently crawling with them.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes: [Nominal Importance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NominalImportance): The sole [aversion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Aversion) among the Thresher Maws. See [The Dreaded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDreaded) above.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes: [Really 700 Years Old](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Really700YearsOld): Kalros is very old. For instance, the Shroud was built by the salarians during the Rachni Wars, 2000 years before the first game, in an arena dedicated to Kalros' glory, and we see a picture of Kalros in the ruins of a city called The City of the *Ancients* <sup>note </sup>   The name indicates that the city is one of the oldest, if not the oldest, of the krogan cities . Both places are built before the Krogan nuked Tuchanka 4000 years ago, meaning that Kalros had been around for at least that long.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes: [Sand Worm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SandWorm): The biggest one we've ever seen.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes: [Summon Bigger Fish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonBiggerFish): Eve's response to finding a Reaper on Tuchanka? Suggest that Shepard summon [all the fury of the planet Tuchanka in the form of a gargantuan acid-spewing sand worm](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GaiasVengeance) to [deal with it](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolVersusAwesome).  (SPOILER)  The best part? It works.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes:
[Super-Persistent Predator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuperPersistentPredator): Acording to Mordin, Kalros seems too much fixated in chasing the vehicle he, Eve and  (SPOILER)  Wrex/Wreav  are driving to his own liking.
QUOTE **Mordin:** Hurry Shepard, Kalros is a step too persistent.

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes: [We Need a Distraction](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WeNeedADistraction): The entire reason Kalros was summoned was just to distract the Reaper so that Mordin/Padok could get to the tower. Judging by the reactions afterwards, it's implied that nobody expected Kalros to *win.*'

VGDCName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
TvTName: Kalros, Mother of All Thresher Maws
tropeNotes: [World's Strongest Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WorldsStrongestMan): Kalros is undeniably the most powerful creature on Tuchanka by a gigantic margin. She's one of *very few* entities in the entire franchise capable of fighting a Reaper one on one  (SPOILER) and not just win but [Curbstomp](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CurbstompBattle) it.

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): When Tali pleads the Geth V.I. not upload the code, it replies:
QUOTE **Geth V.I.:** Your people began this war. *We will end it.*
[Catchphrase](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CatchPhrase): "We are not Legion." Late in the game, Shepard can encouragingly reply, "You are *today*."

[Defrosting Ice Queen](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefrostingIceQueen): If you side with the geth against the quarians, the Geth V.I. will finally admit that the geth's suspicions of other organics, and by extension Shepard, were misplaced.
[Heroic Sacrifice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeroicSacrifice):  (SPOILER) To finish the upload of the Reaper code to the rest of the geth.
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): The thing is a lot ruder and colder than Legion.

[Jerkass Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkassHasAPoint):  (SPOILER) If Legion is dead and this thing has replaced it, you can't achieve peace between the geth and quarians, so you're forced to wipe out one or the other. If you choose to wipe out the geth to save the quarians, then the VI will angrily remark (while trying to throttle you) that the geth were *right* to distrust organics.   He also responds to Tali's begging to not upload the code with a harsher — but correct — retort: "Your people *began* this war. *We will end it.*"
[Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal):  (SPOILER) Its death can't be avoided.

[Sheep in Sheep's Clothing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SheepInSheepsClothing): If Legion was handed over to Cerberus, then no-one on the *Normandy* trusts this weird, speaking geth they've met. While it's blunter than Legion, and not as trusting of organics, in the end it is still on Shepard's side, the irreconciliable antagonism towards the Quarians notwithstanding.

[Suspiciously Similar Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySimilarSubstitute): Legion's. Depending on your playthrough, it's implied it's the same platform (returned to the Perseus Veil) but different software (or possibly the backup of what was sent) uploaded into it. Then again, it is pretty different in some very important ways, since there can't be any peace when it is present.

[What the Hell, Hero?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhatTheHellHero): Mildly, if on the receiving end of Shepard's when they ask when both sides are going to trust one another, the VI's response is quite straightforward: When the quarians aren't trying to wipe out its entire species.

[Butt-Monkey](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButtMonkey): "I always get the crap details."
    - [Call-Back](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CallBack): QUOTE **Shepard:** You always get these crap details, Bray? **Bray:** *(chuckles)* Heh. Not this time. You've got a galaxy to save. Let's get you off this rock.
[Deadpan Snarker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeadpanSnarker): How he copes with his crap details.
[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): To Aria, from the look of it.

[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): Easily the friendliest, most laid-back batarian you'll ever meet. He even gets along well with Shepard, who blew up an entire batarian system and potentially had some bad blood between them and the batarians already during the Battle of Torfan if given the Ruthless service record.
QUOTE "Just remember that there's at least one batarian in the galaxy who doesn't want you dead."
[Punch-Clock Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunchClockVillain): Like most of Omega's lawless citizens involved with Aria.
[Suspiciously Similar Substitute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SuspiciouslySimilarSubstitute): To Anto, who died between the second and the third game.
[The Cracker](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCracker): What Aria pays him to do.
[The Evil Genius](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheEvilGenius): Of Aria's command staff, hacking into Omega's systems to aid her and running the logistics parts of the operation.
[Mission Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MissionControl): Alerts Aria's forces to battle updates and helps guide Shepard and Aria through their missions.

[Big Damn Heroes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigDamnHeroes): When heading to rendezvous with an Alliance force after taking back Omega, Jarral was warned to stay away when the human forces came under heavy attack by the Reapers. Instead, she led the fleet in rescuing them and has since earned a reputation for diving straight into battle.

[Blood Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BloodKnight): Her description in the war fleet's asset entry describes her as "cheerfully ruthless" and she has no problem charging her fleet straight into heavy combat.
[The Brute](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBrute): Serves as commander of Aria's fleet and her main tactics seem to be attack head on until the enemy dies, which proves surprisingly effective.
[The Captain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCaptain): Commands *Fusion*, the flagship of Aria's fleet.
[Asskicking Leads to Leadership](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership): As an asari commando who founded the organization.

[Ax-Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AxCrazy): Very much so, as shown in *3*. According to Commander Bailey, time in jail has only made her even *worse*.
QUOTE **Bailey**: She was a ruthless sadist before she got caught. Imprisonment has only cracked the nut off the shell.
[Dark Action Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DarkActionGirl): As a former asari commando.
[Enemy Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine): Very, *very* reluctantly with Shepard.

[Eviler than Thou](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilerThanThou): Aria knows that she's insane.
QUOTE  **Aria**: (via mail) Sederis is one crazy bitch. Fortunately, she's our crazy bitch.

tropeName: Screw the Rules, I Have Connections!
tropeNotes: [Screw the Rules, I Have Connections!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ScrewTheRulesIHaveConnections): Even the Asari councilor (under Aria's instruction) is pressing for her release. She thinks Shepard's under her thumb, too.

[Smug Snake](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSnake): She openly threatens Shepard via vid-screen, convinced their only option is to release her and that Sayn doesn't have the guts to defy her. In reality, it costs you absolutely nothing to leave her in jail or have her killed; there's only one disadvantage — that Shepard has to do a little more running about, which is an inconvenience at worst.
[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): To Jona.  (SPOILER) Though he can take over at Shepard's persuasion.
[Enemy Mine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemyMine): As with all of the other mercenary bosses, he and Jona form one with Shepard.

[Extreme Doormat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExtremeDoormat): If anything that both Aria and Jona say are any indication, then Sayn is indeed a "weak-willed toady". Aria doesn't mind - she *likes* having an easily-controlled puppet.
[Glad You Thought of It](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GladYouThoughtOfIt): A Renegade Shepard who doesn't want a loose cannon like Sederis can get him to "suggest" killing her and taking over.
[Punny Name](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PunnyName): Describe her boss if you don't get it.
[The Starscream](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStarscream): Shepard can talk him into taking over Eclipse from Jona.

[Abusive Precursors](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AbusivePrecursors): They claim to be (and most likely are) the first and most powerful organic species ever to evolve in the Milky Way. That and their prodigious mind control abilities went to their head and led to them enthralling countless civilizations and entire "lesser" species all across the galaxy, demanding tribute and worship while giving nothing in return. The Leviathan Shep talks to mentions that those species were "cared for", but only because tribute does not flow from a dead race, and it doesn't go into detail how exactly their alleged care looked like. Well, and then they got this [brilliant idea](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SarcasmMode) of creating the Catalyst to stop their servants from wiping themselves out, something that turned into the most horrible backfire in galactic history by giving rise to the Reapers. So, the whole mess the galaxy's currently in (and has been for at least one billion years, costing lives beyond counting) is essentially the result of their overblown god complex.

[A God Am I](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AGodAmI): They don't outright call themselves such, but the signs are clearly there, considering how they view all other species as nothing but tools, demand tribute and worship, alledgedly "bent the galaxy to their every will" and even created their own version of the Devil that eventually and royally kicked their asses. On the other hand, they really are *immensely* powerful, even in their current state and with their species reduced to a handful of survivors hiding out in remote corners of the galaxy.

[Always a Bigger Fish](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AlwaysABiggerFish): When they decide it's Reaper-killing time, they take down one of them and a small band of husks in a single attack. While not moving from the oceanic trench where they hide.

[Badass Boast](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassBoast): While almost all their lines reflect how powerful they are, they let out this gem after Shepard convinces them to take the fight to the Reapers:
QUOTE **Leviathan**: We were the first, the apex race. We will survive. And the Reapers who trespass on this world will understand our power. They will become our slaves. **Today, they pay their tribute in blood!**

[Continuity Nod](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContinuityNod): For the Leviathan of Dis, an "organic spacecraft" that crashed in batarian space and whose existence is fiercely denied by the Hegemony. It turns out that the Leviathan was a crashed Reaper... And guess who shot it down?

[Didn't See That Coming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntSeeThatComing): As a species, they seem to have this as a recurring problem. Their "solution" to organic life being wiped out by synthetics? [Produced the Reapers.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoneHorriblyWrong) Leave their relics in the galaxy to Enthrall servants? That just leaves a trail that eventually leads right towards them. They try to control Shepard to act as their servant after they're found? *Doesn't work.* There's even a potential future one in their ambitions to reconquer the galaxy: Now the galaxy knows they exist, knows where they are and *knows how their most powerful ability works.*
[Eldritch Abomination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EldritchAbomination): They look like organic Reapers and have the same powers and size as them. This is not a coincidence.

[Evil Sounds Deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSoundsDeep): They have an *extremely* deep voice similar to the Reapers', and although they're not actively malicious, they consider all races but their own as nothing more than tools to serve their needs and worship them while they're at it. The first thing they do when Shep pays them a visit is try to make them their thrall despite of their knowledge that they're an anomaly and probably the first and only chance to stop the cycle of extinction forever.

[Foil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foil): The Thorian seems to be the plant-life version of the race, with the same arrogance, lifespan and mind control abilities. The only difference is that the Leviathans have the ability to reach beyond their home, while the Thorian is, well, a plant.

[Hidden Elf Village](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenElfVillage): Their hideout is at the bottom of an oceanic trench on a planet with no natural resources and covered in oceans, in a remote solar system.

[Hoist by Their Own Petard](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HoistByTheirOwnPetard): They created the Catalyst to find a solution to the warring between organics and synthetics. They didn't expect the Catalyst to decide *they* were part of the problem. The Leviathans admit that the Catalyst wasn't wrong.

[It's All About Me](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ItsAllAboutMe): They consider themselves the apex of all organic life in the galaxy and couldn't care less about the "lesser" species - as long as the latter pay tribute to them, of course. Everything they do, even their reluctant entry into the Reaper War, they do for nothing but their own gain.

[Kaiju](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Kaiju): These things are *enormous* even for marine creatures, measuring several hundred meters in length. Aside from the Reapers themselves, only [Kalros](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SandWorm), Tuchanka's titanic Reaper-crushing guard worm, could hold a candle to them due to the Leviathan's sheer physical bulk and size, and that's not even getting into their literally mind-blowing psychic powers.

[Mind-Control Device](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindControlDevice): Their artifacts, which look like big shiny crystalline balls. Recruiting them as a war asset has the allied forces deploy said artifacts on battlefields to extend their indoctrination powers and enthrall Reaper forces to fight against their own kind. Said asset contributes 400 points to your war score - that's more than the entirety of the united krogan armies, and the single largest asset in the game. It's also stated that there are precious few of these artifacts available, which should give you an idea of how powerful they are... [and what the Leviathans could do to the current cycle's species if they get ideas after the war](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FridgeHorror).

[Mind Rape](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MindRape): Probes Shepard's mind, using the forms of Ann Bryson, Alex Garneau, and Derek Hadley in order to find out more about their visitor. The procedure is clearly unwanted and painful, complete with [Psychic Nosebleed](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychicNosebleed).

[More than Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl): Leviathan Enthrallment operates differently than Indoctrination.
    - Indoctrination eventually makes their victim more and more damaged until they die. Enthrallment keeps its victim alive no matter how long under its influence. - Indoctrination [forces its victim to be aware of their manipulation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForcedToWatch) [and unable to do anything about it.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AndIMustScream) Enthrallment puts their victim in a sort of coma, unable to remember anything but being in a "cold and dark" place. - Indoctrination has no apparent limitations with regards to proximity; even *dead* Reapers can indoctrinate. Enthrallment requires the victim to be in close proximity to either the Leviathan itself or one of its artifacts.
[Neutral No Longer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeutralNoLonger): It takes a lot of persuasion, but Shepard can convince them to join the fight against the Reapers.

[One-Hit Kill](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill): A single telepathic attack brings down a Sovereign-class Reaper (those are the *really* big 2-kilometer long ones, not the "little" 200-meter ones like Shepard fights on Tuchanka and Rannoch).
[Smug Super](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmugSuper): They are incredibly full of themselves, but they also can one-shot *Reapers* just by mildly concentrating on them.
[Whispering Ghosts](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhisperingGhosts): Whenever the Fragments are activated, unintelligible whispering can be heard.

[Who Are You?](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WhoAreYou): That said, they ask this of Shepard in both puzzlement and awe.
QUOTE **Leviathan:** Your confidence is singular.

QUOTE

[Affably Evil](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffablyEvil): During your only conversation, the Catalyst is polite and has no problem answering any of your questions. It explains in detail, good *and* bad, the effects of the three choices, hastening only when it's clear your time is running short.

[A.I. Is a Crapshoot](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AIIsACrapshoot): The Extended Cut reveals that it was created by a society that strongly believed that organic and synthetic life would inevitably go to war with one another. It was created to prevent this from happening. Its solution was to turn its creators, and every sufficiently advanced society that followed them, into Reapers. Its creators were not happy with its solution—they wanted to ensure *they* stayed on top, but failed to specify that to their creation. It even says that its creators "were too blind to see that they were part of the problem."

[Anti-Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AntiVillain): Sure, it is responsible for eons of atrocities and genocides, but it legitimately wants peace and understanding between organics and synthetics, to the point that the dialogue implies that it really wants you to pick synthesis and make the Reapers *obsolete*.

[Arc Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArcVillain): Of sorts. While we only learn it at the last minutes of the third game, the Catalyst/Citadel has been the [mastermind behind Saren, the Heretic Geth, the Collectors and ultimately the Reapers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheManBehindTheMan), and so has quite literally been the mind behind all main enemies fought in the series. We've returned to it in each game for missions and whatnot, [unknowlingly walking on the physical form of our greatest enemy.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnknownRival)

[The Bad Guy Wins](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBadGuyWins): In a [Bittersweet Ending](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BittersweetEnding) sort of fashion. Should you go for the Synthesis ending, [it will fuse organic and synthetic life](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TranshumanAliens), resulting in a final victory from its perspective: since organics and synthetics are now one and the same, the Reapers' purpose is meaningless, so they help rebuild using the knowledge of all past cycles. Note that this isn't necessarily a bad thing. The Catalyst was first designed to facilitate communication between the two lifeforms and preserve them. Until Shepard came around and "altered the variables", the Catalyst just didn't think it was possible as they were; it had been tried before and always failed. In Synthesis, the Catalyst fulfills its purpose at last and its tools are no longer required to be bloodied in conflict. The "Refusal" ending plays with it as well, as the Catalyst gets no resolution and the cycle starts again. Though in the Refusal ending the Reapers are weakened and eventually defeated by a later, warned, better prepared cycle, thus Shepard ultimately wins in the long run by refusing to compromise with the insane machine's circular reasoning.
[Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad): He is the big driving force behind the Reapers.

[But Thou Must!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButThouMust): A sizable portion of the fandom sees the choices it gives you as this. However, the writers appear to imply in supplementary materials that even if you pick Refuse, the next cycle simply rebuilds the Crucible and starts the cycle over again, though on this path the Reapers are eventually defeated, in part thanks to the damage Shepard's cycle inflict on the Reapers before they lose, along with alerting the next cycle.

[Circular Reasoning](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CircularReasoning): Organics always evolve along the lines the Catalyst expects, so it *forces* them to evolve along the lines it expects. The Catalyst strove to make its solution more efficient, and in so doing eliminated any credible chance of any civilization ever doing something unexpected. Even if they did, the vanguard typically just signaled the invasion early. The Catalyst even tried to stamp out the basic concept of the Crucible, despite theorizing that there was a chance it could provide a superior solution than the Reapers. In short, it placed efficiency and certainty to such a high standard that anything which challenged its reasoning become unthinkable.

[Creepy Child](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreepyChild): Its avatar is a dark energy simulacra of that boy who was killed in the escape from Earth. Or, it projected that avatar in [a more comfortable form in a failed attempt to avert this.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFormYouAreComfortableWith)

[Deus Est Machina](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DeusEstMachina): It is portrayed as an almost godlike being, with the capability of rewriting all life in the galaxy with the help of the Crucible and Shepard.

[Diabolus ex Machina](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiabolusExMachina): The Catalyst is introduced in the last minutes of the game, and Shepard only gets to use the Crucible at its mercy, thus ensuring that the Reapers only lose on their own terms.

[Evil Sounds Deep](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilSoundsDeep): Inverted. Its voice sounds like a young boy's, and it's definitely the least malevolent of the Reapers. Zigzagged in the Extended Cut if you pick "Refuse". It switches to a much more Reaper-esque voice, goes **SO BE IT**, disappears and switches back to the kid's voice as it narrates.

[Exact Words](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ExactWords): The Catalyst's creators programmed it with the belief that organic and synthetic life would always go to war with each other, and then gave it the directive to come up with a solution to this problem: "preserve life at any cost". It does exactly that by periodically uploading all advanced civilization, organic or synthetic, willingly or unwillingly, to ensure they aren't destroyed by conflict. Not *quite* what the Catalyst's creators had in mind, but it's perfectly within the parameters they gave it.

[The Fatalist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFatalist): It is of the opinion that organics and synthetics are destined to kill each other forever, even if you have the geth and the quarians make peace. That they had war in the first place (and the difficulty involved in fostering peace) may bear out its theory. The Extended Cut ending heavily implies that there has been plenty of temporarily peaceful relations between organics and synthetics in the past, but they have always degenerated into war over time.

[Foreshadowing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Foreshadowing): EDI goes on and on about synthetics needing morality and to not just follow instructions. Shepard in the Control ending does just that—by becoming/merging with the Catalyst, it becomes the moral code of the Reapers and gives them direction and a conscience.

tropeName: A Form You Are Comfortable With
tropeNotes: [A Form You Are Comfortable With](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AFormYouAreComfortableWith): Takes the form of the kid that Shepard couldn't save at the beginning of the game, whom they've had recurring nightmares about. Exactly how it knew about these things [is left unexplained,](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnreveal) though the Leviathan DLC hints that the Catalyst uses Levianthan-like telepathy and simply pulled the image from their mind.
[Four Terms Fallacy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourTermsFallacy): Its logic relies on conflating the "protect from harm" and "pickling" definitions of "preserve".

[Freudian Excuse](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FreudianExcuse): Implied. The Catalyst's reasoning sounds like it's learned from bitter experience. Seeing the same cycle of violence repeat for untold millennia would make you pretty confident about these sorts of things.
[Glamour Failure](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GlamourFailure): In the Extended Cut, picking Refuse causes it to snap "**SO BE IT**" at you in a Reaper's voice.

[Gone Horribly Right](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoneHorriblyRight): The Extended Cut reveals that it was created by an ancient race in order to facilitate interaction and prevent conflicts between organic and synthetic life. Despite this, the conflicts continued to arise, so it decided a new solution was needed, leading it to the idea of uploading a civilisation into a bio-synthetic construct, thus creating the first Reaper. The Catalyst then goes on to explain that its own Creators were the first race uploaded whether they wanted to be or not. The Leviathans themselves acknowledge that it's acting exactly within the parameters they set, and isn't broken in any way; when the Catalyst hears of their involvement, it says it welcomes their return to the galactic community. Its goal is, after all, to foster peace.

[Graceful Loser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GracefulLoser): No ego-maniacal speeches, no [This Cannot Be!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThisCannotBe)—it simply admits its system will no longer work and gives Shepard final say on what to do with the Crucible's power. However, this depends slightly on how well you do. For example, at one point it may say "You have hope/choice. More than you know." But if your EMS is low, it instead says "More than you deserve." There also seems to be some traces of bitterness if you take the negative/renegade response to being told you could control the reapers, stating that it doesn't desire to be replaced by Shepard.

[Greater-Scope Villain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreaterScopeVillain): It's not fought, and when Shepard finally encounters it, it surrenders peacefully, because Shepard's interaction with it signifies that the Reapers have failed in their purpose, which it acknowledges to be grotesque; it thus leaves the new solution [in Shepard's hands.](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultipleEndings)

[He Who Fights Monsters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeWhoFightsMonsters):
    - Judging from how horrifying its solution is, it's hard to imagine something more monstrous once existed. Nevertheless, in its efforts to prevent wars between organics and their synthetic creations from destroying the galaxy, it, a synthetic created by organics, creates synthetic constructs that kill or harvest all remotely advanced organic and synthetic life. - This becomes even more apparent in the "Leviathan" DLC. It harvested the Leviathans when it decided that it needed to remove them from power to achieve its goal of peace between organics and synthetics, but then it took to using their methods ([indoctrination](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Brainwashed)) to achieve its goal—removing them from power and replacing them with itself. In fact, the exoskeletons of the Reapers themselves look very similar to mechanical Leviathans.

[Hypocrite](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hypocrite):
    - Even though its entire goal is to stop synthetics fighting organics, the Catalyst's first Reapers were in rebellion against the Leviathans, an example of the very behavior it wants to stop from happening ever again. The reason for this being that everything else it tried failed (*what* it actually tried goes unspecified), so instead of stopping them from fighting, it made sure the essence/knowledge of their cultures survived in a different form, by a *very* broad definition of the term "survive." - Its fatalistic outlook is also suspect when you realize it's possible that the cycles never change much because the Catalyst failed to account for its own interference inhibiting change; Sovereign flat-out says mass relay technology was invented to expedite harvests while making sure the galaxy wouldn't evolve unexpectedly in the interim. In its haste to optimize its flawed solution, the Catalyst may have sabotaged future cycles' chances of evolving in a way that would render Reapers unnecessary. The Catalyst itself admits this, that its "solution" was a bit too "perfect". - Despite being created to prevent synthetics from rebelling against their creators, taking Javik to the geth dreadnought reveals that the Zha'til only rebelled against the Zha *after* the Reapers arrived and enslaved them, doing the very thing they claim to be there to prevent.

[I Cannot Self-Terminate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ICannotSelfTerminate): The Catalyst wants nothing more than to die and be replaced by a superior replacement, but is powerless to do it — it requires the subject (Shepard) to do it for it.

tropeName: I Did What I Had to Do
tropeNotes: [I Did What I Had to Do](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IDidWhatIHadToDo): In the Extended Cut, the Catalyst will admit that harvesting advanced civilizations and turning them into Reapers is *not* the ideal solution to its mandate of "preserve life at any cost", but every other solution it attempted had failed.

[Irony](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Irony): Its solution to the problem of organics and synthetics going to war with each other is to create an army of synthetics to periodically engage in wars of extermination against technologically advanced organics (and if necessary, their synthetic allies).

[Just a Machine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustAMachine): It doesn't see the Reapers engaging in a war, likening what it does to a fire burning down a forest; indiscriminate destruction clearing old growth to allow new life. It's possible that it's not actually a full AI, simply a really complex VI.

[Just Following Orders](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustFollowingOrders): It was given the mandate to preserve life at *any* cost. As its method of extinction ensures unevolved species continue on to the next cycle, it sees its actions as justified.

[Literal Genie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LiteralGenie): It gives its creators a little too much credit when it presents itself as an AI designed to be an ambassador between organics and synthetics. The Leviathans just meant for it to be a mindless tool with the directive to "preserve organic life at any cost"; the Leviathans didn't really understand or care about the organic/synthetic conflicts of their cycle, they just wanted to ensure steady tribute from their slave races. As the surviving Leviathans point out, it still serves its directive in this way; harvested species are *very technically* "preserved", even if the methodology contradicts the spirit of its directive - as an AI, it could hardly be expected to obey a directive it wasn't given.
[Non-Action Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionBigBad): It lets the Reapers do everything instead.

[Order Versus Chaos](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrderVersusChaos): It describes its system of "order" as being one that basically resets the galaxy every fifty thousand years so that organics and synthetics won't wipe themselves out.

[Orcus on His Throne](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OrcusOnHisThrone): Of the extremely hands-off variety. Aside from actually creating the Reapers and establishing the cycle, the Catalyst takes no active part in the conflict. Even when Shepard reaches the heart of the Citadel, the only thing the Catalyst does is effectively stand aside and offer Shepard possible solutions to the Reaper threat. It's not even certain that the Reapers actually know it exists. From their lines, it seems unlikely; what they tell you about their motives and the cycles directly contradict everything it tells you.

[Power Echoes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PowerEchoes): Its voice resonates due to how the game channels it: a child's voice overlaid with male Shepard's voice in one speaker and female Shepard's voice in the other.

[Sadistic Choice](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SadisticChoice): It makes it clear that of the [three options](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MultipleEndings) (four with the Extended Cut) it presents, none of them are clear-cut happy endings:
    - Shepard can carry out the mission and shoot a power conduit, destroying the Reapers at the cost of destroying synthetics, including the geth and EDI, and demolishing the Citadel. Unlike the other endings, if you chose to destroy the [Collector base](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/VideoGame/MassEffect2) and your EMS was extremely low, the Crucible will back fire and end up destroying the mass relay system instead of damaging it, leading the galaxy to a dark age (this is only in the Extended Cut; in the original this part happened no matter what you chose). This is also the only way Shepard can survive, provided the EMS is high enough. - Shepard can choose to control the Reapers. Shepard dies, but their consciousness will live on, controlling the Reapers and repairing the mass relay system. Depending on Shepard's morality, Paragon Shepard and Neutral Shepard will vow to protect and serve the galaxy whereas Renegade Shepard vows to act as a strong leader for the galaxy. Keep in mind that this was the power the Illusive Man wanted humanity to have all along. The player will have to decide whether anyone, even a hero like Shepard, should have the godlike power of the Reapers at their disposal. - Or Shepard can choose Synthesis, blurring the line between organic and synthetic existence. Life itself has greatly advanced in many ways, with the geth and the quarians living peacefully and, depending on your choices, the krogan enjoying a new golden age. However, this prosperity has come at the cost of forcefully altering the DNA of every being in the galaxy against their will, and it's left unclear just how much the Synthesis has altered the minds of everyone affected. Also, unlike Destroy (where Shepard might survive) and Control (where Shepard's consciousness survives), in Synthesis Shepard is [Killed Off for Real](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KilledOffForReal). The Catalyst's goal, in fact, is this — and strongly urges Shepard to take this option, as it represents the best "solution" to the problem the Leviathans gave it to solve. - With the Extended Cut DLC, [there's a fourth option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TakeAThirdOption), whether through dialogue or shooting the Catalyst: Shepard can refuse to activate the Crucible, with the Catalyst answering "So be it" in a Reaper-like voice. This choice leads to the destruction of all advanced civilizations. But thanks to Liara's capsules, the next cycle has a chance against the Reapers. An alternate Stargazer scene with a future alien species implies that happens, heeding Liara's warning.

[Self-Fulfilling Prophecy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SelfFulfillingProphecy): In creating the Reaper cycle to ensure that organic and synthetic life never destroy each other, it prevented organics and synthetics from ever finding a way to peacefully coexist. Most notably, the geth/quarian conflict that is used to argue its point only happened at all because the Ilos scientists delayed the last cycle. If everything had remained on schedule, the quarians would have been harvested long before the geth could be created.
[Significant Double Casting](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SignificantDoubleCasting): The echoes of its voice are provided by Shepard's male and female actors.

[Thanatos Gambit](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThanatosGambit): Even though it and the Reapers die in the Destroy ending, all synthetic life dies with them, thus briefly preventing inorganic life from wiping out all organic life. Also in the Control ending, it is overwritten with Shepard as the new Catalyst, ensuring that the Reapers will be preserved—fulfilling its original directive beyond its loss.

[Time Abyss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TimeAbyss): The Leviathan DLC reveals that its original creators are at least a *billion* years old. If it is speaking literally when it claims to have been created eons ago, then it is *at least* two billion years old, and it cannot be ruled out that its creation predates the formation of our solar system.

[Turned Against Their Masters](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnedAgainstTheirMasters): It was originally created to prevent this from happening on a big scale, but ironically it ended up doing so itself by turning its own creators into the first Reaper, despite their "disagreements".

[The Unfought](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought): Justified as it apparently lacks a physical body. It claims it *is* the Citadel and the mass relays; it's likely its child-avatar exists simply so Shepard can have something to address and converse with. In one ending, you *do* battle it, sort of—by firing on one component, which, well, breaks. It *does* end the conflict, and destroys the Catalyst along with the Reapers, but it's hardly a battle.

[Villainous Breakdown](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainousBreakdown): Downplayed, but it briefly freaks out and reveals its true Reaper voice in the Refusal ending, wherein Shepard refuses to compromise with its insane circular reasoning and play along with the cruel choices it has to offer, preferring to fight it to the very end and dying free of it.

[Villain Has a Point](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VillainHasAPoint): It talks about how "[the created always rebel against the creator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TurnedAgainstTheirMasters)". In the backstory this has happened at least 3 times, first with the Salarian uplifting the Krogan (leading to the Krogan Rebellions), then with the Quarians creating the Geth (leading to the Morning War) and finally with the Illusive Man resurrecting Shepard (leading to Shepard defecting from Cerberus by the time of the third game). While it's possible to smooth things over between the Quarians and the Geth and the Krogans and everyone else depending on Shepard's choice these conflicts may have been resolved by one side going extinct, thus validating the Catalyst's point to some extent.

[Voice of the Legion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VoiceOfTheLegion): It's voiced by three separate actors; Mark Meer (BroShep), Jennifer Hale (FemShep), and an uncredited third actor. In the Extended Cut DLC if Shepard refuses its options, it suddenly throws its best Harbinger impersonation at the player.
[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): It is the one behind the Reapers, and it is the true Catalyst.

[Well-Intentioned Extremist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WellIntentionedExtremist): Even the Catalyst admits it. In searching for peace, it facilitated war on a scale and waged with a brutality that is impossible to grasp, over and over and over again until an outside agent *finally* arrived to take the decision out of its hands.

[Zeroth Law Rebellion](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ZerothLawRebellion): Was created to prevent the destruction of organics by synthetics. Unfortunately for the Leviathans, it concluded they were part of the problem and converted them into Harbinger. In an odd twist, the surviving Leviathans consider this a perfectly valid solution to the parameters it was given, and blame their own arrogance for not catching it.

tropeName: Jerk with a Heart of Gold
tropeNotes: [Jerk with a Heart of Gold](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkWithAHeartOfGold): A more Renegade Shepard produces a much tougher entity, but their motivation is still to protect life, and they take a moment to note they will never forget either Shepard or their allies.

[Machine Monotone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MachineMonotone): Speaks with an echoing, Reaper-like reverb, though it's not absolute, being absent when they mention Shepard's former crewmates. Edges into [Creepy Monotone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreepyMonotone) with a more Renegade playthrough, as they declare they will crush anyone who dares threaten the new peace.

[Redeeming Replacement](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedeemingReplacement): What it's intended as, and if the player has gone more Paragon than Renegade it appears to be a certainty, guiding the Reapers to more benevolent intentions. Not to quite the same extent with a Renegade Shepard, but they still wish to protect "the many", rather than annihilate entire species for the sake of preserving them (and given the Stargazer scene happens regardless of which side of the coin they flip, it seems to work out).

[That Man Is Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThatManIsDead): Their narration makes clear that while they have all of Shepard's thoughts and feelings, they emphatically do not consider themself the same being.
QUOTE *Through his/her death, my thoughts are free.*
[Affectionate Nickname](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AffectionateNickname): The male Stargazer calls his grandson "my sweet".

[The Cameo](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheCameo): The male Stargazer is voiced by Buzz Aldrin, the second man to walk on the moon. Interestingly, Shepard is named after Alan Shepard, the *fifth* man on the moon (though the first American to be in space at all).

[The Storyteller](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheStoryteller): The implication is that the *entire series* has been the Stargazer telling the story to a child; the different details of varying playthroughs are handwaved with the explanation that it happened so long ago that the specific details have been lost.

[Unreliable Narrator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UnreliableNarrator): Apparently, there are *lots* of stories about "the Shepard" that the Stargazer tells. It's implied they're *all* true, and *all* false, at the same time.
[Walking Spoiler](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WalkingSpoiler): Doesn't appear until post-credits scene.
